question_text: Which of the following is not a part of the vulva?
explanation: Cervix is not a part of the vulva. The vulva includes: Mons veneris Labia majora Labia minora Clitoris Vestibule Vestibular bulb Greater vestibular glands. The vulva is posteriorly related to the perineum. The triangular space bounded by clitoris, labia minora and fourchette is the vestibule. It is present between the labia minora anteriorly and the introitus posteriorly. The posterior part of the vestibule between the fourchette and the vaginal introitus is called fossa navicularis. The vestibule has 4 openings: Urethral opening Vaginal orifice opening Bartholin’s duct on either side Ducts of paraurethral glands
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding labia majora?
options: They join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure
It is homologous to scrotum in male
The round ligament terminates at its posterior end
It contains sebaceous glands and apocrine glands
explanation: The round ligament terminates at the anterior end of the labia majora. The labia majora lie on either side of the vulva and join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure. The inner side is hairless. Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum in males. The labia majora and the mons veneris contain: Hair follicles Sebaceous glands Modified sweat glands, known as apocrine glands The labia minora are two cutaneous folds between the labia major. Anteriorly they enclose the clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form prepuce and frenulum respectively. The labia minora are homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis. The clitoris is a small erectile body lying in the anterior-most part of the vulva. The clitoris is homologous to glans penis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient presented to the gynecology OPD with the following finding. Which structure in men is homologous to the affected structure?
explanation: The given image shows a Bartholin's cyst, which involves the Bartholin's glands. These glands are homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of Bartholin's glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They are stimulated by sexual arousal. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions. Bartholin's cyst occurs due to obstruction of the ducts of the Bartholin's glands by proteinaceous material, or due to infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision. An infected Bartholin's cyst can lead to an Bartholin's abscess. This requires surgical drainage.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the pH of the vagina before puberty?
explanation: The pH of the vagina before puberty is 7. In adult females, the pH is acidic. Doderlein's bacilli (Lactobacillus sp.) are part of the normal vaginal flora. They produce lactic acid from glycogen in the vaginal epithelium and make the vaginal pH acidic. They are present in newborns and disappear in 10-14 days. They reappear at puberty and disappear after menopause. Vaginal flora also includes microbes such as Clostridium welchii. Vaginal defence mechanisms are influenced by estrogen. In newborns, maternal estrogens maintain the defence mechanisms for 10-14 days. After that, the levels wane. During puberty, the circulating estrogen maintains the defence mechanism. Note: The pH is higher in the upper part of the vagina due to mixing with alkaline cervical mucus. Period Vaginal pH Doderlein bacteri a Types of cells Birth-2 week s 4-5 + - 2weeks-pube rty >7 - Parabasal cells Puberty 4-4.5 sparse Superficial & intermediate Reproductiv e 4-5 plenty Superficial & intermediate Pregnancy 3.š-4.1 plenty Intermediate Postmenopa use >7 - Parabasal
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about relations of the vagina?
explanation: Bartholin’s gland is present lateral to the vagina. The vagina is related to the following structures: Anteriorly: Bladder (upper 1/3rd) Urethra (lower 2/3rd) Posteriorly Pouch of Douglas Ampulla of the rectum Perineal body Laterally Mackenrodt's ligament Levator ani Bartholin's glands
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the type of hymen.
explanation: The given image shows cribriform hymen because it has multiple small openings. Based on the shape of its opening, the hymen may be classified as: Other variants of the hymen: The hymen is lined by stratified squamous epithelium on both sides. The hymen is most commonly torn posterolaterally or posteriorly. It is replaced by tags after childbirth which are called as carunculae myrtiformes. Hymen Description Annular Oval central opening Crescen tic Semilunar central opening Vertical Vertical slit-like opening Septate 2 lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissu e Cribrifo rm Multiple small openings Variants Description Absence of hymen Congenital deformity. Infantile Small central linear opening. Imperforate No opening Fimbriated Free margin has symmetrical indentations anteriorly Ring or fringe-like A narrow ring of thick memb rane is present all around the vaginal orificeIt can easily di stend during sexual intercour se without rupturing the hym en
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deep perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
explanation: In the given case scenario, level 3 supports including the superficial and deep perineal muscles are lost. This causes urethrocele. DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of .
explanation: Anteflexion of the uterus is seen at the level of the internal os. (Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina) The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion. In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part. When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip. Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion The angle between thecervix and vagina The angle betweencervix and uterus 90o 120o
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G3P2L2 woman presents in her third trimester with vaginal leaking. On PV examination, the anterior lip of the cervix can be palpated. What is the position of her uterus and the igament that maintains this position?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the uterus is anteverted as the anterior lip of the cervix was palpable. The round ligament helps maintain the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy. However, the anteversion in the non-pregnant uterus is maintained by both the uterosacral ligament and round ligament. (Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina) The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion. In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part. When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip. Anteflexion is seen at the level of the internal os. Angle of anteversion Angle of anteflexion Angle between thecervix and vagina Angle betweencervix and uter us 90o 120o
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multiparous woman presented with a urethrocele, due to weakness of the urogenita diaphragm. What is this structure also known as?
explanation: The urogenital diaphragm is also known as the triangular ligament. The urogenital diaphragm extends from the pubic arch anteriorly to the central point of the perineum posteriorly and consists of two layers of fascia through which pass the vagina and the urethra. The central point of the female perineum lies between the vagina and the rectum. Urogenital triangle: Present between 2 ischiopubic rami Stretching transversely across the rami there are 3 membranes. From above downwards the membranes are as follows: Superior fascia of urogenital diaphragm Inferior fascia of urogenital diaphragm Membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the cavity of the uterus lined by?
options: Single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
Double layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
Single layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium
Double layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium
explanation: The uterine cavity is lined by a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. The wall of the uterus consists of 3 layers: Perimetrium is the serous coat adherent to the underlying muscle. Myometrium - it consists of thick bundles of muscles that form 3 distinct layers during pregnancy: Outer longitudina Inner circular Middle interlacing called living ligature Endometrium - It is the mucous lining of the cavity. It consists of lamina propria and surface epithelium which is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with regular menstrual cycles is undergoing an ultrasound on the 14th day of her cycle. What will the endometrial thickness be?
explanation: During ovulation, the thickness of the endometrium is around 11 mm. Phase Endometrial thickne ss Immediately after menstruati on 1-2 mm Early proliferative phase 5-7 mm Secretory phase 7-16 mm Phase Endometrial thickne ss Phase Endometrial thickne ss Preovulatory phase up to11 mm Postmenopausal <4 mm Postmenopausal - abnormal, requires biopsy >4 mm
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding uterine anatomy?
options: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery
Transverse cervical ligaments are also called cardinal ligaments
Uterine innervation is by the pudendal nerve plexus
Lymphatic drainage is primarily to the obturator, internal and external iliac nodes.
explanation: The uterus is innervated by the fibers of the uterovaginal plexus, also known as the Frankenhauser ganglion. Option A: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery which represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery. Option B: The cardinal ligaments are also called transverse cervical ligaments or Mackenrodt ligaments. They consist primarily of perivascular connective tissue. They attach to the posterolateral pelvic walls near the origin of the internal iliac artery and surround the vessels supplying the uterus and vagina. Option D: Lymphatic drainage of the uterus is primarily to the obturator and internal and external iliac nodes. One theory of endometriosis, states lymphatic spread as cause for seeding in the pelvis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A gynecologist is performing a hysterectomy. She accidentally nicks the ureter in the ureteric canal as it pierces the Mackenrodt's ligaments. Which vessels are likely to be damaged here?
options: Uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below
Uterine plexus of veins above and the uterine artery below
Ovarian artery above and the uterine artery below
Uterine artery above and the ovarian artery below
explanation: The uterine artery above and uterine venous plexus below are likely to be damaged here, as the ureter is present between these vessels. The ureter pierces the Mackenrodt's ligament, forming the ureteric canal. In this canal, the ureter is crossed by the uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below, thus being present in between the uterine vessels. The ureteric canal provides the necessary room for normal peristalsis, without pressure from the surrounding structures. After leaving the ureteric canal, the ureter passes forwards and medially to reach the bladder. It is 1-2 cm away from the cervix.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You take a culture swab from the portio vaginalis of a woman having foul smelling vaginal discharge. What is this region also known as?
explanation: Portio vaginalis or exocervix is the other name for the vaginal part of the cervix. Cervix is the lowermost part of the uterus extending from the histological internal os to the external os. It is cylindrical in shape measuring 2.5 cm in length and diameter. Cervix is made up of 10% muscle and the rest is collagen, elastin, and proteoglycan. The lining of the cervix has the following parts: Exocervix - also known as portio vaginalis. It is lined by non keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. Endocervix - it is lined by high columnar, ciliated epithelium. Endocervical glands - secrete alkaline mucus. When enlarged, they form swellings called Nabothian follicles/cysts. Transformation zone - the epithelium gradually changes from columnar to squamous in this region.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the cervix: corpus ratio before puberty?
explanation: The cervix:corpus ratio before puberty is 2:1. The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body of the uterus varies with age. Age Cervix/Corpus ratio Before puberty 2:1 At puberty 1:2 Age Cervix/Corpus ratio Reproductive a ge 1:3 or 1:4 After menopau se 2:1 - however, the uterus and cervix are both atrophied
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in .
explanation: The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad ligament and the vagina. The Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. It runs parallel to, but below, the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus to the level of the internal os where it passes into the tissues of the cervix. It then runs forwards to reach the anterolateral aspect of the vaginal wall and may reach as far down as the hymen. The duct can sometimes form a cyst in the broad ligament or in the vagina. It is called Gartner’s cyst. It is a benign condition and can be treated with marsupialization.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is false about the contents of the broad ligament?
options: Ovarian vessels in its infundibulopelvic part
Ureter is present the lower portion
Ovarian ligament in its anterior fold
explanation: The ovarian ligaments are contained in the posterior fold of the broad ligament. The broad ligament contains the following parts: Mesosalpinx - it lies between the fallopian tube and ovarian ligament. It contains the pelvic vessels - anastomoses between uterine and ovarian arteries. The ovary is attached via ovarian igament through the posterior folds to the mesovarium. Mesometrium - it contains the ovarian vessels within the infundibulopelvic ligament. The ureter is present in the inferomedial part of the broad ligament. It is related to the uterine artery here and may be damaged during hysterectomy. Note: Broad ligament is not a support of the uterus.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Where are Peg cells seen?
explanation: Peg cells are seen in the fallopian tubes. A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as intercalated or intercalary cells whose function is not yet known. The image below shows pale ciliated cells (arrows) and narrow, dark, non-ciliated peg cells (arrowheads).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the longest part of the fallopian tube?
explanation: The longest and widest part of the fallopian tube is the ampulla (5 cm).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Where is the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary derived from?
options: The sub epithelial connective tissue layer
explanation: Tunica albuginea of the adult ovary is derived from the sub-epithelial connective tissue layer. Structure of the ovary: Surface epithelium - a single layer of cuboidal cells is present, which later gives rise to the surface epithelium of the adult ovary. It is morphologically continuous with the mesothelium of the peritoneum. The subepithelial connective tissue layer - gives rise to the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary and the basement membrane beneath the surface epithelium. The parenchymatous zone - becomes the cortex and contains the egg nests and ovarian follicles. Zona vasculosa - becomes the medulla and contains the blood vessels. Hilar cells present here are homologous to interstitial cells of testes. They can rarely produce hilar cell tumors of the ovary.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: During the histopathological examination of an ovarian mass, Call-Exner bodies are seen. In which of the following layers are these structures seen?
explanation: Call-Exner bodies are formed by granulosa cells present within the granulosa cell layer of the ovary. They are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with acidophilic material, resembling immature follicles. They are characteristically seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary. The image below shows Call-Exner bodies (circled in black). Graafian follicle: The mature Graafian follicle is spheroidal or ovoid in shape. It contains pent-up secretion known as the liquor folliculi. The lining consists of: Theca externa Theca interna - contain the theca cells Granulosa cell layer Cumulus oophorus - projection of granulosa cells into the cavity of the Graafian follicle. It is also called the discus proligerus.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Where is the sympathetic nerve supply of ovary derived from?
explanation: The efferent preganglionic sympathetic fibres to the ovary are derived from the T10-T11 spinal levels. These fibres travel to the prevertebral ganglia, where they synapse. The postganglionic sympathetic fibres arising from these ganglia contribute to the ovarian plexus, which innervates the ovary. The ovarian plexus is a network of nerves comprising: Postganglionic sympathetic fibres Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the sacral outflow (S2-S4) Visceral afferent fibres (responsible for transmitting sensory signals) The ovarian plexus has two parts based on its connections: Upper part: Derived from branches of the renal plexus and aortic plexus Lower part: Derived from the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Bleeding during normal menstruation occurs due to rupture of
explanation: Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the uterine artery. The blood supply of the uterus is as follows: Uterine arteryArcuate arteryRadial arteryBasal arterySpiral artery
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A uterine artery embolization is being planned for a patient with uterine fibroids. Blood flow in which of the following arteries will not be affected by this procedure?
explanation: In the given case scenario, blood flow in the vaginal artery will not be affected, as it is not a branch of the uterine artery. The vaginal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery. It is homologous to the inferior vesical artery in males. It supplies the vagina and the base of the bladder in women. It should not be confused with vaginal branches of the uterine artery. Branches of the uterine artery: Ureteric branch Vaginal branches (descending) - these unite to form the anterior and posterior azygos arteries of the vagina Circular cervical branch Sampson's artery - it runs in under the round ligament. It represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery. Arcuate--> Radial--> Basal--> Spiral and straight arterioles of the functional layer of the endometrium
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A patient with stress incontinence required surgical management. While performing a Burch colposuspension, the surgeon approached the space of Retzius. What is this space also known as?
Prevesical or presacral space
explanation: The space of Retzius is the other name for prevesical or retropubic space. Burch colposuspension is a procedure done to relieve stress urinary incontinence. If an extraperitoneal approach is selected, the retropubic space is entered by perforating the transversalis fascia layer of the anterior abdominal wall. Once the retropubic space is dissected, the bladder neck and the vaginal fascia underneath are identified. The bladder is mobilized to the opposite side. At each side of the bladder neck, two to four, preferably non■absorbable sutures are placed in the space of Retzius. Note:The presacral space is a retroperitoneal space that lies between the peritoneum of the posterior abdominal wall and the sacrum. It contains the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses. The sacral sympathetic trunk lies against the sacrum’s ventral surface. The Physiology of Conception
subject: OBGYN

question_text: When do germ cells appear in the yolk sac?
explanation: Germ cells appear in the yolk sac in the 3rd week. The sequence of events in primordial germ cell formation and migration are: 2nd week - Germ cells are formed in the epiblast. 3rd week - Germ cells move through the primitive streak and migrate to the wall of the yolk sac. 4th week - Germ cells begin to migrate from the yolk sac to gonads. 5th week - Germ cell migration is complete. Gametes are derived from these primordial germ cells.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: When does the ovary contain the maximum number of oogonia?
explanation: The ovary contains the maximum number of oogonia at the 5th month of intrauterine life. The number of oogonia is estimated to be 7 million. Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. At the initiation of puberty, the follicle count is less than 400,000, of which less than 500 are destined to ovulate. Every month, 15–20 follicles are released, out of which one matures to form the ovum.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A man with oligospermia has completed his course of hormonal treatment. After how many days will you test his sperm count?
explanation: The sperm count is tested 80-90 days after hormonal treatment, as the average time is taken for spermatogenesis is 74 days, and approximately 14 days to reach the ejaculatory ducts. The effect of hormonal therapy on the early phase of spermatogenesis is reflected in the ejaculated sperm concentration after three months. Spermatogenesis is the process of the formation of sperms from spermatogonia. Approximately 100 million sperms are produced daily. In patients diagnosed with oligospermia, hormonal treatment is carried out using FSH, hCG, or testosterone. Improvements in sperm count can take a few months, hence the course is usually for 3-6 months. Normal spermatogenesis occurs after this time period. Spermiogenesis refers to the series of changes that occur in the formation of spermatozoa from spermatids. These are: Acrosome formation Condensation of the nucleus Formation of the neck, middle piece, and tail Shedding of cytoplasm as residual bodies Complete motility is obtained in the epididymis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the time taken for capacitation of the sperm?
explanation: The time taken for the capacitation of sperms is 6-8 hours (approximately 7 hours). Sperms have to undergo two changes in the female reproductive tract to be able to fertilise the ovum: Capacitation It is the functional maturation of the spermatozoa. It occurs in the fallopian tube and involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the ucosal surface of the tube. The glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed. Only capacitated sperms can pass through the corona cells and undergo the acrosomal reaction. Acrosomal reaction It occurs after binding to zona pellucida, induced by zona proteins. Enzymes such as acrosin and trypsin-like protein are released to penetrate the zona pellucida Ca2+ plays an important role.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about the resumption of meiosis-I?
explanation: Meiosis-I in the primary oocyte is resumed after LH surge.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In which of the following steps does reductional division occur?
explanation: Meiosis I or reductional division occurs in the transition from primary spermatocyte to secondary spermatocyte. Meiosis takes place in germ cells to generate male and female gametes. Meiosis involves two stages of cell division, namely, meiosis I and II. Meiosis I produces two haploid cells. Because the ploidy is reduced from diploid to haploid, meiosis I is referred to as a reductional division. Meiosis II is an equational division analogous to mitosis, resulting in the creation of four haploid daughter cells.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about the primary oocyte?
options: It is formed after meiosis I
explanation: The secondary oocyte is formed after meiosis I. Primordial germ cells divide by mitosis to form oogonia. The majority of the oogonia divide by mitosis, however, some enter meiosis I and are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase and are now called primary oocytes. Primary oocytes have not yet completed meiosis, hence they are diploid. The primary oocyte along with surrounding epithelial cells forms the primordial follicle. Meiosis I is completed after LH surge during puberty. Hence at the completetion of meiosis I, secondary oocyte is produced.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An embryologist is preparing embryos for implantation. When is zona hatching expected to occur?
explanation: Zona hatching occurs at around 5 days after fertilization. Fertilization is divided into the following phases: Penetration of the corona radiata Penetration of the zona pellucida Fusion of the oocyte and sperm cell membranes After fertilisation, the zygote differentiates to form the morula and then the blastocyst. The zona pellucida disappears at this stage, which is called zona hatching. The trophoblasts (outer cell mass) are now able to associate with the endometrium during implantation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur?
explanation: The fertilized ovum implants by 6–10 days in the uterine cavity. Implantation involves: Apposition: Initial contact of the blastocyst to the uterine wall Adhesion: Increased physical contact between the blastocyst and uterine epitheliu Invasion: Penetration and invasion of syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblasts into the endometriu A successful implantation requires receptive endometrium primed with estrogen and progesterone released by the corpus luteum.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The following figure shows the transverse section of the uterus with an implanted zygote. Identify structure A.
explanation: In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the placenta. Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called the decidua. It is of the following types: Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum for the placenta. Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole. Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus. The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes smooth, and is called the chorion laeve. As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'. Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What do the Langhans cells form?
explanation: Langhans cells form the cytotrophoblast. The cells of the blastocyst differentiate into an outer trophectoderm and an inner cell mass. The trophectoderm is further differentiated into: An inner mononuclear cellular layer called cytotrophoblast or Langhans layer made of Langhans cells. An outer layer of multinucleated syncytium called syncytiotrophoblast. The blastomere further divides to form the morula.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the structure marked A.
explanation: The structure marked A is primary oocyte. Primary oocytes are the germ cells seen in the medullary region of the ovary. These enlarge at the beginning of the growth phase. During this cell growth period, many oocytes undergo degeneration, both before and after birth. A single layer of flattened follicular cells that were derived originally from the germinal epithelium soon surrounds the primary oocytes. The structure that is formed is now called a primordial follicle. These are seen first in the medulla and later in the cortex.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur?
explanation: Fertilization usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube. During ovulation, the ovum is released and it enters the fallopian tube. It is propelled towards the uterine cavity by the peristaltic action of the fallopian tubes, prostaglandins in the male seminal fluid and oxytocin. It can only be fertilized within 24 hours of ovulation. If coitus takes place during this period, the spermatozoa swimming up into the tubes meet the ovum in the ampulla.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A newborn is admitted to the NICU with the following teratoma. Which embryonic layers is this derived from?
explanation: The given image shows an oropharygeal teratoma, which contains derivatives from all three germ layers. The tumor may include gut, bone, skin, and teeth. These tumors arise from pluripotent stem cells that differentiate into any of three germ layers forming tissues of all three germ layers.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
Identify the structure marked as A.

Yolk sac
explanation: The structure marked A is the allantois. The posterior wall of the yolk sac forms the allantois on the 16th day of development. Its distal portion forms the urachus which forms the median umbilical ligament. The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week. Maternal Pelvis and Fetal Skull
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by .
explanation: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by Caldwell and Moloy. The greatest transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet divides the pelvis into anterior and posterior segments. The shapes of these segments help classify the pelvis as follows: Gynecoid Anthropoid Android Platypelloid The various differences between these types is summarised below: Gynecoid Anthropoid Android Platypelloid Shape Round Anteroposteriorly ova l Triangular/ Heart-sha ped Transversely oval / Fl at bowl shaped Sacral angl e >90° >90° <90° >90° Side walls Straight or slightly di vergent Straight or divergent Convergent Divergent Ischial spin es Not prominent Not prominent Prominent Not prominent Subpubican gle Wide (85°) Slightly narrow Narrow Very wide (>90°) Fetal Positi on OccipitolateralObliqu e occipitoanterior Direct occipitoanterio rOccipitoposterior OccipitolateralObliqu e occipitoposterior Occipitolateral Engaging d iameter Transverse / oblique Anteroposterior Transverse / oblique Transverse Delivery No difficulty Face-to-pubis - most common. Deep transverse arres t is common.Difficult delivery with an incre ased chance of perine al injuries No difficulty Option B: McAfee and Johnson's regimen is for the conservative management of placenta previa. Option C: Page's and Sher's classification system is used to grade abruptio placentae. Option D: Burns and Marshall maneuver is used in breech delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An obese woman with dysmenorrhea and irregular periods is diagnosed with dystocia dystrophia syndrome. What type of pelvis is seen here?
explanation: In dystocia dystrophia syndrome, an android pelvis is seen. Dystocia dystrophia syndrome: The patient is stockily built with a bull neck, broad shoulders, and short thighs. She is obese with a male distribution of hair. Subfertile, with dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or irregular periods. There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for postmaturity. The pelvis is of the android type. The occipito-posterior position is common. During labor, there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia, leading to difficult nstrumental delivery or cesarean section. There is a chance of lactation failure.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is false about anthropoid pelvis?
explanation: The anthropoid pelvis has straight side walls, not convergent side walls. G ven below are the differences between various types of pelvis as per Caldwell-Moloy classification.
