subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with gestational diabetes mellitus is admitted to the labour room. The delivery of the baby's shoulder is delayed after the delivery of the head. When is shoulder dystocia considered?
options: Head to shoulder delivery time >30 sec
Head to shoulder delivery time >45 sec
Head to shoulder delivery time >60 sec
Head to shoulder delivery time >120 sec
explanation: Shoulder dystocia is defined as head to shoulder delivery time of more than 60 seconds. It occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively. Prelabour risk factors: Diabetes Mellitus Obesity Postdatism and prior history Excessive weight gain during pregnancy Intrapartum risk factors: Prolonged 1st and 2nd stage of labour Instrumental delivery Augmentation of labour with oxytocin
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labour. After delivery of the head, turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following can be used for the management of this patient?
explanation: A patient with gestational diabetes and the presence of turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Robert's manoeuvre, Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre, Gaskin's manoeuvre, and Rubin's manoeuvre are all used in its management. Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal pelvis. Turtle sign may be seen which refers to the recoil of the fetal head against the perineum. Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia: 1st line of management - Mc Roberts manoeuvre (flexion and abduction of thigh) 2nd line of management - Rubin's (rotation of the easily accessible shoulder by 30-45°), Woods corkscrew manoeuvre (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a cork screw fashion) ; OR Gaskin (all four's position) Last line of management - Zavanelli manoeuvre (head is rotated to its pre-restitution position and caesarian section is performed); OR procedures such as cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of the baby); symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother) In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manoeuvre.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The first manoeuvre for shoulder dystocia consists of:
options: Forceful adduction by extension of legs on abdomen
Forceful adduction by flexion of legs on abdomen
Forceful abduction of legs by extending them on abdomen
Forceful abduction of legs by flexing them on abdomen
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Roberts manoeuvre is the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. It involves flexion and abduction of the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. McRoberts manoeuvre: Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen). The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously. The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre. If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position. Rubin's manoeuvre: Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia. It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder. Wood corkscrew manoeuvre: Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia. It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position. Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of these steps would you undertake for the management of a patient with shoulder dystocia along with performing the McRoberts manoeuvre?
options: Flex the legs over the abdomen
explanation: Applying a gentle suprapubic pressure is the first step in the management of shoulder dystocia along with McRoberts manoeuvre. Fundal pressure is not a method of delivery in such cases. Hernandez and Wendel suggested the use of a shoulder dystocia drill to better organize emergency management: Call for help and mobilize labour assistants, anaesthesia and pediatric doctors. An attempt at traction is tried followed by episiotomy to afford room posteriorly. Apply pressure suprapubically, not fundally, with the palm or fist, directing the pressure on the anterior shoulder. This should be both downward (below the pubic bone) and laterally (toward the baby's face or sternum) in conjunction with the McRoberts manoeuvre. These manoeuvres will resolve most cases of shoulder dystocia. If the above-listed steps fail, the following steps may be attempted, and any of the manoeuvres may be repeated: Rubin's manoeuvre Woods corkscrew manoeuvre Gaskin (all four's position) Zavanelli manoeuvre Cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of baby) Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common fetal malpresentation?
explanation: The most common fetal malpresentation is the breech presentation. The most common breech presentation in primigravida is frank breech and in multigravida, it is flexed/complete breech. It is most commonly seen with prematurity. In breech presentation: The most common position is left sacroanterior The engaging diameter is bitrochanteric. Cord prolapse is common in footling presentation and rare in frank breech. However, among all malpresentations, cord prolapse is most common in transverse lie.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In which of the following conditions is Vagos method used?
explanation: Vagos method is used in cord prolapse. Vagos method is also known as the bladder filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–•50 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech. Breech presentation can be divided into the following: Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation Complete: Breech with flexed legs Breech type Description Presenting part Frank breech(with extended l egs) Thighs flexed on the trunk, le gs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia Footling Both thighs and legs are parti ally extended Foot Knee Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexe d. Buttocks, genitalia, foot
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multigravida presented to the clinic at 36 weeks of gestation. She was found to have a breech presentation clinically and on sonography. Which of the following is not an indication for cesarean section in this type of presentation?
explanation: Flexed breech is not an indication for cesarean section in breech presentation. This baby can be delivered vaginally. Factors favouring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus: Large fetus (> 3800 to 4000 g) Severe IUGR Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse) Hyperextended head Contracted pelvis Previous cesarean section Preterm breec Primi with breec Twins, with the first baby in the breec Lack of surgeon experience Patient requests for cesarean delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A footling breech comes under type of breech presentation.
explanation: A footling breech is a type of incomplete breech presentation with one or more feet below the breech. Breech presentation can be divided into the following: Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling or knee presentation Complete: Breech with flexed legs Breech type Description Presenting part Frank breech(with extended l egs) Thighs flexed on trunk, legs e xtended at knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia Footling Both thighs and legs are parti ally extended Foot Knee Thighs extended, knee flexed Knee Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexe d. Buttocks, genitalia, foot
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A neonate is noted to have Klumpke's paralysis of the left arm following delivery. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the associated fetal presentation?
explanation: Klumpke's paralysis is associated with difficult breech delivery, which is due to hyperabduction of the arm during traction and delivery of the fetus. Preeclampsia is not a risk factor for breech presentation. Risk factors for breech presentation: Early gestational age Abnormal amnionic fluid volume Multifetal gestation Hydrocephalus Anencephaly Uterine anomalies Placenta previa Fundal placental implantation High parity with uterine relaxation Prior breech delivery Prior cesarean delivery Smoking.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of the following presentation?
explanation: The presentation depicted in the image is breech presentation. The most common cause of this presentation is prematurity. The incidence of breech at term is 3%. At 28 weeks of pregnancy, 20% of women have a breech presentation. The fetus undergoes spontaneous version usually between 30 - 34 weeks thereby correcting its position by itself. Persistent breech occurs when this spontaneous version is prevented by any of the following causes: Intrauterine death of the fetus Anomalies such as trisomy 13, 18, 21 Anomalies of uterus (septate/bicornuate) Oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios Twins Short cord Hydrocephalus Placenta previa Contracted pelvis Recurrent/habitual breech is when breech recurs in 3 or more pregnancies. It is usually due to uterine anomalies and cornufundal attachment of the placenta.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The following procedure is planned for a pregnant woman at 3• weeks of gestation. What is an absolute contraindication for this?
explanation: Placenta previa is an absolute contraindication for external cephalic version (ECV). Relative contraindications for ECV: early labor oligohydramnios ruptured membranes known nuchal cord structural uterine abnormalities fetal-growth restriction multifetal gestation prior abruption or its risk factors severe pre-eclampsia and hypertension previous LSCS šote: In twin gestation, with a cephalic-noncephalic presentation, after the delivery of the first twin, an internal podalic version or intrapartum external cephalic version can be attempted for the second non-cephalic twin. However, ECV in this case, can lead to an increased incidence of fetal distress when compared with the internal podalic version. Hence, ECV is only a relative contraindication in twin pregnancy. Previous LSCS is a relative contraindication for ECV. However, it is not attempted often and needs to be performed with caution.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multiparous woman presents in labour at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus appears asymmetrical and fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. On fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. What is the likely fetal presentation?
explanation: The given examination findings are suggestive of transverse lie. The likely fetal presentation is shoulder presentation. The most common cause of transverse lie is prematurity. In term pregnancy, it is commonly seen in patients with placenta previa. Although the most common cause of cord prolapse is transverse lie, hand prolapse is also frequently seen in such conditions. The transverse lie is managed by the caesarean section. In a twin pregnancy, management of 1st twin with a transverse lie is caesarean section whereas the 2nd twin is managed by internal podalic version.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An obstetrician is performing a breech delivery. Which of the following manoeuvres can be used for chin to pubis delivery?
explanation: In a breech presentation, chin to pubis delivery can be done by Prague manoeuvre. Rarely, the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the anterior. In such cases, rotation of the posteriorly oriented back of the fetus to the anterior may be achieved by using stronger traction on the fetal legs or bony pelvis. If this still does not succeed, the fetus still may be delivered using the modified Prague manoeuvre. This consists of two fingers of one hand grasping the shoulders of the back-down fetus from below while the other hand draws the feet up and over the maternal abdomen. If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau manoeuvre and delivering the fetus back down.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following methods is not used for delivery of the aftercoming head in breech?
explanation: Delivery of the aftercoming head in breech is not done with the help of Keilland's forceps. These forceps are used for the rotation of the fetal head. It is not used anymore. The methods used for delivery of the aftercoming head include the following: Burns-Marshall manoeuvre: When the occiput is seen under the pubic symphysis, steady traction is given on the feet. The baby is swung in an arc towards the mother's abdomen. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is given and the head is born by flexion. Malar flexion and shoulder traction (modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique): The baby is placed on the supinated left forearm (preferred) with the limbs hanging on either side. The middle and the index fingers of the left hand are placed over the malar bones. The ring and little fingers of the pronated right hand are placed on the child’s right shoulder. The index finger is placed on the left shoulder and the middle finger is placed on the suboccipital region. Traction is now given in a downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch. The assistant gives suprapubic pressure during the period to maintain flexion. The fetus is carried in an upward and forward direction toward the mother’s abdomen releasing the face and brow. Lastly, the trunk is depressed to release the occiput and vertex. The image below shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not used in the management of entrapment of aftercoming head?
explanation: The management of entrapment of aftercoming head does not involve Kristellar manoeuvre. Kristeller manoeuvre is the application of uterine fundal pressure during the second stage of labour to shorten the second stage of labour. This should be used sparingly used as it leads to avulsion of the levator ani. An incompletely dilated cervix will constrict around the neck and impede the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech. Management options: With gentle traction on the fetal body, the cervix may be manually slipped over the occiput. If this is not successful, then Dührssen incisions may be necessary. These are a set of three incisions in the cervix: Can be made at the 2 and 10 o'clock position on the cervix. An additional incision at the 6 o’clock position is sometimes needed. Done for delivery of aftercoming head in breech or delivery of head through an incompletely dilated cervix. There is a significant risk of haemorrhage; the cervical incision may extend upwards within the broad ligament causing broad ligament haematoma. Other alternatives include intravenous nitroglycerin, typically 100 g, to provide cervical relaxation. General anaesthesia with halogenated agents is another option. As a last resort, the following methods are used: Zavanelli manoeuvre: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery. This is performed for the protruding head and intractable shoulder dystocia. Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal cartilage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis. It is also used to aid the delivery of an entrapped aftercoming head.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false?
options: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for vaginal delivery
Breech delivery is done in an hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available
Continous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician
explanation: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is not a contraindication for normal delivery. Vaginal breech delivery is considered when: Fetal weight is between 1.5 kg and 3.5 kg There is an adequate pelvis The presentation is frank breec The fetal head is flexed There are no medical or obstetric complications Facilities for emergency cesarean section are available (anesthetists, neonatologists) (option B) Facilities for continuous labor monitoring are available (option C) A skilled obstetrician is present (option D) Detailed informed consent has been obtained, explaining the risks of vaginal breech delivery Cesarean delivery for breech presentation is considered in the following cases: Lack of operator experience Patient's request for cesarean delivery Prior perinatal death or neonatal birth trauma Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g Severe IUGR, term weight <2.5kg to 2.8kg Incomplete breech presentation Oligohydramnios Fetal anomaly incompatible with vaginal delivery Hyperextended head Contracted pelvis Prior cesarean delivery Preterm breec Twins, with the first baby in the breech position
subject: OBGYN

question_text: On doing PV examination of a woman in labour, mouth with hard alveolar margins and malar eminence is palpable. Which of the following is not a cause of this fetal presentation?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of face presentation. Gynecoid pelvis is not a cause of this fetal presentation. Causes of face presentation: Anencephaly (most common cause) Intrauterine deat Multiparity Prematurity Twist of cord around the neck Anthropoid pelvis Platypelloid pelvis Tumours of neck of the fetus.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multiparous woman was admitted to the labour room at term with complaints of draining per vaginum. On examination, the uterus corresponds to term size, presentation is cephalic and the presenting part is face. Which diameter is engaged in this type of presentation?
explanation: Engaging diameter in face presentation is submentovertical and submentobregmatic. Presentation Engaging diameter Measure ment Vertex (Complete flexion) Suboccipitobregma tic Ž.5 cm Vertex (Incomplete flexion) Suboccipitofrontal 10 cm Vertex (Marked Deflexion) Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm Face ( Incomplete extension) Submentovertical 11.5 cm Face Submentobregmati c Ž.5 cm Brow Mentovertical 14 cm
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1 woman presented to the clinic at 40 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus corresponds to term size and the fetal head is mobile. What is the most common cause to be suspected here?
explanation: Occipitoposterior position (OP) is the most common cause of a mobile head at term. It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation. Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in android pelvis/deflexed head. The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal/occipitofrontal. The most common type in occipitoposterior position is right OP. A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth. Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) is a disproportion in the size of the fetus relative to the maternal pelvis. This can result in the failure of progress of labour in the second stage. This usually occurs due to fetal malposition e.g., extended or asynclitic fetal head, occipitoposterior or transverse position. It is also seen in malpresentations like mentum posterior, brow. The diagnosis of CPD is subjective. However, true CPD may occur if the fetus has a large anomaly e.g., teratoma or conjoined twin, or in cases of a large fetus. It can also occur when the maternal pelvis is small or deformed like after pelvic trauma.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman in labour was admitted to the hospital at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the fetus was found to be in occipitoposterior position. What is the most appropriate management?
options: Wait and watch for progress of labour
explanation: The most appropriate management for pregnant women in labour whose fetus is in occipitoposterior position is to wait and watch for progress of labour. In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle and the baby is born as occipitoanterior. Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior is made, labour is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and favourable pelvis. Indications of caesarean section in occipitoposterior position: Arrest of labour Inadequate uterine contraction Fetal distress Other obstetrical indications.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
What is the most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery?
Intracranial injury
Cephalhematoma
Paraurethral tears
explanation: The most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery is complete perineal tears. In face to pubis delivery, the occiput is posterior, and therefore, the largest biparietal diameter (Ž.4 cm) distends the perineum rather than the smaller bitemporal diameter (8 cm). A liberal episiotomy helps to avoid perineal tears. Operative Vaginal Delivery
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A forceps delivery is being planned for a patient with prolonged second stage of labour. Which of the following is not a prerequisite for this procedure?
explanation: Completely dilated cervix is a prerequisite for forceps delivery. Prerequisites for forceps delivery: Experienced operator Engaged hea Ruptured membranes Vertex presentation Completely dilated cervix Precisely assessed fetal head position Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspecte Absent fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder Before operative vaginal delivery, the bladder should be emptied to provide additional pelvic space and minimize bladder trauma.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: All of the following are criteria for the use of the following instrument except:
options: Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
Fetal head is on the perineum
Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
Rotation of fetal head is more than 45°
explanation: The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is a type of outlet forceps. Rotation of the fetal head should not exceed 45° for the application of outlet forceps. This is because it increases the risk of vaginal wall lacerations.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is true about instrumental vaginal delivery?
options: Full cervical dilatation is the only prerequisite
Forceps can be used for delivery of the after-coming head of breech
Ventouse cannot be used in rotational occipitotransverse/ posterior delivery
Engaged head is not a prerequisite
explanation: Forceps can be used for delivery of the aftercoming head of breech. The advantages are as follows: Delivery can be controlled by giving pull directly on the head and the force is not transmitte through the neck. Flexion is better maintained. Mucus can be sucked out from the mouth more effectively. Prerequisites for instrumental vaginal delivery: Ruptured membranes vertex presentation Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspecte No fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder Completely dilated cervix Precisely assessed fetal head position Engaged hea Experienced operator Note: Ventouse can be used for occipitotranverse or posterior position.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old woman at 35 weeks of gestation is wheeled into the labour room following the onset of labor. A forceps delivery is planned for her. Which of the following is not a contraindication for this?
explanation: Forceps can be used to deliver a preterm baby where it is believed to form a protective cage. Vacuum is contraindicated in these cases. Contraindications of forceps delivery: Unengaged hea Cephalopelvic disproportion Malpresentations like brow and face (mentoposterior position) Cervix not completely dilate Inability to define position Fetal coagulopathy or osteogenesis imperfecta Note: Forceps delivery is only reserved for mentoanterior position.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the given device used for?
explanation: The image shown is a vacuum delivery system. It is used for vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery of the fetus. Theoretical advantages of ventouse (vacuum extraction) compared to forceps include: Simpler requirements for positioning of the fetal hea Avoidance of space occupying blades within the vagina Lower maternal trauma rates
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman with a history of mitral valve prolapse was planned for ventouse delivery. Which statement is true regarding the mode of delivery planned for this patient?
options: Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are frequently seen
It can be applied when fetal head is above the level of ischial spine
Maternal trauma is seen more frequently when compared to forceps
It cannot be used when fetal head is not fully rotate
explanation: Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are more frequently seen with ventouse delivery than with forceps delivery. Maternal morbidity is seen more with forceps deliveries and perinatal morbidity is seen more with vacuum deliveries. Maternal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include: Increased third and fourth-degree vaginal lacerations Pelvic floor disorders Postpartum hemorrhage Perinatal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include: Vacuum-assisted perinatal injuries: Cephalohematoma, subgaleal hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhage, neonatal jaundice secondary to these hemorrhages, shoulder dystocia, clavicular fracture, intracranial hemorrhage, and scalp lacerations. Forceps-assisted perinatal injuries: Higher rates of facial nerve injury, brachial plexus injury, epressed skull fracture, and corneal abrasion. In cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred. It is conducted with the laboring woman in an upright or left decubitus position. Prophylactic use of vacuum is done to cut short the second stage of labor. This is to minimize aortocaval compression. Caesarean section is not preferred since it is associated with more blood loss and higher thromboembolic and infection risk.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Contraindications of ventouse include all except:
explanation: Deep transverse arrest is an indication for ventouse delivery. In ventouse delivery technique, suction is created within a cup placed on the fetal scalp such that traction on the cup aids fetal expulsion. The important step in ventouse extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point. The vacuum is gradually created by increasing the suction in increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 minutes until a total negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 is reached. Progressive descent should accompany each traction attempt.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are an intern posted in the labor room assisting the delivery of a primigravida in labor. The obstetrician planned for a ventouse delivery because of maternal exhaustion. She asked you to help place the ventouse cup. Where would you place it?
options: On the sagittal suture 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
On the sagittal suture 3 cm behind of anterior fontanelle
On the coronal suture 6 cm away from anterior fontanelle
explanation: An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point. It is a point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. Advantages of correct positioning of cup in vacuum extraction: Maximum traction Minimum cup detachment Twisting of fetal head is avoide Smallest head diameter is delivered through the pelvic outlet Success rate is improve Fetal scalp injury rates are lowere Perineal trauma is reduced because the smallest fetal head diameter distends the vulva
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old term primigravida was brought to the hospital in labor. Prophylactic ventouse was used due to ineffective expulsive efforts by the mother. What is the maximum negative pressure used in this procedure?
explanation: The maximum negative pressure used in ventouse is 0.8 kg/cm2 Gradual vacuum creation is recommended. This is generated by increasing the suction in increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 minutes. This is done until a total negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 is reached. This slow incremental approach would allow for a more firm attachment of the vacuum cup to the fetal head and thereby a lower failure rate.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A prophylactic ventouse was planned for an anaemic pregnant woman. Delivery through this mode should occur within .
explanation: Delivery with ventouse should occur within 3 pulls over 15-20 min.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by assisted forceps delivery. What is not an advantage of this mode of delivery?
options: Quick in case of fetal distress
explanation: Autorotation is seen with vacuum extraction and not assisted forceps delivery. Advantages of ventouse over forceps: No need of anaesthesia Less expertise require Less maternal injuries Promotes autorotation Does not occupy the sides Less traction force neede Advantages of forceps over ventouse: No maternal effort is neede Quick in case of fetal distress Can be used in face and breech Can be used in preterm Less cephalohematoma Delivery failure is less
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the advantage of ventouse over forceps?
options: Can be used in preterm hea
explanation: The advantage of ventouse over forceps is that less expertise is required in this technique. Advantages of ventouse over forceps: No need of anaesthesia Less expertise require Less maternal injuries Promotes autorotation Does not occupy the sides Less traction force neede Advantages of forceps over ventouse: No maternal effort is neede Quick in case of fetal distress Can be used in face and breech Can be used in preterm Less cephalohematoma Delivery failure is less
subject: OBGYN

question_text: During a routine check-up of a multigravida at 32 weeks of gestation, the fetus was found to be in breech presentation. The obstetrician planned to do an external cephalic version. What is the ideal time to do this procedure?
explanation: The ideal time to do external cephalic version is 37 weeks. This procedure is attempted in a woman who has completed 36 weeks of gestation and has a breech fetal presentation. Before 37 weeks, a breech presentation has a high likelihood of correcting spontaneously. Moreover, if performed too early, there is time to return back to breech. After 37 weeks, the success rates of ECV are very low. Although it can be performed until the early stages of labour, it is not recommended.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old multigravida at 36 weeks presents for routine ANC. On examination, a hard, ballotable structure is felt at the fundus. NST is reactive. The obstetrician performs the following procedure on her. When will this procedure be contraindicated?
explanation: The procedure shown here is external cephalic version. A relative contraindication for this procedure is intra-uterine growth restriction.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
At which angle would you perform a mediolateral episiotomy in a primigravida?
15°
explanation: The mediolateral episiotomy is directed at an angle of 60°. The mediolateral episiotomy incision starts in the midline at the fourchette and is directed at an angle 60° from the midline. This 60-degree angle takes into consideration a distortion of perineal anatomy during crowning and ultimately yields an incision that is 45° from the midline following delivery. Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesarean (VBAC)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: When should an elective caesarean section ideally be performed?
explanation: An elective caesarean section should ideally be performed after 39 weeks. It is not done before 39 weeks of gestation as there is an increased risk of: Complications related to prematurity including respiratory problems Neonatal adaptation problems such as hypothermia and hypoglycemia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is set to undergo an elective LSCS 2 days later. What is the ideal time to administer antibiotics to this patient?
explanation: According to ACOG guidelines, the ideal time to administer antibiotics is within a time period of 60 mins prior to the planned caesarean section. Antimicrobial administration before surgical incision has been shown to lower postoperative infection rates without adverse neonatal effects, as compared with drug administration after umbilical cord clamping. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice. For emergency delivery, antibiotic prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The partogram of a 26-year-old G2P1 woman is shown below. What is the prophylactic antibiotic of choice for this patient before definitive management is done?
explanation: The above partogram is suggestive of obstructed labour and the definitive management in this case is caesarean section. Cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice for antibiotic prophylaxis before caesarean section. According to the partogram, there is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate indicating fetal distress. Hence, the management plan is to perform a caesarean section. The recommended prophylactic drug is a single intravenous dose of a -lactam antimicrobial. This could either be a cephalosporin or an extended-spectrum penicillin derivative. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is usually given. For obese women, a 2 g dose is better to provide an adequate coverage.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are asked to administer antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis to a patient posted for elective LSCS. What condition does the patient likely have?
explanation: Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis before surgical procedures is recommended in patients with prosthetic valves, prior history of endocarditis, and unrepaired cyanotic heart diseases. Pregnant women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease, prosthetic valves, or both. However, endocarditis prophylaxis is not required if the patient is already receiving intrapartum prophylaxis with broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent endometritis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for atrial septal defect (ASD). The risk of endocarditis with ASD is negligible. Bacterial endocarditis is associated with unrepaired ventricular septal defects where antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended. Similarly, prophylaxis for bacterial endocarditis is indicated at delivery for unrepaired patent ductus arteriosus.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old obese pregnant woman is scheduled for caesarean section. While going through her file, you find that she is allergic to penicillin. What is/are the antibiotic(s) you would prescribe for her?
explanation: In an obese pregnant woman who is allergic to penicillin, a dose of 900 mg clindamycin with an aminoglycoside is used for antibiotic prophylaxis. In women with significant penicillin or cephalosporin allergy, a single 600 mg intravenous dose of clindamycin combined with a weight-based dose of aminoglycoside is recommended. For obese women, a 900 mg dose is preferred.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with preeclampsia presents with haemorrhage at 38 weeks of gestation. You decide to perform a caesarean section and terminate the pregnancy. What is the anaesthesia of choice?
explanation: General anaesthesia is the anaesthesia of choice here since the patient presents with haemorrhage. General anaesthesia may be indicated for emergency cesarean delivery in patients with a reassuring airway examination. It is also recommended for patients with severe coagulopathy where neuraxial anesthesia is contraindicated. Spinal anesthesia is not preferred when the operation is expected to result in blood loss or in a previously haemorrhaging patient. It is because in such cases the development of severe hypovolemia is likely which is a contraindication for this type of anaesthesia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An elective cesarean section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected cephalopelvic disproportion. In which of the following abdominal incisions are the recti muscles transected?
explanation: The recti muscles are transected in the Maylard incision for caesarean delivery which is marked as '2' in the given image. It is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision. The various incisions mentioned in the image are: Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the transverse abdominal incision. Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally. Incision '4' - Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery. It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: All of the following are benefits of using a transverse abdominal incision for caesarean delivery in a patient except .
explanation: Transverse abdominal incisions offer a narrow operating space.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An elective C-section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected contracted pelvis. After opening the abdomen through a modified Pfannenstiel incision, the obstetrician makes a low transverse uterine incision. How should this incision be extended?
options: By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each index finger
By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each index finger
By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each thumb
By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each thumb
explanation: In a C-section, the incision on the uterus can be extended by using lateral and slightly upward pressure applied with each index finger. If the lower uterine segment is thick, then cutting laterally and then slightly upward with bandage scissors will extend the incision. Note: When scissors are used, the index and middle fingers of the non-dominant hand should be insinuated between the myometrium and the fetal parts to prevent fetal laceration.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The highest risk of uterine rupture is seen with .
explanation: A T-shaped incision has the highest risk of uterine rupture among the given options. Among all the incisions, a previous classical cesarean incision has the highest risk of rupture but it is not an option here. Overall, the maximum risk of uterine rupture is in patients who have had a previous upper segment uterine rupture. Women with single prior low-transverse hysterotomy have the lowest risk of symptomatic scar separation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An obstetrician performing a C-section exteriorises the uterus before performing uterine repair. All of the following are true about this procedure except .
options: Incision and bleeding points are easily visualized and repaire
Relaxed/atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applie
Vomiting and discomfort is caused by traction due to exteriorization
Adnexal exposure is low so tubal sterilization is difficult
explanation: Adnexal exposure is high and hence tubal sterilization is easy. After delivery of the placenta, the uterus is lifted through the incision onto the draped abdominal wall. The fundus is covered with a moistened laparotomy sponge and this is known as exteriorisation of uterus. Benefits of exteriorization: Relaxed, atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied. The incision and bleeding points are more easily visualized and repaired. Adnexal exposure is superior, and thus, tubal sterilization is easier. Drawbacks of exteriorization: Intraoperative nausea and vomiting Need for additional uterotonics Longer time duration to the first recognized bowel movement The below image shows the exteriorisation of the uterus.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy?
explanation: Cervical cancer is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy. Indications for peripartum hysterectomy include: Uterine atony - when every other method fails to control PPH Uterine extension Uterine rupture Postpartum uterine infection Cervical laceration Leiomyoma - large leiomyomas in a woman with completed family Ovarian neoplasia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section?
explanation: Skin laceration is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section. Other injuries seen include: Cephalohematoma Brachial plexus injury Clavicular fracture Skull fracture Facial nerve palsy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An elective caesarean section is planned for a pregnant woman with a cardiac ailment. Which of the following complications is she not at an increased risk for?
explanation: Elective caesarean section decreases the risk of chorioamnionitis. Maternal complications increase with caesarean section when compared with vaginal deliveries. Some of these complications include: Post-operative infection Haemorrhage Thromboembolism Anaesthesia-related complications Mendelson syndrome/ aspiration pneumonitis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below?
explanation: The given image shows a pneumatic compression device. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for cesarean section (statement A) and it is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery (statement C). The device is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism. According to recent guidelines, patients with no additional risk factors and not placed on any pharmacological thromboprophylaxis are placed on pneumatic compression devices before cesarean delivery. Patients undergoing cesarean delivery with additional risk factors are put on both pneumatic compression devices and pharmacological therapy (UFH or LMWH). UFH-unfractionated heparin, LMWH-lower molecular weight heparin. Indications of pharmacological thromboprophylaxis: Inherited coagulation disorder Overweight or obese patient Heart failure Family history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The risk factors for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section include all except .
explanation: Age >35 years is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section. The other risk factors include: Emergency cesarean Obesity Parity >3 Caesarean hysterectomy Concurrent infection Preeclampsia Prior deep-vein thrombosis or thrombophilia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 28-year-old multigravida with a history of C-section is being considered for vaginal delivery. The presence of which of the following features would categorise this procedure as low risk?
explanation: Transverse incision in prior caesarean section is a low risk factor in vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). Risk factors for VBAC: High risk - Classical or T-incision in prior cesarean Prior rupture Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa Inadequate facilities Low risk - Transverse incision in prior cesarean Prior vaginal delivery Sufficient personnel and equipment
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A trial of scar is performed on a G2P1L1 woman. The risk of which of the following complications is increased in this baby when compared to their elder sibling?
Birth trauma
explanation: Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) in neonates has a higher incidence with trial of scar or VBAC as compared to elective cesarean. Uterine rupture is a dangerous complication of VBAC. This leads to hemorrhage which can cause the baby to be hypoxic eventually leading to permanent brain damage from hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. This results in developmental delay and cerebral palsy. Birth trauma, transient tachypnea of newborn (TTN) and neonatal sepsis are more commonly seen with elective caesarean in comparison to VBAC. Puerperium
subject: OBGYN

question_text: When does puerperium begin?
options: After the fourth stage of labour
explanation: Puerperium begins as soon as the placenta is expelled and lasts for approximately 6 weeks. It is the period following childbirth during which body tissues revert back approximately to the pre-pregnant state, both anatomically and physiologically. Puerperium can be divided as follows: Immediate puerperium: within 24 hours Early puerperium: up to 7 days Remote/late puerperium: up to 6 weeks or 42 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: How long does early puerperium last?
explanation: Early puerperium is considered to last up to 1 week after delivery. Puerperium can be divided as follows: Immediate puerperium: within 24 hours Early puerperium: up to 7 days Remote/late puerperium: up to 6 weeks or 42 days
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the weight of the uterus immediately after delivery?
explanation: Immediately following delivery, the uterus weighs 1000 g. Involution of the uterus occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibers. question_text: Which of the following is true regarding puerperium?
options: The number of muscle fibres decrease
The uterus weighs 1000g by 1 week postpartum
There is decreased activity of uterine collagenase
explanation: During puerperium, the number of muscle fibers is not decreased, but there is a substantial reduction in the myometrial cell size. There is an increased activity of uterine collagenases and release of proteolytic enzymes. Within the puerperal uterus, larger blood vessels become obliterated by hyaline changes. These vessels are gradually resorbed and replaced by smaller ones. Time following delivery Features Weight of the uteru s Immediately following delive ry Uterus corresponds to 20 we eks gestational ageFundus lie s just below the umbilicus 1000 g 48 hours Myometrial involution starts - 1 week Rapid involution of uterus 500 g 2 weeks The uterus becomes apelvico rgan 300 g 4 weeks Clinically,involution is compl ete 100 g 6-8 weeks Uterus returns to normal (pr e-pregnant) sizeSonographica lly,involution is complete at 8 weeks 60 g
subject: OBGYN

question_text: After how many weeks of postpartum will the uterus becomes a pelvic organ?
explanation: The uterus becomes a pelvic organ by 2 weeks of postpartum. Involution of the uterus occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibers. Time following delivery Features Weight of the uteru s Immediately following delive ry Uterus corresponds to 20 we eks gestational ageFundus lie s just below the umbilicus 1000 g 48 hours Myometrial involution starts - 1 week Rapid involution of uterus 500 g 2 weeks The uterus becomes apelvico rgan 300 g 4 weeks Clinically,involution is compl ete 100 g 6-8 weeks Uterus returns to normal (pr e-pregnant) sizeSonographica lly,involution is complete at 8 weeks 60 g
subject: OBGYN

question_text: When does the uterus return to pregravid size sonographically?
explanation: The uterus and endometrium return to pregravid size by 8 weeks when assessed by sonography. On clinical examination, the involution of the uterus is complete by 4 weeks. Time following delivery Features Weight of the uteru s Immediately following delive ry Uterus corresponds to 20 we eks gestational ageFundus lie s just below the umbilicus 1000 g 48 hours Myometrial involution starts - 1 week Rapid involution of uterus 500 g 2 weeks The uterus becomes apelvico rgan 300 g 4 weeks Clinically,involution is compl ete 100 g 6-8 weeks Uterus returns to normal (pr e-pregnant) sizeSonographica lly,involution is complete at 8 weeks 60 g
subject: OBGYN

question_text: External os reverts back to the pre-pregnant state by how many weeks?
explanation: External os never returns back to normal whereas the contour of the cervix takes 6 weeks to regain normalcy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Endometrial regeneration following delivery starts by which day?
explanation: Endometrial regeneration starts by 7th day and is completed by the 10th day. Regeneration of the epithelium at the placental site takes about 6 weeks. Endometrium regenerates from zona basalis which remains intact and is the source of new endometrium. This arises from proliferation of the endometrial glandular remnants and the stroma of the interglandular connective tissue.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 34-year-old woman has just delivered a boy by spontaneous vaginal delivery. How often should her BP be recorded for the next 2 hours?
explanation: For the first 2 hours following delivery, blood pressure and pulse should be recorded every 15 minutes. Temperature is assessed every 4 hours for the first 8 hours after delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman on post-natal day 1 presented with abdominal pain which worsens when she is breastfeeding. What is this known as?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of afterpains which are seen during puerperium. In primiparous women, the uterus tends to remain tonically contracted following delivery. In multiparous women, it often contracts vigorously at intervals and gives rise to afterpains, which are similar to but milder than labor contractions. These are more pronounced as parity increases and worsen when the infant suckles, likely because of oxytocin release. Afterpains gradually decrease in intensity and become mild by the third day.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What would be the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
explanation: The average duration of lochial discharge in a postpartum woman is about 24-36 days. The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL. The lochial discharge appears as follows: Name Colour Timing after deliver y Content Lochia rubr a Red First few days Blood, decidua, fetal membra nes, vernix, lanugo, meconiu m Lochia sero sa Yellowish/Pi nk After 3-4 days WBC, cervical mucus, microo rganisms Lochia alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterol crystals, and fat c ells
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the contribution of postpartum diuresis to weight loss?
explanation: Postpartum diuresis results in a relatively rapid weight loss of 2 to 3 kg. Decreased estrogen levels are associated with the diuresis of excess extracellular fluid accumulated during pregnancy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the single most important galactopoetic hormone in post-natal women?
explanation: Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone in postnatal women. Function Definition Hormone Mammogene sis Breast growth and developm ent Estrogen (ductal growth)Prog esterone (alveolar growth) Lactogenesis Initiation of milk secretion Prolactin Galactokines is Ejection of milk Oxytocin Galactopoies is Maintainence of lactation Prolactin
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two days after vaginal delivery. Which nerve is likely involved in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament. It is the most common obstetrical neuropathy after vaginal delivery, followed by femoral nerve involvement. Note: The nerves most commonly injured during cesarean section are the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury?
explanation: The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve causing foot drop. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve after vaginal delivery followed by femoral neuropathies. Obstetrical neuropathies are due to the pressure on branches of the lumbosacral nerve plexus during labor. They can manifest as complaints of intense neuralgia or cramp-like pains extending down one or both legs as soon as the head descends into the pelvis. Footdrop can be secondary to injury at the level of the lumbosacral plexus, sciatic nerve, or common fibular (peroneal) nerve. Injury of the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves may occur with cesarean delivery, which may manifest as an inguinal hernia and loss of sensation at the pubic region respectively. Note: Since there are no options relating to intense neuralgia in the lower limb, foot drop becomes the best possible answer.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of .
explanation: Puerperal fever is defined as the temperature of 38 °C or higher (100.4 °F) recorded on 2 separate occasions 24 hours apart within the first 10 days following delivery. This excludes the first 24 hours. In the first 24 hours, a slight rise of temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hours are excluded while defining puerperal pyrexia. Note: Generally, fever in an adult is defined as an oral temperature of >37.5 °C.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presents with high-grade fever and foul-smelling lochia 2 days after vaginal delivery. Lower abdominal tenderness is elicited on examination. Her WBC count is 25,000/ microlitre. Which is the commonest route for the spread of her likely condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, foul-smelling lochia, and pelvic tenderness is suggestive of puerperal sepsis. The most common route of spread of this condition is direct spread. Streptococcus sp. is the most important causative organism of puerperal sepsis. The commonest manifestation is endometritis. The route of delivery is an important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis (cesarean> vaginal). The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in cesarean section. The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following cesarean section is administrating a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of caesarean delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother?
explanation: Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers and should be taken for 10-14 days. Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus. It is common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. Clinical features of mastitis include: Fever and malaise Localized pain and tenderness Purulent nipple discharge Redness and swelling of the affected breast Positive fluctuation test A culture from nipple discharge or test-needle aspiration of the cellulitic area is done to confirm the organism and its antibiotic sensitivity. An ultrasonogram of the involved breast is done to exclude abscess. They are treated with antibiotics and adequate breast support. Choice of antibiotics in lactational mastitis: Dicloxacillin 500 mg 4 times a day is to be started empirically. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive. If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus species then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given for at least 10 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A nursing mother in her third week postpartum presents with breast pain and difficulty in breastfeeding. On examination, warmth and tenderness over the left breast are noted. Her temperature is 38.3 °C and her WBC count is 13,000/mm3. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Most common etiological agent is streptococcus
Immediate source of infection is the infant's nose and throat
explanation: The clinical vignette of breast pain, fever, and leucocytosis with the image showing a red and swollen breast suggests a diagnosis of mastitis. The most common etiological agent is Staphylococcus aureus. Mastitis refers to infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. Symptoms usually appear in the 3rd or 4th week. The infection is usually unilateral, with the source of infection being the infant's nose and throat. Predisposing factors are fissures, abrasions, and nipple cracks. Management: Breastfeeding should be continued. If the infant is unable to nurse on the inflamed breast, the mother may resort to breast pumping. When nursing bilaterally, suckling is best started on the uninvolved breast. Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment of mastitis. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive. If an abscess forms, surgical treatment is done.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A mother started to feel sad and tearful over the first two weeks following childbirth. She felt overwhelmed by the responsibilities of nursing her baby and changing diapers in the middle of the night. She felt that she was a failure as a mother. What is false regarding this condition?
options: It is observed 4-5 days after delivery
Lowered tryptophan levels have been noticed
Nearly 50% of women suffer from this problem
Antidepressants are the treatment of choice
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of puerperal blues. It is also known as 3 day blues/baby blues/maternity blues. It is treated by reassurance and psychological support. Features Puerperal blues Post-partum depression Onset 4-5 daysafter delivery 4-6 monthsafter delivery/abo rtion Cause Sudden decrease in hormone levels Multifactorial Features Puerperal blues Post-partum depression Features Puerperal blues Post-partum depression Features Puerperal blues Post-partum depression Duration Lasts for a few days to 2-3 we eks - Incidence in postpartum mot hers 50% 10-20% Treatment Reassurance and psychologic al support Antidepressants (Fluoxetine/ Paroxetine) Recurrence rate 25% 50-100%
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she came back with fever, tachycardia, and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical situation likely suggests cortical vein thrombosis. Risk factors: Pregnancy and puerperium Oral contraceptives Prothrombotic conditions Most common clinical presentation is headache with or without vomiting, papilledema, or focal deficits. Investigations: Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive CT - normal in 30 % of cases. Option A: Subarachnoid hemorrhage - As there are no focal deficits, this diagnosis is unlikely. Option B: Meningitis - The patient would have presented with neck rigidity or photophobia. Moreover, the presence of early papilledema goes against acute meningitis. Option C: Acute migraine - It does not present with seizures.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A mother, previously on OCPs, comes with her 2-week-old baby to the OPD. She informs you that she is currently breastfeeding her child and enquires about re-starting contraception.
When would you recommend she start using contraceptives?
explanation: Lactating women should start using contraceptives in the 3rd postpartum month. Progesterone-only methods are the hormonal contraception of choice in a lactating mother. Efficacy of contraceptives used in postpartum period: Levonorgestrel IUD/ Implant > DMPA > Progestin-only pill. Contraception should be ideally started after the resumption of ovulation. However, there are no contraindications for the use of contraceptives as early as 4-6 weeks in lactating women and immediately in non-lactating women. Lactating mother Non-lactating mother Ovulation occurs after 10 wee ks Ovulation occurs after 4 wee ks Use contraceptive in3rd post- partum month Use contraceptive in3rd post- partum week.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism secondary to the necrosis of the pituitary gland. It usually results from severe hypotension or shock caused by massive hemorrhage during or after delivery. Patients with SS have varying° of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of infarction. Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years. It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death. Also, it can present late with the following features: Loss of pubic and axillary hair Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out. Fertility can be achieved in these women with hMG and hCG. Clomiphene is ineffective. Option B: Rotor syndrome is a type of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia with autosomal recessive inheritance. Affected individuals have mild jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia. Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 g/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea. Option D: Acromegaly is characterized by the signs and symptoms pertaining to excessive growth hormone secretion.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A woman presents with fever on the 3rd postpartum day and is put on antibiotics. Fever is still not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her?
Stop antibiotics and start heparin
explanation: Antibiotics plus heparin is the next course of treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis refers to the presence of an endovascular thrombus in the setting of associated bacterial or fungal infection. The treatment of septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is broad-spectrum antibiotics plus anticoagulation. Anticoagulation is thought to prevent further thrombosis and reduce the spread of septic emboli. Multifetal Pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common type of multifetal pregnancy?
explanation: The most common type of multifetal pregnancy is dizygotic twinning, which is always dichorionic diamniotic. The incidence of dizygotic twins is 80% among twins. Of the monozygotic twins, monochorionic diamniotic is the most common (13-14%). Zygosity refers to the type of conception while chorionicity refers to the type of placentation. Types of twin pregnancies: Dizygotic: 2 ova are fertilized by 2 sperms to form 2 separate zygotes. Monozygotic: Single zygote (1 ovum fertilized by 1 sperm) divides into 2. Feature Monozygotic Dizygotic Phenotype Identical Non-identical Genotype Identical Non-identical Incidence 1:250 (constant worldwide) Varies with demograp hy Incidence after ART Increases Increases Perinatal complication s High Low

question_text: What is the time of division of the inner cell mass in a diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy?
explanation: Diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy occurs if the division of inner cell mass takes place between 4th - 8th day after fertilization. The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below. Monozygotic twin types Time of zygote division Dichorionic diamniotic <72 hours Monochorionic diamniotic ( more common) 4-8 days Monochorionic monoamnioti c 8-12 days Monozygotic twin types Time of zygote division Monozygotic twin types Time of zygote division Conjoined twins >12 days
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding multifetal pregnancies?
options: Number of embryos implanted affects the risk of twinning
Isograft is done between monozygotic twins
Twins of opposite sex are usually dizygotic
Same sex twins having same blood group are always monozygotic
explanation: Same sex twins of the same blood group are not always monozygotic but can also be dizygotic twins as well. The genetic relationship between dizygotic twins is the same as any siblings. Option A: More the number of embryos transferred in IVF, more is the risk of twinning. Hence, single embryo transfer is being recommended by the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (2017) to prevent twin gestation. Option B: Isograft is done between monozygotic twins as they have HLA homology. Option C: Twins of the opposite sex are usually dizygotic. Rarely, somatic mutations or chromosomal aberrations can change the sex of 1 or both of the monozygotic twins.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The examination findings of a pregnant woman are suggestive of her having conjoined twins. Which is the most common type of such twins?
explanation: Thoracopagus is the most common type of conjoined twins. Division of the inner cell mass after the 12th day of fertilization results in the development of conjoined or Siamese twins. Based on the parts of the body joined, they are of the following types: Ventral Rostral Omphalopagus (abdomen) Thoracopagus (upper chest) Cephalopagus (head) Caudal Ischiopagus (conjoined spines at 180 angle) Lateral Paraphagus (side by side fusion with a shared pelvis) Dorsal Craniopagus (skull) Rachipagus (vertebral arches) Pyopagus (pelvis) Sharing of organs is common among conjoined twins. MRI imaging is done later in pregnancy for the evaluation of organ sharing between conjoined twins who are being planned for surgical separation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following can be used to calculate the incidence of multifetal gestation?
explanation: The incidence of multiple pregnancies is calculated by Hellin’s rule. According to this rule, incidence= 1 : 80(n-1), where n is the number of fetuses. Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies are: Monozygotic ART Dizygotic Race Heredity Maternal age Parity Family history of twinning Good nutritional status Infertility therapy Option A: Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is calculated using ventricular doppler imaging. It is used to assess cardiac function in TTTS. Option C: CHOP score is used for cardiac evaluation of recipient twin in TTTS. Option D: Kleihauer-Betke test is used to evaluate the approximate volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage in cases of Rh-D alloimmunization.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In which of the following instances is there an increased chance of twinning?
explanation: Increasing maternal age, family history of twinning, and conception after stopping OCPs increase the risk of twinning. Taller, well-built women have an increased risk of twinning compared to shorter undernourished women. IVF increases the risk of twinning but single embryo transfer reduces the risk of multifetal pregnancies. Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies: Monozygotic ART Dizygotic Race Heredity Maternal age Parity Family history of twinning Good nutritional status Infertility therapy Note- A family history of twinning (maternal and paternal) causes an increased chance of twinning. It is seen that maternal history of twinning has a higher chance of twinning as compared to a paternal history of twinning.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen?
options: Fertilisation of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilisation of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different ccasion
explanation: Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova released in the same cycle, by two separate acts of coitus within a short period of time. Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova in the same menstrual cycle (as suggested by the same gestational age) by separate acts of coitus. It can occur even after artificial reproductive therapy. Hence, after embryo transfer, intercourse must be avoided. Heteropaternal superfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may give rise to the doubt of adultery and infidelity. Superfetation is the fertilization of two ova released in different menstrual cycles. This is not seen in humans. The nidation and development of one fetus over another fetus is theoretically possible until the decidual space is obliterated by 14-16 weeks of pregnancy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image?
options: It is more common in monochorionic pregnancies
It cannot be detected by sonography
It is diagnosed usually after delivery
Morbidity in the co-twin is due to hypotension
explanation: The above image shows fetus compressus which appears as a tan ovoid mass compressed against the fetal membranes. It can be detected early by sonography. In multifetal pregnancies, if one of the fetuses dies early in pregnancy, the surviving fetus continues to develop normally. It can lead to the following outcomes: Factors affecting the prognosis of the surviving twin: Gestational age at fetal death: 2nd and 3rd trimester deaths increase the risk of morbidity in the surviving twin Chorionicity: Monochorionic twins with early fetal death have an increased risk of morbidity in the surviving twin. This is due to neurological abnormality and vascular anastomoses. Duration between fetal demise and delivery of surviving twin Surviving twin may be born preterm leading to an increased risk of fetal demise Death in the surviving twin occurs mostly due to vascular anastomoses between the twins. The surviving twin can develop sudden hypotension due to these anatomoses after fetal demise. Outcome Type Disappears Vanishing twin Gets compressed Fetus compres sus Flattened through desiccatio n Fetus papyrace us
