question_text: A woman is diagnosed to have twins during her dating scan. What is the most common presentation in such pregnancies?
explanation: The most common presentation in twins is both vertex/ cephalo-cephalic presentation (60%). The other presentations include: Cephalo-Breech (20%) Breech-Cephalic (10%) Breech-Breech (6-10%) Transverse-Transverse (Rarest) Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin as: Presentation of the 1st twin Mode of deliver y Vertex Vaginal Breech Caesarean secti on Transverse Caesarean secti on
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is:
explanation: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is 11-14 weeks. Twin pregnancies should ideally be dated when the crown–rump length (CRL) measurement is between 45 and 84 mm (i.e. 11 + 0 to 13 + 6 weeks of gestation). Chorionicity should be ideally determined between 11 + 0 and 13 + 6 weeks of gestation (the earliest time to identify chorionicity is 7 weeks). This is done using the membrane thickness at the site of insertion of the amniotic membrane into the placenta. The T■sign (in monochorionic twins) or lambda sign (in dichorionic twins) can be seen here. As the determination of chorionicity is most accurate when the amnion and chorion have not yet been fused, the first■trimester scan in twin pregnancy is highly important. Markers of dichorionicity include 4 layers of membranes between the twins, membrane thickness >2mm, different sex of twins, 2 different placentas, and positive twin peak sign. Women with an uncomplicated dichorionic twin pregnancy should have a first■trimester scan, a detailed second■trimester scan, and scans every 4 weeks thereafter. Women with uncomplicated monochorionic twins should have a first■trimester scan and then scans every 2 weeks from 16 weeks onwards. This is done in order to detect TTTS and TAPS in a timely manner.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign. In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane. Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following: Number of placental masses - 2 Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign Thickness of intervening membranes  2mm The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida presents to the ANC clinic for the first time at 14 weeks of gestation. She complains of excessive nausea and vomiting. On examination, fundal height is midway between pubic symphysis and umbilicus. The T sign in seen on USG. What is her diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the T sign seen on USG points towards a diagnosis of monochorionic diamniotic twins. The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the separating membrane is made up only by the two amniotic membranes with no intervening chorion. This can be seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester. Symptoms of multifetal pregnancy: Increased nausea and vomiting in early months Palpitations and shortness of breath Increased swelling of legs, varicose veins and haemorrhoids Unusual rate of uterine growth Excessive fetal movements Signs of multifetal pregnancy: Increased weight gain Hypertension Barrel shaped abdomen Increased fundal height and abdominal girth Multiple fetal parts Palpation of 2 fetal heads FHS at different spots with FHR difference of at least 10bpm Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy is terminated between 34-37 weeks+6 days. The below image shows the T sign.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy?
explanation: The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign. In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions. This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign. Sonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following: Single placental mass Presence of intervening membrane - T sign Thin intervening membrane <2mm The best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34 - 37weeks + 6 days. Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda sign Image 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between them Image 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A mother with twin pregnancy underwent routine USG. Estimated fetal weights were calculated for both twins. What is the criteria to diagnose pathological discordant growth in this pregnancy?
options: Difference of >25% with larger twin as index
Difference of <50% with larger twin as index
Difference of >50% with smaller twin as index
Difference of >20% with larger twin as index
explanation: A difference in estimated fetal weight of >20% with larger twin as index is one of the criteria for diagnosing discordant growth. Discordant growth is the unequal size/ weight among the fetuses in a multifetal gestation. It can be diagnosed by either of the following: Estimated fetal weight difference > 20% Discordance = (weight of larger twin - weight of smaller twin/weight of larger twin) x 100 Discordant growth in monochorionic twins is due to placental vascular anastomoses. In dichorionic twins, it occurs due to differences in genetic growth potential and suboptimal implantation site for one of the fetuses.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a woman receiving artificial reproductive therapy, the inner cell mass divides on the 7th day. Which of the following complications is not seen in the resulting multifetal pregnancy?
explanation: The division of the inner cell mass on the 7th day will result in monochorionic diamniotic type of twin pregnancy. Cord entanglement is seen in monoamniotic twins and not in diamniotic twins. The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below. Complications in monochorionic diamniotic twins occur due to placental vascular anastomoses. They include: Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) or acardiac twin Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome (TAPS) Monochorionic monoamniotic twins have a high fetal death rate. This is due to the following complications: Preterm birth Congenital anomalies Low birth weight Cord entanglement Monozygotic types Time of zygote division Dichorionic diamniotic <72 hours Monochorionic diamniotic ( more common) 4-8 days Monochorionic monoamnioti c 8-12 days Conjoined twins >12 days
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common type of placental vascular anastomoses seen in monochorionic twin pregnancies?
explanation: Artery-vein anastomoses are most commonly seen in monochorionic pregnancies. All monochorionic placentas have anastomoses that can be: Superficial artery-vein Deep artery-vein Artery-artery Vein-vein One vessel with connections to multiple arteries and veins These anastomoses are not functional as long as the fetuses are hemodynamically balanced. When a pressure gradient develops between the fetuses, complications can occur like: TTTS - Twin-twin transfusion syndrome TAPS - Twin anemia polycythemia sequence TRAP - Twin reversed arterial perfusion The most common complication in monochorionic twins is twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). Deep artery-vein anastomosis is the pathology seen in this condition.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is diagnosed to have twin-twin transfusion syndrome. Which of the following statements is true regarding the recipient twin in this condition?
options: It is called the stuck twin
explanation: Congestive heart failure is seen in the recipient twin. Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic diamniotic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through the anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. Oxygenated blood is taken up by the recipient twin causing imbalance in the blood volumes. Diagnosis of TTTS depends on 2 USG criteria: Monochorionic diamniotic gestation Hydramnios (DVP>8cm) in one twin and oligohydramnios (DVP<2cm) in the other twin Treatment modalities for TTTS: Serial amnioreduction Laser ablation of vascular placental anastomoses Selective fetal termination Note: Donor twin is called the stuck twin as the oligohydramnios limits fetal movement. Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics Oliguria Polyuria Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios Hypotension Hypertension Anaemia Polycythemia Activation of renin-angiotens in-aldosterone system (RAAS) Activation of atrial natriureti c peptide (ANP) Renal failure, growth restricti on, pulmonary hypoplasia, co ntractures Congestive cardiac failure, pr emature rupture of membran es

question_text: The ultrasound findings in a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy are indicative of poly-oli syndrome. What is the pathology seen in this condition?
explanation: In poly - oli or polyhydramnios - oligohydramnios syndrome, the basic pathology is the presence of a deep artery-vein anastomosis. TTTS can present as poly-oli syndrome or twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome (TOPS). This is usually seen in mid-pregnancy. In this syndrome, there is decreased donor renal perfusion, causing oliguria and oligohydramnios. Because of the anastomosis, the recipient twin has increased renal perfusion and increased urine production causing polyhydramnios. Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics Oliguria Polyuria Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios Hypotension Hypertension Anemia Polycythemia Renal failure Congestive cardiac failure Growth restriction Premature rupture of membr anes Pulmonary hypoplasia Hyperbilirubinemia Contractures

question_text: Ultrasound findings in a twin pregnancy are given below:
explanation: The given USG findings are indicative of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) with twin A being the recipient and twin B being the donor twin. Oligohydramnios (AFI<5cm), absent urine and abnormal Doppler flow findings in the donor twin indicate stage III of twin-twin transfusion syndrome according to Quintero staging. Quintero staging system for TTTS classification: Stag e USG findings I Discordant amniotic fluid vol umes + urine visible in donor' s bladder II Discordant amniotic fluid vol umes + urine not visible in d onor's bladder III Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of umbilical artery/vei n or ductus venosus IV Ascites or frank hydrops in ei ther twin V Death of either twin

question_text: An anxious mother pregnant with twins was recently diagnosed with twin-twin transfusion syndrome. She wants to know the possible fetal outcome of the pregnancy. Which of the following investigations can be used to predict this?
explanation: In twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), the fetal outcome depends on the cardiac function of the recipient twin. Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is used to assess the ventricular function using doppler. Option A: Deepest vertical pocket on USG is used to diagnose polyhydramnios-oligohydramnios in TTTS. Options B and D: Fetal haemoglobin and MCA peak systolic velocity are used to diagnose TAPS (Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome).

question_text: What is/are the placental vascular abnormality that can be seen in the condition depicted in the image given below?
explanation: The given image shows an acardius acephalus fetus. This refers to the acardiac twin seen in twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP). Both artery-artery and vein-vein anastomosis can be seen in TRAP. TRAP is a placental vascular anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. In this disorder, deoxygenated blood from the donor twin enters the recipient twin through the anastomosis and supplies the lower half of the recipient’s body. Hence, the heart and upper body of the recipient is poorly developed. The below image depicts the circulation pattern seen in TRAP. Based on the supply of deoxygenated blood, the recipient twin might have the following fates: The donor twin develops high output cardiac failure. The treatment for this condition is radiofrequency ablation of the acardiac or recipient twin. Fate Type Lower body is perfused with f ailed head growth Acardius acephalus Partially developed head with identifiable limbs Acardius myelecephal us Fate Type Fate Type No recognizable structure Acardius amorphous

question_text: A 25-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, goes into labour. Following the vaginal delivery of the first twin, she was taken to the OT for internal version. What could have been the possible indication for this procedure?
explanation: The second twin being in transverse lie is the only indication for internal version in modern obstetrics. In a twin pregnancy, if the first twin has vertex presentation, vaginal delivery can be performed. Following the vaginal delivery of the first twin, if the second twin is in transverse lie, it is corrected by external version (preferably cephalic) into a longitudinal lie. If external version fails and the membranes are intact, internal version is done under general anaesthesia, followed by breech extraction. If the membranes are ruptured, caesarean section is done immediately. Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin: Presentation of the 1st twin Mode of deliver y Vertex Vaginal Breech Caesarean secti on Transverse Caesarean secti on
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify this condition.
explanation: The given specimen depicts a monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy as: 2 umbilical cords are arising from 1 placenta (monochorionic) No intervening amniotic membrane is attached to the placenta. This means that both fetuses must have been inside a single amniotic cavity (monoamniotic). Option B: In Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, on gross examination, there will be 1 placenta and intervening 2 layers of amnion attached to the placenta. In this type of pregnancy, each fetus will have its own amniotic cavity (diamniotic) with a shared placenta (monochorionic). This is seen if the fertilized zygote divides into 2 between 4-8 days. The below given gross image of monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy shows two umbilical cords arising separately from the placenta with the intervening amniotic membrane held by the forceps. Option D: In dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy each fetus has it’s own amnion & chorion. The placentas here may be fused or separate. This is seen in dizygotic twins as well as monozygotic twins that divide within 0-4 days. Option A: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) most commonly complicates monochorionic (single placenta) twin pregnancy. In TTTS blood is transfused from the donor twin to the recipient twin through the abnormal vascular connections within the placenta leaving the donor anemic while the recipient becomes polycythemic. The box below describes the type of amnion and chorion seen in different types of twins depending on the time of division. Dizygotic twins Dichorionic diamniotic Monozygotic twins- division occurs within0-4 days4-8 day s8-12 days>13 days Dichorionic diamnioticMono chorionic diamnioticMonoch orionic monoamnioticMonoc horionic monoamniotic conjo ined twins

question_text: A pregnant woman was diagnosed with triplets on ultrasound. The obstetrician has planned to do a selective fetal reduction of one of the fetuses to improve the outcome of the pregnancy. What is the ideal timing and the method for the procedure?
explanation: Selective fetal reduction is done between 10-13 weeks via intracardiac injection of KCl. In multi-chorionic multifetal gestations, selective reduction of the smallest or anomalous fetus/fetuses is done to increase the chance of survival of the other fetuses. Laser ablation or bipolar coagulation of the umbilical cord of the targeted fetus is done. This protects the surviving fetuses from the adverse effects of the drug.

question_text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?
options: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation
explanation: Immediate cesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation. Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy: The mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin: After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd twin is in a transverse lie, the internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by breech extraction. Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and breech: Interlocking of twins Fetal head trapping above the cervix Umbilical cord prolapse According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In the case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks. According to the updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, a Caesarean section can be done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy. Type of twin pregnancy Timing of delivery Dichorionic diamniotic 38 weeks Monochorionic diamniotic 34 - 37 weeks + 6 days Monochorionic monoamn iotic 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean s ection 1st twin presentatio n Mode of delive ry Vertex Vaginal Breech Cesarean secti on Transverse Cesarean secti on

question_text:
A 26-year-old primigravida with dichorionic diamniotic twins presents to the clinic in active labor. The first twin is delivered vaginally but the second has a transverse lie. A trial of ECV was unsuccessful. What is not a complication of the procedure performed next for the delivery of the second twin?
Face presentation
explanation: The given clinical procedure is suggestive of internal podalic version for the second twin. Shoulder presentation, and not face presentation, is a complication of this procedure. The complications seen with internal podalic version are as follows: Maternal- Failure of the procedure Uterine rupture Vaginal and perineal trauma Placental abruption Postpartum haemorrhage Ascending infection Anaesthetic risks Fetal- Cord prolapse Shoulder presentation with prolapsed arm Skeletal injury (femur, hips, humerus, skull) Visceral injury (kidney, liver, spleen) Neural injury (facial nerve) Hypoxic brain injury Death Ectopic Pregnancy

question_text: Arrange the following sites of ectopic pregnancy from the most common to the least common.
explanation: The order of the most common site to the least common site in the fallopian tube for ectopic pregnancy is ampulla>isthmus>fimbriae>interstitium. An ectopic pregnancy is any pregnancy implanted outside of the endometrial cavity. Extrauterine sites: The most common site of ectopic pregnancy is the extrauterine fallopian tube. Tubal - 97% (most common) Ampulla - 55% Isthmus Infundibulum Interstitium Ovarian Abdominal Intrauterine ectopic sites: Cervical Caesarean scar Rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus Heterotopic pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
explanation: Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the given options. Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy: Prior ectopic pregnancy Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy Infertility Artificial reproductive therapy Endometriosis Smoking Maternal age >40 years Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The fall in which of the following hormone/s leads to endometrial sloughing in ectopic gestation?
explanation: Endometrial sloughing in ectopic gestation is due to the fall in the levels of progesterone and hCG. During normal pregnancy, endometrium is maintained by the high levels of hCG and progesterone. In ectopic pregnancy, a fall in the levels of these hormones will cause endometrial sloughing and uterine bleeding. If the decidua is expelled as a single piece through the cervix, it is called a decidual cast.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which type of tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage?
explanation: Interstitial tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage i.e. at 12-16 weeks. This is because pregnancy at this site is closer to the uterine myometrium which provides support as pregnancy progresses. Isthmic and ampullary pregnancies terminate by tubal rupture. However, isthmic pregnancy ruptures earlier. Ampullary and infundibular pregnancy can terminate by tubal abortion as well.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following clinical features is not seen in a patient with ruptured ectopic pregnancy?
explanation: A shock index of >0.85 is seen in a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. There is massive blood loss (SBP<110 mmHg) sometimes leading to shock. The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP. Option A: Sub-diaphragmatic blood irritates the phrenic nerve. This causes a referred pain at the shoulder tip. This is called as Danforth sign. Option B: The expulsion of decidua in a single piece through the cervix is called a decidual cast. This is due to the fall in the levels of  hCG and progesterone. Option C: Vertigo and syncope are due to reflex vasomotor disturbances due to peritoneal irritation from hemoperitoneum. Condition Range of shock ind ex Normal value of shock index (non-pregnant) 0.5 - 0.7 Normal value of shock index in pregnancy (i.e) obstetrical shock index 0.7 - 0.8 Significant or massive blood l oss 0.9 - 1.1
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman presented with complaints of amenorrhoea for 6 weeks and a history of prior ectopic pregnancy. Serial serum beta hCG levels were estimated in her. Which of the following findings will increase the suspicion of ectopic gestation in her?
options: Low levels with prolonged doubling time
High levels with decreased doubling time
explanation: Low levels of  hCG and prolonged doubling time increase the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy. Urine pregnancy test is very sensitive and found positive in most ectopic pregnancies. Hence, serial serum  hCG levels are estimated to detect ectopic pregnancy. In early normal pregnancy, the doubling time of  hCG concentrations in plasma is 1.4 to 2 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient presented with 6 weeks of amenorrhoea and a positive UPT. TVS revealed a tubal ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following findings can be usually picked up on colour Doppler?
options: Enhanced blood flow pattern in the uterine artery
explanation: Ring of fire pattern is seen on color doppler in a tubal ectopic pregnancy. This is due to placental blood flow in the tubal pregnancy. This finding may also be seen in corpus luteum cysts but the wall is less echogenic compared to tubal ectopic. Option A: There is an enhanced blood flow pattern outside the uterine cavity in case of ectopic pregnancy. Option B: Arias-Stella reaction/phenomenon is a histological finding. It is an atypical endometrial change due to the action of progesterone on the endometrial tissue seen in normal, ectopic, and molar pregnancies. On histology, there are: large cells with abundant eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm nuclear enlargement hyperchromasia Option D: Whirlpool sign refers to the twisted ovarian pedicle seen on USG of ovarian torsion.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman came for routine antenatal USG. Which of the following features is suggestive of a pseudogestational sac?
explanation: Central location is a feature of the pseudogestational sac seen in ectopic pregnancies. Pseudogestational sac is a collection of fluid between the endometrial layers, surrounded by a thick decidua. Its presence increases the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy. Differences between pseudogestational sac and true gestational sac: Feature Pseudogestational sa c True gestational sa c Location within the endomet rial cavity Central Eccentric Shape Usually ovoid Usually round Fetal and yolk sac poles Absent Present Double ring sign Absent Seen Intradecidual sign Absent Seen
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which was inconclusive. What is the next step of management?
explanation: In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum  hCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and early intrauterine pregnancy. If the level is 2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <1500 IU/L, a repeat serum  hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are: Doubled - early intrauterine pregnancy Decreased - abortion Increased but less than doubled value - ectopic pregnancy Investigations for ectopic pregnancy: Serum  hCG - lower levels compared to normal pregnancy, prolonged doubling time Transvaginal ultrasound - empty uterine cavity, fluid in pouch of Douglas, adnexal mass Colour Doppler - ring of fire pattern Laparoscopy Dilatation and curettage - decidua identified without villi Serum progesterone Culdocentesis Diagnostic laparoscopy may be done when the diagnosis is still uncertain after serial -hCG monitoring and repeat ultrasonography. In high-risk situations, such as a history of previous ectopic pregnancy, earlier diagnostic laparoscopy is considered.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with unruptured ectopic gestation. Which of the following is not an indication for expectant management in this patient?
options: Initial serum beta hCG level of 200 mIU/mL
explanation: A gestational sac size of <4 cm is an indication of expectant management. Expectant management is done only in the case of unruptured tubal pregnancy. In this, observation is done till there is spontaneous resolution. It can be done but is not preferred due to prolonged follow-up and uncertainty in resolution. The indications are: Initial serum  hCG <1500 IU/L Falling serum  hCG levels Gestational sac size <4 cm No fetal cardiac activity on TVS No evidence of rupture or bleeding on TVS
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida in her first trimester came for a routine ANC. USG findings revealed an empty uterine cavity. Serum beta hCG was measured and was found to be 1700 IU/mL. All of the following drugs can be used in managing this patient except:
explanation: Oxytocin is not used in the management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy. Indications for medical management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy: Hemodynamically stable patient Serum  hCG <5000 IU/L Tubal diameter <4 cm No fetal cardiac activity No intra-abdominal haemorrhage Medical management of unruptured tubal ectopic: Direct local therapy (laparoscopy or USG guidance) - Methotrexate Potassium chloride Actinomycin Hyperosmolar glucose PGF2 Systemic therapy - single dose of methotrexate 50 mg/m2 IM Follow-up after medical management is done by measuring the decline in serial serum  hCG.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy is planned for medical management with methotrexate. What is the multi-dose protocol for this drug?
explanation: In the multi-dose protocol, methotrexate is given at a dose of 1 mg/kg as an IM injection on alternate days 1, 3, 5, and 7. This regimen is continued on alternating days until the hCG level drops by 15% over two days. Up to 4 doses may be given. Along with this, leucovorin rescue (folinic acid) is given at 0.1 mg/kg after 24 hrs (on days 2, 4, 6, and 8) to buffer the side effects of methotrexate. Note: If the decline is 15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. M aximum 4 doses Second dose onDay 7if hCG d oes not decline 15%
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following must be avoided by a patient with tubal pregnancy on methotrexate?
explanation: Sunlight exposure, sexual intercourse and NSAIDs must be avoided when patients are on methotrexate therapy. The following should be avoided when methotrexate therapy has been initiated for the treatment of ectopic gestation: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs - can cause reduced renal blood flow and delay drug excretion Alcohol - can predispose to concurrent hepatic enzyme elevation Sunlight - may provoke methotrexate-related dermatitis Sexual intercourse - can rupture the ectopic pregnancy Phenytoin, tetracyclines, salicylates, and sulfonamides - can increase serum methotrexate levels
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state with complaints of bleeding PV associated with abdominal pain and a history of amenorrhoea for 8 weeks. On examination, BP was 90/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and UPT was positive. What is the next step of management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy which must be immediately managed with simultaneous resuscitation and laparotomy. On laparotomy, salpingectomy is the definitive surgery. Diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made based on clinical features: Amenorrhoea for 6-8 weeks followed by bleeding PV Abdominal pain Hemodynamically unstable Urine pregnancy test - positive Surgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy includes salpingectomy or salpingostomy, performed either through laparoscopy or laparotomy. Management of suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy consists of initial resuscitation and stabilization, followed by point-of-care ultrasound (FAST) to identify intraperitoneal free fluid and surgical exploration. Laparotomy is done for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingectomy is the treatment of choice and is done with preservation of the ipsilateral ovary and its vascular supply. For patients wishing to preserve future fertility, if the contralateral fallopian tube is damaged, salpingostomy is preferred. However, salpingostomy may result in inadequate evacuation of the products of conception and a recurrence of symptoms. Therefore, after a patient undergoes salpingostomy, it is important check the -hCG level on a weekly basis to ensure that it reaches zero. The image given below shows a laparoscopic visualization of a tubal pregnancy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Match the following criteria used for the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy:
explanation: Spiegelberg’s criteria used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy include intact ipsilateral tube, pregnancy occupying ovary connected by the utero-ovarian ligament. Studdiford’s criteria used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy include the presence of normal bilateral tubes and pregnancy related to the peritoneal surface. Rubin's criteria used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy includes presence of soft, enlarged cervix and closed internal os and partially opened external os. Ectopic pregnan cy Criteria Abdominal Studdifor d Cervical Rubin Ovarian Spiegelbe rg
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An O-ve primigravida underwent surgery for ectopic pregnancy at 13 weeks of gestation. What will be the dose of anti-D immunoglobulin to be given to her?
explanation: Anti-D is given at a dose of 300 g intramuscularly for alloimmunization after surgical management of ectopic pregnancy. The dose of anti-D in a surgically treated case of ectopic is 50 g if gestation <12 weeks. If the gestation is >12 weeks, 300 g of anti-D is given intramuscularly. Anti-D is not given when the ectopic is treated with medical methods.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old female patient (G2P0A1) with a history of FSH therapy and in vitro fertilization presented with lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and vaginal discharge. On examination, she was hemodynamically stable. Transvaginal ultrasound showed a viable intrauterine pregnancy of 8 weeks associated with a heterogeneous right adnexal mass showing a positive bagel sign. What is the most appropriate management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heterotopic pregnancy. Surgery is the ideal treatment in heterotopic pregnancy. A normal uterine pregnancy co-existing with an extrauterine (ectopic) pregnancy is termed a heterotopic pregnancy. Although heterotopic pregnancy can occur spontaneously, it is more likely after ART and ovulation induction. Tubal ring sign also referred to as bagel sign is one of the ultrasound signs of a tubal ectopic. It comprises an echogenic ring that surrounds an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. USG image showing bagel sign or tubal ring sign: Methotrexate is not to be given as it harms even the normal intrauterine fetus. Although potassium chloride may be injected into the sac of the ectopic, the safer method would be surgery to remove the ectopic.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Methotrexate was administered to a patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy. At what serum beta hCG levels will this drug be most effective?
explanation: Methotrexate is most effective when given at  hCG levels are <5000 IU/L. Methotrexate is given at a dose of 50 mg/m2 of body surface area. Monitoring is done by measuring  hCG levels on days 4 and 7. If the decline is 15% of the initial value, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. If the decline is <15%, a 2nd dose of methotrexate is given on day 7.
subject: OBGYN

Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of
Ovarian pregnancy
explanation: Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy. Primary abdominal pregnancy is the rarest type of ectopic gestation. The conceptus implants on the peritoneal surface of the abdomen. Studdiford’s criteria: The presence of normal bilateral tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy. No evidence of a uteroperitoneal fistula. The presence of pregnancy, related exclusively to the peritoneal surface, early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are: Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria); Rubin's criteria (histological criteria) Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria Abortion and Medical Termination of Pregnancy

subject: OBGYN

question_text: Antepartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from the genital tract after .
explanation: Antepartum haemorrhage (APH) is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract after 28 weeks of gestation up to the delivery of the baby. The lower limit is the period of viability and the upper limit includes the 1st and 2nd stages of labour. Causes of APH: Placental causes: Abruptio placenta (most common) Placenta previa (2nd most common) Circumvallate placenta Circummarginate placenta Fetal causes: Vasa previa Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions): Local trauma Varicose veins Cervical polyp Carcinoma cervix. Note: According to RCOG criteria, the lower limit for APH is 24 weeks. However, in India, the period of viability is 28 weeks, so it is taken as the lower limit for APH.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage?
explanation: Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage (APH). Placental abruption or abruptio placenta is the premature separation of a normally situated placenta. The bleeding can be revealed, concealed or mixed type. Causes of APH: Placental causes: Abruptio placenta (most common) Placenta previa (2nd most common) Circumvallate placenta Circummarginate placenta Fetal causes: Vasa previa Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions): Local trauma Varicose veins Cervical polyp Carcinoma cervix.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Transvaginal ultrasound findings in a multiparous woman revealed a low lying placenta. What does this mean?
options: Placental edge within 2 cm from the internal os
Placental edge within 3 cm from the internal os
Placental edge within 4 cm from the internal os
explanation: In low lying placenta, the edge of the placenta lies within 2 cm from the internal os but does not cover the internal os. Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted over the lower uterine segment (partially or completely). ACOG classification of placenta previa: True placenta previa - placenta covers the internal os partially or completely Low lying placenta - placenta does not cover the internal os but the edge is within 2 cm of the internal os
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following types are included in the major° of placenta previa?
explanation: Major degree of placenta previa includes posterior marginal, partial and complete central. Clinical classification of placenta previa: Mild degree Type I or lateral or low lying Type II anterior or anterior marginal Major degree Type II posterior or posterior marginal or dangerous placenta previa Type III or partial central Type IV or complete Older (Browne's) classification of placenta previa: Type Position Definition Type I Lateral The placenta dips into the lo wer segment but does not rea ch up to the os Type II Marginal The placental edge reaches th e os Type III Incomplete or partial central The placenta partially covers the internal os Type IV Complete or central The placenta completely cove rs the internal os
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old multiparous woman presented at 32 weeks of gestation with complaints of recurrent painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, fundal height corresponded to gestational age and fetal heart rate was 140 bpm. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa. Pre-eclampsia is a risk factor for abruptio placenta, not placenta previa. Painless bleeding PV, fundal height proportional to gestational age and presence of FHS are the differentiating features of placenta previa from abruptio placenta. Risk factors for placenta previa are: Demographic factors Maternal age >35 years Multiparity Cigarette smoking Clinical factors Prior caesarean section Past history of placenta previa Artificial reproductive technology Multifetal pregnancy Succenturiate lobe.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Per speculum examination findings in a pregnant woman with vaginal bleeding showed placenta protruding through the cervical os. What is the type of placenta previa in this case?
explanation: Placenta protruding through the internal os on per speculum examination indicates complete placenta previa or type IV placenta previa. Older (Browne's) classification of placenta previa: Cervical digital examination must only be done in suspected cases of placenta previa in an operation theater with provisions for cesarean section kept ready. Type Position Definition Type I Lateral The placenta dips into the lo wer segment but does not rea ch up to the os Type II Marginal The placental edge reaches th e os Type III Incomplete or partial central The placenta partially covers the internal os Type IV Complete or central The placenta completely cove rs the internal os
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient at 34 weeks of gestation presented with placenta previa. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: Painful recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen
The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age
explanation: Painless recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen in placenta previa. Clinical features of placenta previa: Bleeding per vaginum - sudden onset, painless, recurrent, bright red in colour, sometimes a history of warning haemorrhage is present Uterus - relaxed, soft, no tenderness, size proportional to the period of gestation Floating head i.e., persistent displacement of fetal head as it cannot be pushed down into the pelvis Fetal heart sound - present Stallworthy sign - seen in low lying placenta, especially the posterior type. Slowing of fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Abdominal examination during a routine antenatal checkup gave a positive Stallworthy sign. What could be the most probable cause?
explanation: Stallworthy sign is observed in posterior placenta previa. The slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly when the pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign. Note: This sign is not always significant as this could also occur in normal pregnancies due to fetal head compression.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1 woman presents to the casualty at 30 weeks with a history of self-limiting painless bleeding PV 3 hours ago. On examination, BP - 110/70 mmHg and PR - 80 bpm. What is the next best step in management?
options: Transvaginal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis
Start injection corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of antepartum haemorrhage (APH) due to placenta previa (painless bleeding PV). The next step in the management is to confirm the diagnosis with transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) as the patient is stable. Transabdominal ultrasound (TAS) is used to detect the cause of APH. If the placenta is in the lower uterine segment on TAS, confirmation of placenta previa is done by TVS. TVS provides a clearer image of the relationship between the edge of the placenta and the internal cervical os than TAS. Approach to placenta previa after confirmation with TVS: Minor placenta previa - repeat USG at 36 weeks Major placenta previa or accreta - USG at 32 weeks followed by elective caesarean delivery Bleeding present - individual management On TAS, if the placenta is in the upper uterine segment with evidence of retroplacental blood clot, abruptio placenta is suspected. Per vaginal examination in placenta previa must not be done as it may further separate the placenta and cause excessive bleeding. However, transvaginal ultrasound is safe as long as the probe is 2-3 cm away from the cervix.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1L1 woman at 30 weeks of gestation was rushed to the casualty with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding. She had woken up to find herself in a pool of blood. On examination, her vitals were unstable. Active bleeding per vaginum was present. Which of the following complications would not be anticipated in her?
explanation: Then given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa and precipitate labour is not a complication. Precipitate labour is seen in abruptio placenta and uterine tachysystole. Vaginal bleeding in placenta previa is sudden in onset, recurrent, painless, unrelated to activity, and often occurs during sleep. Complications of placenta previa: Maternal complications: Fetal complications: Low birth weight Asphyxia Intrauterine death Birth injuries Congenital malformations. Period Complication Antepart um Antepartum haemorrhageMa lpresentationPreterm labour Period Complication Period Complication Intrapart um Early rupture of membranesS low dilatation of cervix Postpart um Postpartum haemorrhage Puerperi um SepsisSubinvolution
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Transvaginal ultrasound in a multiparous woman at 32 weeks confirmed placenta previa. Her vitals are stable and there is no active bleeding PV. What is the next step in management?
options: Manage as per McAfee and Johnson method
Manage as per Sher and Page grading
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the next best step of management is conservative management till 37 weeks i.e., McAfee and Johnson's regimen. The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. Prerequisites: Blood for transfusion Facilities for cesarean section Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks No active vaginal bleeding Fetus reactive on cardiotocography and no congenital anomalies on USG Conduct of expectant treatment: Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity Bed rest or pelvic rest Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding PV Fetal surveillance with USG Tocolytics if contractions are present Anti-D to all Rh-negative unsensitized women Option A: Immediate caesarean section after resuscitation is done if the patient is unstable. Option B: Vaginal delivery is considered when the edge of the placenta is >2 cm away from the internal os. Option D: Sher and Page grading is for abruptio placenta.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include all except:
explanation: The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which was advocated by McAfee and Johnson. The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. Prerequisites: Availability of blood for transfusion Facilities for cesarean section available Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks No active vaginal bleeding Fetus normal on USG and reactive on CTG Conduct of expectant treatment: Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity Bed rest or pelvic rest Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding pv Fetal surveillance with USG Tocolytics if contractions are present Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics?
explanation: Placental abruption is the most common cause of severe consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics. Consumptive coagulopathy, also known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), is a pathologic disruption of hemostasis. It is characterized by systemic activation of blood coagulation, which results in thrombosis and fibrin deposition in the small blood vessels throughout the body. Other causes of DIC in pregnancy: Amniotic fluid embolis Sepsis Preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome Acute fatty liver of pregnancy Postpartum haemorrhage.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following does not increase the risk of placental abruption?
explanation: Post term pregnancy does not increase the risk of abruptio placenta. Risk factors for placental abruption: Prior abruption Increased age and parity Pre-eclampsia and chronic hypertension Chorioamnionitis Preterm ruptured membranes Multifetal gestation Cocaine use Cigarette smoking Uterine leiomyomas Single umbilical artery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following clinical features can be seen in a patient presenting with accidental haemorrhage?
explanation: Abruptio placenta is also known as accidental haemorrhage or premature separation of placenta. Tender uterus is seen in abruptio placenta. Abruptio placenta is defined as premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It is of the following types: Concealed Revealed Mixed Clinical features of abruptio placenta: In mixed type, features of concealed variety will be predominant. Features Revealed Concealed General conditi on Proportionate to visible bloo d loss Shock may be pronounced w hich may be out of proportio n to visible bleeding. Symptoms Abdominal discomfort or pai n followed by bleeding Abdominal acute intense pai nNo or minimal bleeding Uterine height Proportionate to the period o f gestation Maybe disproportionately enl arged FHS Usually present Usually absent
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multiparous woman at 34 weeks of gestation presented with bleeding per vaginum and was diagnosed to have grade 2 abruptio placenta. Which of the following features may be seen in her?
explanation: Grade 2 abruptio placenta is characterized by fetal distress. Sher and Page clinical classification of placental abruption: Grade 0 of abruptio placenta is seen in an asymptomatic patient, where a retroplacental clot is observed only after delivery of placenta. Feature Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3 Vaginal bleeding Slight Mild to moderate Moderate to severe or concea led type Uterine tenderness Minimal Present Marked Maternal BP and pulse rat e Unaffect ed BP maintainedPulse rate incr eased Hypovolemic shockAnuria Fetal condition FHS go od Fetal distress Fetal death Maternal fibrinogen Unaffect ed Decreased Coagulation defect
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
options: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
It is an indication for hysterectomy
It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy
explanation: The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta. There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity. It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Colour doppler studies in a patient with velamentous cord insertion revealed fetal vessels which were overlying the cervical os. Which of the following is false regarding her condition?
options: Bleeding is triggered by membrane rupture
Bleeding is managed by category I caesarian section
explanation: The doppler findings are suggestive of vasa previa. Maternal mortality is not seen in vasa previa, but fetal mortality is seen. Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture. Fetal mortality is high and is due to fetal exsanguination. Investigations of vasa previa: Colour flow Doppler (TVS) Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells Apt test (alkali denaturation test) - to detect fetal haemoglobin Management of vasa previa: No bleeding 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance 37 weeks - elective caesarean section Bleeding present Category I emergency caesarean section is done (immediate threat to the life of mother or fetus and decision delivery interval <30 mins)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Sample from a patient with bleeding PV at 30 weeks showed a positive Apt test. What is the most probable cause?
explanation: Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal haemoglobin (HbF). It is positive in vasa previa and Rh incompatibility. Apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. It is done by taking the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding 10% NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube. Bleeding due to vasa previa must be managed immediately with an emergency caesarean section. Hence, Apt test is not practically done in all cases. Other options: Bleeding due to cervical polyp, placenta previa, and abruptio placenta is of maternal origin. So, Apt test will be negative in these cases.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following investigations can be used in the antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa in a patient with no history of bleeding PV?
explanation: The antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa can be done by colour doppler. Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture. Fetal mortality is high due to fetal exsanguination. Investigations of vasa previa: Colour flow Doppler (TVS) Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells Apt test - to detect fetal haemoglobin Management of vasa previa: No bleeding 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance 37 weeks - elective caesarean section Bleeding present Emergency caesarean section done by category I Options A and B: Colour Doppler is superior to MRI and TAS in the antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa. Option D: Singer's alkali denaturation test to detect fetal RBCs can be used in intrapartum diagnosis of vasa previa (as there might be bleeding).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multiparous woman at term presents to the labour room with bleeding per vaginum and ruptured membranes. NST shows fetal distress and sinusoidal heart rate pattern. How will you manage this patient?
options: Rapid induction and delivery by vacuu
Rapid induction and delivery by forceps
Adopt Vagos method and rapid vaginal delivery
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vasa previa since bleeding is associated with fetal distress and sinusoidal pattern in NST. Actively bleeding vasa previa in a term gestation is managed by immediate LSCS. Sinusoidal pattern in CTG is a regular, smooth, undulating signal resembling a sine wave. It can be seen in conditions associated with severe fetal anemia like: Anti-D allo-immunisation Fetal-maternal haemorrhage Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome Ruptured vasa previa Acute fetal hypoxia Infection Cardiac malformations Hydrocephalus Gastroschisis Sinusoidal pattern on CTG: Management of vasa previa: No bleeding 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance 37 weeks - elective caesarean section Bleeding present Emergency caesarean section Note: Vagos method is used in the management of umbilical cord prolapse.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes all except .
explanation: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism does not include metabolic acidosis. Classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism: Hypotension Hypoxia DIC Conditions predisposing to the development of amniotic fluid embolism: Rapid labour Meconium-stained amniotic fluid Tears in uterine and other large pelvic veins Older maternal age Post-term pregnancy Labour induction or augmentation Eclampsia Cesarean/forceps/vacuum delivery Placental abruption/placenta previa Polyhydramnios.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A G2P1L1 woman presented with placental abruption and was delivered by normal vaginal delivery. The next day, she develops petechiae, cold extremities, and her BP drops to 90/60 mmHg. Her blood reports show increased FDP, D-dimer, and decreased platelets. Which of the following is not used in the management of her condition?
Epsilon-aminocaproic acid
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Epsilon-aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid are not used in the treatment of DIC. Evaluation and management of DIC: Vigorous restoration and maintenance of circulation to treat hypotension Crystalloids and colloids to treat hypotension Whole blood and packed cells Fresh frozen plasma - contains fibrinogen, antithrombin III, factors V, XI, XII Cryoprecipitate - contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, von Willebrand’s factor, factor XIII Platelet replacement if low Identification of the cause: Abruptio placenta PPH HELLP syndrome Amniotic fluid embolis Sepsis Acute fatty liver Assess the fetal condition and plan for termination of pregnancy. Postpartum Haemorrhage
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient who has completed the 3rd stage of labor following vaginal delivery, what is the minimum amount of blood loss required for her to be diagnosed with postpartum hemorrhage?
explanation: Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) in vaginal delivery is defined as a blood loss of more than 500 ml after completion of the third stage of labour. In Caesarean section, blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract is called PPH. Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be: Minor (<1L) Major (>1L) Severe (>2L) In most cases, the magnitude of haemorrhage cannot be assessed accurately as visual estimates are unreliable. Note: as per the latest ACOG guidelines, PPH is defined as cumulative blood loss 1000 mL or bleeding associated with hypovolaemia in the first 24 hours after birth, irrespective of the route of delivery. It is added that despite the new definition, blood loss >500 mL in a vaginal delivery should raise suspicion and mandates further evaluation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. W at could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
explanation: Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara. Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site. Types of PPH: Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH. Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause. The risk factors for atonic uterus include: Primiparity or grand multiparity Previous PPH Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia Precipitate labour Prolonged labour Uterine malformations Uterine fibroid Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta Obesity Age >40 years Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: W ich of the following is the most probable cause of bleeding per vaginum occurring 24 ours after delivery?
explanation: Retained cotyledon is the most probable cause of late or secondary PPH i.e., bleeding that occurs after 24 hours of delivery. Other options are causes of early PPH. Types of PPH include: Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. The causes are: (mnemonic 4T) Tone: Atonic PPH (è0%) Trauma: Traumatic PPH Thrombin: Coagulopathy Tissue: retained products of conception Risk Factors for primary PPH: Atonic PPH: Primiparity or grand multiparity Previous PPH Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia Precipitate labour Prolonged labour Uterine malformations Uterine fibroid Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/abruptio placenta Obesity Age >40 years Traumatic PPH: Instrumental delivery Episiotomy Precipitate labour Macrosomia Coagulopathy: Sepsis IUD HELLP syndrome Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes include: Retained parts of cotyledon or membranes Endometritis Abnormal involution of placental site Secondary haemorrhage from caesarean section wound Placental polyp Infected fibroid Uterine AV fistula Puerperal uterine inversion Carcinoma cervix.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: W ich of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH?
explanation: Placenta previa does not cause secondary postpartum hemorrhage. It causes primary postpartum hemorrhage. Types of PPH: Primary/early: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Secondary/ late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes and risk factors for PPH: The image below shows the prevention and management of PPH: Primary PPH Secondary PPH Atonic PPH Traumatic PPH Coagulopath y Primiparity or grand multipa rity Instrumental deliver y Sepsis Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes Placental abnormalities like p lacenta previa/accreta/increta /percreta/abruptio placenta Precipitate labour HELLP synd rome Secondary haemorrhage fro m Caesarean section wound Overdistended uterus as in m ulti-gestational pregnancy, hy dramnios, macrosomia Macrosomia IUD Puerperal uterine inversion Induction of labour with pros taglandins or oxytocin Episiotomy Abnormal involution of place ntal site Prolonged labour Infected fibroid Precipitate labour Endometritis Previous h/o PPH Placental polyp Obesity Carcinoma of cervix Age >40 years Uterine av fistula
subject: OBGYN

question_text: W ich of the following complications during pregnancy does not increase the risk of PPH?
explanation: Oligohydramnios does not increase the risk of PPH. However, polyhydramnios can increase the risk by causing uterine atony, due to an overdistended uterus. Risk factors for primary PPH: Atonic PPH: Primiparity or grand multiparity Previous PPH Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia Precipitate labour Prolonged labour Uterine malformations Uterine fibroid Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta Obesity Age >40 years Traumatic PPH: Instrumental delivery Episiotomy Precipitate labour Macrosomia Coagulopathy: Sepsis IUD HELLP syndrome Causes of secondary PPH: Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes Endometritis Abnormal involution of placental site Secondary haemorrhage from Caesarean section wound Placental polyp Infected fibroid Uterine av fistula Puerperal uterine inversion Carcinoma cervix.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient with GDM complicating pregnancy, there was severe bleeding following the delivery of the placenta. On abdominal palpation, the fundus felt soft and later became hard on massaging. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
explanation: In the above scenario, a soft uterus that becomes hard on massaging indicates an atonic uterus. Uterine rupture is a risk factor of traumatic PPH, not atonic PPH. Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Thus, bleeding from the placental implantation site is not arrested. GDM complicating pregnancy can cause macrosomia, which is a risk factor of this condition. Risk factors for atonic PPH: Primiparity or grand multiparity Previous PPH Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia Precipitate labour Prolonged labour Uterine malformations Uterine fibroid Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta Obesity Age >40 years
subject: OBGYN

question_text: W ich of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?
options: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord
explanation: As per the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component of AMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterine atony as a part of the management of PPH. AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterotonics are the most important components in AMTSL to do so. The currently recommended components of AMTSL are as follows: Note: In the event that uterine atony is diagnosed during the assessment of uterine tone, uterine massage can be performed to control PPH. 1. Injectinguterotonicswithin1 minuteof delivery of the baby or immediately after delivery of theanterior shoulder Most importantstepOxytocin 10 IU im/iv infusion is thepre ferred uterotonic.(Not recom mendedby WHO-carboprost) 2 Delayed cord clamping Done within1-3 minsof delive ryè0 mlof additional blood g oes to the fetusPreventsfetal anemia 3 Delivery of placenta by contr olled cord traction: Modified Brandt Andrews technique The uterus is pushed upward s and backwardThe traction o f cord is downwards and forw ards 4 Intermittent assessment of ut erine tone Done every 15 mins for 2 hou rs
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with pre-eclampsia presents with profuse bleeding after delivery. Which of the following drugs can be used in the medical management of this patient?
explanation: PPH in a patient with pre-eclampsia can be treated with misoprostol. It is a PGE1 analogue used as a second line uterotonic in the treatment of PPH. The drug of choice for PPH in normal patients is oxytocin. Option A: Methergine and other ergot derivatives cause dangerous hypertension in pre-eclampsia. Options B and D: Carboprost and Dinoprost cause severe hypertension in pre-eclampsia. Medical Management of PPH: Drug Dose Side effects Contraindications Oxytocin 10-40 U in 1L crystalloid(nev er given as iv bolus) Water intoxication - Methergi ne 0.2 mg Hypertension Pre-eclampsia Carbopro st 0.25 mg (è doses max) DiarrhoeaHypertensionVomi ting Bronchial asthmaCardiac, re nal or hepatic diseases Misopros tol 600-1000 mcg FeverTachycardia -
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a case of atonic PPH, a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative was given every 15 mins as a uterotonic. What is the maximum number of times the drug can be administered?
explanation: Carboprost is a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative. The normal dosage is 0.25mg. The maximum dose is 2mg. So, 2/0.25 = è times. Carboprost is a 15-methyl PGF2 alpha derivative used as a 2nd line drug in the treatment of PPH that is unresponsive to oxytocin. Side effects: Diarrhoea Hypertension Nausea Vomiting Contraindications: Bronchial asthma Suspected amniotic fluid embolism Active cardiac, renal or hepatic diseases.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: As per 2017 WHO guidelines for the treatment of PPH, which of the following statements is true?
options: Uterine massage is not recommended in PPH when oxytocin is administered
Intravenous colloids are the recommended fluids for initial resuscitation
If the PPH is not responsive to uterotonics, uterine artery embolisation is the next step
Tranexamic acid is administered early in all cases of PPH
explanation: Early administration of tranexamic acid is done in all cases of PPH. Tranexamic acid for the treatment of PPH is used as follows: Tranexamic acid should be given in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause. Early use of iv tranexamic acid (i.e) within 3 hours of birt Fixed-dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) iv at 1 mL per minute If bleeding continues after 30 minutes, the second dose of 1 g iv is given Option A: Uterine massage must be done in addition to oxytocin in all cases of PPH. This will help in the contraction of an atonic uterus. In normal patients, uterine massage is not compulsory as per AMTSL. Option B: IV crystalloids are the recommended fluids for resuscitation. Option C: Balloon tamponade is the next step after uterotonics.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Following normal vaginal delivery, a patient developed PPH and lost about 700mL of blood. Her PR was 100 bpm and her BP was 100/60mmHg. What is the value and corresponding interpretation of her shock index?
explanation: S ock index = 1 and it indicates significant blood loss. The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP. Here, PR=100 and systolic BP=100. S ock Index = 100/100 = 1 If the shock index is 0.9 – 1.1, it indicates massive blood loss and the need for intensive resuscitation. Description Range of shock ind ex Normal value of shock index (non-pregnant) 0.5 - 0.7 Normal value of shock index in pregnant (i.e) Obstetrical s hock index 0.7 - 0.è Significant or massive blood l oss 0.9 - 1.1
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient was referred to the casualty from a district hospital with atonic PPH. Which of the following measures is least likely to be done?
options: Use non-pneumatic anti-shock garment to stabilize the patient
explanation: Using a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) is not one of the first measures for the management of atonic PPH. NASG is used to reduce bleeding and stabilize the patient for shifting to tertiary centers. The below image shows a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment. Non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) works by applying circumferential counterpressure. It decreases blood flow to the abdomen, pelvis, and lower extremities. It increases the blood flow to the heart, lungs, and brain. First step measures in the management of PPH must be done immediately and simultaneously. This includes: Continuous iv oxytocin infusion Fundal massage and bimanual uterine compression Volume resuscitation with crystalloids Insertion of Foley’s catheter to monitor urine output Alert the anesthesia team to begin a manual exploration of the uterus under GA to check for: Retained placental fragments Uterine abnormalities Lacerations Rupture Blood transfusion should be done if vitals are still unstable If bleeding still continues, further steps are taken depending on the patient profile: Balloon tamponade Surgical methods: B lynch compression sutures Uterine artery ligation Internal iliac artery ligation Angiographic embolization Hysterectomy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 35-year-old multipara with atonic PPH continues to bleed profusely despite medical management and tamponade. Which of the following methods cannot be used to reduce bleeding in this patient?
explanation: Thermal endometrial ablation is a treatment modality for Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB). It is not used in the treatment of PPH. In patients who are unresponsive to initial resuscitation and medical management, the following methods can be used: Balloon tamponade Surgical methods: B lynch compression sutures Uterine artery ligation Internal iliac artery ligation Angiographic embolization Hysterectomy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the instrument in the image given below.
explanation: The image shows a Bakri balloon. It is used in uterine tamponade in patients with atonic PPH who are unresponsive to medical management. The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine cavity. It acts by stimulating uterine contraction and direct hemostatic pressure to the open uterine sinuses (tamponade effect). The maximum capacity of the balloon is 500mL. It is inflated with normal saline (200-500mL) and can be retained for up to 12 hours. Success rates are high and it can be used to avoid hysterectomy. Other options: Sengstaken Blakemore tube, condom catheter, and 34F Foley with 60mL balloon are other instruments that can be used for uterine tamponade. The image below depicts Sengstaken Blakemore tube. The image below depicts Foley's catheter.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: W at is the capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH?
explanation: The capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH is 300 to 500 mL. Bakri balloon is used in uterine tamponade in cases of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management. Insertion of Bakri balloon requires three team members. One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure. Another member places the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilizes it. The third member instills fluid to inflate the balloon. Initially, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL of normal saline is done. It is followed by further infusion over a few minutes up to 300 to 500 mL.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A P3 woman bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate oxytocin infusion. The patient continues to bleed and the uterus fails to contract despite bimanual compression. S e becomes tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the next best step in her management?
explanation: Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management and bimanual uterine massage. Option A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealed bleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient to tertiary care centers. Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compression sutures). Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually, the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy is done sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A pregnant lady delivered her baby unattended while she was on the way to the hospital.
W ile examining her, you note a perineal tear in which the anal sphincter is disrupted. This tear is classified as .
explanation: The perineal tears in which anal sphincter is disrupted are classified as third-degree perineal tear.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify B lynch suture from the image given below.
explanation: Image 1 depicts B lynch suture. All these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose the walls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with severe PPH is shifted to the emergency OT for B lynch compression sutures. W ich of the following statements is false about this procedure?
options: The suture loops over the fundus
Uterine ischaemic necrosis is a complication
explanation: The procedure is B-lynch compression sutures and it is used in atonic PPH. B lynch suture is a technique to arrest hemorrhage in severe postpartum atony. The suture bites are taken over the lower uterine segment anteriorly. Then it is looped over the fundus to go posterior. Another bite is taken posteriorly. Then it is looped back over the fundus and taken anteriorly. The final bite is taken over the lower uterine segment and the free ends are tied in a surgical knot. The uterus is compressed antero-posteriorly. The success rate is high. Ischaemic uterine necrosis is a complication of this procedure.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: W ich of the following statements are true?
explanation: Statements 1, 2 and 3 are true. Statement 4: Hematomas <5 cm can be managed conservatively with cold compress. Larger ematomas need to be explored surgically. Statement 5: Lower uterine segment rupture causes supra-levator hematoma. Types of pelvic hematomas: Feature Infralevator hematoma Supralevator hematoma Incidence Common Rare Location Below the levator ani Above the levator ani Causes Improper hemostasis during repair of vaginal/ perineal tea rs or episiotomy wound Extension of cervical lacerati on, lower uterine segment ru pture Presentati on Severe pain with rectal tenes mus Unexplained shock with feat ures of internal haemorrhage Treatment Small hematomas can be con servatively managed with col d compress Laparotomy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient with hydramnios complicating pregnancy, the third stage of labour was managed by applying fundal pressure and controlled traction of the cord. On palpation, the uterus was still soft and boggy. Within a few minutes, there was moderate bleeding per vaginum following which a reddish-purple mass was expelled. The patient then developed hypotension, bradycardia and went into shock. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion. Hydramnios is a risk factor for uterine inversion due to uterine over-distension. Fundal pressure while the uterus is atonic (soft, relaxed, and boggy) causes uterine inversion. It results in haemorrhage followed by complete uterine inversion protruding out of the vulva. Neurogenic type of shock develops due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament and the ovaries. Option A: Amniotic fluid embolism causes cardiac arrest, acute hypoxia and severe haemorrhage. Option B: There was only moderate bleeding per vaginum and soft uterus. But since there is protrusion of the uterus per vaginum, the most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion. Option D: Placenta accreta rarely causes uterine inversion. Uterine inversion is an extremely rare but life-threatening complication in the 3rd stage of labor, in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely. Causes: Most common cause is mismanagement of 3rd stage of labour Spontaneous Placenta accreta (rarely) Features: Shock immediately after delivery The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding Shock is either neurogenic or hemorrhagic Per abdomen examination - fundus of the uterus is not palpable. Management of uterine inversion: Vaginal operatio ns Abdominal operati ons Hydrostatic meth od šustner Huntingtons O Sullivan Spinelli Haultain Oguch
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
W ich among the following is the most potent drug to control PPH?
Oxytocin
explanation: Carboprost is the most potent drug to control PPH. Though oxytocin is the most commonly used drug for the prevention and treatment of PPH, Carboprost is highly efficacious than oxytocin in treating PPH. If the question would have been "Drug of choice to treat PPH" then the answer will be Oxytocin. Initially for PPH, oxytocin or methergin (ergometrine) is given. If it fails to control the bleeding then Misoprostol is given. Drug Use in PPH Oxytocin DOC to prevent and treat PP H Methergin Drug to prevent and treat PP H Carboprost(PGF 2) Best drug to control PPH Misoprostol(PG E1) 2nd line drug to treat PPH Preterm Labor and Postterm Pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Preterm labour is defined as when the labour starts before
explanation: Preterm labour is defined as when labour starts before 37 completed weeks (<259 days) counting from the first day of the last menstrual period. Timing of deliver y Terminolog y <33 weeks Early prete rm 34 to 36 weeks Late preter m 37to 38 weeks Early term 39 to 40 weeks Full term
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for preterm labour?
explanation: Progesterone intake is not a risk factor for preterm labour. Progesterone is used for prophylaxis of preterm labour. Risk factors for preterm labour: Maternal history - Previous history of spontaneous abortion or preterm delivery Artificial reproductive technique Asymptomatic bacteriuria or recurrent UTI Smoking Maternal stress Pregnancy complications - Pre-eclampsia Antepartum haemorrhage PROM Overdistended uterus - polyhydramnios, multiple pregnancy Cervical incompetence Uterine malformations Intrauterine death Maternal chronic diseases - Hypertension Nephritis Diabetes Severe anaemia Periodontal diseases Option A: Multifetal pregnancies are common following artificial reproductive techniques and can be associated with preterm labour. Option B: Asymptomatic bacteriuria or bacterial vaginosis can cause spontaneous preterm labour. Option C: Chronic diseases like periodontal disease increase the risk of preterm labour.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Late preterm births include births between .
