explanation: Late preterm births include births between 34 to 36 weeks of gestational age. Timing of deliver y Terminolog y <33 weeks Early prete rm 34 to 36 weeks Late preter m 37 to 38 weeks Early term 39 to 40 weeks Full term
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 31-year-old G3P2 woman presents at 29 weeks of gestation with a blood-tinged vaginal discharge. She is suspected to have preterm labour. Which of the following findings will not help confirm her diagnosis?
explanation: A cervical length of 32 mm (3 cm) does not help in confirming preterm labour as it is highly unlikely when the cervical length is >3 cm. The length of the cervix in preterm labour, as measured in transvaginal ultrasound is 2.5 cm. Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). Features of preterm labor: Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, with/without pain Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge or bleeding PV Predictors of preterm labor: Clinical predictors: History of prior preterm birth Multiple pregnancies Presence of genital tract infection Symptoms of preterm labour Biophysical predictors: Uterine contractions 4/hour Bishop score 4 Cervical length (TVS) 25 mm Biochemical predictors: Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervical/vaginal discharge >50 ng/mL Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alpha The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on TVS.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following cannot be used to predict preterm labour in a patient having irregular uterine contractions at 30 weeks of gestation?
explanation: IL-2 is not a biochemical predictor of preterm labour. Biochemical predictors of preterm labor: Fetal fibronectin IL 6 IL 8 TNF Investigations of preterm labour: Fetal fibronectin >50 ng/ml TVS - length of cervix 2.5 cm Urine culture High vaginal swab Maternal salivary estriol Uterine activity monitoring
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old G2P1L0 woman came for a routine antenatal checkup at 20 weeks of gestation. She is worried about preterm labour as her previous baby was born preterm. What will be the timing and cut-off limit for fetal fibronectin (fFN) assay to predict this condition?
explanation: Fetal fibronectin value of >50 ng/mL in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 and 34 weeks is predictive of preterm labor. Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua. It is normally found in the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and after 37 weeks of gestation. It is measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. When the test is negative, it reassures that the delivery will not occur within the next 7 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman presented with blood-tinged vaginal discharge at 35 weeks of gestation. A nitrazine paper test was performed on her. What is this test used to detect?
options: Fetal blood cells in Rh isoimmunisation
explanation: The nitrazine paper test is used to detect premature rupture of membranes. The nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH >6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of 4.5 - 6.0. False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, and bacterial infections. The below image shows the nitrazine paper. Option A: Fetal hemoglobin in vasa previa is detected by Apt test. Option B: Estimation of the volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation in Rh isoimmunisation is done by Kleihauer-Betke test. Option D: In abruptio placenta, the diagnosis is mainly based on clinical features.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sample of the vaginal fluid from the posterior fornix of a patient gave a positive nitrazine paper test. Which of the following conditions does not give a false positive result?
explanation: Oligohydramnios shows a false negative nitrazine paper test. Nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH >6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of 4.5 - 6.0. False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, and bacterial infections. False-negative nitrazine test can be seen in the case of scanty amniotic fluid.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Transvaginal sonography in a case of clinically suspected preterm labour revealed a short cervix and funnelling of the internal os. What is the shape of the cervix that is likely to be seen here?
explanation: U-shaped cervix is seen on tranvaginal sonography (TVS) in preterm labour. On TVS, the cervix should be assessed to determine whether funnelling (internal os width >5 mm) is present. The following is a TVS image showing a V-shaped cervix: Shape of cervi x Inference T shaped Normal Shape of cervi Inference x Shape of cervi Inference x Y shaped Suspicion of preterm labour V shaped Funneling of internal os U shaped Incompetent osPreterm labo ur
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multigravida presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes. According to RCOG guidelines, which of the following antibiotics is preferred for her?
explanation: According to RCOG guidelines, erythromycin is the preferred antibiotic in the case of PPROM (preterm premature rupture of membranes). Spontaneous rupture of membranes before the onset of labour between 28 to 37 weeks is called preterm premature rupture of membranes. If PPROM occurs between 28 to 34 weeks, prophylactic antibiotics and corticosteroids are given to the patient.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation presents with labour pains but her membranes were intact. You decide to start her on corticosteroids and a tocolytic. Which of the following drugs will not be useful in this case?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of preterm labour with intact membranes and progesterone is not used as a tocolytic in these cases. Progesterone can be used for the prophylaxis of preterm labour in women with a previous history of spontaneous preterm labour. Glucocorticoid therapy is given in preterm labour when the period of gestation is <34 weeks to hasten fetal lung maturity. Short term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). Tocolytics that can be given as short term therapy include: Terbutaline Magnesium sulphate Indomethacin Nifedipine Atosiban
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour. Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
explanation: Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects. According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestation but may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3 days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects: Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects Beta-adrenergic agonists:Rito drineTerbutalineIsoxsuprine Headache, palpitations, tachy cardia, hypotension, pulmon ary edema, cardiac failure, A RDS Fetal heart failure, intrauteri ne deathNeonatal hypoglyce mia, intraventricular haemor rhage Calcium channel blockers:Nif edipineNicardipineVerapamil Hypotension, headache, flush ing, nausea - Oxytocin antagonists:Atosiba n(not approved for use in Ind ia) Nausea, vomiting, chest pain - Magnesium sulphate Flushing, perspiration, heada che, muscle weakness, respir atory paralysis Neonatal cardiac arrest, letha rgy, hypotonia, respiratory d epression COX inhibitors:Indomethaci nSulindac Heartburn, asthma, GI bleedi ng, thrombocytopenia, renal i njury, platelet dysfunction, ol igohydramnios Constriction of ductus arterio sus, pulmonary hypertension, intrauterine growth restricti on
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for tocolysis in a patient with preterm labour?
explanation: Placenta previa is not a contraindication for tocolysis. In placenta previa, nifedipine and magnesium sulphate are used as tocolytics. Contraindications to tocolysis: Chorioamnionitis Preeclampsia/Eclampsia Advanced labour Fetal distress Intra-uterine death Congenital anomalies not compatible with life Pregnancy >34 weeks Abruptio placenta
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G3P1A1 woman presents with preterm labour at 27 weeks of gestation. She tells you that her previous child who was born preterm developed cerebral palsy. Which of the following drugs can you use to reduce the incidence of this condition?
explanation: Magnesium sulphate has a neuroprotective effect and hence decreases the risk of developing cerebral palsy. Magnesium sulphate can be used for neuroprotection in preterm labour when the pregnancy is <32 weeks. The dose is 4 g IV over 20 mins followed by an infusion of 1 g/hr.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A primigravida was administered tocolytics and corticosteroids for preterm labour. The following day, she suddenly started coughing and gasping for air. On examination, her BP
was 160/100 mmHg and SpO2 was 80% in room air. Which of the following drugs could have caused this?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pulmonary edema which is a side effect of the tocolytic ritodrine. Acute pulmonary edema in pregnancy can be due to: Non-cardiogenic causes - Pre-eclampsia Acute haemorrhage Sepsis Tocolysis with ritodrine and magnesium sulphate Vigorous IV fluid therapy Cardiogenic causes Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects: Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects Beta-adrenergic agonists:Rito drineTerbutalineIsoxsuprine Headache, palpitations, tachy cardia, hypotension, pulmon ary edema, cardiac failure, A RDS Fetal heart failure, intrauteri ne deathNeonatal hypoglyce mia, intraventricular haemor rhage Calcium channel blockers:Nif edipineNicardipineVerapamil Hypotension, headache, flush ing, nausea - Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects Oxytocin antagonists:Atosiba n(not approved for use in Ind ia) Nausea, vomiting, chest pain - Magnesium sulphate Flushing, perspiration, heada che, muscle weakness, respir atory paralysis Neonatal cardiac arrest, letha rgy, hypotonia, respiratory d epression COX inhibitors:Indomethaci nSulindac Heartburn, asthma, GI bleedi ng, thrombocytopenia, renal i njury, platelet dysfunction, ol igohydramnios Constriction of ductus arterio sus, pulmonary hypertension, intrauterine growth retardati on
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following tocolytics can cause multiple fractures in the fetus if given for a prolonged duration?
explanation: Magnesium sulphate can cause multiple fractures and hypocalcemia in a preterm baby. The FDA warned against prolonged use of magnesium sulphate to arrest preterm labour. The antagonistic effect of magnesium lowers the calcium levels in the fetus. This causes bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed to the drug for more than 5 to 7 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Post-term pregnancy refers to pregnancy continuing beyond .
explanation: ACOG defines post-term pregnancy as a pregnancy continuing beyond 42 completed weeks of gestation. For clinical purposes, a pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery (> 294 days) is called a post-term pregnancy. Inaccurate LMP is the most common cause of misdiagnosis of post-term pregnancy. Hence, early ultrasound dating is important to determine fetal gestational age.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman presented for an antenatal checkup 2 weeks past her EDD. Which of the following is not an etiological factor for her condition?
explanation: Maternal stress is associated with preterm labour, not post-term pregnancy. Etiological factors of post-term pregnancy are: Inaccurate LMP Heredity Primiparity Previous prolonged pregnancy Sedentary habits Elderly multipara Anencephaly Placental sulphatase deficiency
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You have performed an artificial rupture of membranes in a primigravida for augmentation of labour. You note the amniotic fluid to be saffron-coloured. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Saffron-coloured amniotic fluid is seen in postmaturity.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A newborn baby was found to have wrinkled, patchy skin, a long thin body and long nails. Which of the following could be a cause for his condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of postmaturity syndrome which can occur due to placental sulphatase deficiency. Etiology of post-term pregnancy: Wrong dates - inaccurate LMP (most common) Heredity Previous prolonged pregnancy Anencephaly Placental sulphatase deficiency (leads to decreased estrogen synthesis) Primipara/ elderly multipara Features of postmaturity syndrome in a newborn: Wrinkled, patchy, peeling skin, particularly prominent on the palms and soles Long, thin body suggesting wasting Long nails Eyes open and unusually alert Looks old and worried Note: Placental aromatase deficiency causes disorder of sexual development of fetus.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1L1 woman came for a routine ANC at 41 weeks of gestation. On examination, her Bishop score was 2. She was admitted for fetal monitoring and induction. Which of the following complications would you not anticipate in the fetus even if her pregnancy continues further?
explanation: In the given scenario, the pregnancy continuing further would cross 42 weeks of gestation and thus turn into a post-term pregnancy. Hypoglycemia is seen in a post-term neonate. Complications of post-term pregnancy: During labour: Fetal hypoxia Labour dysfunction Macrosomia Shoulder dystocia Oligohydramnios Cord compression Birth trauma Meconium aspiration Intracranial haemorrhage Following birth: Meconium aspiration syndrome Hypoxia Hypoglycemia Polycythemia Neonatal convulsions
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida was admitted at 42 weeks for induction of labour. Which of the following conditions is she not at an increased risk for?
explanation: The risk of post-partum haemorrhage does not increase in post-term pregnancy. Complications of post-term pregnancy are due to placental insufficiency and placental ageing. It manifests as placental infarcts and calcifications. During post-term pregnancy, diminished placental function can cause oligohydramnios. Complications of post-term pregnancy are: During labour: Fetal hypoxia Labour dysfunction Macrosomia Shoulder dystocia Oligohydramnios Cord compression Birth trauma Meconium aspiration Following birth: Chemical pneumonitis, atelectasis, pulmonary hypertension (due to meconium aspiration) Hypoxia Hypoglycemia Polycythemia Neonatal convulsions
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The term small for gestational age implies birth weight
explanation: Small for gestational age implies birthweight is <10th percentile for gestational age. With respect to the size, a newborn can be appropriate, small or large for gestational age. Birth weight Terminology <10th percentile Small for gestational age >90th percentile Large for gestational age Between 10th and 90th perce ntile Appropriate for gestational a ge
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
What is the normal pH of amniotic fluid?
8.1 - 8.7
explanation: The normal pH of the amniotic fluid is 7.1 - 7.3 The normal pH of the vaginal secretions is 4.5 - 5.5. In premature rupture of membranes (PROM), the pH of the vaginal secretions becomes 6 - 6.2 as the amniotic fluid mixes with it. This forms the basis for nitrazine paper test. Gestational Trophoblastic Diseases
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole?
explanation: Partial hydatidiform mole has a 69XXY or 69XYY karyotype. Hydatiform mole belongs to the benign group of gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD). It is an abnormality in chorionic villi making them partly proliferative and degenerative, thereby resulting in the formation of multiple small cysts. Based on the portion of the chorionic villi involved, they could be complete (diffused) or partial (focal)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding hydatidiform moles?
options: Complete moles show diffuse trophoblastic hyperplasia
Fetal tissue is seen in partial mole
Early USG is sensitive for partial moles
Complete moles have higher malignant potential
explanation: Early ultrasonography is not highly sensitive in a patient with partial molar pregnancy. However, USG features like thickened, multicystic placenta along with fetal tissue or even a fetus may be seen. Hydatidiform mole or molar pregnancy is an abnormal condition of the placenta. It is characterized by trophoblastic proliferation and stromal edema. They are classified into complete and partial moles based on the absence or presence of embryonic elements. Pathogenesis of complete and partial moles are as follows:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not associated with the development of a hydatidiform mole?
explanation: Vitamin A deficiency, not Vitamin C deficiency is a risk factor for hydatidiform mole. Risk factors for hydatidiform mole are: Maternal age - pregnancy in teenage and women >35 years Previous history of gestational trophoblastic disease Dietary deficiency - vitamin A deficiency, inadequate protein and animal fat intake AB blood group.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 20-year-old primigravida with bleeding PV was diagnosed to have a complete hydatidiform mole. Which of the following is not true in this condition?
options: Serum free T4 levels normalise after uterine evacuation
explanation: Theca lutein cysts are rare in partial molar pregnancy, but may be seen in 25-30% of patients with complete molar pregnancy. Serum -hCG levels are elevated more than expected for gestational age in a complete mole. The sensitivity of most hCG tests is set to the pregnancy hCG range. An excessive -hCG hormone causes an oversaturation of the test assay giving a false negative UPT. This is called the hook effect. The thyrotropin-like effects of hCG frequently cause serum free-T4 levels to be elevated which normalize after uterine evacuation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents with spotting PV, hyperemesis, and lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. USG done is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and USG showing snowstorm appearance is suggestive of a complete mole. The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces. Fetus and amniotic sac are absent. Investigations for molar pregnancy are: USG - shows snowstorm appearance Serum  hCG - elevated to >2 MoM (multiples of median) for corresponding gestational age Histological examination of products of conception Snowstorms in radiology: Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound) Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound) Carcinoma thyroid - pulmonary metastases (chest X-ray).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of the expulsion of grape-like vesicles PV for the past day. A diagnosis of molar pregnancy was made on USG examination. Incidentally, the following adnexal lesion was also noted. What is the lesion?
explanation: The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. These cysts are usually seen in patients with complete molar pregnancies. They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple pregnancies. Theca lutein cysts result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of  hCG. The cystic fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin, estrogen, and progesterone.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient who was treated for molar pregnancy came for follow-up after 4 months. Her USG revealed a large, twisted theca lutein cyst. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: Untwisting of the cyst is the only management in an asymptomatic patient with a twisted theca lutein cyst. Laparoscopic oophorectomy is done only when there is associated extensive necrosis or hemorrhage. Theca-lutein cysts regress within 2 months after pregnancy evacuation, and hence expectant management is preferred in uncomplicated cases. If the cysts are symptomatic, they can be aspirated trans-abdominally under ultrasound guidance.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman at 14 weeks of gestation complains of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal bleeding for 2 weeks. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks and fetal heart sounds are absent. USG shows a snowstorm appearance and no fetus. What is the best step of management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy which is managed by suction and evacuation, regardless of uterine size. If the cervix is unfavorable, slow dilatation is done with vaginal PGE1. Volume resuscitation with IV fluids and parenteral antibiotics can be given as supportive therapy. Blood transfusion is done if the patient is anaemic. Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied. Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy: Women who have completed their family Age >40 years Uncontrolled hemorrhage Perforation during surgical evacuation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 36-year-old woman underwent suction evacuation for a hydatidiform mole. Which of the following statements is true regarding her follow-up with -hCG estimation?
options: Twice weekly estimation for a month following evacuation
Monthly follow-up for 6 months after three consecutive normal values
After 6 months of follow-up, regular yearly estimation should be done
explanation: In the given scenario, the patient is followed up with serum  hCG every month for 6 months. Follow-up after the termination of molar pregnancy is done with serum  hCG levels. During the follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the  hCG levels. The initial -hCG level is obtained within 48 hours after evacuation and used as a baseline. It is measured weekly till it becomes negative, and three consecutive normal values are obtained. This normally happens in 4-8 weeks. After this,  hCG levels are measured monthly for 6 months. Women who undergo chemotherapy must be followed up for 1 year.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following are complications that can be seen in a patient with molar pregnancy?
explanation: Thyrotoxicosis is seen as a complication of molar pregnancy, not hypothyroidism. Complications in molar pregnancy include: Immediate: Early-onset pre-eclampsia - molar placentas produce more antiangiogenic proteins than normal placentas. Thyrotoxicosis - as  component of hCG mimics TSH and causes thyroid storm Acute pulmonary insufficiency - due to embolization of trophoblastic cells Electrolyte imbalance i.e., hypokalemia, hyponatremia - due to hyperemesis caused by  hCG Shock - hemorrhage due to the separation of vesicles and intra-peritoneal haemorrhage Disseminated intravascular coagulation Late: Choriocarcinoma.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include
explanation: A partial mole is not a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm (GTN). Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is the term used to describe a group of tumors due to abnormal trophoblast proliferation. Malignant forms of GTD are termed gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Modified WHO Classification of GTD Molar Pregnancies Trophoblastic tumors Hydatidiform mole (benign) - PartialandCompleteInvasive mole (malignant) Choriocarcinoma (malignant) Placental site trophoblastic t umor (malignant)Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (maligna nt)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: All of the following are non-molar trophoblastic neoplasms except .
explanation: Invasive mole is a molar trophoblastic neoplasm.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common non-metastatic gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that develops following hydatidiform mole?
explanation: Chorioadenoma destruens or invasive mole is the most common non-metastatic GTN that follows hydatidiform moles. Almost all invasive moles arise from partial or complete moles. Invasive mole is characterized by extensive tissue invasion by trophoblast and whole villi. They can penetrate deep into the myometrium, peritoneum, parametrium, or vaginal vault. They are locally aggressive and do not usually metastasize. The most common GTN following term pregnancy or miscarriage is choriocarcinoma.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following are risk factors for malignant change in a patient with molar pregnancy?
explanation: Maternal age >40 years, -hCG levels >100,000 mIU/mL and grand multiparity are risk factors for malignant change in a patient with molar pregnancy. Risk factors for malignant change are: Patient's age  40 years or <20 years Parity 3 Uterine size >20 weeks Previous history of molar pregnancy Complete moles have 15-20% risk of malignant transformation, partial moles have 1-5% risk Serum  hCG >1,00,000 mIU/mL Large theca lutein cysts >6 cm in diamete Post-evacuation uterine sonographic surveillance can be used as a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. Findings indicative of malignant transformation are: Suburethral nodules Myometrial nodules Hypervascularity.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except:
options: Increased number of theca lutein cysts
explanation: Increased number of theca lutein cysts is not an indicator of choriocarcinoma. Increased size or persistence of theca lutein cysts indicates choriocarcinoma. Plateau of high serum -hCG level for four measurements for 3 weeks is an indicator of choriocarcinoma. Risk factors for malignant change are: Molar pregnancy - complete moles have 15-20% risk, partial moles have 1-5% risk Patient's age  40 years or <20 years Parity 3 Serum  hCG >1,00,000 IU/mL Uterine size >20 weeks Previous history of molar pregnancy Large theca lutein cysts >6 cm in diamete Post-evacuation uterine sonographic surveillance can be used as a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. Findings indicative of malignant transformation are: Suburethral nodules Myometrial nodules Hypervascularity.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with a history of molar pregnancy was treated with suction and evacuation. Which method of contraception would you not recommend for her?
explanation: IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) is contraindicated in this patient as the uterus is friable and can cause further bleeding. Accepted methods of contraception after suction evacuation in molar pregnancy include: Oral contraceptive pills Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate Barrier methods.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What will be the WHO score in a patient with low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia?
explanation: Low-risk GTN has a WHO score of 0 to 6. High-risk GTN has a WHO score of  7. Features Low risk High risk Total score 0-6 7 Age 39 years 40 years hCG 105IU/L 105IU/L Features Low risk High risk Features Low risk High risk Features Low risk High risk Type of antecedent pregnanc y Molar pregnancy Full term pregnancy Duration of antecedent pregn ancy <4 months >12 months Metastasis site Lungs, vagina Brain, liver Number of metastases <4 >8 Size of the tumor <3 cm >5 cm Antecedent chemotherapy Single-agent chemothera py Multiple-agent chemothera py
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient was diagnosed to have choriocarcinoma two years post-evacuation of molar pregnancy. Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis in this patient?
explanation: The common sites of metastases of choriocarcinoma are in the following order: Lungs - most common Vagina - second most common Vulva •idneys Live Ovaries Brain Bowel Lung metastases present as cannon-ball or snowstorm appearance on chest X-ray. Vaginal metastases present as purplish sub-urethral nodules.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is considered as stage .
explanation: Metastases in the lungs are considered stage III GTN (gestational trophoblastic neoplasia) in FIGO classification. International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) staging for GTN is as follows: The chest X-ray below shows lung metastasis - stage III GTN. Stag e Description I GTN confined to theuterus Stag Description e Stag Description e II GTN extends outside of the u terus but is limited to thegeni talstructures(adnexa, vagina, broad ligament) III GTN extends to thelungs, wit h or without known genital tr act involvement IV Allothermetastatic sites i.e. ki dney, liver, brain, bowel, etc. Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated -hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN: Persistence of -hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longe Rise in -hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longe Elevated -hCG level for 6 months or more Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma Treatment for low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 43-year-old woman presents with complaints of hemoptysis, vaginal bleeding, and abdominal pain for 7 days. Chest X-ray is shown below. Transabdominal USG revealed a solid mass occupying the uterus which was found to be choriocarcinoma with a WHO score of 8.
How would you manage this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of high-risk (WHO) stage III choriocarcinoma which is treated with EMA-CO regimen. The given X-ray shows numerous, dense, bilateral metastatic nodules, of varying sizes indicative of lung metastases. The components of EMA-CO are: Etoposide Methotrexate Actinomycin D Cyclophosphamide Oncovin i.e. vincristine Option A: PSTT (placental-site trophoblastic tumor) and ETT (epithelioid trophoblastic tumors) are treated by hysterectomy only, as they are resistant to chemotherapy. Option B: R-CHOP regimen is used for B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Option D: MVAC regimen is used for advanced bladder carcinoma. Risk Criteria Treatment Low FIGO stage I GTNFIGO Stag e II or III GTN with a WHO r isk score<6 Single agent chemotherapy w ith Methotrextate or Actinom ycin D. High Stages II and III with WHO isk score>7Stage IV disease EMA-CO regimen
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from .
explanation: Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from implantation site intermediate trophoblast. As syncytiotrophoblastic cells are generally absent in this site, it is composed mainly of cytotrophoblastic cells. Patients with placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly elevated serum -hCG levels. Local invasion into the myometrium and lymphatics occurs. Hysterectomy is the preferred treatment.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 26-year-old woman with a history of early miscarriage presented with amenorrhoea. Her serum beta hCG levels were persistently low and USG revealed a single solid mass in the uterine fundus. Histopathological examination of the biopsy showed abundant intermediate trophoblastic cells. What is the next step of management?
Methotrexate
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placental-site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT). Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice because they are locally invasive tumors and resistant to chemotherapy. PSTT is a rare tumor arising from intermediate trophoblastic of the placental bed. Patients with placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly elevated serum -hCG levels. They produce variant forms of hCG. Anemia in Pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with complaints of dizziness. On examination, pallor was present. She will be considered severely anemic if her hemoglobin is less than
.
explanation: Severe anemia is defined as Hb < 7 g/dL. Anemia in pregnancy is said to occur when Hb level is <11 g/dL. It is classified as shown below: Hemoglobin values (g/d L) WHO classification of anemi a in pregnancy ICMR classification of anemi a in pregnancy 11 NormalIn thesecond trimeste r, Hb10.5g/dL is considered normal Normal 10-10.9 Mild Mild 7-9.9 Moderate Moderate <7 Severe Severe Hemoglobin values (g/d WHO classification of anemi ICMR classification of anemi L) a in pregnancy a in pregnancy Hemoglobin values (g/d WHO classification of anemi ICMR classification of anemi L) a in pregnancy a in pregnancy Hemoglobin values (g/d WHO classification of anemi ICMR classification of anemi L) a in pregnancy a in pregnancy <4 - Very severe
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the second most common pathological cause of anemia in pregnancy?
explanation: The second most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is anemia associated with chronic disease. The most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is iron deficiency anemia. Women with chronic disorders may develop anemia for the first time during pregnancy. Causes include: Chronic renal insufficiency - the most common cause. Recombinant erythropoietin is used for treating anemia due to chronic renal failure. Inflammatory bowel disease Connective tissue disorders Granulomatous infections Malignant neoplasms Rheumatoid arthritis Chronic suppurative conditions. Note: The most common cause of anemia in pregnancy is physiological. It is normally seen during pregnancy. This occurs due to the expansion of plasma volume by 30–40%. This increase is much more than the increase in red cell mass (20-30%) during pregnancy. This leads to hemodilution and an apparent decrease in hemoglobin levels.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the average maternal requirement of iron during a singleton pregnancy?
explanation: Maternal requirement of iron during a singleton gestation averages close to 1000 mg. The average iron stores in a non-pregnant female is around 300 mg. This falls short of the requirement of iron during pregnancy which is 1000 mg. Hence iron supplementation is necessary to prevent iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy. This also forms the basis for prophylactic iron supplementation during pregnancy. Note: The Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (FOGSI) states that the iron requirement in pregnancy is 840 mg, as about 160 mg of iron is saved due to amenorrhea during pregnancy. Iron requirement during pre gnancy Fetus and placenta 300 mg Iron requirement during pre gnancy Iron requirement during pre gnancy Expansion of maternal hemo globin mass 500 mg Losses through normal excret ion routes 200 mg Total 1000 mg
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
You initiate iron and folic acid supplements for a woman at 13 weeks of gestation. According to the ministry of health & family welfare (MoHFW), what is the minimum duration for
which she should take these supplements?
explanation: The guideline recommends 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 g of folic acid daily for at least 180 days, starting from the 4th month of pregnancy, and to be continued throughout pregnancy. Ideally, this must be continued until 180 days postpartum.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the correctly matched dose for folic acid supplementation that should be given in pregnant women with the following conditions?
options: Previous child with neural tube defect - 1 mg
explanation: The amount of folic acid to be given to pregnant women suffering from sickle cell anemia is 5 mg. This is to reduce the risk of neural tube defects and to compensate for the increased demand for folate during pregnancy. Normally in all sickle cell patients (irrespective of age or sex), 1mg of folic acid is given to prevent folate deficiency. Note: William's Obstetrics 26th Edition mentions folic acid 4 mg daily for pregnant women with sickle cell disease. However various other sources and RCOG guidelines mention it as 5 mg daily. Hence this is the best answer.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestation presented with insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving her legs. Blood tests revealed a Hb value of 10.1 g/dl. Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator for her underlying condition?
explanation: In the given scenario, history suggestive of restless leg syndrome and Hb of 10.1g/dL points to a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Serum ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women. This is because its concentrations are not affected by the recent intake of iron-rich foods. Serum ferritin concentration <15 g/L indicates iron deficiency anemia. However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls <30 g/L, as this indicates early iron depletion. Restless leg syndrome also called Willis-Ekbom Disease, causes unpleasant or uncomfortable sensations in the legs along with an irresistible urge to move them. It may be associated with iron deficiency anemia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant teacher presented with complaints of difficulty concentrating at work. Investigations revealed normal MCV with blood picture as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario presence of microcytic hypochromic RBCs indicates iron deficiency anemia, and hyper segmented neutrophils indicate anemia due to folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency. This is also known as dimorphic anemia. Blood picture in iron deficiency anemia: Microcytic hypochromic RBCs Typical photo pencil cells Presence of poikilocytes (pre-erythrocytes) Blood picture in folic acid/vitamin B12 deficiency anemia: Hyper segmented neutrophils - earliest change Macrocytic RBCs
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman at 36 weeks of gestation was brought to the clinic by her concerned husband. He mentioned that over the last few weeks he noticed her chewing on cardboard pieces and ice cream sticks on multiple occasions. On examination, pallor was present and Hb was 8.6 g/dl. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of pica associated with moderate iron-deficiency anemia. Since the anemia was diagnosed late in pregnancy, the most appropriate treatment is parenteral iron therapy. Ferrous sucrose is a form of parenteral iron given as an IV infusion. If anemia is diagnosed: In the first trimester - Oral iron therapy is preferred In the second trimester - Oral iron therapy should be switched over to parenteral iron if Hb falls <8g/dl or if serum ferritin is <15ng/ml In the third trimester - Parenteral iron therapy is preferred Ferrous sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion. It is safe and does not require a test dose. Other iron preparations include: Oral preparations- Ferrous sulfate, ferrous gluconate, ferrous ascorbate IM preparations- Iron sorbitol, Iron polymaltose IV preparations- Ferric carboxymaltose Both IM and IV- Iron dextran.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the most effective parenteral iron preparation prescribed for postpartum women with iron deficiency anemia?
explanation: Ferric carboxymaltose is considered superior to all other parenteral iron supplementation especially for iron deficiency anemia in postpartum women. Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) is a dextran-free IV iron preparation. It allows rapid administration of high doses of iron (up to 1000 mg iron in 15 min). It is safe and effective in improving the mean Hb level. It avoids the need for blood transfusions.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You have been asked to start parenteral iron infusion for a woman at 38 weeks of gestation. What formula would you use to calculate the required dosage?
explanation: The formula for calculating dose of parenteral iron is: Total dose in mg = 2.4 š (Target Hb - Actual Hb) š Body Wt. + 500 mg 2.4 - conversion factor Target Hb - Hb you want to achieve Actual Hb- level of current Hb 500 mg - additional amount to replenish the iron stores Iron sucrose must be diluted only using normal saline at a concentration of 1-2 mg of iron/mL of saline. It is given over 20-30 minutes intravenously.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding parenteral iron therapy for iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women?
options: Can be given in first trimester
Sensitivity test is mandatory before administration
Can be given alongside oral iron therapy
explanation: Parenteral iron therapy for iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is avoided if the patient has a history of chronic liver disease. It is used as an alternative therapy in people who cannot tolerate oral iron. Contraindications include: A history of prior anaphylactic reaction to parenteral iron therapy First trimester of pregnancy - there is no evidence on the use of IV iron in the first trimester of pregnancy Chronic liver disease Active infection (acute or chronic) A sensitivity test prior to the infusion is not mandatory. IV iron should be given with caution even if previous administrations have been well tolerated. Oral iron should be stopped at least 24 hours prior to therapy to avoid iron toxicity.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G3P2 female patient who is an agricultural laborer presents with complaints of fatigue at 36 weeks of gestation. On examination, pallor and mild pedal edema are present. Her hemoglobin is 6.7 g/dl. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: The treatment of choice for severe anemia (< 7g/dL) in the third trimester is packed cell transfusion. It is preferred over whole blood as it avoids volume overload. Indications of blood transfusion in pregnancy include: Pregnancy <34 weeks Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure Pregnancy >34 weeks - Hb <7 g/dL.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A pregnant woman was brought by her husband after fainting at home. He gave a history of her being clumsy and forgetful over the last few weeks. Investigations revealed high MCV
with hypersegmented neutrophils. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: The given scenario points to vitamin B12 deficiency. It is treated by vitamin B12 injections with folic acid supplementation. 1000 g of IM cyanocobalamin should be given initially every week for 6 weeks, following which it should be given once every month. Megaloblastic anemia caused by Vit B12 deficiency should be identified and treated accordingly because folic acid supplementation alone will not help. Causes of Vit B12 deficiency leading to anemia in pregnancy: Gastric resection Addisonian pernicious anemia Crohn’s disease Ileal resection Bacterial overgrowth in the small bowel.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An anxious primigravida with sickle cell trait comes to you for her first antenatal checkup. Which of the following is she at a higher risk of developing during the course of this pregnancy?
explanation: Among the given options, patients with sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing urinary tract infections. Sickle cell disease, on the other hand, is associated with increased risk of : Miscarriages Fetal growth restriction Preterm labor Venous thromboembolism Pre-eclampsia Placental abruption Fetal distress in labor Note: Sickle cell trait is a benign condition in which the affected person has only one abnormal hemoglobin beta gene allele whereas, in sickle cell disease, the affected person has two abnormal hemoglobin beta gene alleles and is hence severely symptomatic. Unlike individuals with sickle cell disease, those with sickle cell trait do not have symptoms related to sickling and mostly lead a normal life.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sexually active woman with sickle cell anemia comes to the clinic for advice regarding contraception. Which of the following is the ideal contraceptive for this patient?
explanation: Low-dose oral progestins or progesterone injections or implants are ideal contraceptives in a patient with sickle cell anemia. Progesterone has been known to prevent painful sickle cell crises. It is considered very safe in pregnancy. It is rated level 1 indicating that there is no restriction in their use. Contraceptive methods and their safety profile in sickle cell anemia: Level 1 contraceptives (no restriction): Progestogen-only injection (DMPA) Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena) Emergency contraception containing progestins Level 2 contraceptives (advantages outweigh disadvantages): Combined oral contraceptive Copper intrauterine device.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A pregnant woman with thalassemia major presents to the clinic at 24 weeks of gestation with fatigue and shortness of breath. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of this condition?
Parenteral iron therapy is the treatment of choice
options: Breast feeding is safe after delivery
Repeated transfusions are necessary to maintain Hb levels above 10 g/dl
explanation: In thalassemia major, both oral and parenteral iron preparations are avoided. This is because these patients are already in a state of iron overload due to multiple blood transfusions. Pregnancy in patients with thalassemia major is very rare. In case pregnancy occurs the following strategies are adopted: Iron chelating agents should be stopped 5mg folic acid supplementation should be given daily Pneumococcal vaccination and boosters are advised prior to pregnancy Repeated blood transfusions are given to maintain Hb levels above 10 g/dL Breastfeeding is safe and iron chelation therapy can be resumed post-delivery. Hypertensive Disorders in Pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Gestational hypertension is defined as:
explanation: Gestational hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 after 20 weeks of gestation. Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least a 4-hour interval. Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia. Pre-eclampsia is hypertension with any of the following features: Proteinuria Thrombocytopenia Renal insufficiency Liver involvement Cerebral symptoms Pulmonary edema. Note: A normotensive pregnant woman may have an acute increase in BP from baseline levels and develop eclamptic seizures/HELLP syndrome, despite being normotensive. This condition is known as delta hypertension. Gestational hypertensio n Pre-eclampsia Chronic hypertension in p regnancy Rise in BP After 20 weeks of pregn ancy After 20 weeks of pregnan cy Before 20 weeks of gestati on Proteinuria Absent May be present:>300 mg i n 24 hrs urine>30 mg/dl i n a random urine sample ’rine dipstick 2+ Absent Fall in BP to normal lev els Within 12 weeks of deliv ery Within 12 weeks of deliver y Does not return to normal
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the minimum cut-off for defining proteinuria in a random urine sample?
explanation: The cut-off for defining proteinuria is 30 mg/dl (0.3 g/L) in a random urine sample. Proteinuria in preeclampsia is also defined by: 0.3 g protein in a 24-hour urine specimen. Random urine protein: creatinine ratio (PCR) 0.3 mg protein/mg creatinine Protein 1+ on urine dipstick A urine dipstick is used only if the above quantitative methods are not available. Note: Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a normal pregnancy, when does the remodeling of spiral arteries begin?
explanation: In a normal pregnancy, the remodeling of spiral arteries begins at 12 weeks. Remodeling of arteries includes invasion of arteries by trophoblasts that convert them from low-flow, high-resistance to high-flow, low-resistance vessels. These modified vessels are more capable of meeting the demands of the developing fetus. ’teroplacental vessel development takes place in two stages: The first stage occurs before 12 weeks post-fertilization. During this stage, invasion of spiral arteries up to myometrium occurs. The second stage occurs between 12-16 weeks. It involves invasion of the endovascular trophoblasts into the intra-myometrial segments of spiral arteries. Interstitial trophoblasts surround the arteries. Incomplete trophoblastic invasion leads to pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) where the vessels remain in a state of high resistance leading to placental ischemia and release of inflammatory mediators and vasoactive substances leading to endothelial injury. As the second stage of invasion occurs by 18 weeks, PIH develops after 20 weeks of pregnancy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 28-year-old G2P1 patient at 17 weeks of gestation comes for a routine antenatal visit. Her blood pressure is 142/94 mm of Hg. A repeat blood pressure after 4 hours is measured to be 148/92 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the above scenario of hypertension in a patient with gestational age <20 weeks, the diagnosis is chronic hypertension. Chronic hypertension is diagnosed when the patient is a known hypertensive (or) BP > 140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation. Gestational hypertension and preeclampsia are only diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following does not put a patient at an increased risk for preeclampsia?
explanation: Smoking is not a risk factor for pre-eclampsia rather it is protective. Although smoking during pregnancy causes various adverse pregnancy outcomes, it is associated with a reduced risk for hypertension in pregnancy. Risk factors for pre-eclampsia are: Previous history of pre-eclampsia Primigravida: young or elderly Family history: Hypertension, pre-eclampsia. Placental abnormalities: Hyperplacentosis: excessive exposure to chorionic villi (molar pregnancy, twins, diabetes) Placental ischemia Thrombophilias: APLA, Protein C, Protein S deficiency, Factor V laden mutation, homocysteinemia Twin pregnancy Molar pregnancy Rh-negative pregnancy New paternity - A new partner for subsequent pregnancies
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following does not occur in patients developing pre-eclampsia?
options: Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels
Maladaptive immunological tolerance to fetal antigens
Maladaptation to cardiovascular changes of normal pregnancy
Increased placental perfusion due to inflammation
explanation: Placental perfusion is reduced in patients developing pre-eclampsia. The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by: Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels, leading to decreased placental perfusion. Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading to immunological maladaptation. Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy. Genetic factors and epigenetic influences.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of patients with an increased risk of pre-eclampsia?
options: Low dose aspirin may reduce severity of disease
Calcium supplementation above RDA reduces the incidence
Treatment with magnesium lowers endothelin-1 concentrates
Megadoses of vitamin C has no proven benefit
explanation: Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia. However, women who have a calcium-deficient state may benefit from calcium supplementation to reduce their risk of preeclampsia. Prophylactic measures for the prevention of pre-eclampsia include low-dose aspirin administration (50–150 mg/day). It is started after the 1st trimester, continued throughout pregnancy, and is to be stopped 7 days before labor. Magnesium administration may be beneficial as it lowers endothelin-1 concentrates. There is no role of a low salt diet, anti-oxidants, or vitamin C.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenesis of pre-eclampsia?
options: Vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2 is increased
There is an increase in sFlt -1 levels
A decrease in the level of soluble endoglin is seen
explanation: In pre-eclampsia, there is an increase in the level of soluble endoglin. Excessive amounts of antiangiogenic factors, increased sensitivity to angiotensin, and lowered angiotensinase levels worsen hypoxia at the uteroplacental interface. Trophoblast of women who develop preeclampsia overproduces at least two antiangiogenic peptides that enter the maternal circulation. They increase months before clinical preeclampsia develops. Soluble endoglin (sEng) is derived from the placenta and blocks endothelial nitric oxide-dependent vasodilatation. It also inhibits various TGF isoforms from binding to endothelial receptors. Soluble Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) is a variant of the Flt-1 receptor for placental growth factor (PlGF) and for VEGF. Increased maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and decrease circulating free PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup. Her BP is 152/96mmHg. ’rine analysis shows proteinuria of 3+. All of the following would be consistent with her probable diagnosis, except:
explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of pre-eclampsia and low fibronectin is not a feature of pre-eclampsia. Features associated with pre-eclampsia: Fibronectin is a glycoprotein associated with vascular endothelial cell basement membrane and is elevated in women with preeclampsia. Thrombocytopenia (HELLP syndrome) Hemolysis (HELLP syndrome) Increased hemoglobin, caused by a decrease in plasma volume. Hemoconcentration is a hallmark of eclampsia. In preeclampsia, hemoconcentration is present but usually not marked.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which finding is most likely to be seen in a patient with pre-eclampsia?
explanation: Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia. During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia, renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. The hallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatinine levels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhanced tubular reabsorption. The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system. Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. This is often used as a predictive test.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Ophthalmic manifestations in patients with preeclampsia syndrome include all, except:
options: Central vision loss due to temporary scotoma
Permanent visual loss due to retinal artery occlusion
Permanent blindness due to serous retinal detachment
explanation: Serous retinal detachment does not cause permanent visual loss. The most common visual symptom of preeclampsia is scotoma. Blindness can be due to occipital cortex edema, Purtscher’s retinopathy (retinal ischemia), or retinal detachment. The blindness is mostly reversible and corrects automatically after delivery. Retinal artery occlusion sometimes causes permanent vision loss.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A patient, diagnosed with preeclampsia was brought to the emergency room with three episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, urinary incontinence, and altered sensorium for 3 hours. After stabilization, an MRI revealed the following findings. Which of the following is
true regarding this condition?
options: Anterior circulation is most commonly involved
This lesions may be seen in most pre-eclampsia patients
explanation: The above clinical scenario and radiological image are suggestive of posterior reversible leukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES). This condition is usually reversible. Endothelial dysfunction and cerebral autoregulation failure are implicated as etiologies of PRES. PRES lesions are almost universal in women with eclampsia but less frequent in pre-eclampsia. PRES is characterized by the following: Severe headaches Altered sensorium Seizures Visual disturbances. Radiological findings in PRES: Hyperintense T2 lesions in the subcortical and cortical regions of the parietal and occipital lobes. The basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellum are commonly involved. Posterior circulation is commonly involved, and anterior circulation involvement is seen in severe cases. Neurological manifestations of preeclampsia include: Headaches Convulsions Cerebral edema Blindness Cerebral hemorrhage.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following are indicators of severe disease in a patient with preeclampsia?
explanation: Among the given statements, the presence of pulmonary edema, scotoma, or epigastric pain is indicative of severe pre-eclampsia. Criteria for diagnosing severe preeclampsia include: Signs and symptoms of significant end-organ dysfunction are: New-onset cerebral or visual disturbance i.e., photopsia, scotoma, altered mental status, and severe headache Severe, persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, unresponsive to medication and not accounted for by an alternative diagnosis (OR) Serum transaminase concentration 2 times upper imit of normal. Thrombocytopenia with platelets <100,000/microL. Progressive renal insufficiency (serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL) Pulmonary edema. Systolic BP Diastolic BP Proteinur ia Signs of end-organ dama ge 160 mm Hg 110 mm Hg + +/- 140 mm Hg 90 mmH g +/- +
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient at 32 weeks of gestation with pre-eclampsia is admitted to your ward. All of the following symptoms would warn you of impending eclampsia, except:
explanation: Decreased deep tendon reflex is not a symptom of impending eclampsia. There will be increased deep tendon reflex i.e., hyperreflexia. Symptoms and signs of impending eclampsia include: Severe occipital or frontal headache Oliguria - diminished urine output <400 ml/day Epigastric pain Visual symptoms - blurring, scotomas, blindness Disturbed sleep Ankle clonus Severe elevation in blood pressure Pulmonary edema.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1 woman with a history of pre-eclampsia presents at 24 weeks of gestation for an antenatal check-up. You decide to evaluate her risk of developing pre-eclampsia in the present pregnancy. Which of the following results is not an indicator?
options: Absence of diastolic notch on Doppler
High resistance index in uterine artery Doppler in the second trimester
Presence of free fetal DNA in maternal serum
explanation: In this above scenario, the absence of a diastolic notch at 24 weeks on Doppler is not a predictor of pre-eclampsia. In normal pregnant women, a diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks. Thus, a persistent diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks is predictive of preeclampsia. Predictors of preeclampsia: Free fetal DNA in maternal plasma Diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks (high resistance index in the second trimester) Average MAP >90 mmHg Predictors no longer used include: Hemoconcentration Elevated fibronectin Increase in uric acid levels Hypocalciuria - calcium in urine <12mg/dl in 24 h Increased homocysteine levels Roll-over test - screening test is done between 28-32 weeks.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old G3P2 at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted as her BP was 150/90mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. Which of the following drugs is not suitable to control BP in this patient?
explanation: Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy. High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of preeclampsia. The following drugs are used for the management of pre-eclampsia. ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. When given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as: Bony malformations Persistent PDA Respiratory distress syndrome Limb contracture Pulmonary hypoplasia. Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include: ACE inhibitors Angiotensin receptor blockers Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF) Reserpine Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension) Diazoxide. Drug Dose Labetalol 100 mg TID or ›ID Methyl-d opa 250–500 mg TID or ›ID Nifedipin e 10–20 mg BD Hydralaz ine 10–25 mg BD
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a patient with severe pre-eclampsia?
explanation: Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling BP in severe pre-eclampsia. It is the first-line agent for urgent control of BP in pregnancy. It is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and has a good safety profile. Labetalol is a nonselective  blocker and vascular  blocker. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction. Option B: Hydralazine causes maternal hypotension and fetal distress. Option C: Nifedipine causes reflex tachycardia and headache in the mother. Option D: In methyldopa, a change in BP is an indirect action. So it is less effective in controlling BP. Note: Experimental antihypertensive drugs for pre-eclampsia treatment are calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and anti-digoxin antibody Fab (DIF). DIF is directed against endogenous digitalis-like factors, also called cardiotonic steroids. Choice of anti-hypertensives i n pregnancy PIH /pre-eclampsia / severe p re-eclampsia Labetalol Acute hypertension/ Hyperte nsive crisis IV labetalol, nifedipine, hydr alazine Chronic hypertension in preg nancy Labetalol > methyl dopa.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G3P1A1, preeclamptic patient at 33 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal check-up. At present, her BP is 130/90 and an NST is reactive. What is the plan of management for this patient?
explanation: The scenario is suggestive of mild pre-eclampsia as the patient has a BP of 130/90 mmHg and no fetal compromise. Hence, the plan of management would be to wait till 37 weeks for termination. In all cases of hypertension during pregnancy, the preferred mode of delivery is vaginal. Cesarean is indicated only for any co-existing obstetrical reasons. Hypertensive condition Time of delivery Gestational hypertension 38–39 weeks Mild pre-eclampsia 37 weeks Severe pre-eclampsia 34 weeks Eclampsia, HELLP syndr ome Immediate termination irres pective of gestational age
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presents with features suggestive of HELLP syndrome. Which of the following is false about her condition?
options: Corticosteroids aid in increasing platelet count
It is characterised by microangiopathic hemolysis
MgSO4 can be used in the management of HELLP syndrome
Termination of pregnancy is the definitive management
explanation: Corticosteroid treatment for thrombocytopenia is not recommended in patients with HELLP syndrome. HELLP syndrome is a serious complication in pregnancy characterized by HEmolysis, ELevated liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count. It occurs in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies and in 10–20% of patients with severe preeclampsia. Management of HELLP syndrome is supportive, including: Antiseizure prophylaxis with MgSO4 Platelet tansfusion if platelet count <50,000/mm3 , FFP transfusion Plasmapheresis Immediate termination of pregnancy in the interest of the mother. The most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is abruptio placenta and DIC.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following is false regarding HELLP syndrome?
options: PT, PTT, fibrinogen levels are norma
All patients with HELLP syndrome have abnormal BP
Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis
explanation: 15% of pregnant women with HELLP syndrome have normal blood pressure. HELLP syndrome occurs at 27-37 weeks. PT, PTT, and fibrinogen levels are normal. This differs from DIC where PT and PTT are elevated while the plasma fibrinogen level is decreased. Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis and Mississippi classification is used to grade HELLP syndrome. Tennessee criteria for diagnosis of true/complete HELLP Platelet count <1 lakh/cu mm AST >70 I’/L, LDH >600 I’/L Mississippi classification divides HELLP into 3 grades based on the platelet count.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1 patient at 25 weeks of gestation is brought to the emergency with right upper quadrant pain and one episode of seizure. CBC reveals a Hb of 7.6gm/dl and a platelet count of 70,000/microL. What is the definitive management?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome. The definitive management is the termination of pregnancy. In cases of pre-eclampsia, indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, are as follows: Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor) HELLP syndrome Persistent symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia or severe hypertension Pulmonary edema Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy Abruption of placenta Fetal compromise In mild pre-eclampsia, steroids are given and the patient is delivered at 37 weeks. In severe pre-eclampsia: If pregnancy is >34 weeks - MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia and the pregnancy is terminated. If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks - in the absence of contraindications, expectant management is followed and the baby is delivered at 34 weeks, as shown below in the flowchart.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pre-eclamptic patient at 30 weeks of gestation is rushed to the hospital as she suddenly lost her vision 1 hour ago. During admission, she has a seizure. Which of the given statements is correct?
options: Convulsions within 7 days of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia
Thrombocytosis is likely to be found
Blindness due to this condition is usually reversible
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia. Blindness due to eclampsia is usually reversible. Blindness due to eclampsia can be due to a central or peripheral cause. It is irreversible only if the etiology is a combination of retinal infarction and bilateral lateral geniculate nuclei lesions. Option A: Convulsions within 48 hours of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia. Option B: The most common hematological finding in pregnancy-induced hypertension is thrombocytopenia. Option D: The seizures are generalized seizures. Note: The most common cause of death in patients with eclampsia is intracerebral hemorrhage.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G3P2 patient with preeclampsia develops seizures and is started on the Pritchard regimen. What level of serum magnesium should be maintained in this patient in order to prevent seizures?
explanation: The clinical picture is suggestive of eclampsia and to control fits, optimum serum magnesium levels of 4-7 mEq/L have to be maintained. MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia: Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose Intramuscular (Pritchar d) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3– 5 minfollowed by10 g (50%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock) 5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in alte rnate buttocks Intravenous (Zuspan or Sib ai) 4g IV slow over 15–20 minut es 1–2 g/hr IV infusion
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The mechanism of action of MgSo4 includes all, except:
options: It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to Ach
explanation: MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium. Mechanism of action of MgSO4: It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach. It blocks neuronal calcium influx. It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. It blocks glutaminergic NMDA receptors and potentiates adenosine action.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is an indication to skip the next dose in a patient with severe pre-eclampsia taking MgSO4 prophylactically?
explanation: Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if knee jerks are present. The next dose of MgSO4 is only given when all signs of magnesium toxicity are absent. Signs of magnesium toxicity: Loss of deep tendon reflexes Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min) ’rine output <30 ml/hr Chest pain, heart block Management of magnesium toxicity: Stop magnesium therapy Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels Injection of calcium gluconate 10 ml (10% solution) IV Side effects of MgSO4: Anuria Pulmonary edema.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia is started on prophylactic MgSO4 in view of signs of impending eclampsia. An hour later, examination reveals RR - 16 breaths/minute and absent patellar reflexes. What is her plasma concentration of MgSO4 most likely to be?
explanation: Patellar reflexes disappear when plasma magnesium concentration reaches 10 mEq/L. As there is no respiratory depression, the plasma concentration is likely to be 10-12 mEq/L. The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending magnesium toxicity. MgSO4 is prophylactically used in impending eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome. Signs of magnesium toxicit y Plasma concentrations of ma gnesium (mEq/L) Loss of patellar reflex 10–12 Respiratory depression 12-13 Cardiac arrest >30
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:
options: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby
explanation: Magnesium sulfate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a premature baby, where there is a deficit of surfactant (which results in alveolar collapse). Magnesium in the MgSO4 competes with calcium on voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby altering its uptake and release. Functions of MgSO4 include : Membrane protector and neuro stabilizer. It is used in the prevention of cerebral palsy in very ow birth weight neonates. Reduction of motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine, and thus is used as an adjunct in the management of acute severe asthma in children and adults Blocking of neuronal calcium influx, and is thus used in the conservative management of pre-term labor (tocolytic, option D) Inducing cerebral vasodilatation, dilating the uterine arteries, increasing the production of endothelial prostacyclin, and inhibiting platelet activation. Hence it is used in the management of pre-eclampsia (option A) and to prevent progression to eclampsia (option A).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida at 33 weeks of gestation was rushed to the hospital with recurrent seizures. Her husband says that prior to the seizures, she had complained of a headache and visual disturbances. She was on antihypertensives from the first trimester and there is no history of neurological disease. Which of the following is true regarding her management?
options: First step of management is intravenous MgSO4
Diazepam is recommended as an anticonvulsant if MgSO4 fails
Treatment may be based on recommendations from the Magpie tria
Maternal alkalosis commonly occurs and needs correction
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and management may be based on recommendations from the Magpie trial. The Magpie trial showed that prophylactic use of magnesium sulfate lowers the risk of eclampsia. The first step in the management of eclampsia is maintaining the airway, ensuring oxygen delivery to both mother and fetus. Then, MgSO4 is administered to control seizures. Thiopentone > phenobarbitone may be used to control seizures. No attempt should be made to shorten the convulsion using diazepam as it often leads to thrombophlebitis and respiratory depression. Maternal acidosis usually occurs and is corrected when present.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding eclampsia?
explanation: Antepartum eclampsia has the worst prognosis and the most common MRI finding of eclampsia is subcortical white matter edema. Antepartum eclampsia is the most common type of eclampsia. It has the highest rate of maternal mortality. The outcome of eclampsia depends on the duration of hypertension and not severity. The most common cause of death in eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia is intracranial bleeding.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation?

Ascending aorta syndrome
explanation: Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation. The image shows compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus which can sometimes lead to supine hypotension. During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the aorta, owing to its structure is relatively resistant. Normally, the vena cava compression results in opening up collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygous veins but in some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed resulting in hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position. Diabetes in Pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following are not risk factors for developing gestational diabetes?
explanation: Obesity in first-degree relatives is not a high-risk factor for gestational diabetes mellitus. However, severe obesity is a risk factor for developing gestational diabetes. Gestational diabetes mellitus is defined as carbohydrate intolerance of variable severity with onset or first recognition during the present pregnancy. It usually presents in the second or third trimester. More than 50% of women with GDM ultimately develop overt diabetes within 20 years. It is recommended to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus in the presence of the following high-risk factors: Severe obesity Strong family history of type-2 diabetes Previous history of gestational diabetes mellitus Impaired glucose metabolism or glucosuria.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine USG scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes?
explanation: Overt diabetes is when fasting blood sugar is  126 mg/dl. Overt diabetics are women who are known to have diabetes before pregnancy. A patient is said to have overt diabetes if: Fasting blood sugar  126 mg/dL A random blood sugar of  200 mg/dL HbA1c of  6.5% The maternal complication of diabetes: increased Miscarriage and preterm labor. increased incidence of preeclampsia polyhydramnios prolongation of labor due to shoulder dystocia, operative interference, and cephalo-pelvic disproportion. Fetal and Neonatal complications of diabetes: fetal macrosomia (birth weight > 4kg) congenital malformations - Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient underwent a one-step procedure for gestational diabetes screening. Which of the following statements regarding this procedure is false?
options: Fasting blood glucose  92 mg/dL is diagnostic
100 grams of glucose is given after overnight fast
explanation: In one-step procedure, the patient is given 75g of glucose after an overnight fast, and blood glucose is measured hourly for 2 hours. Diagnostic criteria with one-step procedure is as follows: Fasting  92 mg/dL 1-hour  180 mg/dL 2-hour  153 mg/dL In two-step approach patient is given glucose and subsequent values measured in two separate steps. Step 1 - the patient is given 50 grams of glucose and blood glucose is measured after one hour. If it is 140 mg/dl then the screen is positive and step 2 is done. Step 2 - the patient is given 100g of glucose and values measured hourly, for 3 hours. A diagnosis is made if at least two values are high using one of two methods. DIPSI (Diabetes In Pregnancy Societies of India) recommends a one-step procedure without regard to the time of the last meal. Here the patient is given 75 grams of oral glucose. A blood glucose value of 140 mg/dL after 2-hours is diagnostic.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman at 28 weeks of gestation is started on insulin therapy after being diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus. What should be the fasting blood glucose target in her?
explanation: The target fasting blood glucose level in a patient with gestational diabetes mellitus is 95 mg/dl. In gestational diabetes mellitus, the targets are: Fasting  95 mg/d 1-h postprandial  140 mg/d 2-h postprandial  120 mg/d HbA1c  6.0%.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: According to Priscilla White's classification for diabetes in pregnancy, all of the following classes should be managed with insulin except
explanation: Class A1 is managed by diet therapy. Other than A1, all the other classes are managed by insulin therapy. Priscilla White's classification for diabetes in pregnancy is not used anymore. It was modified by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists in 1986. Class Description Gestational Diabetes Mellitus A1 Diet-controlled GDM A2 Insulin-controlled GDM Diabetes Mellitus B Onset >20yDuration <10y C Onset 10-19yDuration 10-19y D Onset <10yDuration >20yBe nign retinopathy F Nephropathy R Proliferative retinopathy H Heart disease
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of hyperglycemia during pregnancy?
options: Metformin crosses the placenta and has teratogenic effects on the fetus
Diet control is the first line management
HbA1c monitored at the end of the first trimester and then every 3 months thereafter
Insulin is the first line pharmacological agent
explanation: Metformin crosses the placenta. However, no teratogenic effects have been observed as yet. Insulin is the preferred treatment in gestational diabetes mellitus because it does not cross the placenta (American Diabetes Association). Management of diabetes in pregnancy: Preconceptional counseling: To achieve tight control of diabetes before the onset of pregnancy. HbA1C level measured to plan pregnancy.
