Appropriate advice about diet and insulin given Antenatal care (at monthly intervals up to 20 weeks and thereafter at 2 weeks intervals): Diabetic diet—30 ™cal/kg for normal BMI, 24 ™cal/kg for overweight women, and 12 ™cal/kg for morbidly obese women Frequent monitoring of blood glucose HbA1c determination at the end of the first trimester and then every 3 months thereafter. HbA1c evel of 6% is desirable Insulin therapy - initiated when diabetes is not controlled by diet alone Oral hypoglycemic drugs- glibenclamide and metformin are safe.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100 mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
explanation: Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes. First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity, neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia. First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy: Insulin Glyburide Metformin
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation is admitted with preterm labour contractions. She was diagnosed with gestational diabetes, on screening. Which of the following tocolytic drugs should be avoided in her?
explanation: Terbutaline should be avoided in pregnant women with diabetes. Terbutaline (-mimetic drugs) given for tocolysis can cause hyperglycemia, which can cause diabetic ketoacidosis. Factors precipitating ketoacidosis in pregnancy: Hyperemesis gravidarum Infection Non-compliance Insulin pump failure -sympathomimetic drugs Corticosteroids Poor glycemic contro
subject: OBGYN

question_text: According to the American college of obstetricians, macrosomia is defined as the fetal birth weight of .
explanation: According to the American college of obstetricians (ACOG), macrosomia is defined as the fetal birth weight of  4.5 kg. Macrosomia refers to growth beyond a specific threshold, regardless of gestational age. In developed countries, the most commonly used threshold is the weight above 4.5 kg, but weight above 4 kg is also commonly used. The WHO defines the cut-off at 4.0 kg for fetal macrosomia in its guidelines for the management of common maternal conditions. This is followed in India.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In gestational diabetes, which of the following is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia?
explanation: BMI (body mass index) is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia in both diabetic and non-diabetic mothers. BMI levels are associated with increased birth weight, regardless of glucose levels. Gestational diabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1 percent for every 1 kg/m2 increase in BMI. BMI cutoffs for pregnancy: Underweight - < 18 kg/m2 Normal - 18.5 to 24.9 kg/m2 Overweight - 25 to 29.9 kg/m2 Obese - >30 kg/m2 Weight distribution also seems to play a role because the risk of gestational diabetes is increased with truncal obesity. HbA1c levels are associated with fetal malformations in pre-gestational diabetes.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: According to ACOG, routine cesarean delivery is advocated in a woman with gestational diabetes mellitus if the sonographically estimated fetal weight is g.
explanation: According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), routine cesarean delivery is advocated in a woman with gestational diabetes mellitus if the sonographically estimated fetal weight is  4500 g.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery?
explanation: The most appropriate time for the delivery in this patient would be 39 weeks as she has good glycemic control with insulin. The timing for delivery in a pregnant woman with GDM would vary depending on the control of glucose levels & mode of treatment. Appropriate timing for delive ry in gestational diabetes Well-controlledwith diet 39 weeks to 40 weeks +6 day s Well-controlledwithinsulin/or al agent 39 weeks to 39 weeks + 6 day s Co-morbidityor suboptimal c ontrol Induction before 39 weeks Withpoor glycemic control Reasonable to deliver at 37 to 38 weeks + 6 days of gestati onIn extreme cases where all efforts for glycemic control h ave failed induction prior to 37 weeks (no clear cut guideli ne )
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following complications is unlikely in a patient with gestational diabetes?
explanation: Polyhydramnios is a complication of diabetes, not oligohydramnios. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is commonly defined as glucose intolerance first recognized during pregnancy. Complications of gestational diabetes: Spontaneous abortion Preterm labor Unexplained fetal demise Hypoglycemia Malformations Altered fetal growth Hypocalcemia Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy Pre-eclampsia Respiratory distress syndrome Polyhydramnios
subject: OBGYN

question_text: On screening, a primigravida is found to have fasting blood glucose of 110mg/dl. What is the likelihood that she will develop overt diabetes within the next 20 years?
explanation: 50 % of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they are recommended to undergo screening and revaluation from time to time. Fasting blood glucose of  92 mg/dL indicates gestational diabetes.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 29-year-old woman with overt diabetes comes to you for pre-conception counseling. Which of the following congenital heart defects are least likely to occur if she were to have a child?
explanation: Tetrology of Fallot (TOF) is usually not seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Ventricular septal defect and transposition of great arteries are the most common cardiac anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers. Cardiac defects that present more often in infants of diabetic mothers are: Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) Double outlet right ventricle (DORV) Ventricular septal defect (VSD) Truncus arteriosus Tricuspid atresia Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) The most common cardiac anomaly in an infant of a diabetic mother is a controversial topic. Most resources mention VSD and TGA are the most common and do not specify which among them is more common.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Hypocalcemia in a newborn is defined as serum calcium mg/dl.
explanation: Hypocalcemia in a newborn is defined as serum calcium < 8 mg/dl. Hypocalcemia is one of the potential metabolic derangements in neonates of diabetic mothers. There is hypomagnesemia in the mother and the infant due to increased maternal urinary excretion of magnesium due to diabetes. There is maternal hyperparathyroidism due to hypomagnesemia which leads to increased maternal calcium. This maternal calcium passes to the infant through the placenta and suppresses fetal PTH synthesis and impairs PTH response to postpartum hypocalcemia. PTH suppression, in this case, can be severe and lead to convulsions in the early neonatal period and may persist for months.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are performing capillary blood glucose charting for newborns in the post-natal ward. Below what level is it considered hypoglycemia?
explanation: Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose levels <45 mg/dL. Maternal hyperglycemia stimulates the fetal pancreas to secrete excess insulin, which causes increased neonatal fat deposition, abdominal girth, and macrosomia (Pederson's hypothesis). It also leads to a rapid drop in plasma glucose concentration after delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.
explanation: The image showing a poorly developed lower limb suggests the diagnosis of caudal regression sequence/sacral agenesis seen in pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes. The caudal regression sequence is a rare malformation, frequently associated with maternal pre-gestational diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae. E evated maternal HbA1c levels correlate with fetal malformations. It occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants. Overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is associated with higher malformation rates than the general population. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters. Option B: Malformations are not associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Malformations occur due to the disruption of organogenesis, usually occurring in the first trimester. The abnormal glycemic status in GDM manifests only in the second trimester. Option C: Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis. Option D: ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
Which of the following will be the most effective contraception in a female with hypertension and a history of gestational diabetes mellitus?
Oral contraceptives
explanation: Intrauterine devices are the most effective contraceptive choice in patients with gestational diabetes mellitus and hypertension. It is suitable in patients with diabetes and comorbidities like obesity, hypertension, or dyslipidemia. It is a method without potential cardiovascular consequences, unlike hormonal contraceptives. Low-dose hormonal contraceptives can be used safely in women with gestational diabetes if there are no associated comorbidities. Even though the barrier method will not lead to complications in such patients, the failure rate is high due to incorrect use and non-compliance. Hence it is not preferred. Option D: DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate) is an injectable hormonal contraceptive that is contraindicated in diabetic pregnant women with co-morbidities. Cardiovascular Conditions in Pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The most common valvular heart disease in pregnancy is
explanation: Mitral stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease in pregnancy. The commonest cardiac lesions are of rheumatic origin followed by congenital conditions. The incidence of cardiac lesions is less than 1% amongst hospital deliveries. Rheumatic valvular lesions predominantly include mitral stenosis (80%).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed in pregnancy?
explanation: Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed in pregnancy. Mitral stenosis is the commonest acquired heart lesion during pregnancy. Condition in pregnancy Most common lesion Congenital heart disease Atrial septal defect Congenital valvular lesion Mitral valve prolapse Cyanotic Congenital Heart di sease Tetrology of Fallot Acquired valvular heart disea se Mitral stenosis > Mitral regur gitation > Aortic stenosis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old lady with rheumatic mitral stenosis becomes pregnant. At what point during her pregnancy would you be least concerned about her developing cardiac failure?
explanation: Cardiac failure in pregnancy is least likely to occur during 24 weeks, considering the given options. The order of risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy is immediate postpartum > 2nd stage of labor > 30 weeks > 22 weeks. Maternal cardiac risk predictors: [Mnemonic: NOPE] N-NYHA class >2 O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2 or aortic valve area <1.5 cm2, peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg) P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancy E-Ejection fraction <40% Scoring systems used to calculate risk are Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy (CARPREG) and ZAHARA scores.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An intern posted in the antenatal OPD auscultates a patient who came for her routine checkup. Presence of which of the following features would not suggest a physiological change of pregnancy?
options: Ejection systolic murmur at left sternal border
Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
explanation: Late systolic murmur is pathological in pregnancy. CVS physiological changes in pregnancy: Pulse rate: Increases Diastolic BP: Decreases S1: Loud and split S2:Normal S3:prominent (occasional) Jugular venous distension and venous hum Murmurs Ejection systolic murmur at left sternal border. Continous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle) Heart is displaced upwards and to the left ECG changes Left axis deviation (due to elevation of diaphragm) T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement Mild ST changes in the inferior leads Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not an absolute indication for therapeutic termination of pregnancy?
explanation: Prosthetic valve replacement is not an indication for therapeutic termination as it comes under the WHO category risk 3. Only conditions included under WHO category risk 4 are considered as indications for termination of pregnancy. WHO class 4 comprises of diseases with very high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity, such as: Pulmonary arterial hypertensio Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (NYHA III-IV or LVEF 30-40%) Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular functio Severe left heart obstructio Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >40 mm Termination of pregnancy is also advised in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant lady with heart failure planned for valve replacement surgery is posted for cesarean section. Which of the following is not a cardiac indication for cesarean delivery?
explanation: Primary pulmonary hypertension is not a cardiac indication for caesarean delivery. In primary pulmonary hypertension, maternal mortality is about 50% and the majority die (75%) postpartum. Simpson’s criteria for cesarean delivery for cardiac disease in pregnancy: Dilated aortic root >4 cm or aortic aneurysm Acute severe congestive heart failure Recent myocardial infarctio Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis Warfarin administration within 2 weeks of delivery Need for emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery Coarctation of the aorta and aortic dissection are other indications for cesarean delivery. In general, vaginal delivery is preferred, and labor induction is usually safe. Cesarean delivery is limited to obstetric indications, and considerations are given for the specific cardiac lesions only. Epidural anesthesia is given during LSCS in heart disease. The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are performing CPR on a woman who is 38-weeks pregnant. She was admitted to the emergency after a massive pulmonary embolism led to cardio-pulmonary arrest. Despite the initial management of airway, oxygenation and vasopressor support, there is no improvement. What is the cut off time for perimortem cesarean delivery in this patient?
explanation: Perimortem cesarean delivery should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation in 5 minutes, according to the AHA 2020 Guidelines. The goal of perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) should be primarily aimed at saving the life of the mother. PMCS improves maternal survival by decreasing compression of the IVC by the gravid uterus. This improves venous return and diaphragmatic displacement, which in turn improves respiratory dynamics.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G2P1 patient with mitral valve prolapse goes into labor. Which of the following should not be done in the management of this patient?
options: Cut short second stage of labour using ventouse
Trendelenburg position during first stage of labor
explanation: Lateral recumbent position is advised during the first stage of labor in this patient. Management of labor in patients with heart disease: First stage: Lateral recumbent or propped up positio Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min) Analgesia by epidural Fluids should not be infused more than 75 ml/h Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labour and 48 h after delivery Central venous pressure monitoring Second stage: No maternal pushing Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anaesthsia The benefit of avoiding haemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, haemorrhage and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery. Third stage: Oxytocin by infusio IV frusemide if needed
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised?
explanation: The final switch to heparin in a pregnant women is advised at 36 weeks of pregnancy and is continued till 7 days postpartum. This switch is made from warfarin to heparin at 36 weeks, as warfarin is a strong anticoagulant which can cause post partum hemorrhage in the mother at the time of labour and can also cross the placenta into the fetal blood and can increase the risk of intracranial hemorrhage in the fetus The below given algorithm is followed for administration of anticoagulants in a pregnant female: LMWH- low molecular weight heparin UFH- Unfractionated heparin Period of pregnancy Anticoagulation of choice First trimester If dose of warfarin< 5mg/day –continue warfarin till 36 we eksIf dose ofwarfarin > 5mg/ day or warfarin embryopathy present –replace it with hepa rin / LMWH From12 weeks to 36 weeks warfarin At 36 weeks Switch toLMWH 1 week before EDD / 3 days b efore EDD Switch toUFH(as LMWH hav e longer T1/2– increased cha nces of PPH) On the day of delivery Stop all anticoagulant Period of pregnancy Anticoagulation of choice Period of pregnancy Anticoagulation of choice 6 hrs after vaginal delivery / 6-12 hrs after cesarean Restart UFH and Warfarin. When INR is 2.5 to 3 withdra w UFH & continue warfarin
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 28-year-old G2P1 was admitted to the labor room at 38 weeks of gestation. She is a known case of mitral valve prolapse. Which of the following is the best for managing the second stage of labor in this patient ?
explanation: The best technique for managing the second stage of labor in a patient with heart disease is using ventouse. For most cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred and cesarean section is reserved for obstetric indications since the cesarean section is associated with more blood loss and higher thromboembolic and infection risk. If vaginal delivery is selected as the mode of choice, it will be conducted with the laboring woman in an upright position, or in the left decubitus position. This minimizes aortocaval compression. Active pushing during the second stage may also be limited, depending on the degree of cardiac compromise. In moderate to severe cardiac disease, it may be prudent to completely avoid an active second stage. Regional anesthesia can be used to allow the fetal head to descend to the perineum without active pushing. Delivery can be further facilitated by forceps or vacuum extraction. The benefit of avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, hemorrhage, and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery. Some journals report that ventouse is preferable to forceps, as it can be applied without putting the patient in lithotomy position (raising the legs increases the cardiac load) however it is controversial.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: General anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia in pregnant women with
explanation: In pregnant ladies with intracardiac shunts, general anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia. The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given. Note: Aortic stenosis will also be affected by the hypotension caused by epidural/spinal analgesia. However, in aortic stenosis, slow epidural anesthesia is adequate and doesn't compromise ventricular preload. Only a few severe cases of aortic stenosis warrant GA. Hence, in the context of this MCQ, 'intracardiac shunts' would be the most appropriate answer.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant lady with mitral stenosis requires anticoagulation. Which of the following statements is false regarding her management?
options: LMWH or UFH is used until 13 weeks of pregnancy
From 13 weeks till close to delivery substitute UFH with warfari
Following vaginal delivery, anticoagulation with LMWH or UFH is restarted after 6 hours
explanation: Warfarin is not contraindicated during lactation. Warfarin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH) do not accumulate in breast milk. They do not induce an anticoagulant effect in the infant. The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons: Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths. Heparin: It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin. LMWH: Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves. If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously. Period of gestation Anticoagulant Till 12 completed weeks LMWH or UFH 13 to 36 weeks Warfarin 36 weeks to 6 hours before d elivery LMWH or UFH 6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section LMWH or UFH (ACOG reco mmendation)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in pregnancy?
options: Most affected patients are asymptomatic during pregnancy
Diuretics are generally not used in this patient
She may develop chest pain, palpitations, and syncope
The most common cause for death is cardiac failure
explanation: The most common cause of death in HOCM in pregnant women is ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Most affected women are asymptomatic, but some patients may develop: Dyspnea Anginal or atypical chest pai Syncope Arrhythmias. Strenuous exercise is prohibited during pregnancy. Abrupt positional changes are avoided to prevent reflex vasodilation and decrease of preload. Diuretics and vasodilators are generally not used as they decrease preload. If angina develops, beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers are used. The mode of delivery depends upon obstetric indications and if cesarean section is done, general anesthesia is considered the safest.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except
options: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery
explanation: Left ventricular systolic dysfunction is a feature of peripartum cardiomyopathy (also known as postpartum cardiomyopathy) and not diastolic dysfunction. Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. It develops during the last month of pregnancy or within the first 5 months following delivery. The predisposing factors include Cardiac gene mutations involving several genes like TTNC1, TTN, and STAT3, Twin pregnancy/ multifetal gestation, Smoking, and Preeclampsia. Other proposed causes include viral myocarditis, abnormal immune response to pregnancy, malnutrition, inflammation, etc. PPCM is associated with increased secretion of prolactin by the pituitary and antiangiogenic molecule sFlt-1 (soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase) by the placenta at term gestation. Pearson’s diagnostic criteria for PPCM: Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy, and Left ventricular systolic dysfunction demonstrated by echocardiographic criteria, such as ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30% along with a dilated left ventricle. Management involves treating the features of heart failure. Bromocriptine has been found useful in this condition. Many women recover within 6 months of delivery, while some continue to have residual effects.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following agents has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy?
explanation: Prolactin has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy. Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes. The etiology of peripartum cardiomyopathy remains unknown. Many potential causes have been proposed but are not proven. Viral myocarditis Abnormal immune response to pregnancy Abnormal response to the increased hemodynamic burden of pregnancy Malnutritio Inflammatio Apoptosis Prolacti
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A P1L1 lady presents with complaints of fatigue and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea 3 months after her delivery. On examination, she has pedal edema and echo shows left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Which of the following drugs has shown to be effective for the treatment of her condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of peripartum cardiomyopathy and bromocriptine is effective for its treatment. Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes. Based on this proposed mechanism, bromocriptine therapy has been suggested because it inhibits prolactin secretion.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 34-year-old lady came to the antenatal OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her UPT is positive. She is a known case of mitral stenosis for 5 years. Which is the best time to do surgery for mitral stenosis in this patient?
explanation: The best time of surgery for mitral stenosis in pregnancy is between 14–18 weeks. Balloon valvuloplasty is the procedure of choice for mitral stenosis in pregnancy. Any cardiac surgery in pregnancy should usually be postponed until after delivery, but if required, it can be performed safely in the 2nd trimester.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A lady with ventricular septal defect becomes pregnant. Which of the following is not a common complication that is expected to occur in this patient?
explanation: Hypertension is a common maternal complication of congenital cardiac disease in pregnancy. The common maternal complications in patients with congenital cardiac disease include: Congestive cardiac failure Pulmonary edema Arrhythmia Hypertensio
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common arrhythmia encountered in pregnancy?
explanation: The most common arrhythmia seen in reproductive-aged women is paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Women with the highest risk of endocarditis in pregnancy are those with
explanation: Women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease and prosthetic valves. The American heart association recommends prophylaxis for dental procedures with: Prosthetic valves Unrepaired cyanotic heart defects Valvulopathy after heart transplantatio American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists do not recommend endocarditis prophylaxis for either vaginal or cesarean delivery in the absence of pelvic infection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of maternal mortality during pregnancy?
explanation: Eisenmenger syndrome is the heart disease with the worst prognosis, having a maternal mortality rate of 50%. The most common cause of death in Eisenmenger’s syndrome is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock. If antenatal diagnosis of Eisenmenger syndrome is made in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised. Eisenmenger syndrome has the highest risk of maternal mortality. However, since mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac condition in pregnancy, it is the most common cause of maternal mortality overall. Mitral regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse and pulmonary stenosis are well tolerated during pregnancy. Severe aortic stenosis can be life-threatening. However, women with mild to moderate aortic valve stenosis may have a relatively low-risk pregnancy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 32-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by vaginal delivery. She is a known case of rheumatic mitral stenosis for 4 years. After the delivery of the placenta, she started to bleed profusely. Which among the following should not be used to control bleeding?
Methyl ergometrine
explanation: The given scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in a primigravida with rheumatic mitral stenosis. Methyl ergometrine is contraindicated in patients with organic heart disease. Contraindications of methyl ergometrine are: Twin pregnancy - Second baby gets compromised by tetanic contractions of uterus if given after delivery of first baby Organic cardiac disease - Causes overloading of right heart by squeezing blood from uterine circulation. Severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia Rh negative mother - Increases chance of fetomaternal transfusion. Rhesus Isoimmunization
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The Rhesus blood group antigen complex is located on which chromosome?
explanation: The genetic locus for the Rh antigen complex is on the short arm of chromosome 1. RhCcEe and RhD are the two distinct genes located within the Rh locus. The presence of D antigen on one or both chromosomes 1, determines heterozygosity or homozygosity respectively.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Antigens of which of the following blood group systems do not cause alloimmunization in a newborn/fetus?
explanation: The Lewis antigens do not cause alloimmunization or hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn. Alloimmunization/isoimmunisation is defined as an immune response to foreign antigens after exposure to genetically different cells or tissues. The Kell blood group system is complex and contains many antigens that are highly immunogenic. These antigens are the third most potent, after those of the ABO and Rh blood groups, at triggering an immune reaction. Anti-Kell causes severe fetal anemia by suppressing fetal RBC synthesis. MNS and Kidd blood types cause alloimmunization. Hemolytic disease of newborn is mild with Kidd whereas MNS causes potentially severe anemia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant Rh-negative woman presents for her regular antenatal visit. Her Indirect Coombs test is negative. When would you give her prophylactic Anti-D?
explanation: In a non-immunized Rh-negative primigravida, Anti D is given at 28 weeks of gestation. It is also given within 72 hours of delivery. Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72 hours of delivery decreases the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent. Additionally, the provision of Anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks of gestation reduces the third-trimester alloimmunization rate from approximately 2 percent to 0.1 percent.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following events in Rh-negative patients does not require Anti-D prophylaxis?
explanation: Postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication of Anti-D prophylaxis. Anti-D prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative patients in the following circumstances: Pregnancy loss due to: Ectopic pregnancy Spontaneous abortion/hydatiform mole Elective abortion Fetal death (any trimester) Procedures: Amniocentesis Chorionic villus sampling Fetal blood sampling External cephalic version Delivery Trauma Placental abruption Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Chorionic villus sampling was performed on a G2P1 Rh-negative woman at 10 weeks of gestation. What is the dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin that should be administered?
explanation: The dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given in the first trimester is 50 g. All Rh-negative unsensitized women should receive 50 g of Rh-immune globulin IM in the first trimester in the following conditions: Within 72 hours of induced or spontaneous abortion Ectopic/molar pregnancy Chorionic villus sampling Women with a pregnancy beyond 12 weeks should receive a full dose of 300 g. Generally, a 300 g dose will protect a woman from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood. The dose in the 3rd trimester and post-delivery is 300 g or 1500 international units (IU).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An Rh-negative G2P1 mother delivered her Rh-positive baby by cesarean section. Kleihaeur Betke test, as shown in the image, was done. Which of the following statements is true regarding the test?
options: Fetal erythrocytes are the ghost cells
The reagent used is citric acid
explanation: The reagent used for the Kleihauer-Betke test is citric acid. Kleihauer-Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test used to detect fetomaternal hemorrhage i.e., the approximate volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation. It is also known as the acid elution test. The principle behind it is that fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A. After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as “ghosts.” Fetal cells are counted and expressed as a percentage of adult cells. Flow cytometry is the best test for the quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage. It is more sensitive and accurate as compared to the Kleihauer-Betke test. Flow cytometry can analyze a larger number of cells and is not influenced by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin and fetal levels of maternal hemoglobin. It utilizes monoclonal antibodies to HbF or to the D antigen followed by quantification by fluorescence.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose of Rh-immunoglobulin calculated is:
options: 10 g for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs
10 g for every 5 mL of fetal RBCs
0.5 g for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood
5 g for every 10 mL of fetal whole blood
explanation: If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose of Rh-immune globulin calculated is 10 g for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs. The calculation is done as follows: 300 micrograms of Anti-D can neutralize 15 ml of fetal RBCs or 30ml of fetal whole blood. 50 micrograms of Anti-D can neutralize 2.5 ml of fetal RBCs. The half-life of anti D is 16-24 days. It is administered intramuscularly either in the deltoid or in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old Rh-negative primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 12 weeks of pregnancy. Her husband is found to be Rh-positive. An Indirect Coombs test is also positive. At what critical titer of the test, would the fetus require monitoring for signs of anemia?
explanation: The critical titer for the indirect Coombs test (ICT ) is 1:16 Protocol for management Rh isoimmunisation is as follows:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother?
explanation: MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mothers. The middle cerebral artery is used as other fetal vessels require a larger insonating angle and confers significant measurement error. MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood, which permits the reliable, noninvasive detection of fetal anemia in cases of blood-group alloimmunization. If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced amniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In modified Liley's (Queenan) chart, which zone represents a severely affected fetus?
explanation: A severely affected fetus is represented by zone 3. Liley developed a chart of changing amniotic fluid bilirubin levels (delta OD450) and weeks of gestation. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm (OD450). However, middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PCV) is non-invasive and more accurate than optical density at 450 nm, hence Liley’s chart is no longer used in practice. Liley’s chart has three zones as shown below, delineating the severity of rhesus disease. Liley’s zone I (low zone) - mild disease. Liley’s zone II (mid zone) - fetal anemia. Liley’s zone III (high zone) - severely affected fetus and fetal death is imminent.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: u are performing a Doppler assessment of a fetal middle cerebral artery. What is the threshold value of its peak systolic velocity that would prompt you to consider fetal blood sampling?
explanation: Threshold (critical value) of middle cerebral artery (MCA) peak systolic velocity is 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM). If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MoM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling is necessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion. The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The velocity increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity. In many centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia. This method provided 100 percent sensitivity.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 32-year-old G4P3 Rh-negative patient with an antibody titer of 1:32 presents to the clinic at 30 weeks. A USG reveals features of fetal edema, ascites, and polyhydramnios. Cordocentesis was done for fetal blood sampling. At what hematocrit value is intrauterine blood transfusion indicated?
explanation: Intrauterine transfusion is done if fetal haematocrit is <30%. The blood for transfusion is usually O negative and cross-matched with the mother's blood. It is highly packed to achieve a hematocrit of 75 -80%. Intrauterine transfusions may be done intraperitoneally where blood is absorbed through diaphragmatic lymphatics. It may also be done intravascularly through the umbilical vein. The segments of the umbilical vein used are the intrahepatic portion or at its insertion into the placenta. Complications of intrauterine transfusion include: Fetal demise Chorioamnionitis Placental abruption Pre-term labor Bradycardia/tachyarrhythmia Umbilical cord hematoma
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient presented for an antenatal checkup at 25 weeks of gestation. She had bilateral pitting pedal edema and a history of mild headaches. While updating her antenatal card, a weight gain of 13 kgs in the past 2 weeks was noted. USG revealed gross fetal hydrops and a hyperechoic placenta. Which of the following is not true about the patient's condition?
options: It is also known as Ballantyne syndrome
Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization
It is associated with elevated liver enzymes
It is a not a form of pre-eclampsia
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of maternal mirror syndrome/Ballantyne syndrome. It may be considered a form of severe pre-eclampsia. Maternal mirror syndrome is the association between fetal hydrops and the development of maternal edema. The syndrome is named as such because the mother mirrors the fetus. It is characterized by triple edema i.e., the fetus, mother, and placenta become edematous. The pathogenesis of mirror syndrome, although not well established, mimics trophoblastic damage and maternal vascular endothelial dysfunction, as is also seen in pre-eclampsia. Hence, these two conditions may have a similar clinical presentation, with common features such as: Edema Hypertension Proteinuria Liver enzyme elevation Headache and visual disturbances. However, in contrast to preeclampsia, the following features are noted in maternal mirror syndrome: Low maternal hematocrit i.e., hemodilution rather than hemoconcentration Polyhydramnios rather than oligohydramnios The fetus always shows signs of hydrops. The etiology of fetal hydrops is not related to the development of mirror syndrome. Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, congenital infections, fetal cystic hygroma, Ebstein anomaly, sacrococcygeal teratoma, vein of Galen aneurysms, etc. In most cases with mirror syndrome, prompt delivery is indicated, because women with severe features of preeclampsia can deteriorate rapidly. In few cases, identification and treatment of the cause of fetal hydrops resulted in the resolution of symptoms for both the mother and baby for the remainder of the pregnancy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An ultrasound was done on a pregnant Rh-negative patient to screen for hydrops fetalis. What is the earliest sign that may be seen on USG?
explanation: The earliest sign of hydrops fetalis on a USG is scalp edema. Subcutaneous scalp edema is also known as the Halo sign. Other USG signs include: Ascites Pleural effusion Pericardial effusion Typical position termed as Buddha's position The image below shows skin thickening at the level of the fetal skull, on ultrasonography:
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
An Rh-negative patient who did not have access to antenatal care delivered a stillborn fetus as shown in the image. Which of the following is not associated with the fetal condition?

Oligohydramnios
Extramedullary hematopoesis
Cardiac failure
explanation: The pale, oedematous fetus in the image is suggestive of fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is associated with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. It often occurs as an effect of iso-immunization in an Rh-negative pregnancy. Other complications that may occur are fetal anemia and hyperbilirubinemia. Fetal anemia occurs in the initial stage of iso-immunization. It is associated with polyhydramnios and increased placental thickening (hyper-placentosis). An increase in the right atrium size of the fetus is seen. Fetal hydrops is usually accompanied by severe anemia. It results in stillbirth or fetal demise soon after birth. It is also associated with: Congestive cardiac failure Ascites Pleural effusion Pericardial effusion Hepatosplenomegaly. Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding obstetric cholestasis?
options: Pruritus usually develops in the third trimester
explanation: Obstetric cholestasis is a condition in which cholestasis occurs in pregnancy. Serum bilirubin increases very late in the disease and total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 5 mg/dL. Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment. It is also referred to as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum. There is a significant genetic influence. It may be more common in multifetal pregnancies. Patients present with pruritus that develops usually during the third trimester, typically involving the palms and soles. It is worse at night. Icterus may also be present. Disorder AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/d L) Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5 Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10 Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe itching over her palms and soles for 2 weeks. She gives a history of similar complaints in her last pregnancy. On examination, she is icteric. Which of the following is the preferred investigation to diagnose this condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of cholestasis in pregnancy. Serum bile acid is the earliest and most consistent parameter to increase in obstetric cholestasis. Serum cholic acid is preferred compared to serum chenodeoxycholic acid. Although serum bile acid increases after meals it is still considered an important investigation among women with obstetric cholestasis. This is because serum bile acid levels remain significantly elevated in women with obstetric cholestasis in comparison to pregnant women without it.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A food critic at 32 weeks of gestation presents with nausea and mild right upper abdominal pain. She also gives a history of itching over palms and soles for 2 weeks. On examination, she is icteric. Investigations done are shown below. What is the preferred treatment in this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of obstetric cholestasis. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice in obstetric cholestasis. It relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum enzyme levels (like SGOT, ALP). It may also reduce certain neonatal complications such as preterm birth, fetal distress, and respiratory distress syndrome. Antihistamines and topical emollients may provide some relief. Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial hemorrhage and stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred. Disorder AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/d L) Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5 Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10 Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following features are not likely to be seen in a patient with acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
explanation: Hyperglycemia, hypercholesterolemia, and thrombocytosis are not likely to be seen in acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP). Clinical features of AFLP include: Persistent nausea and vomiting Progressive jaundice Hypoglycemia Hypertension Proteinuria Edema Thrombocytopenia Moderate to severe liver dysfunction - manifested by: Hypofibrinogenemia Hypoalbuminemia Hypocholesterolemia Prolonged clotting time.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A woman at 37 weeks of gestation with icterus, nausea, and yellowish discoloration of urine has abnormal liver function tests. She is suspected to have acute fatty liver of pregnancy.
Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Occurs due to heterozygous defect for fatty acid oxidation
explanation: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is more commonly associated with male fetuses and not female fetuses. AFLP is a rare, potentially fatal complication also known as acute fatty metamorphosis or acute yellow atrophy. It is more common in the third trimester. It is due to a defect in the long-chain-3-hydroxy acyl-CoA-dehydrogenase (LCHAD) pathway. It is also associated with: First pregnancy - uncommon in subsequent pregnancies Maternal obesity Multiple pregnancies Investigations: Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Hemolysis with coagulopathy: Decreased platelets and fibrinogen Elevated d-dimers and prothrombin time Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration. The definitive management of AFLP is rapid delivery of the fetus and supportive care. Hepatic dysfunction usually normalizes within a week of delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following will not increase the risk for urinary tract infection in pregnant women?
explanation: Hypertension is not a risk factor for urinary infections in pregnancy. Risk factors for urinary infections in pregnancy include: Urinary retention Vesicoureteric reflux of pregnancy Diabetes in pregnancy Sickle cell anemia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A G3P2 lady at 13 weeks of gestation presented for a regular antenatal checkup. A urine routine revealed the presence of 2,00,000 gram-negative bacilli/mL. Repeat urinalysis showed the following results. Which of the following is not true about this condition?
options: Incidence is similar to that in non pregnant women
It is higher in people with sickle cell trait
Antibiotic therapy is required only if symptoms develop
There is risk of developing chronic renal lesions
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of asymptomatic bacteriuria. Antibiotic therapy should be given regardless of the symptoms. Asymptomatic bacteriuria refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinary tract in asymptomatic women. Organisms that cause urinary infections are those from the normal perineal flora. The most common causative agent is E.coli. Others include Klebsiella, and Proteus. Incidence is similar to that in non-pregnant women. Prevalence depends on parity (more in higher parity), race, socioeconomic status (more in low SES). It is more common in patients with sickle cell anemia/trait, diabetes. There is a high risk of developing chronic renal lesions in later life. It is also associated with: Hypertension Anemia Premature labor Intrauterine growth retardation Urinary tract abnormalities in recurrent cases. Diagnostic criteria: A positive bacterial count of the same species - over 1,00,000/mL Organisms in midstream clean-catch specimen of urine on two occasions No symptoms of urinary infection Treatment: Single-dose therapy - Amoxicillin 3g, Nitrofurantoin 200mg Regular 10-14 days therapy - Amoxicillin, Nitrofurantoin, Cephalexin, or Amoxiclav Recurrent cases need to be treated until delivery with prophylactic doses.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman presented to the clinic with severe lower abdominal pain and dysuria at 28 weeks of gestation. Suprapubic tenderness was noted on palpation. Urine examination revealed pyuria with microscopic hematuria. All of the following can be used to treat this condition except?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystitis. Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibiotic, is contraindicated in pregnancy as it causes cartilage and bone defects in the fetus. Antibiotics are used for treating cystitis in pregnancy. Antibiotics safe in pregnancy include: Penicillin group Cephalosporins Erythromycin Metronidazole (except in the 1st trimester) Antibiotics unsafe in pregnancy include: Tetracycline Aminoglycoside Chloramphenico Metronidazole(in the first trimester) Fluoroquinolones
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which stage of pregnancy is most often complicated by acute pyelonephritis?
explanation: Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy most often complicates 2nd trimester of pregnancy. Acute pyelonephritis occurs more commonly in those with preexisting renal disease. It is caused by E. coli >> Streptococcus sp., S.aureus > Enterobacter, Klebsiella sp. Clinical features include: Fever with chills Loin pain Vomiting Right-sided renal angle tenderness Patients may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome due to endotoxin-mediated alveolar injury. Hemolysis can also occur due to endotoxins, leading to anemia. Treatment includes intravenous fluids with antibiotics.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following congenital infections are associated with the triad of Gregg in a neonate?
explanation: Triad of Gregg is seen in a neonate infected congenitally with rubella virus. The features include: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) Cataract Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) Other infections which cause congenital malformations are: Organis m Effect Toxopla sma Hydro/microcephaly, convuls ions, chorioretinitis, cerebral calcification Varicell a Skin scarring, hypoplastic li mbs, eye defects, microcepha ly Parvovir us Non-immune hydrops Syphilis Hutchinson's triad:Interstitia l keratitisHutchinson's teeth Eighth nerve deafness
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about toxoplasmosis in pregnancy?
options: Maximum transmission and damage in 1st trimester
Maximum transmission in 1st trimester and maximum damage in 3rd trimester
Maximum damage in 1st trimester and maximum transmission in 3rd trimester
Maximum transmission and damage in 3rd trimester
explanation: Toxoplasmosis causes maximal complications in 1st trimester and is maximally transmitted in the 3rd trimester. This is because the risk of transmission increases and the risk of damage decreases as pregnancy progresses further. Clinical features of affected neonates include: Hydrocephalus or microcephaly Chorioretinitis Intracranial calcifications Convulsions Low birthweight Hepatosplenomegaly Jaundice Anemia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman presents for a regular antenatal check-up at 12 weeks of gestation. She works at a rescue center that held an adoption drive for cats a few weeks ago. On examination, mild cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Sabin-Feldman dye test is positive. Which of the following will be used to treat this condition?
explanation: The given scenario points to a diagnosis of maternal toxoplasmosis. It is treated using spiramycin. Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide is used when fetal infections are confirmed. It should be avoided in the first trimester. Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. Cats are definitive hosts. It can be transmitted to humans either by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat or by ingestion of oocysts via exposure to cat litter or soil. Acute infection is diagnosed either by the presence of IgG and IgM antibodies or by a four-fold increase in paired specimens 4 weeks apart.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A per-vaginal examination performed on a lady in labor reveals multiple painful tiny vesicular ulcers over the vulva and vaginal walls. A slide showing the microscopic findings is given below. What is the best step in the management of delivery in this patient?
options: Give tocolytics and treat the infection
explanation: Painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy are suggestive of herpes virus infection. The cytological image showing multinucleate giant cells, Tzanck cells confirms the diagnosis of HSV. The best step in the management of delivery in this patient is a cesarean section. Herpes infection in the newborn may occur during birth, particularly if the mother has genital lesions due to HSV-2. In such cases, a cesarean section may prevent neonatal infection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a pregnant woman with herpes simplex infection, the risk of transmission to the fetus will be maximum during which stage of the pregnancy?
explanation: The maximum risk of HSV transmission from mother to child is during labor. This is due to the shedding of the virus from an active infection in the genital tract during delivery. HSV is a sexually transmitted infection. There is a higher risk of transmission during primary infections than with recurrences. Reactivations are less severe. Cesarean delivery reduces the risk of vertical transmission during labor and is indicated in: Cases of active genital lesions - both primary and recurrent Prodromal symptoms - like vulval itching or burning Suspicious lesions should be sent for PCR testing or culture. Antiviral treatment with acyclovir should be given if found positive. Women without active genital lesions, without symptoms, or those with active lesions in non-genital areas can undergo normal labor and delivery. Management of HSV infection during pregnancy: Primary or recurrent infections during pregnancy - Oral acyclovir or valacyclovir Severe or disseminated infection - IV acyclovir followed by oral acyclovir Pain relief - Oral analgesics or topical anesthetics Urinary retention - catheterization.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between .
explanation: The risk of developing fetal varicella syndrome (congenital varicella syndrome) is highest when the mother develops varicella infection between 13 to 20 weeks. Congenital varicella syndrome occurs in 2% of infants with maternal varicella between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation and in 0.4% of infants before 13 weeks of gestation. It is rare after 20 weeks. Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like pattern (zig-zag scarring), and limb hypoplasia (shown below). They can also present with neurological abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation), ophthalmic features (chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataract), and renal and autonomic system abnormalities (hydronephrosis, neurogenic bladder). Low birth weight is also common. Infants born to mothers with varicella in the period from 5 days prior to delivery up to 2 days after delivery are at high risk for severe neonatal varicella. They acquire the infection transplacentally. Since the mother has not developed a strong antibody response, the infant lacks the protective effect of maternal anti-varicella-zoster virus (VZV) antibodies. Therefore varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) should be administered as soon as possible after birth to newborns whose mothers have varicella 5 days before and up to 2 days after the delivery. Since perinatally acquired varicella can be potentially life-threatening, the infant should typically be treated with intravenous acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hours) when lesions appear. For pregnant women with uncomplicated primary varicella or herpes zoster that does not require hospitalization, the recommended treatment is oral acyclovir (800 mg five times daily for seven days).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman delivered a baby with limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions. Which of the following infections did the mother most likely have during her pregnancy?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. It is seen in babies born to mothers who had chickenpox infections during their pregnancy. Features of congenital varicella syndrome include: Chorioretinitis Limb hypoplasia Cicatricial skin lesions Microphthalmia Cerebral cortical atrophy Growth restriction Hydronephrosis The image below shows limb hypoplasia in fetal varicella syndrome:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a pregnant woman with syphilis, the infection can get transmitted to the fetus during which stage in pregnancy?
explanation: A pregnant woman with syphilis can transmit T. pallidum to the fetus at 10–15 weeks of gestation. Features of congenital syphilis include: Hutchinson's triad - It is seen in late congenital syphilis. Hutchinson’s teeth - small widely spaced, peg-shaped, notched upper incisors Interstitial keratitis Sensorineural hearing loss Mulberry molars Rhagades - deep fissuring of mucocutaneous junctions in the nares, lips, and anus Frontal bossing Saber shins - anterior tibial bowing Clutton’s joints - painless, symmetric hydrarthrosis of the knees and elbows The image below shows Hutchinson incisors. Note: The risk of fetal infection during untreated early maternal syphilis is ~75–95%, decreasing to ~35% for maternal syphilis of >2 years duration.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are posted in the labor room. While inspecting the placenta to rule out any abnormalities, you notice that it appears pale and enlarged. Which of the following infections does the mother most likely have?
explanation: Enlarged and pale placenta is due to infection by syphilis. Other clinical manifestations and complications include: Spontaneous abortion Stillbirth Non-immune hydrops Intrauterine growth restriction Perinatal death.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sexually active woman presents with amenorrhea for the past 3 months and a history of a painless genital ulcer. UPT is positive and routine antenatal tests revealed a reactive VDRL report. What is the dose of benzathine penicillin that should be given for this patient?
options: 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection
2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally for 14 days
2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of early syphilis in a pregnant woman. 2.4 million units of benzathine penicillin should be given intramuscularly as a single injection. Treatment of syphilis includes: Early syphilis - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection Late syphilis (>1 year duration) - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses Treatment of neurosyphilis: Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3–4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10–14 days Procaine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally four times daily, both for 10–14 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman at 24 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and the following rash for 3 weeks. Urinalysis showed proteinuria and anti-Smith antibodies were positive. Which of the following complications is least likely in this patient?
explanation: The above scenario points to a diagnosis of SLE. Preterm labor is a complication in pregnant women with SLE, not post-term delivery. Complications in a pregnant patient with SLE include: Thrombophilia Preterm labor Hypertension, eclampsia, and preeclampsia Anemia Thrombocytopenia Stroke Renal failure Features of neonatal lupus include: Cardiac abnormalities - Complete heart blocks Cutaneous lupus Hepatobiliary diseases - liver failure, transient conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, transient transaminase elevations Hematologic abnormalities - thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, or anemia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with HIV presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 35 weeks of gestation. Investigations revealed a viral load of >1000 copies/ml. What will be the best mode of delivery in this patient?
explanation: Cesarean delivery is the preferred mode of delivery in a woman with HIV viral load above 1000 copies/ml at 34-36 weeks of gestation. Cesarean delivery is usually scheduled at 38 weeks of gestation, or two weeks before the due date. Pregnant women with HIV on ART throughout pregnancy, with a viral load <1000 copies/mL evaluated within 4-6 weeks of delivery, may choose to have a vaginal delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriate management?
options: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
explanation: ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeeding women with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count. *Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with HIV on antiretroviral therapy is in labor. Which of the following will be given to her newborn baby prophylactically?
options: 12 weeks of zidovudine, nevirapine and lamivudine
explanation: In India, according to the NACO guidelines, nevirapine is given in the syrup form for 6 weeks to an infant of a mother who is on long-term ART. In infants born to mothers with HIV who are not on ART, syrup nevirapine should be continued for 12 weeks. According to the NIH guidelines, zidovudine should be given to the neonate for 4 weeks.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The risk of developing a stroke is highest during what period of gestation in a pregnant woman?
explanation: The highest incidence of stroke in pregnancy is 5 days to 2 weeks postpartum. This is followed by the intrapartum period. There is an increased risk of cerebrovascular thrombosis post-delivery due to a sudden reduction in the blood volume, a fall in the level of circulating antithrombotic factors, and venous stasis. Risk factors of stroke in pregnancy include: Hypertensive disorders Gestational diabetes Antepartum hemorrhage Cesarean delivery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
Which of the following is false regarding epilepsy in pregnancy?
It increases risk of fetal malformations by 5%
options: Seizure risk is more at the time of delivery
Seizure frequency increases in 30% of women
Ideal contraceptive in breast feeding mother with seizure disorder is DMPA
explanation: Untreated epilepsy has no association with fetal malformations. Anti-epileptic medications such as valproate, phenytoin, etc., are responsible for fetal malformations. Seizure frequency is unchanged in 50%, increased in 30%, and decreased in 20% women. Seizure risk increases during labor as pain and hyperventilation decrease the seizure threshold. The ideal contraceptive in a breastfeeding mother with a seizure disorder is depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA), as progestins increase the seizure threshold. Disorders of Menstruation
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding amenorrhoea?
options: MRKH syndrome is associated with secondary amenorrhoea
Primary amenorrhoea is seen in Turner syndrome
Primary amenorrhea is absence of menarche by 13 years
Secondary amenorrhea is absence of menses for 6 months
explanation: Primary amenorrhoea is seen in Turner syndrome Amenorrhoea is a symptom and not a disease entity. It refers to the absence of menstruation that can be physiological or pathological. Primary amenorrhea is defined as an absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years. At age 13 years, if no menses have occurred and there is a complete absence of secondary sexual characteristics such as breast development, evaluation for primary amenorrhea should begin. Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome), androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Turner syndrome present with primary amenorrhea. In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure, resulting in hypogonadism and amenorrhea. Secondary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menses for 3 or more months or fewer than 9 cycles per year after the establishment of regular menstrual cycles. Polycystic ovarian syndrome and hypothyroidism are associated with secondary amenorrhea. Pregnancy is the most common physiological cause of secondary amenorrhea.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: While evaluating a patient with secondary amenorrhoea, you administer her estrogen and progesterone. However, withdrawal bleeding is not seen. What is the likely site of lesion here?
explanation: The absence of withdrawal bleeding after the estrogen-progesterone challenge test points towards a local endometrial lesion. Estrogen–progesterone challenge test is indicated as an investigation in case of secondary amenorrhea. It depends on estrogen-primed endometrium being present in the uterus. Procedure: Ethinyl estradiol 0.02 mg or conjugated equine estrogen 1.25 mg is to be taken daily for 25 days. Medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily is added from day 15–25. Alternately, one course of oral contraceptive pill is given and to observe whether withdrawa bleeding occurs or not. Results: If there is no bleeding, a local endometrial lesion is present such as uterine synechiae. This is to be confirmed by HSG or hysteroscopy. If withdrawal bleeding occurs, the endometrium is responsive but the endogenous estrogen production is inadequate. Hence, the defect lies in the ovary, hypothalamus, or pituitary.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The risk of Asherman syndrome is highest if D&C is done for .
explanation: The risk of developing Asherman syndrome is the highest if D&C is done for postpartum hemorrhage. This is because the postpartum uterus is larger and bulkier. Hence, a greater area of the uterine wall is curetted. This increases the risk of developing Asherman syndrome. Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium. The treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding oligomenorrhea?
options: Menstruation occurring at an interval of more than 30 days
explanation: Oligomenorrhoea can progress to develop into amenorrhoea. Oligomenorrhoea means infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring at intervals of more than 38 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with uterine fibroids complains of frequent menstruation with an average cycle duration of 19-21 days. What is this menstrual irregularity called?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of polymenorrhoea, also known as epimenorrhea. It refers to frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less. The definitions of various menstrual cycle irregularities are: Amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menstruation. Intermenstrual bleeding refers to occasional episodes of bleeding (usually not excessive) that occur between otherwise normal menstrual cycles. Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed cycles, but having scanty episodes of bleeding. Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed menstrual cycles with excessive bleeding (>80 mL in amount) and/or increased duration of flow (>8 days). Metrorrhagia refers to normal cyclical bleeding with superimposed irregularly timed episodes of bleeding. Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals. Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed cycles with intervals of more than 38 days. Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding menorrhagia?
options: Heavy and regularly timed episodes of bleeding
Amount of bleeding greater than 50 m
Duration of bleeding greater than 5 days
explanation: Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>8 days). Nowadays, menorrhagia has been replaced by the term heavy menstrual bleeding. This is defined as greater than 80 mL per cycle, which will result in anemia if recurrent Investigations done in case of menorrhagia: Complete blood count (CBC) - to rule out anemia and thrombocytopenia. Coagulation studies are ordered only in case of clinical suspicion and correlation with CBC Sonohysterography/Hysteroscopy - to diagnose endometrial polyps and fibroids Endometrial biopsy - in case of suspected endometrial hyperplasia Transvaginal ultrasound - supplements biopsy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
explanation: Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy. Menorrhagia/heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding, >80mL of blood loss, or >8 days of bleeding per menstrual period. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months). It is managed as follows: Medical - first line of treatment. NSAIDs Tranexamic acid OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails Mirena IUCD GnRH agonists Blood transfusion, if required Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis: Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc (option B) Uterine artery embolization (option A) Uterine tamponade Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail (option D)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of menometrorrhagia?
explanation: Menometrorrhagia refers to menstrual bleeding at frequent intervals. Menometrorrhagia means excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals. It can be caused by cervical cancer and granulosa cell tumors.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient who had undergone a dilatation and curettage procedure comes to the clinic 6 months later for a follow-up visit. She informs you that since the procedure, she has had scanty blood loss during menses which only lasts for 1-2 days. What is this pattern of bleeding called?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the pattern of bleeding is called hypomenorrhea. Hypomenorrhea along with a prior history of dilatation and curettage are suggestive of partial Asherman's syndrome. Hypomenorrhoea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding. It can be seen in: Partial Asherman's syndrome - uterine synechiae, causing scarring Oral contraceptive use Perimenopausal age group
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the gynecology OPD with complaints of occasional bleeding PV between her usual menstrual cycles. Which of the following is true about her condition?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of intermenstrual bleeding, also known as metrorrhagia. Usually, this is scanty, and not excessive. Intermenstrual bleeding or metrorrhagia refers to irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding. It can be caused by: Ovulation (physiological) Polyps Cervical cancer Lower genital tract infections etc.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young girl with McCune-Albright syndrome is noted to have precocious menstruation. This condition is defined as the occurrence of menstruation at .
explanation: Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years. Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years. McCune Albright syndrome is associated with cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (and precocious menstruation), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia leading to recurrent fractures. The image given below shows cafe-au-lait spots.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 45-year-old woman presents with profuse, painless vaginal bleeding. She has a history of 6-8 weeks of amenorrhea and her UPT is negative. On ultrasound, endometrial thickness is 21mm. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica. Metropathia hemorrhagica is a form of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding. It is characterized by continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhea. It is usually seen in the age group of 40-45 years. A history of menorrhagia may be present. On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are: Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as swiss cheese pattern Absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of corkscrew glands Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity Corpus luteum is absent One or both ovaries may contain a cyst Option A: Senile endometritis occurs after menopause when the endometrium is thin and atrophic. It may be associated with accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity. Option B: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow is present. Option D: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which does 'I' stand for in the PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding?
explanation: The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands for iatrogenic causes. AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic: Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB. Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum. PALM-COEIN classification of AUB: Polyp (AUB-P): Endometrial polyps Endocervical polyps Adenomyosis (AUB-A) Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as: Submucosal (SM) Other (O) Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) Endometrial hyperplasia Endometrial carcinoma Coagulopathy (AUB-C) von Willebrand's disease Hemophilias Ovarian causes (AUB-O) PCOD Hypothyroidism Hyperprolactinemia. Endometrial causes (AUB-E) Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I) Intrauterine contraceptive devices Anticoagulants Tricyclic antidepressants Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as Arteriovenous malformations Myometrial hypertrophy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 28-year-old P1L1 woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and occasional spotting between cycles. What is the first investigation to be done for her?
explanation: The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in the reproductive age group is urine -hCG estimation. This is done to rule out pregnancy. In the reproductive age group, anovulatory uterine bleeding is encountered less often. Therefore, pregnancy must be excluded. Pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, ectopic pregnancies, and molar pregnancies may present with AUB, hence these need to be ruled out by urine -hCG levels. This is done for all women in the reproductive age group. Other investigations to be done for AUB are: Pap smear - to rule out cervical cancer and preinvasive lesions (CIN). Transabdominal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs and lesions such as endometria hyperplasia, polyps, fibroids, etc. Transvaginal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs. It is done after evaluating -hCG. This is more comfortable for a patient compared to a transabdominal ultrasound as it doesn't require a full bladder.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with AUB-E, who was unresponsive to medical management, underwent a hysteroscopic ablation. Which of the following is false about this procedure?
explanation: Fertility is not preserved with ablative procedures, because the endometrium and superficial myometrium are destroyed. In ablative procedures, the uterus is preserved, and hysterectomy is avoided. The endometrium along with 2-3mm of superficial myometrium is destroyed. Various methods of endometrial ablation include: Hysteroscopic endometrial ablation Transcervical endometrial resection (TCRE) - now replaced by bipolar electrode called Versapoint Radiofrequency induced thermal ablation (RITEA) Microwave ablation NovaSure - impedance-controlled endometrial ablation Bilateral uterine artery embolization Uterine tamponade
subject: OBGYN

question_text: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated?
explanation: Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) as it increases the risk of ascending genital infection. D&C is a minor gynecological procedure of dilating the cervix and curetting the endometrial tissue from the uterine cavity.
