Diagnostic indications of D&C include AUB, secondary amenorrhea to detect tubercular endometritis, postmenopausal bleeding to rule out endometrial cancer or hyperplasia, and infertility due to genital TB. Therapeutic indications of D&C include missed abortion, incomplete abortion, retained products of conception, and endometrial polypectomy. Absolute contraindication of D&C includes Suspected/ desired pregnancy and lower genital tract infection. However, D&C is performed in some cases with genital infections like septic abortion (where retained pieces of placenta act as a nidus and need to be removed) and pyometra (as there is cervical obstruction with superinfection of menstrual blood and cellular debris, D&C is appropriate to remove the obstruction as well as the source of infection) Complications of D&C include ascending infection, cervical tear with bleeding, incompetent os, uterine perforation, and ashermann syndrome.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 31-year-old woman presented with acute abdominal pain and spotting. UPT was negative. On examination, she was tachycardic and afebrile. Guarding and abdominal tenderness was present. CT abdomen showed air in the uterine wall and pneumoperitoneum. Which of the following is her condition most likely to be a complication of?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine perforation. In a non-pregnant uterus, uterine perforation is most likely to occur due to dilatation and curettage. In pregnancy and uterine malignancies, the uterus is soft. Hence, uterine perforation is common during surgeries. The etiology of uterine perforation is as follows: Insertion of intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCD)- due to the lack of provider experience. Spontaneous migration of IUCD within the myometrium Dilatation and curettage (D&C) Hysteroscopy - diagnostic (e.g, hysteroscopic biopsy) or therapeutic (adhesiolysis) Laparoscopy It can present with fever, acute abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and bleeding pv. Imaging reveals air within the uterine wall or pneumoperitoneum. The management is as follows: Conservative management - Fundal injuries are managed conservatively, as the myometrium contracts around the defect. Surgical management: Small defects can be repaired laparoscopically or hysteroscopically. Emergency laparotomy - as abdominal viscera may prolapse through the defect. Hysterectomy - if the defect is large, and the patient has completed her family, hysterectomy is done as last resort.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An 18-year-old girl presents to you with cramping abdominal pain. It starts at the onset of menses and is more pronounced in the first two days. Which condition is she likely suffering from?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of spasmodic dysmenorrhea. It presents with cramping pain at the onset of menses which is more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation. Dysmenorrhoea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation. It can be classified as follows: Etiological classification: Primary dysmenorrhoea - no identifiable pelvic pathology. Commonly occurs in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhoea - is associated with pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis. Unilateral dysmenorrhoea can occur in a rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus, IUCD users, and cervical stenosis. Clinical classification: Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea: Most prevalent Cramping pain at the onset of menses, more pronounced on the first 2 days. Occurs due to myometrial contractions due to increased PGF2 Common in adolescents and young women Congestive dysmenorrhoea: Pelvic pain and pelvic discomfort occurs, a few days before menses begin Occurs due to pelvic venous congestion Seen in pelvic endometriosis, PID, fibroids, and IUCD users Membranous dysmenorrhoea: Least prevalent The endometrium is shed as a cast at the time of menstruation The passage of the cast is associated with painful uterine cramps
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An increase in which of the following is spasmodic pain during dysmenorrhoea attributed to?
explanation: Spasmodic pain is attributed to myometrial contractions occuring due to increased PGF2 . This is secreted under the effect of progesterone. Progesterone is secreted after ovulation by the corpus luteum. Hence, in anovulatory cycles, menstruation is not accompanied by spasmodic pain.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of mood swings and depression 10 days prior to her menses. This is associated with fatigue, breast tenderness, and bloating. Her symptoms resolve once menses begin. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
Evening primrose oi
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine, sertraline, and paroxetine are the treatment of choice for PMDD. DSM-5 defines premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) as the presence of at least five of the associated symptoms most of the time during the premenstrual week. Symptoms improve within a few days after menses and are minimal in the postmenstrual period. These symptoms include: Marked emotional lability Marked irritability or anger Marked depressive mood, self-deprecating thoughts Marked anxiety Decreased interest in activities Difficulty in concentration Lethargy Appetite changes Bloating Breast tenderness Weight gain Treatment of PMDD is as follows: Lifestyle changes such as - stress reduction, adequate sleep, and exercise, reduction in caffeine intake, smoking cessation Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) - fluoxetine, paroxetine, sertraline Evening primrose oil - to treat breast tenderness Ovulation suppression - danazol, leuprolide, drospirenone Other less proven methods - cognitive behavioral therapy, calcium supplements, etc. Note: Premenstrual syndrome has no scientific definition. The constellation of symptoms is now defined under PMDD. Uro-gynecology
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with urinary incontinence was diagnosed to have a vesicovaginal fistula. What is the most common cause of this condition?
explanation: Vesicovaginal fistulas are mostly acquired. In developing countries, the most common cause is obstetric trauma. In developed countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible for 90% of the vesicovaginal fistulas. Congenital genitourinary fistulas and fistulas resulting from infectious conditions are rare.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following types of genitourinary fistulas has not been reported?
explanation: Uterourethral type of fistula has not been reported. A genitourinary fistula is defined as an abnormal communication between the urinary system (ureter, bladder, urethra) and the genital systems (vagina, cervix, uterus). Most genitourinary fistulas are acquired. In developing countries, the most common cause is obstetric trauma. In developed countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible for 90% of the vesicovaginal fistulas. Congenital genitourinary fistulas are rare. If present, they are commonly associated with other renal or urogenital abnormalities.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following does not cause genitourinary fistulas?
explanation: Hysteroscopy is not an etiology for genitourinary fistulae. It can occur following hysterectomy. Most genitourinary fistulas are acquired. Its causes are enumerated below: Prolonged obstructed labor - major cause in developing countries Difficult instrumental or manipulative deliveries Injury to bladder or ureter during hysterectomy - major cause in developed contries Congenital (rare) Other causes include: Radiation Malignancy Trauma Infections - PID, tuberculosis etc.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A P1L1 woman presents with constant dribbling of urine. She gives a history of unattended vaginal delivery following a difficult and prolonged labor 3 months back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a vesicovaginal fistula. Vesicovaginal fistulas usually present with: Constant dribbling of urine from the vagina Excoriation in the groin region due to constant leakage of urine History of pelvic surgery, vaginal delivery or prolonged labor Amenorrhea may be present On examination, the fistula may be visualized by observing urine collection in the vagina. Bimanual examination reveals its fixity and extent. Note: Ureterovaginal fistulas usually occur following accidental ureteric injury during C-sections in developing countries.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most useful test in vesicovaginal fistula?
explanation: Cystoscopy is the most useful test and also the investigation of choice for vesicovaginal fistula (VVF). Cystoscopy or cystourethroscopy helps to visualize the size of the fistulas, the exact location of multiple fistulas and their proximity to the ureteral orifice. It can also assess the bladder mucosa for any injuries. The 3-swab test (Option B) is done to identify the types of genitourinary fistula. In this test, three sterile pieces of cotton swabs are serially placed in the vaginal cavity, while 50-100ml of methylene blue solution is instilled in the bladder using a catheter. The cotton swabs are placed one at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. Interpretation: Uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, as seen in ureterovaginal fistula Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, as seen in vesicovaginal fistula Lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra,as seen in urethrovaginal fistula The below image shows the 3-swab test. Option C: MRI is usually not needed for the diagnosis of VVF. They can be used to study vesicouterine fistulas. Option D: Cystometry is done to measure the capacity of the bladder. It is used to investigate urge incontinence.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient comes with a complaint of dribbling of urine from the vagina during micturition. She has a history of obstructed labor. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done, and the lowest swab gets stained. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a urethrovaginal fistula. Urethrovaginal fistulas have the following clinical features: Continent and dry at rest Urinary dribbling during micturition Fistulous opening is seen on per speculum examination In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter. Interpretation: The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula The given image shows the 3-swab test.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of colporrhaphy is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following investigations is not preferred in this patient?
explanation: MRI is not preferred for a case of vesicovaginal fistula as other investigations are more specific and useful. Investigations in VVF include: Urine culture - to treat concurrent UTI. Ultrasound abdomen - kidney, bladder and ureter should be observed for the presence of a urinoma or hydronephrosis. Intravenous pyelography - to look for hydronephrosis Cystoscopy - used to visualise the number of fistulae and their location. Methylene blue 3-swab test in urinary fistulae - A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra and 50-100ml methylene blue is injected. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. It is interpreted as follows: The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula. Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula. The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula. The given image shows the methylene blue 3-swab test.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 40-year-old woman came for a follow-up visit one week following a vaginal hysterectomy. You note she has developed a large vesicovaginal fistula. What is the best time for fistula repair in this case?
explanation: In the given scenario, the best time to perform fistula repair is 6 weeks after the inciting surgery. In uncomplicated fistulas, early surgical intervention is preferred within the first 24 to 48 hours following the inciting surgery. This avoids the brisk postoperative inflammatory response. However, if extensive and severe inflammation is present, repair of fistula can be delayed to 6 weeks after the surgery. This is usually done in a patient who has undergone major surgery, During this delay it is ensured that all the tissue inflammation has subsided, tissue vascularisation has improved and local infection has cleared. Estrogen therapy should be instituted in postmenopausal women in this time period. In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 34-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of blood in her urine. She informs you that this happens every month for 1 week and stops on its own. She underwent a
C-section 1 year ago and has no history of incontinence. During clinical examination, a catheter is inserted into the bladder, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows the catheter emerging from the cervical os. This, along with the history of cyclical hematuria, is suggestive of Youssef syndrome seen in a case of vesicouterine fistula. Vesicouterine fistulas can develop after cesarean section, uterine rupture, and placenta accreta. Most cases present weeks to years later. Vesicouterine fistulas can present with cyclical hematuria, urinary incontinence or complete continence, menstrual abnormalities, and urinary tract infections. Youssef syndrome is seen in cases of vesicouterine fistulas, and it is associated with a classic triad: Amenorrhea Cyclical hematuria - also called menouria: Menstrual blood trickles into the bladder through the fistula, causing hematuria Urinary continence (there is no vaginal leakage of urine) Hysteroscopy and cystoscopy are gold-standard investigations. Vesicouterine fistulas are treated as follows: Prolonged bladder catheterization - leads to spontaneous closure Surgical repair via abdominal route
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Intravenous pyelography in a patient suspected to have a genitourinary fistula revealed a ureteric fistula. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: It is mostly caused by gynecological surgeries
Continuous dribbling of urine occurs, but the patient can also micturate
In 3-swab test, the swab is stained blue
Hydronephrosis is present on the affected side
explanation: Swabs stained with methylene blue are obtained in a bladder fistula and not in a ureteric fistula. Ureteric fistulas can present with the following features: Constant urinary dribbling Flank pain or loin tenderness Renal angle tenderness Fever Hematuria Oliguria Ureteric fistulas are most commonly caused by iatrogenic trauma during pelvic surgeries, especially gynecological surgeries. An excretory urogram (intravenous pyelography) or a CT urogram are the investigations of choice. Hydronephrosis may be present on the affected side. It is managed by performing a ureteroneocystostomy and percutaneous nephrostomy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You need to locate the ureter while performing an abdominal hysterectomy. Which of the following features will help you identify it?
explanation: The ureter is identified intraoperatively by the following features: Ovarian artery crosses anterior to it It is cord-like on palpation Peristalsis occurs on palpation It has a pale, glistening appearance Uterine artery crosses it, from lateral to medial, 2 cm lateral to the cervix
subject: OBGYN

question_text: During post-op rounds, you note one of the patients has developed fever and flank pain. The nurses inform you that her abdominal drain outputs have been consistently high. Which of the following procedures has the highest incidence of the complication suspected here?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of ureteric injury. The highest incidence of this complication is seen with Wertheim’s hysterectomy. Urinary tract injury occurs almost exclusively in major gynecologic surgery that involves surgical dissection in proximity to the ureters or bladder. Vaginal hysterectomy tends to have lower rates of ureteric injuries than open (abdominal, Wertheim) or laparoscopic routes. The highest risk for ureteric injury is associated with the following procedures: Surgical debulking of gynecological cancers Advanced pelvic reconstructive surgery Laparoscopic hysterectomy Patients with ureteric injuries have a complicated post-operative period. They can present with the following features: Fever Flank pain Abdominal distension Prolonged paralytic ileus - bowel sounds are absent High drain outputs, in case abdominal drains are placed. CT urogram and retrograde pyelography are the investigations of choice. They reveal urinary extravasation from the ureter. Ureteric injuries are prevented by careful division of tissue planes during pelvic or genitourinary surgeries. The condition is managed by prompt surgical repair by ureteroureterostomy or percutaneous ureterostomy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with uterine fibroids is set to undergo a hysterectomy. While obtaining informed consent for the procedure, you counsel her about the potential risk of ureteric injury. Which of the following sites is the injury least likely to occur at?
explanation: Iatrogenic injury to the ureter is unlikely to occur at the ureteropelvic junction during gynaecological surgeries like a hysterectomy. Ureteric injury is most commonly caused by gynecological surgeries such as laparoscopic hysterectomy, abdominal hysterectomy, etc. It can occur at: The infundibulopelvic ligament on the lateral pelvic wall In the ureteric canal when the uterine vessels are ligated Near the internal cervical os Near the uterosacral ligament
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula?
explanation: Improper suturing of complete perineal tears is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula. Rectovaginal fistulas occur most commonly due to obstetric causes such as perineal tears, obstructed labor, and instrumental deliveries. Other causes include: Tuberculosis Lymphogranuloma venerum Bartholinitis - rupture of an abscess into the rectum can cause a fistula Diverticulitis Carcinoma cervix Radiotherapy - can cause ulceration which can develop into a fistula
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a prerequisite for maintaining female urinary continence?
options: Normal urethral closure pressure more than 20 cm of water
Internal urinary sphincter must lie above levator ani
Innervation of internal sphincter by Onuf's nucleus
explanation: The external urinary sphincter is innervated by the Onuf's nucleus, but not the internal one. The following factors are prerequisites for continence in women: Position of internal urinary sphincter lies above levator ani muscles Normal urethral closure pressure is >20 cm of water Urethrovesical angle >100 The tone of pelvic floor muscles
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An elderly woman presented with a mass per vaginum and incontinence. She complains that she has to push the mass inwards to be able to urinate normally. What is the type of incontinence seen here?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocele in a case of genital prolapse. Stress incontinence is seen in these cases. In stress incontinence, involuntary leakage of urine occurs when there is increased intraabdominal pressure, such as during laughing, sneezing, or coughing. There is no normal urge to pass urine. Option A: Urge incontinence is the involuntary voiding of urine when there is an imminent urge to urinate. Option C: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs due to defects anywhere in the pathway of the micturition reflex, e.g., spinal cord trauma, diabetes etc. It presents with with urgency or urge incontinence.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A gynecologist performs a Marshall and Bonney test in the OPD on an elderly woman. Which of the following conditions is this used to diagnose?
explanation: Marshall and Bonney's test is used to diagnose genuine stress incontinence. It also helps in assessing how successful a surgical repair will be. It is performed as follows: Test Marshall test Bonney's test Procedure The vagina in the region of th e bladder neck is infiltrated with local anesthetic and it is elevated. Two fingers are placed in the vagina at the urethrovesical j unction and the bladder neck is elevated. Positive tes t Absence of leakage of urine o n straining or coughing Absence of leakage of urine o n straining or coughing
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A wrestler in the post-partum period complains of spurting of urine during weight-lifting practice. Which of the following investigations will help aid your diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. It can be diagnosed with the help of the Q-tip test. This test is performed by placing a xylocaine-covered Q-tip cotton swab stick in the patient's urethra. Initially, the stick will be parallel to the floor. Then the patient is asked to strain or cough. Normally the stick will reach an angle of around 10-15°. In genuine stress incontinence (GSI), this angle increases by 20° or more. A positive test indicates a sufficient degree of bladder neck descent. Unfortunately, all patients with GSI may not have a positive test, and it is not specific. Tests done for GSI(Genuine stress incontinence) include: Stress test Cotton swab stick test Marshall and Bonney test Urethroscopy Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry etc
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young mother presented with dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. Marshall and Bonney's test was positive. What is the next step in management?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. In this case, the first line of treatment is conservative management. Stress incontinence is managed as follows: Conservative management: It is the first line of treatment. It includes: Kegel pelvic floor exercises for 4–6 months Electric/magnetic stimulation for nerve damage, magnetic stimulation Artificial urinary sphincter in neurological condition Vaginal cones It is also done in case surgery fails. Medical management: Estrogen cream in menopausal woman Venlafaxine 75 mg daily Imipramine 10–20 mg BD Surgical management: Kelly's repair - vaginal approac Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis. Burch colposuspension Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation Slings Tension-free vaginal taping Transobturator taping Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck Periurethral collagen injection Vaginal sling operations have the highest long term cure rate in cases of GSI (genuine stress incontinence). Their long term cure rate is more than 90%.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old primiparous woman with Grade 2 genuine stress incontinence did not respond to conservative management. Which of the following surgeries will not be beneficial for her condition?
explanation: Latzko procedure is not beneficial for a patient with genuine stress incontinence as it is done for vesicovaginal fistula. The various surgeries done for genuine stress incontinence (GSI) are as follows: Vaginal approac Kelly repair Pacey repair Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It is not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis. Burch colposuspension Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation Slings Tension-free vaginal taping Transobturator taping Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck Periurethral collagen injection
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 62-year-old woman presented with complaints of urinary urgency followed by involuntary escape of urine. What is the etiology of the condition she's likely suffering from?
options: Pelvic mass in pouch of Douglas
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of urge incontinence. It occurs due to detrusor instability. During normal micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts after being stimulated by the parasympathetic nerves. In detrusor instability, detrusor muscle contracts spontaneously or on provocation during filling of the bladder. It is often caused by overactivity of parasympathetic nerves. It is usually seen in older women and is caused by: Decreased bladder capacity - due to fibrosis Decreased sensation Central nervous system (CNS) inhibition - due to stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord involvement etc. It is associated with the following symptoms: Incontinence Urge to urinate Increased frequency Nocturia Urination during sexual intercourse and with the sound of water, hand-washing.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following patients with urinary incontinence will not have detrusor instability?
explanation: In patient 3, detrusor instability is not seen, as this is a case of functional incontinence. During normal micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts after being stimulated by the parasympathetic nerves. In detrusor instability, detrusor muscle contracts spontaneously or on provocation during filling of the bladder. It is often caused by the overactivity of parasympathetic nerves. It is seen usually in older women and is caused by: Decreased bladder capacity - due to fibrosis Decreased sensation Central nervous system (CNS) inhibition - due to stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord involvement etc. It is associated with the following symptoms: Incontinence Urge to urinate Increased frequency Nocturia Urination during sexual intercourse and with the sound of water, hand-washing. Treatment is initially conservative and include decreasing caffeine intake, smoking cessation, fluid restriction and weight reduction. Anticholinergic drugs and bladder training may also be tried. Note: Functional incontinence occurs in patients with disabilities, whose bladder movements are normal. However, due to environmental or physical barriers, involuntary leakage of urine occurs.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman presents to the ER with hypotension, tachycardia, and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable in the abdomen. USG abdomen revealed a large uterine wall defect. What's the most common cause of this condition?
C-section scar dehiscence
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. The most common cause is scar dehiscence due to a previous cesarean section. This can occur due to trial of labour after C-section, or due to spontaneous labor in a patient with previous C-section. Other causes of uterine rupture are: Prolonged induction or augmentation of labor Obstructed labor Blunt abdominal trauma during pregnancy Rupture of hematometra Rupture of pyometra Uterine rupture is managed as follows: Immediate cesarean section Depending upon the extent of rupture: Subtotal hysterectomy Hysterectomy Prolapse
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is an uncommon etiology for prolapse?
explanation: Congenital prolapse is an uncommon cause of prolapse. The most important etiological factors that lead to prolapse are the atonicity of the uterus and asthenia, which occurs due to aging and follows menopause. The other factors which lead to prolapse are as follows: Pregnancy Vaginal childbirth Menopause Aging Hypoestrogenism Peripheral nerve injury to the pudendal nerve Premature bearing down before full dilatation of the cervix Chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure Chronic bronchitis Constipation Obesity Spina bifida occulta Congenital weakness of pelvic floor muscles Abdominoperineal excision of rectum Surgeries such as Stamey and Pereyra operation for stress incontinence
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most important support of the pelvic viscera?
explanation: The most important support of the pelvic viscera is the levator ani muscle. The levator ani forms a large portion of the pelvic floor. It is composed of three separate paired muscles: Pubococcygeus Puborectalis Iliococcygeus Supports of the genital organs are given by DeLancey's levels of support. However, the broad ligament is a fold of the peritoneum, which doesn't provide support to pelvic organs.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman presented to you with the following finding. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
explanation: The given image shows uterine prolapse, for which an episiotomy is not a risk factor. Episiotomy shortens the second stage of labor and prevents the atonicity of the uterus, thus reducing the risk of prolapse. The risk factors for uterine prolapse are: Pregnancy Vaginal delivery Menopause Aging Hypoestrogenism Peripheral nerve injury to the pudendal nerve Premature bearing down before full dilatation of the cervix Chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure Chronic bronchitis Constipation Obesity Spina bifida occulta Congenital weakness of pelvic floor muscles Abdominoperineal excision of rectum Surgeries such as Stamey and Pereyra operation for stress incontinence
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of a mass descending PV. On examination, you note that the external os lies at the level of the introitus. What is the degree of uterine prolapse?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of 2nd degree prolapse.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is correctly matched between classification systems of prolapse and their reference point?
explanation: In Baden-Walker halfway system of classification of prolapse, the reference point is the hymen. Prolapse classification syste m Reference poi nt Shaws Introitus Baden Walker halfway Hymen POP-Q Hymen
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is seen in congenital elongation of the cervix?
options: The vaginal portion of the cervix gets elongated
The supravaginal portion of the cervix gets elongated
Both the vaginal and supravaginal portions of the cervix get elongated
There is no true elongation and it is a misnomer
explanation: In congenital elongation of the cervix, the vaginal portion of the cervix is elongated. The fornices are hence deep, and there is no accompanying vaginal prolapse. In 2nd and 3rd degree uterine prolapse, the supravaginal portion of the cervix gets stretched and elongated as it is well supported by the Mackenrodt’s ligaments, while the vaginal portion of the cervix prolapses with the vagina. In prolapse, the cervix can elongate to as much as 10cm in length. However, in procidentia, the entire uterus slides with the vagina, and hence the cervix retains its normal length.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following differential diagnosis will you not consider in a case of prolapse?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine prolapse. A retroverted uterus is not a differential diagnosis for uterine prolapse. However, retroversion of the uterus does occur with uterine prolapse. Differential diagnoses of genital prolapse include: Congenital elongation of the cervix - vaginal part of the cervix is elongated. In genital prolapse, supravaginal part is elongated and vaginal part is prolapsed. Vulval cyst and Gartner cyst - large cysts may mimic prolapse Cyst of the anterior vaginal wall - tense with well-defined margins and cannot be reduced on pressure. Urethral diverticula - rare, small, and situated low in the anterior vaginal wall. Urethroscopy helps in the diagnosis. Cervical fibroid polyp - cervix remains high up in its anatomical position. Chronic inversion of the uterus - Uterine sound is used to confirm the diagnosis. USG and aparoscopy will show fundal depression and the absence of uterine fundus in the pelvis. Rectal prolapse
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 57-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months. On examination, grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer are observed. What causes this ulcer?
explanation: Decubitus ulcer seen in uterine prolapse is due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes. Decubitus ulcer refers to the ulceration of prolapsed tissue which occurs due to the chronic dependent position causing venous congestion and stasis. It has a clean edge and usually heals well with prolapse reduction and daily packing with glycerine (hygroscopic agent) and acriflavine (antiseptic). It is a benign and non-infectious disease and does not require further investigation such as biopsy or culture.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a mass protruding from the vagina that increases in size on coughing and sneezing. Which of the following is not a complication of this condition?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse. Urge incontinence is not a complication of this condition. Complications of prolapse are: Damage to the ureter - can occur during Surgical repair Kinking due to procidentia Urinary tract infection - due to retention of urine in a cystocele Hydronephrosis and hydroureter Incarceration of the prolapse - the prolapsed organ becomes irreducible Decubitus ulcer Stress incontinence Squamous cell carcinoma over the decubitus ulcer (rare)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A multiparous woman notices a bulge at the vulva that diminishes in size on lying down. She also finds it difficult to initiate micturition. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocoele. A cystocele is the herniation of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It is usually associated with uterine prolapse, and presents with the following features: Mass descending in the vagina - Increases in size on straining and coughing Reduces on lying down, or manual reduction Difficulty in micturition - difficulty initiating, straining required Mass needs to be pushed inwards to urinate - repositioning of cystocele required Increased frequency of micturition Backache - due to stretching of uterosacral ligaments
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is correct about the POP-Q staging system?
options: Stage 4 involves complete eversion of the vagina.
In stage 3, the leading point is 1 cm above hymen.
Five reference points are present in the vagina.
The points above the hymen are described as plus.
explanation: The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system was described by the International Continence Society and has the following features: The hymen is taken as a fixed point. Six reference points are measured, using a scaled spatula: Two on the anterior vaginal wa Two on the apical vagina Two on the posterior vaginal wa Three measurements: The genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length. The points above the hymen are described as minus and points below as plus. Staging of pelvic organ prolapse according to the POP-Q system: Stag e Description Stag e 0 No descent of pelvic organs Stag e 1 The leading edge of the prola pse is>1 cm abovethe level of thehymen. Stag e 2 The leading edge of the prola pse is<1 cmproximal or distal to the hymen. Stag e 3 The leading point of prolapse is>1 cm belowthehymenbut protrudes no further than 2 c m less than the total length o f the vagina. Stag e 4 Completeeversionof the vagin a
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 35-year-old woman presents with pelvic pain, and a mass descending PV with increases in size on coughing. She is posted for a Fothergill repair. Which of the following is false about this procedure?
options: It is also known as Manchester operation
It does not preserve the reproductive functions
Recurrent abortions are a sequelae of this operation
explanation: Fothergill's operation preserves menstrual and reproductive functions. Fothergill's repair is also known as Manchester's operation. It is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. The steps are: Preliminary D and C Anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. Raw area covered with the vaginal mucosa. Mackenrodt ligaments sutured in the front of the cervix Colpoperineorrhaphy Since the uterus is preserved in this procedure, the patient is able to menstruate and can conceive and carry the pregnancy. However, fertility decreases due to the loss of cervical mucus. Moreover, cervical incompetence occurs, leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?
options: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
explanation: In the clinal scenario of a 55-year-old woman with third-degree uterine prolapse, the ideal management is vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair. Uterine prolapse is the descent of the uterus from its normal position which usually occurs due to laxity of ligaments that offer support, seen often due to childbirth, aging, or trauma. The uterine descent is clinically categorized into: First degree: the external os remains above the vaginal introitus Second degree: The external os protrudes below the vaginal introitus but the uterine body remains inside the vagina Third degree (Syn: Complete prolapse): The uterine, cervix, body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus Procidentia involves prolapse of the uterus with the entire vagina everted. The patient usually presents with a sense of heaviness in the pelvic region with lower back discomfort. Based on the structures involved the patient can additionally have urinary symptoms (like incontinence and urgency), bowel disturbances (constipation and tenesmus), or sexual discomfort during intercourse. Symptomatic uterine prolapse is managed surgically with different procedures based on the profile of the patient. Conservative management is done for old asymptomatic women with mild degree prolapse. A vaginal hysterectomy is recommended for patients who satisfy the following criteria: >40 years of age Have completed their families Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function Other options: Option A: Fothergill repair or Manchester operation is a procedure done to preserve the reproductive function and vaginal prolapse with supravaginal cervix elongation. It initially involves preliminary curettage with low amputation of the cervix. After Mackenrodt's ligament is plicated, anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy are performed. Option B: Sling operation (Purandare's operation) is indicated in congenital or nulliparous prolapse without cystocele. The procedure involves the extraperitoneal passage of rectus sheath strips joined to the anterior surface of the cervix by silk sutures. Option D: Shirodkar procedure is a type of abdominal sling surgery done in young women to retain menstrual and reproductive function. It involves using a sling to fix the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 75-year-old woman diagnosed with procidentia is posted for operative repair. During a pre-anesthetic check-up, she was determined to be medically unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended in her?
explanation: Le Fort’s repair is recommended in this case. This repair is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria: Elderly (>60 years) Do not wish to retain sexual function Medically unfit for major surgeries
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman presents to you with primary infertility. On examination, stage 2 uterine prolapse is present. What is the next step in management?
explanation: Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include: Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wa Shirodkar’s sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape Khanna’s abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis. Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectus compartment Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 67-year-old woman diagnosed with uterine prolapse, now presented with dyspareunia and fecal incontinence. After manually reducing the prolapse, a peristaltic bulge is seen in the posterior vaginal wall. What is the preferred method of management in this case?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of an enterocele associated with fecal incontinence. It is preferably repaired using an abdominal approach like Moschcowitz repair. An enterocele is herniation of the pouch of Douglas and small bowel loops into the rectovaginal septum. Enteroceles are most commonly associated with uterine prolapse. Patients present with the following clinical features: Fecal incontinence Sexual dysfunction Constipation/diarrhea Mass descending PV Pelvic pain or pelvic discomfort A bulge in the posterior vaginal wall: Upper 1/3rd - enterocele Lower 2/3rd - rectocele Peristalsis may be observed in the bulge Enterocele repair is done via the following methods: Vaginal approach - it is usually preferred over an abdominal approach. In McCall's culdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are used to suspend the vaginal vault. The posterior peritoneum and uterosacral ligaments are approximated. Abdominal approach - it is preferred in cases where there is associated fecal incontinence. It includes: Moschcowitz repair - the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse-string sutures. Halban's procedure - the peritoneal sac is obliterated using vertical sutures. This can also be done transvaginally. Option B: Purandare's sling operation is abdominal wall cervicopexy for uterine prolapse. It is done for young nulliparous women. Option D: Le Fort's repair is done in elderly patients with uterine prolapse, who are unfit for surgery. Note: Enteroceles may be present along with uterine prolapse. Failure to identify and repair it during vaginal hysterectomy can lead to vault prolapse.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: How many° of vault prolapse are there?
explanation: There are 3° of vault prolapse. Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of both abdominal and vaginal hysterectomy. It can also occur due to failure to identify and repair an enterocele during a hysterectomy. In vault prolapse, level 1 supports become weak and deficient. Risk factors apart from past history of surgery are: Advanced age Menopause - due to estrogen deficiency Parity Obesity Chronic cough
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 55-year-old woman presented with a mass bulging into the vagina, difficult intercourse, and back pain. She has a history of hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, you observe that the vaginal vault is protruding outside the introitus. What is the best management in this case?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of vault prolapse. Sacrospinous colpopexy is the gold standard management for vault prolapse. Vault prolapse presents with pelvic or back pain, the descent of the vault through the vagina, difficulties in intercourse, and difficulty in walking due to the mass. It is commonly associated with a cystocele or a rectocele. It can be prevented by identifying and repairing an enterocele and by attaching the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments to the vault during a hysterectomy. Vault prolapse is managed as follows: If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacra suspension If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation/colpopexy - the gold standard Laparoscopic colpopexy If the patient does not want to retain sexual function: Colpocleisis Le Fort's repair Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried Posterior intravaginal slingplasty Note: Kelly's repair and Burch colposuspension are done to manage stress incontinence.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman with uterine prolapse following pelvic trauma underwent a hysterectomy. A year later, she presents with vault prolapse. What would you not recommend for her?
explanation: In a young patient with vault prolapse, ring pessary is not recommended. Vault prolapse is managed as follows: If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacra suspension - The best method for vault prolapse. If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation. Laparoscopic colpopexy If the patient does not want to retain sexual function: Colpocleisis Le Fort's repair Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried Posterior intravaginal slingplasty
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The given instrument was used to treat a patient with uterine prolapse. Which of the following statements is false about this instrument?
options: It should be changed every 3 months.
It can be used in pregnant patients.
It may rarely cause carcinoma of vagina.
explanation: The given image shows a ring pessary, which is only a palliative treatment for genital prolapse. A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients and very elderly women. In these patients, it is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. After being placed, they should be changed every 3 months. They may cause vaginitis; dyspareunia; and, rarely, carcinoma if retained for a long time. The image below shows the types of pessaries:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained?
options: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva manouvre and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary.
explanation: The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's maneuver or cough and see if the pessary is in place. There is some level of descent of the pessary with these maneuvers is to be expected, but the pessary should return to its normal position when these efforts are stopped. If the pessary descends to the introitus with these maneuvers, then a larger size pessary should be tried. The pessary is well-fitted if you are able to slide the ring of the pessary up and down along the vaginal sidewall. It is well-fitted if you are able to insert one finger between the vaginal sidewall and the edge of the pessary. When the labia are separated, a well-supported pessary is not usually visible. The patient should be comfortable, and able to void urine with the pessary in place before leaving the clinic.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The deepest part of perineal body injury, which causes cystocoele, enterocoele and urethral descent is
explanation: Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent. Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces. Weakening of levator ani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra. The levator ani muscle is a complex unit, which consists of 3 muscle components namely Pubococcygeus (anterior fibers) Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis Puboanalis - elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed Puborectalis (intermediate fibers) Iliococcygeus (posterior fibers) Origin: The levator ani muscle has a linear origin from the pelvic surface of the body of the pubis, a tendinous arch of obturator fascia, and the pelvic surface of the ischial spine. Insertion: The anterior fibres form a sling around the prostate (levator prostatae) or vagina (sphincter vaginae) and are inserted into the perineal body (a mass of fibrous tissue) in front of the ana canal. The intermediate fibres (puborectalis) form a sling around the anorectal junction to be inserted into the anococcygeal raphe (a fibrous raphe which extends from the anorectal junction to the tip of the coccyx). The posterior fibres (iliococcygeus) are inserted into the anococcygeal raphe and the coccyx. Nerve supply: perineal branch of 4th sacral nerve (S4) from its pelvic surface. perineal branch of the pudendal nerve (S2, S3) from its perineal surface. Actions: The levator ani muscles of two sides together support the pelvic viscera and resist the intra-abdominal pressure during straining and expulsive efforts of the anterior abdominal wa muscles. They also subserve a sphincteric action on the anorectal junction to maintain the continence of faeces in both sexes and vagina in females. The given image below shows the pelvic floor:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: All of the following are correctly matched regarding the management of prolapse except
options: Vaginal pessary is contraindicated in pregnancy
Postnatal - Ring pessary and pelvic floor exercises for 3–6 months
Woman beyond 40 years and multipara - Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair
explanation: The vaginal pessary is not contraindicated in pregnancy. During pregnancy, depending on the severity and patient preference, prolapse is managed conservatively as follows: Intravaginal pessaries - simple, effective, potentially effective in preventing preterm birth Pelvic floor exercises Pelvic physiotherapy Electrical therapy
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
All of the following surgeries are done in vault prolapse except
Uterosacral suspension
explanation: Colposuspension is done in stress urinary incontinence and not for vault prolapse. Management of Vault prolapse: If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacra suspension The best method for vault prolapse. If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation. Fibroid
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about fibroids?
options: More common in Asians than African-Americans
Does not usually increase in size during pregnancy
explanation: Fibroids are more common in African-American women. Uterine fibroids are benign, smooth muscle tumors present in the uterine musculature. They are most commonly seen during reproductive years. Estrogen and progesterone promote the development of fibroids. Option B: Hypoestrogenism occurs in smokers, therefore smoking is protective for fibroids. Option C: Estrogen exposure is increased in nulliparous women, therefore fibroids are more common. Increased parity is protective for fibroids. Option D: Most fibroids do not increase in size during pregnancy. Pregnancy can have an unpredictable effect on fibroids based on individual genetic and environmental factors.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following genes is not associated with leiomyomas?
explanation: MLH1 gene is not associated with leiomyomas. Its mutation leads to endometrial carcinoma. MED12 and HMGA2 are the most common genes associated with leiomyomas. Other genes involved are COL4A5-A6 and the gene for fumarate hydratase (FH). FH gene mutation leads to hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC) syndrome.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic state by all of these mechanisms except:
options: Cells contain a greater density of estrogen receptors
Have higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase
explanation: Leiomyomas convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone. Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic environment, which is a requisite for their growth and maintenance. The hyperestrogenic environment is created by the following mechanisms: Compared to normal myometrium, leiomyoma cells contain a greater density of estrogen receptors, which results in greater estradiol binding. These tumors convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone. There are higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase in leiomyomas compared with norma myocytes. This specific enzyme catalyzes the conversion of androgens to estrogen.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Initially, all fibroids are .
explanation: Initially, all fibroids are intramural. Fibroids develop in the myometrium, as intramural/interstitial and then branch out to form the other types. Classification of fibroids based on anatomical location: Body (corporeal) fibroids- Interstitial/intramural fibroids: They are the most common (75%). Subserosal fibroids: They are the least common (10%). Interstitial fibroids grow outwards to form subserous fibroids and are covered by the peritoneum. These include wandering or parasitic fibroids and broad ligament fibroids. Submucous fibroids: Interstitial fibroid grows inwards towards the uterine cavity. It is the most symptomatic type. Cervical fibroids
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, and white-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid). Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and is more common in obese females(hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the most common symptom is menorrhagia. Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed. The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations: Sub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the most common type of uterine fibroids. Other options: Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or as a diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and may show areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, they appear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into the uterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium. Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky and symmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may show tiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy. Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women. The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following symptoms would you not expect in a patient diagnosed with uterine fibroids?
explanation: Menouria and hypomenorrhea are not seen in patients with uterine fibroids. Menouria occurs due to vesicouterine fistulas. Hypomenorrhea is seen in Asherman's syndrome and due to OCP use. Fibroids present with the following clinical features: Menstrual symptoms such as: Menstrual irregularities - heavy menstrual bleeding/menorrhagia which is the most common symptom, polymenorrhoea, and intermenstrual bleeding (metrorrhagia) Dysmenorrhea Postmenopausal bleeding Abdominal pain Abdominal distension, mass abdomen Vaginal discharge Infertility Recurrent abortions Pressure symptoms such as: Urinary retention Increased frequency of urination Constipation Broad ligament fibroids can cause compression of the ureter leading to hydronephrosis or hydroureter.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient presented with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Which of the following types of fibroid is usually associated with this symptom?
explanation: Intermenstrual bleeding is common with submucous fibroids. Metrorrhagia or intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs during the middle of the menstrual cycle. Metrorrhagia in a woman over 40 years warrants a dilatation and curettage procedure to rule out endometrial cancer. This is associated with fibroids in 3% of cases. Polymenorrhoea in a patient with fibroids occurs when she has polycystic ovaries or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Progressive menorrhagia is seen in intramural and submucous myoma due to increased vascularity, endometrial hyperplasia, and an enlarged uterine cavity. Note: Further the distance of the fibroid from the cavity, lesser is the possibility of menorrhagia. For this reason, subserous and pedunculated fibroids do not cause menorrhagia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 46-year-old woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea. You suspect a diagnosis of submucous uterine fibroids. Which of the following investigations will help you confirm this?
explanation: Investigations required to identify submucous fibroids include: USG - most commonly done. Transvaginal USG is useful to assess the location, dimension, and associated adnexal pathology. MRI gives better soft tissue details but is not routinely done Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy - help to visualise submucous fibroid more clearly Laparoscopy - If uterus <12 weeks size and associated pelvic pain and infertility and to detect pelvic endometriosis and tubal pathology. Uterine curettage – A bump is felt in submucous fibroid during endometrial curettage. Dilatation and curettage is done in patients presenting with postmenopausal bleeding. Hysterosalpingography – A filling defect is seen. CT abdomen is not very useful for the identification of submucous fibroids. These cannot be visualised on colposcopy either. The image below shows the ultrasonographic appearance of a submucous fibroid (asterisk): The image given below shows hysteroscopic view of a submucous fibroid:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An adnexal mass seen on ultrasound in a 38-year-old woman was diagnosed to be a secondary broad ligament fibroid. Which of the following is true about the same?
options: It arises from the broad ligament
The uterine vessels always lie medial to it
The ureter always lies lateral to it
It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid
explanation: The ureter and uterine vessels lie lateral to a secondary broad ligament fibroid. There are 2 types of broad ligament fibroids: Primary broad ligament fibroid: It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid. The arise from: Uterosacral ligament Round ligament Tissues in the broad ligament Relations: The uterine vessels lie medial to it. The ureter is usually beneath the fibroid. However, it can be present anywhere in relation to it. Secondary broad ligament fibroid: It is also known as false broad ligament fibroid. They arise from the lateral wall of the uterus or cervix, but grow laterally, between the two layers of the broad ligament. Relations - the uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to it.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about fibroids?
options: Hyaline degeneration begins at the centre
explanation: Fibroid calcification begins at the periphery and spreads inwards along the vessels. A typical myoma is a well-circumscribed tumor with a pseudo-capsule and firm in consistency. Its cut surface has a whorled appearance. The vessels that supply blood to the tumor lie in the capsule and send radial branches into the tumor. Therefore, the central portion of the tumour receives the least blood supply, and degeneration is noticeable early in this part of the tumour. However, fibroid calcification begins at the periphery. The image given below show the gross appearance of fibroids. The below image shows the histological appearance of fibroids.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with a history of miscarriage underwent a myomectomy. The specimen is shown below. Where does the degenerative change shown here begin from?
explanation: The given specimen shows red degeneration of fibroid. Degeneration is most likely to start from the centre of the fibroid. In a fibroid, centre of the tumor is the least vascular part and hence degeneration is more common here. The only exception is calcareous degeneration where phosphates and carbonates of lime are deposited in the periphery along the course of the vessels.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 44-year-old woman presenting with acute abdominal pain had previously been diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Which of the following complications is most unlikely to have occurred here?
explanation: Hyaline degeneration of fibroids is unlikely here as it is usually painless and presents as an abdominal mass causing distension and heaviness. Acute pain in fibroids is seen in the case of: Fibroid torsion Hemorrhage into the fibroid Red degeneration Sarcomatous change - seen in postmenopausal women.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A primigravida presented with severe abdominal pain and fever at 28 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals a healthy fetus in utero and a large submucosal fibroid with multiple,
hyperechoic areas within. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid. It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. The gross appearance is described as follows: Fishy odor Thrombosis of subcapsular vessels and vessels within the fibroid Purplish-red color due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels. Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid. The image given below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration of fibroids Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen, but fever and leukocytosis are absent. Option C: Infection is more common in puerperium and presents with blood-stained vaginal discharge. Option D: Sarcomatous changes occur very rarely, and are unlikely in patients <40 years of age. They are more commonly seen in post-menopausal women.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 34-year old woman with a history of fibroids presented with 1.5 months of amenorrhea. UPT is positive. Which of the following complications will you not expect in this patient?
explanation: Fetal malformations have not been recorded to occur due to fibroids. Pregnancy complications due to fibroids are: Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage Preterm labor Abnormal presentation Fibroid degeneration (Red degenaration) Accidental hemorrhage Dystocic labor Postpartum hemorrhage Puerperal sepsis Uterine inversion
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following changes are not seen in fibroids?
explanation: Squamous metaplasia is not seen in fibroid.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: CT pelvis of a woman with fibroids is shown below. Which type of degeneration is seen here?
explanation: The given image shows womb-stone appearance on CT, suggestive of calcific degeneration of fibroid. These are also called calcareous myomas and are seen in old patients with long-standing myomas. This occurs due to the deposition calcium phosphates and calcium carbonates in the periphery of the fibroid, along the course of the vessels. It is easily visualized on radiography.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the least common secondary change seen in fibroids?
explanation: Sarcomatous change is the least common secondary change in fibroids. Its incidence is <0.5%. Sarcomatous change leads to the development of malignant leiomyosarcomas. This is seen in postmenopausal women and is rare in women <40 years of age. Intramural and submucous tumors have a higher potential for sarcomatous change than subserous tumors. Its gross appearance is described as follows: Soft consistency Yellowish-grey Hemorrhagic spots seen Radiology shows dark, irregular areas and air levels within the fibroid. These are indicative of sarcomatous change. The image given below shows the CT appearance of a large fibroid that has undergone sarcomatous change. The image on the right shows a fluid level within the tumor.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a lower abdominal mass for the past 2 years. She had undergone uterine artery embolisation for fibroids 5 years ago. Ultrasound showed a homogeneous mass near the uterine fundus. On exploratory laparotomy, the mass was observed to be attached to the greater omentum and it was excised. Histopathology of the mass is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a parasitic fibroid. The given histopathological image shows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei that are characteristic of a fibroid. A parasitic fibroid or a wandering fibroid gets cut off from its uterine origin and derives its blood supply from the vessels of the organ it is attached to. Thus, it can continue to grow in spite of uterine artery embolisation. It is managed by complete resection. Option A: Pedunculated fibroids have a pedicle with which they're attached to the myometrium. Option C: Leiomyosarcoma commonly presents in postmenopausal women with sudden increase in size and postmenopausal bleeding. It would show nuclear atypia on histology. Option D: Disseminated intraperitoneal leiomyomatosis involves large areas of sub peritoneal surfaces. It is seen during pregnancy and while on oral contraceptives.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever and the WBC count is 8000 cells/mL. The most likely diagnosis is:
explanation: The given scenario of severe acute abdominal pain without fever/leucocytosis in a pregnant woman with a fibroid is suggestive of fibroid torsion. The incidence of fibroid in pregnancy is about 1 in 1,000. Due to increased vascularity in pregnancy, the fibroid increases in size and becomes softer. The torsion is seen in the subserous pedunculated fibroid where the venous return is blocked at its site of attachment in the uterus. This leads to severe acute abdominal pain. Due to the complication being more local than systemic, fever or leucocytosis are generally not seen. A transvaginal ultrasonogram is immediately done to detect the position and size of the fibroid, which is followed by laparotomic myomectomy as a part of emergency surgical management. Other options: Option A: Red degeneration of fibroid is seen commonly in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium. It is due to a hemorrhagic infarction of the tissue and typically presents as acute focal abdominal pain with fever and leucocytosis. Treatment is usually conservative with bed rest, analgesics, and sedatives. Option B: Preterm labor is where the labor starts before 37 completed weeks. It is characterized by true labor pain. The abdominal pain is slowly increasing in intensity and duration and is also accompanied by show (expulsion of the cervical mucus plug). There are intervals between episodes of contractions where the patient doesn't complain of abdominal pain.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida at 24 weeks presents to you for a routine antenatal checkup. On ultrasound, you incidentally note the presence of two 3x3cm submucosal fibroids. How will you manage this case?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of an uncomplicated fibroid during pregnancy. These are managed conservatively. Surgery is only indicated in the case of a pedunculated fibroid undergoes torsion.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presented with menorrhagia and increased frequency of micturition. Ultrasound abdomen shows the following picture. Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of her condition?
explanation: The given case scenario and ultrasound image showing a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoic mass are suggestive of a uterine fibroid. Misoprostol does not help to reduce the size of the fibroid and so is not recommended for its management. Medical management of fibroids helps to reduce their size. The drugs used in therapy are as follows: Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone / RU-486 GnRH analogs Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, buserelin Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM) – Asoprisni Danazol - usually not used due to androgenic side effects.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient diagnosed with leiomyoma was prescribed an intranasal spray to manage her disease. Which of the following drugs is it unlikely to contain?
explanation: The nasal spray is unlikely to contain histrelin, as it is only available as a subcutaneous implant. GnRH analogues are used to treat leiomyomas. Intranasal preparations are available for leuprolide, nafarelin, and buserelin. However, leuprolide has maximal action as an intramuscular injection. GnRH analogue therapy in fibroids is given as follows: Leuprolide acetate (Lupron) - given intramuscularly. It is also available as an intranasal spray, but isn't commonly used. Goserelin (Zoladex) - subcutaneous depot implant Triptorelin (Trelstar) IM injection Nafarelin and buserelin - given as intranasal sprays bd Histrelin - available as subcutaneous implants.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman was diagnosed with red degeneration of fibroid at 26 weeks of gestation. What is the next step in her management?
explanation: Red degeneration of fibroid is managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics. It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 32-year-old woman presented with anemia due to heavy menstrual bleeding in spite of medical management of fibroids. She was posted for a myomectomy as she wanted to have children in the future. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?
explanation: Red degeneration is not an indication of myomectomy. It is conservatively managed. Myomectomy is indicated in the following: Symptoms compromising the quality of life such as: Heavy menstrual bleeding, causing anemia Pelvic pain Urinary symptoms and ureteric obstruction. The patient is unwilling for hysterectomy The patient wishes to preserve childbearing function Fibroids causing infertility
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following modalities is not used for the treatment of leiomyomas?
explanation: Ultrasound-guided transcervical metroplasty is not used in the treatment of leiomyomas. It is used for the resection of the uterine septum. Uterine artery embolization/Uterine fibroid embolization (UAE/UFE) is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. The vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, hence these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, thus sparing the surrounding myometrium. Nd:YAG myolysis is laparoscopic myolysis performed with an Nd:YAG laser. It causes coagulation of a subserous fibroid. The below image shows uterine artery embolization. Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS) is also called MR-guided high-intensity focused ultrasound (MR-HIFU). Ultrasound energy is focused to heat and incite coagulative necrosis in selected myomas. Concurrent MR imaging enables precise targeting and provides real-time tissue temperature feedback to limit surrounding thermal injury. The given image shows MRgFUS.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
The following procedure was planned for a patient with uterine fibroids. Which of the following statements is false about this procedure?

Can be done in nulliparous women
options: Ovarian failure is one of the complications
explanation: The given image shows uterine artery embolization (UAE). UAE cannot be done in nulliparous women as embolization of ovarian vessels can cause ovarian failure and premature menopause. Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is approached through percutaneous femoral catheterization. Embolization is done by releasing polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils into the uterine artery. Endometriosis and Adenomyosis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following accurately describes Sampson's theory for endometriosis?
explanation: Sampson's theory describes the implantation of endometrial tissue due to retrograde menstruation. The various theories for the etiology of endometriosis include: Given below is an illustration showing retrograde menstrual flow that is leading to the development of patches of endometriosis. Theory Mechanism Sampson's implantation theo ry Reflux of menstrual endomet rium and subsequent implant ation in the surrounding stru ctures Theory of coelomic metaplasi a by Meyer and Ivanoff Metaplastic changes in embr yonic mesothelium which res pond to hormone stimulation Metastatic theory by Halban Embolization of menstrual fr agments through vascular an d lymphatic channels Theory of histogenesis by ind uction Induction of undifferentiated peritoneal cells to endometri al tissue by an endogenous fa ctor
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about endometriosis?
options: In utero exposure to DES increases risk
Most common site is the cervix
explanation: The most common site of occurrence of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of the ovary is known as endometrioma. By definition, endometriosis is the occurrence of benign endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the cavity of the uterus. Endometriosis can occur anywhere in the body (except spleen) including the abdominal wall, lung, pleura, brain, etc. It is a proliferative, hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. Women between the age groups of 30-40 years are most commonly affected. Risk factors for endometriosis are as follows: Family history (7-10x risk with a 1st-degree relative) Nulliparity In utero exposure to Diethylstilbestrol (DES) Estrogen dependent conditions/Estrogen therapy Immunological factor - Impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the most common symptom associated with endometriosis?
explanation: The most common symptom of endometriosis is dysmenorrhea. Pain begins before the onset of menstruation and builds up continuously until the flow starts. Thereafter, the pain gradually declines. This pattern of pain is called triple dysmenorrhea.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient diagnosed with endometriosis, which of the following symptoms would you not expect?
explanation: Patients diagnosed with endometriosis are not likely to present with vaginal discharge. Clinical features of endometriosis include: About 30% of the patients are asymptomatic. The classic symptom complex includes: Dysmenorrhoea Dyspareunia Menorrhagia Infertility (30-40%) Dysmenorrhoea - most common symptom Dyspareunia - occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved. Deep-seated pelvic pain Premenstrual and postmenstrual spotting
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 2…-year-old lady presented with complaints of severe pain on menstruation and heavy flow. She is subsequently diagnosed with endometriosis. The pain in this condition mainly correlates with
explanation: Pain in endometriosis mainly correlates with the depth of penetration. Lesions penetrating more than 5mm are responsible for pain, dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. The dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis precedes menses by 24 to 48 hours and is less responsive to NSAIDs and combined OCPs.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Arrange the following sites of endometriosis in the order of frequency of occurrence.
explanation: The sites of endometriosis arranged in the order of frequency of occurrence are: Ovary > Pouch of Douglas > Broad ligament > Uterosacral ligament > Fallopian tube. Endometriotic lesions have been identified on all organs except the spleen.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. On examination, you note tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligament points towards a diagnosis of endometriosis. The nodularity of the uterosacral ligament in endometriosis gives rise to the cobblestone appearance seen on laparoscopy. This is referred to as 'sine qua non of endometriosis'. The below image shows the cobblestone appearance of the uterosacral ligament. Note: Endometrioma or chocolate cyst is endometriosis of the ovary. It presents as an adnexa mass.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman presented to your clinic with complaints of painful menstruation and postmenstrual spotting. On examination, you note tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a fixed retroverted uterus. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to confirm the likely diagnosis?
