explanation: The given clinical scenario of dysmenorrhea with tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a retroverted uterus is suggestive of endometriosis. The gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of this condition is a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. It is also the investigation of choice for the condition. Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis: Detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis Locate the site of endometriosis and staging To take biopsy To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation Other investigations for endometriosis include: Estimation of CA-125 levels - raised in endometriosis. Estimation of MCP-1 (Monocyte chemotactic protein) levels - raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a 27-year-old woman with severe dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia. The following finding was seen on the pelvic peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical history and the image showing characteristic powder burn spots seen over the pelvic peritoneum on laparoscopy point toward a diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis. On laparoscopy, the typical endometriotic lesions appear like small black, dark brown or bluish dots. These are called powder burns or gunshot appearance of the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are nodules or small cysts containing old haemorrhages surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis. Subtle appearances of endometriosis seen on laparoscopy are: Red flame-shaped areas Red polypoid areas Yellow-brown patches White peritoneal plaques or scarring Peritoneal defects - known as Allen Masters Syndrome Subovarian adhesions. The lesions mentioned above are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas. Endometriotic lesions in the peritoneal cavity contain yellowish-brown fluid. This fluid contains prostaglandins that are responsible for the pain associated with this condition. Endometriosis of the ovary leads to formation of the chocolate cyst which is a true cyst with columnar epithelium lining. The image below shows the laparoscopic appearance of endometriotic lesions in the pouch of Douglas and on the right, the sacrouterine ligament. Dyspareunia occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In endometriotic lesion, histology represents its:
explanation: In endometriotic lesions, histology represents its high estrogen activity. Endometriosis is defined by the presence of “ectopic” endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Endometriosis is a proliferative hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. It is extremely rare before menarche and disappears after menopause. The endometriotic implants show certain differences when compared to normal endometrium. There is increased production of estrogen by endometriotic stromal cells due to high levels of the enzyme aromatase. This is absent in normal endometrial stroma. Management of endometriosis:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following operative procedures are least likely to be followed by scar endometriosis?
explanation: Among the given operative procedures, hysterectomy is least likely to be followed by scar endometriosis. Operations most likely to be followed by scar endometriosis are: Hysterotomy Classical Cesarean section Myomectomy Ventrofixation (fixing uterus to the abdominal wall) Episiotomy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 39-year-old nulliparous woman presented with dysmenorrhea and a progressively growing, painless abdominal mass. USG scan revealed a cystic lesion of the left ovary which was excised. The below image shows the excised specimen. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: It is seen in endometriosis of ovary
It is lined by columnar epithelium
It is usually a bilateral condition
It is a malignant cystic lesion
explanation: The given clinical history and the image is suggestive of a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is a benign cystic lesion. Chocolate cysts of the ovary are a manifestation of endometriosis. Both the ovaries are usually affected. On histology, the cyst is lined by columnar epithelium. Pseudoxanthoma cells are present which are large macrophages or scavenger cells that appear brown in colour due to ingested blood pigments such as haemosiderin. They are polyhedral in shape and resemble lutein cells. Given below is a gross image of the chocolate cyst of the ovary. Given below is a histopathological section of an endometriotic lesion showing the pseudoxanthoma cells.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal pain. Her lab reports revealed elevated CA-125 levels. Which of the following conditions is the least likely diagnosis?
explanation: CA-125 levels are not expected to be elevated in malignant pancreatic tumours. CA-125 is a glycoprotein and cell surface antigen. Its levels are raised in the following conditions: Abdominal or pelvic tuberculosis Pelvic inflammatory disease Endometriosis Malignant epithelial ovarian tumour Chronic liver disease 2% of normal women, especially during menstruation. Endometrioma refers to ovarian endometriosis. CA-125 levels are raised to more than 35 U/mL in 80% of cases of endometriosis. The level is directly proportional to the extent of the disease.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old woman with dyspareunia is diagnosed to have endometriosis. Which of the following drugs is not useful for her treatment?
explanation: Estrogen is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as the condition is estrogen-dependent. For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe disease, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They are known to antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy. The drug of choice is GnRH agonists. Note: The best time to conceive in a patient with endometriosis is immediately after surgery.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with endometriosis requires treatment with GnRH analogues. She is scared of injections so you plan to prescribe a nasal preparation for her. Which of the following GnRH agonists could you prescribe?
explanation: The GnRH agonist available as a nasal preparation for the treatment of endometriosis is nafarelin. GnRH analogues are used in the management of endometriosis and are given by continuous administration. This suppresses the secretion of pituitary gonadotropins and leads to atrophy of the endometrial tissue in 90% of cases. Leuprolide and triptorelin are GnRH agonists which are given IM. Goserelin is available as a depot preparation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding adenomyosis?
explanation: Patients with adenomyosis commonly present with symptoms of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. It usually occurs following vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. They commonly present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Other symptoms include pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia. On per-vaginal examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. This is known as Halban's sign. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia. Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger patients. The image below is an illustration of adenomyosis. The image below shows adenomyosis as seen during laparoscopy. The uterus is soft and enlarged; the blue spots represent subserous endometriosis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with menorrhagia and backache is diagnosed with adenomyosis. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
explanation: Adenomyosis is not associated with sub involution of the uterus. Uterine subinvolution is impaired or retarded involution of the uterus. It is associated with uterine fibroid, cesarean section and conditions causing overdistension of the uterus like twin pregnancies or polyhydramnios. Adenomyosis often coexists with the following conditions: Uterine fibromyomas Pelvic endometriosis (15%) Endometrial carcinoma
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 43-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia and secondary dysmenorrhea. On examination, Halban's sign was positive. The transvaginal USG findings are given below. Which of the following is the definitive treatment for her condition?

Hormonal therapy
explanation: The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis is hysterectomy. Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of subendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination. Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women. The image below is of a sagittal MRI showing a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall. Gross enlargement of the posterior wall is noted, with many foci of hyperintensity. Disorders of Ovary
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young lady who presented with oligomenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed with PCOS. Mutation of which of the following genes can cause this condition?
explanation: Mutation of the CYP21 gene can cause polycystic ovarian syndrome. The gene for 21-hydroxylase (CYP21) is located in the short arm of chromosome 6. Heterozygosity of the gene has been linked to the development of PCOS. Defects in this gene also lead to congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A teenage girl presented with complaints of excessive growth of coarse hair on her jawline and upper lip. Which of the following is the most common cause for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical history of excessive growth of coarse hair is suggestive of hirsutism. The most common cause for hirsutism in female patients is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Hirsutism is defined as excessive growth of androgen-dependent sexual hair or male distribution of hair in female patients. PCOS accounts for 70-80% of the cases of hirsutism, which typically begins in late adolescence or the early 20s. Idiopathic hirsutism is the second most frequent cause. The most common rapid onset of hirsutism in young females is a testosterone-producing tumour like granulosa cell or Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours. Other less common causes of hirsutism include: Late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia Tumours of the ovary and adrenal glan Cushing’s syndrome Drug-induce Virilisation: Characterized by more extensive androgen-induced changes than hirsutism alone. It has the following features: Acne Increased oily skin Temporal balding Clitoromegaly Deepening of the voice Development of male muscular pattern and body habitus Atrophy of breasts Hypertrichosis: Excessive growth of non-sexual hair.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A mother brought her 15-year-old daughter to the OPD with concerns of excessive growth of coarse hair over her face and chest. Which scoring system is used to clinically grade this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hirsutism. The Ferriman-Gallwey score is used to clinically assess and quantify the degree of hirsutism. Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed at nine body areas and each of them scored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. The maximum score is 36. The degree of hirsutism is mild if the score is 8. Moderate to severe hirsutism is present if the score is 15. Note: Ferriman Gallwey score originally had 11 sites which were modified later to exclude 2 sites, viz., forearm, and legs.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following conditions is the Rotterdam criteria used to diagnose?
explanation: The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose Stein-Levinthal syndrome or PCOS. ESHRE/ASRM or Rotterdam criteria (2003): Any two out of these three must be present- Clinical/ Biochemical hyperandrogenism Oligo/anovulation Polycystic ovaries Other criteria used for diagnosing PCOS: National Institute of Health (NIH) criteria (1990) To include both Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism Oligo/anovulation Androgen excess and PCOS society(AE-PCOS) criteria: To include both: Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries Option A: Meig's syndrome refers to ascites and pleural effusions that accompany a benign ovarian tumor. Option B: Asherman's syndrome refers to the formation of intrauterine synechiae, usually following endometrial destructive procedures like curettage or ablation. Option C: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome is characterised by congenital absence of vagina, primary amenorrhoea, rudimentary cornua uteri and morphologically normal ovaries and Fallopian tubes situated on the pelvic sidewall.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An adolescent girl was brought by her mother to the clinic with complaints of irregular periods and acne. A USG scan was performed which showed the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical history and the necklace appearance on ultrasound are suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease. The original Rotterdam consensus defined polycystic ovaries when 12 follicles were seen per ovary on USG. Each follicle should measure between 2 and 9 mm, and/or an ovarian volume should be >10 ml. Due to improvement in imaging modalities since that time, the threshold for follicle number has now been raised to 20 per ovary.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 26-year-old woman who presented with complaints of irregular cycles and weight gain was diagnosed with PCOS. This condition is characterised by multiple ovarian cysts that are less than in size.
explanation: PCOS is characterised by multiple small ovarian cysts, each less than 1 cm in size. Sonographic findings seen in PCOS are:  12 small cysts of 2 to 9 mm in diameter. Increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. A single ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS. However, this criteria does not apply to women taking combined oral contraceptive pills. Note: In settings with improved sonographic imaging resolution, a follicle number  20 cysts per ovary can be considered significant for PCOS.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 29-year-old lady presented to your clinics with lesions as shown in the below images. Which of the following is a false statement regarding her condition?
explanation: The hyperpigmented areas in the given image are acanthosis nigricans and this is associated with hyperinsulinemia. This skin condition is thought to be a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance. Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in the intertriginous areas. It has poorly defined borders, usually occurs in skin fold areas, such as the back of the neck, axilla, and groin, and may include thickening of the skin. The pathogenesis of acanthosis nigricans is linked to growth factor levels and insulin-mediated activation of insulin-like growth factor (IGF) on keratinocytes and increased growth factor levels. Acanthosis nigricans is usually seen in people younger than 40 years of age and is associated with the following disorders: Obesity Hypothyroidism Acromegaly Polycystic ovary disease Insulin-resistant diabetes Cushing’s disease Addison’s disease Gastrointestinal malignancies such as adenocarcinoma of the stomach or pancreas. The treatment for acanthosis nigricans is directed towards the management of the underlying cause.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with hirsutism. After further evaluation, a diagnosis of HAIR-AN syndrome was made. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
explanation: HAIR-AN syndrome is not characterized by mild hyperandrogenism but marked hyperandrogenism (HA). It also includes insulin resistance (IR) and acanthosis nigricans (AN). HAIR-AN syndrome and ovarian hyperthecosis are exaggerated phenotypes of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Women affected by HAIR-AN syndrome often present with symptoms of severe hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne) and may occasionally display signs of virilization like clitoromegaly, temporal balding and voice deepening. Ovarian hyperthecosis is a rare condition characterized by nests of luteinized theca cells distributed throughout the ovarian stroma.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young lady being evaluated for infertility is diagnosed to have PCOS. Which of the following lab findings would you not expect to see in her?
explanation: A depressed HDL level and elevated total cholesterol:HDL ratios are seen in patients with PCOS. The following are associated with PCOS: Insulin resistance Impaired glucose tolerance and type 2 diabetes mellitus Dyslipidemia: Increased LDL and triglyceride levels, elevated total cholesterol levels:HDL ratios. Infertility/subfertility A three-fold increased risk of endometrial cancer Mild elevations in testosterone levels <200 ng/dL Normal range of testosterone in women is 20-70 ng/dL. A mild elevation in testosterone is consistent with the diagnosis of PCOS. However, values > 200 ng/dL may suggest an ovarian tumour and warrant pelvic sonography.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A teenage girl who recently got diagnosed with PCOS presented with skin lesions on her forehead as shown in the image below. On examination, hirsutism was also noted. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to this patient?
explanation: The lesions shown in the image are acne. The drugs used to treat acne and hirsutism in a patient with PCOS are OCPs with cyproterone acetate. The first step in the management of PCOS is weight reduction. OCPs are the drugs of choice for regularisation of cycles. They are also the drugs of choice for hirsutism and acne. OCPs used for PCOS should contain a 3rd/4th generation progestagen like cyproterone acetate. OCPs induce regular menstrual cycles, lower androgen levels and causes thinning of the endometrium. Insulin sensitizers like metformin have been found to improve metabolic and gynecologic issues. It acts by reducing the insulin level and reducing hepatic production of glucose (liver neoglycolysis). Other benefits of metformin include improvement in fertility rate and reduction of the total and free testosterone levels. It also increases levels of sex hormone-binding globulin. Metformin is contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease. Treatment of infertility associated with PCOS is done using ovulation-inducing drugs like letrozole and clomiphene citrate. If medical management fails, surgical options like laparoscopic ovarian drilling can be considered. Note: FOGSI, in 2024, has replaced Letrozole as the first-line drug for induction of ovulation in patients with PCOS. However, the FDA approval for the same is still pending.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 31-year-old lady has been unable to conceive for the past 2 years in spite of regular intercourse. She has recently been diagnosed with PCOS. Which of the following is the FDA approved medication that you could recommend to her?
explanation: Clomiphene is an FDA approved drug used for the treatment of infertility associated with PCOS. Clomiphene induces ovulation in 80% of the cases and 40–50% patients conceive. However, abortions are common due to luteal phase defects. Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs in <1% cases. Co-administration with dexamethasone leads to better outcomes. In resistant case, tamoxifen 20–40 mg daily for 5 days should be tried. Currently, letrozole has proven to be more effective in ovarian infertility in obese women but its use in such cases is pending FDA approval.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient diagnosed with PCOS, which of the following is not an indication for surgical management?
explanation: Surgical management is indicated in all the above conditions except for morbid obesity. Indications of surgery in PCOS include: Failed medical therapy Ovarian hyperstimulation Infertility Previous pregnancy losses Surgery comprises of laparoscopic drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine milieu and improves fertility for a year or so. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce the fertility rate. The formation of adhesions can be reduced by hydrofloatation. The advantages of surgery are as follows: Tubal testing with chromotubation can be performed simultaneously Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be looked for One-time treatment Intense and prolonged monitoring for side effects is not require Cost-effective compared to IVF Reduces androgen and LH production Following surgery, single ovulation occurs with drugs, and hyperstimulation and multiple pregnancies are avoide Ovulation occurs in 80–90% and pregnancy in 60–70% The disadvantages of surgery are as follows: It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy Adhesions may form postoperatively If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human menopausal gonadotropin. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image showing enlarged ovaries with multiple large cysts along with the history of treatment for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin suggests the diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). Human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is a medication that is composed of FSH and LH. It is used to stimulate the release of ova in women who do not ovulate spontaneously. It can lead to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a condition associated with ovarian enlargement due to exogenous gonadotropin therapy. Symptoms include abdominal pain, distention, ascites, gastrointestinal problems, respiratory compromise, oliguria, and thromboembolism. It can occur during ovulation induction or in early pregnancies conceived through exogenous ovarian stimulation. Predisposing factors for OHSS include multi-follicular ovaries (such as in PCOS), young age, high estradiol levels during ovulation induction, and pregnancy. Vasoactive substances produced by the corpus luteum, such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and angiotensin II, are believed to contribute to enhanced capillary permeability, resulting in the loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity and hemoconcentration. Sonographic examination reveals enlarged ovaries with numerous follicular cysts and ascites. Maintaining fluid balance with isotonic fluids like normal saline is crucial. Strategies to prevent OHSS during exogenous ovulation include reducing follicular stimulation (low FSH dose), coasting (withholding FSH administration one or more days prior to the hCG trigger), prophylactic volume expanders, and substituting hCG for FSH towards the end of ovarian stimulation. Other options: Option B: Theca lutein cysts are a rare form of follicular cysts characterized by luteinization and hypertrophy of the theca interna layer. Both ovaries are enlarged and cystic. This condition is commonly associated with gestational trophoblastic disease, multifetal gestation, and placentomegaly. Option C: Polycystic ovarian syndrome shows 12 or more small follicles each 2-9 mm in size placed peripherally (necklace pattern) (shown below). The patient presents with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, etc.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 21-year-old nulliparous woman presented with galactorrhoea and breast engorgement. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this condition?
Prolactin is the most important hormone involved in its pathophysiology
options: Prolactin levels more than 25 ng/ml cause this condition
All patients with hyperprolactinemia present with galactorrhoea
The drug of choice is Cabergoline
explanation: All patients with hyperprolactinaemia do not present with galactorrhoea. Galactorrhoea is the secretion of milky fluid from the nipple which is unrelated to childbirth. Prolactin is the most important hormone involved in the pathophysiology of amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. Majority of women (80%) with high prolactin levels present with galactorrhoea. However, some hyperprolactinemic women may not have this symptom. Normal prolactin level is 25 ng/mL and levels more than this can cause galactorrhoea. Levels up to 100 ng/mL occur in hyperprolactinaemia but prolactin level over 100 ng/mL is seen in pituitary tumours. Galactorrhoea is caused by pituitary adenoma and hyperprolactinemia. The condition is associated with amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea and infertility. The drug of choice for this condition is cabergoline. Contraception and Sterilization
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the rhythm method?
options: Anencephaly is seen on accidental conception
It is a cost effective method
Safe period is determined using temperature or mucous method
Abstinence is required for 7-10 days in a month
explanation: Anencephaly is not seen in the case of accidental conception in a woman using the rhythm method. It occurs due to deficiency of folic acid in the mother. The calendar method or the rhythm method is one of the natural methods of contraception by fertility awareness. The couple is advised avoidance of sexual intercourse around ovulation. Thus, it is very cost-effective but it can only be used by educated couples. According to this method, safe period in a normal 28-day cycle is from the 1st day of menstrual period to the 10th day and from the 18th to the 28th day. An alternate method is by calculating the risk period i.e., 3 days before and 3 days after ovulation. Ovulation can also be estimated by changes in cervical mucus and basal body temperature. Another method of calculating the safe period is the Knaus–Ogino method. The fertile period is determined by subtracting 18 days from the shortest cycle and 10 days from the longest cycle. This gives the first and the last day of the fertile period, respectively.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What does Billing's method of contraception refer to?
explanation: Billing’s method of contraception refers to the cervical mucus method. It is also called ovulation method. The properties of the cervical mucus change during the menstrual cycle. The female partner can predict the fertile period by examining her cervical mucus. Under the influence of estrogen, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes more slippery and elastic i.e. wet days. This continues till it reaches a peak. After this, under the influence of progesterone, it becomes thicker, scanty i.e. dry days. Abstinence is advised during the wet days till 4 days after the peak day. The safe period includes the dry days after menses till the appearance of mucus and from the 4th day after the peak day. The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image.
explanation: The given image shows a female condom. It consists of a pouch made of polyurethane which is 17 cm in length with a flexible ring at each end. The inner ring at the closed end is smaller than the outer ring. The inner ring is inserted at the apex of the vagina and the outer ring remains outside. It covers the cervix, the entire vagina, and external genitalia. Hence, it provides protection against HIV and STDs. It has a failure rate of 5–15 per 100 woman-years, which is higher than that of a male condom. It can be fitted by the patient hours before intercourse, and easily removed soon after. It covers the cervix, vagina, and external genitalia and is protective against sexually transmitted diseases. It can also be worn in the puerperal period, unlike the cervical diaphragm. The female condom should not be used along with a male condom because if worn together they may slip, tear, or become displaced. The given image below shows the insertion of a female condom:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A nulliparous woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does this contain?
explanation: Today sponge contains 1 g of nonoxynol 9. It is a mushroom-shaped polyurethane disposable sponge that is 2 inches wide and 1.25 inches thick. It is provided with a loop for easy removal. It should be placed high up in the vagina with the concave side covering the cervix. It can remain effective for 24 h. It can be used only once. It acts as a mechanical barrier preventing the entry of sperms into the cervical canal, absorbs semen, and contains a spermicidal agent. The failure rate is 9-16 per 100 woman-years.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the use of the contraceptive shown below?
explanation: The given image shows a cervical diaphragm or Dutch cap. It can be used by women having multiple sex partners. Contraindications of cervical diaphragm usage: Prolapse, cystocele, rectocele - accurate fitting is not possible Recurrent urinary tract infection Allergy to rubber or spermicidal agent It must be removed following intercourse as it can lead to toxic shock syndrome (TSS) if left in the vagina for a long period. TSS is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus infection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are prescribing nonoxynol-9 jelly to a woman using a cervical diaphragm for contraception. What is its mechanism of action?
explanation: Nonoxynol-9 is one of the spermicidal agents which act by disruption of the sperm cell membrane. Spermicidal agents are chemical contraceptives as they contain surfactants, such as nonoxynol-9, octoxynol, menfegol and enzyme-inhibiting agents. These are available as: Foam tablets Soluble pessaries Creams Jellies Films The spermicidal agent remains effective for 1–2 hours after the application. They are always used along with other contraceptives such as the diaphragm, cervical cap, and condom. When they are used alone, the failure rate is high i.e., 30 per 100 woman-years. Chronic use of spermicides can cause vaginal irritation, abrasion, and ulceration. This increases the risk of HIV spread. Hence, spermicidal agents should not be recommended to HIV-positive couples.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman who is using a cervical diaphragm asks for an alternative contraceptive. You suggest a recently launched contraceptive Phexxi. What is its composition?
options: Lactic acid, Citric Acid, Potassium bitartrate
Ascorbic acid, Citric acid, Calcium bitartrate
Lactic acid, Ascorbic acid, Potassium bitartrate
Ascorbic acid, Lactic acid, Calcium bitartrate.
explanation: Phexxi is a vaginal gel that contains lactic acid, citric acid, and potassium bitartrate. Phexxi is a vaginal pH regulator which is a non-hormonal contraceptive. It works by maintaining vaginal pH within the range of 3.5 to 4.5. This acidic environment is inhospitable for sperms. Phexxi comes in pre-filled vaginal applicators. A single dose must be applied before vaginal intercourse. If more than one act of vaginal intercourse occurs within one hour, an additional dose must be applied.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A newly married woman was prescribed Mala-N at a PHC. What is its composition?
explanation: Mala-N is a combined oral contraceptive containing 0.15 mg levonorgestrel (LNG) and 0.03 mg ethinyl estradiol. It is supplied free of cost through all PHC's, urban family welfare centers, etc. All combined oral pills contain a mixture of ethinyl estradiol in a dose of 20-30 mcg and an orally active progestogen. Mala-D has the same composition as Mala-N but is available at a price of Rs 3/- per packet. Combined oral pill works by suppressing pituitary hormones, FSH, and LH peak which prevents ovulation. At the same time, progestogen causes atrophic changes in the endometrium and prevents implantation. Progestogen also acts on the cervical mucus making it thick and tenacious and impenetrable by sperms. It also interferes with tubal motility and alters tubal transport. , so the fertilized egg reaches the uterine cavity before the endometrium is receptive for implantation. These tablets are taken starting on the first day of the cycle for 21 days. A new course of tablets should be commenced 7 days after the cessation of the previous course. They should be taken at bedtime, preferably after a meal.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not an advantage of norgestimate OCPs?
explanation: Norgestimate is one of the 3rd generation progesterone agents. All OCPs have the disadvantage of increasing the risk of venous thrombosis. Third-generation progesterone agents are less androgenic and so reduce the occurrence of acne and hirsutism. They also have a lower risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders compared to the previous generation progesterone agents. Benefits of combined pills: Effective contraceptive Useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhoea Relieves dysmenorrhoea and premenstrual tension Prevents anaemia by reducing the menstrual loss Lower incidence of benign breast neoplasia (fibrocystic disease), functional ovarian cyst, ovarian and uterine malignancy Reduced risk of PID - due to thick cervical mucus caused by progestogen, preventing the organisms from entering into the uterine cavity Reduced incidence of ectopic pregnancy - due to suppression of ovulation and decreased risk of PID Protects against rheumatoid arthritis Reduces the risk of anorectal cancer Useful in acne, PCOD, and endometriosis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of OCPs?
explanation: Thyroid disorders like hypothyroidism are not a contraindication for OCP usage. Contraindications of OCPs: Absolute contraindications - Breast and genital cancers Liver disease History of thromboembolism Cardiac abnormalities Congenital hyperlipidemia Undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding Relative contraindications - Age over 40 years, if smoker >35 years Mild hypertension Chronic renal disease Epilepsy Migraine First 6 months of breastfeeding Diabetes mellitus Gallbladder disease History of infrequent bleeding or amenorrhea
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following drugs do not lead to failure of OCPs?
explanation: Sodium valproate is an inhibitor of CYP enzymes that are responsible for OCP metabolism. Thus, it does not lead to OCP failure. Drugs leading to OCP failure are : Rifampicin Tetracyclines - interferes with enterohepatic circulation of estrogen Phenytoin Phenobarbitone Antifungals Cephalosporin Ritonavir for HIV - interferes with absorption of OCP Most of the anti-convulsants are enzyme inducers and hence increase the clearance of OCPs. This leads to OCP failure.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills?
options: Kills the sperms in the cervical cana
explanation: Minipills or progesterone-only pills (POP) do not kill sperm in the cervical canal. Progesterone-only pills act by thickening the cervical mucus (the main mechanism of all POPs except cerazette) that inhibits penetration of sperms, inhibiting tubal motility, and suppressing ovulation. Other advantages of POPs include a reduction in the incidence of pelvic inflammatory diseases and sexually transmitted diseases (due to thickened cervical mucus). Due to the inhibition of tubal motility, the absolute risk of all pregnancies including ectopic pregnancy decreases, while the relative risk of ectopic pregnancy increases. But a previous history of ectopic pregnancy is not a contraindication for POP. POPs do not affect clotting, lipid metabolism, and carbohydrate metabolism. So they can safely be used by women who are obese, breastfeeding, hypertensive, have SLE or a history of thromboembolism, diabetic with vascular disease. Significant adverse effects of POPs are irregular bleeding (mostly scanty), and secondary amenorrhea after longtime usage as it causes endometrial atrophy. Contraindications for POPs include undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, pregnancy, known or suspected breast cancer, and benign or malignant liver tumors.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient has come to your clinic for contraceptive advice. As she has a family history of breast cancer, you suggest a non-hormonal oral contraceptive to her. What is the initial dose of this drug?
explanation: Centchroman is a non-hormonal oral contraceptive that is started at a dose of 30 mg on the first day of the menstrual cycle. It can be given to women with a family history of breast cancer where hormonal contraceptives are contraindicated. Centchroman or ormeloxifene is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive. Following the initial dose of 30 mg on the first day of menses, it is taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter. It prevents implantation through endometrial changes. The return of fertility occurs within 6 months of stopping the drug. It can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 hours of coitus. It has a failure rate of 1.83 per 100 woman years. It does not provide protection against HIV and other STDs. Side effects of centchroman: Headache, nausea, vomiting Weight gain Delay in return of fertility (up to 6 months) Atypical endometrial hyperplasia - prolonged use Contraindications of centchroman: PCOD Hepatic dysfunction Cervical dysplasia Allergy to the drug This drug has been developed by Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow. It has been released in India under the name of Chhaya (previously called Saheli) under the National Family Planning Programme.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the most effective reversible method of contraception?
explanation: The most effective reversible method of contraception among the given options is Norplant, which is a subdermal hormonal implant. The most effective method of contraception overall is sterilization, which is one of the permament methods. Both methods belong to the first-tier category of contraceptives. There are 2 types of subdermal implants: Implanon (which has replaced Norplant I) Norplant II The implants work by inhibition of ovulation, endometrial atrophy, and thickening of cervical mucus. Implanon contains desogestrel and also reduces acne and osteoporosis. The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days of insertion. The image below shows an implanon: The image given below shows the insertion of a subdermal implant: Advantages of implants: Long-acting with sustained effect Good compliance Coital-independent with no nuisance of daily oral or frequent injections Failure rate - 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman-years Implanon reduces acne and osteoporosis. Disadvantages of implants: Breakthrough bleeding Irregular cycles Amenorrhoea Ectopic pregnancy Local infection Requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules Expensive.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the device given in the image below?
explanation: The given image shows Multiload Cu250, which is one of the copper containing IUCDs. Formation of cervical mucus plug is not one of its mechanisms of action. However, progesterone-containing IUCDs can alter the cervical mucus along with the local effects. The various mechanisms of action of a copper-containing IUCD are: Interference with the migration of spermatozoa Foreign body reaction releasing prostaglandins - provokes uterine contractility and increases the tubal peristalsis which interferes with implantation Leucocytic infiltration in the endometrium - macrophages engulf the fertilized egg if it enters the endometrial tissue Enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue which interferes with implantation of the fertilized ovum Some IUCDs like CuT-380A are effective for up to 10 years. They are a good choice of method of contraception for the following groups of women: Having low risk of STD Multiparous woman Having a monogamous relationship Wanting long-term reversible method of contraception Unreliable users of oral contraception or barrier contraception IUCDs are avoided in unmarried and nulliparous patients because of the risk of PID and subsequent tubal infertility. Copper IUCDs can also be used as emergency contraception following intercourse.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: IUCD insertion is being considered in a multiparous woman who wants long-term contraception. This method of contraception is absolutely contraindicated in all of the following except .
explanation: IUCDs can be used in HIV-affected women. Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) provide long-term contraception by preventing fertilization. Contraindications for IUCD insertion: Suspected pregnancy Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) Lower genital tract infection Presence of fibroids Severe anaemia Uncontrolled diabetes - due to increased pelvic infection Scarred uterus eg, post caesarean section Septate uterus Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea - if Copper T is used Breast cancer - if LNG IUCD is used Complications of IUCD usage: Immediate - Vasovagal attack Uterine cramps Early - Expulsion of IUCD Perforation of uterus Spotting, menorrhagia Dysmenorrhoea Vaginal infection Actinomycosis Late - PID Ectopic pregnancy Perforation of uterus Menorrhagia Dysmenorrhoea The failure rate of IUCD is 1–3 per 100 woman-years. Levonorgestrel IUCD also causes hormonal adverse effects such as headache, acne, breast tenderness, and functional ovarian cysts. Amenorrhoea occurs in 35% of women after 2 years of use.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are inserting Nova-T in a patient for spacing of births. This device contains .
explanation: Nova-T contains both copper and silver. The addition of the silver increases its effective lifespan. In copper-carrying devices, copper wire is wrapped around the vertical stem of a polypropylene frame. Some of them have copper wire wrapped around the arms too. Based on the surface area, they are of various types: Copper T 380 A Multiload copper 250 Copper T 200 Copper 7 Copper T 220 Nova-T They are effective for 3–5 years. It is estimated that about 50 mcg of copper is eluted daily in the uterus. Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years. Nova T has a lifespan of 5 years.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A nursing mother was prescribed progestasert for contraception. How much progesterone is released by this device?
explanation: Progestasert releases 65 g of progesterone/day. Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect of IUCDs. There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea compared to copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearly replacement.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following increases the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease?
explanation: Copper IUCDs increase the risk of PID. OCPs, Mirena and DMPA injectables contain progesterone which causes thickening of the cervical mucus and decreases the motility of the female genital tract. Thus, they reduce the risk of PID by preventing the ascent of bacteria from the vagina.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most effective mode of contraception for a woman with heart disease?
explanation: IUCDs are the most effective mode of contraception for women with heart diseases. IUCDs are safe in these patients and come under the first-tier contraceptive methods. Condoms are not contraindicated in heart disease patients but they are third-tier contraceptives. Hence, they are not as effective as IUCDs. OCPs and hormonal implants are contraindicated in patients with heart diseases as the constituent hormones can cause thromboembolic disorders.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following techniques of permanent contraception does not require an abdominal incision?
explanation: Essure permanent device is a method of hysteroscopic sterilization. Pomeroy, Parkland, and Irving procedures are methods for tubal ligation via an abdominal approach. Essure device consists of a micro-inserter with a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel titanium alloy (nitinol). This device is inserted into the fallopian tube by hysteroscopy. It acts by benign local fibrous tissue growth leading to occlusion of the tube. The failure rate is 3.5%. Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and the procedure can be done under local anaesthesia. Disadvantages of Essure: Hysteroscopy required for the procedure and to confirm the blockage Expensive procedure Expertise required Irreversible - tuboplasty for reversal not possible 3 months waiting time to ensure sterility - HSG must be done after 3 months to confirm tuba blockage Bilateral insertion difficult due to spasm Can cause perforation of the tube
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman has come to your clinic for a checkup following tubal ligation by Pomeroy technique. Which portion of the tube is ligated in this technique?
explanation: Isthmus of the fallopian tube is ligated in Pomeroy technique. It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation. Midline, paramedian or transverse abdominal incision is made 2 inches above the pubic symphysis (1 inch in puerperal sterilisation). The fallopian tube is identified, made into a loop and tied at the base. The loop is then excised. The operation is simple and requires a short period of hospitalization. The failure rate is only 0.4% and it is mainly due to spontaneous canalization. It is surgically reversible. The below image shows Pomeroy’s method of tubal ligation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Fimbriectomy is also known as:
explanation: Fimbriectomy is also known as Kroener's procedure. This procedure involves ligation of the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures. Then, resection of the infundibulum of the tube is done. Some more techniques of permanent sterilization include: Pomeroy method - The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. The middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. This is the most commonly used technique. Uchida's method - The tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube. The muscle layer is excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. This minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty. Irving's procedure - The mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion is excised. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. It is a reliable method but irreversible and may require a laparotomy incision. Madlener's procedure - A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 40-year-old male patient underwent a vasectomy. What is the failure rate of this procedure?
explanation: The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15% This procedure is done under local anaesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens are divided on both sides which disrupts the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps and skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The sperms can remain in the reproductive tract for up to 3 months. Hence, sterility is not immediate. The couple must abstain from intercourse during this period or use other methods of contraception. Approximately, 20 ejaculates clear the semen of all sperms. Two semen analysis reports must confirm the absence of sperms before the man can be declared sterile.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A couple with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse requires emergency contraception. Which of the following is not a mechanism by which these drugs act?
options: Preventing the implantation of the fertilized egg
explanation: Emergency contraceptives do not interrupt early pregnancy, once conception has occured. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. Hence, they are also called interceptives. The main action of emergency contraceptives is to make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperms. Methods of emergency contraception: Drug Dose Levonorgestrel 0.75mg stat and repeat dose after 12 hours or1.5mg as a si ngle dose Ethinyl estradiol 50 g + Nor gestrel 0.25 mg 2 tabs stat and 2 tabs after 12 hours RU486 (Mifepristone) Single dose of 25-50mg Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5 mg BD X 5 days Copper IUDs Insertion within 5 days of int ercourse Centchroman 2 tabs(60 mg) to be taken twi ce at an interval of 12 hoursS hould be taken within 24 hou rs of intercourse. Ulipristal 30 mg within 5 days of interc ourse
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of unprotected intercourse 2 days ago. Which of the following will you prescribe as a single dose contraceptive?
explanation: Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg can be used as a single dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in interval between coitus and drug intake. LNG prevents ovulation and makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation. The failure rate is 1.1%. If pregnancy occurs as a result of contraceptive failure, the risk of ectopic pregnancy increases but it is not teratogenic. Advantages of LNG: No oestrogen and its associated side effects Can be used in hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic patients Suitable for lactating woman Can be given up to 120 hours after the unprotected intercourse Single-dose therapy Contraindications of LNG: Liver disease Thrombophlebitis Migraine Galactose allergy - as the tablet contains lactose
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
What is the dose of ulipristal for emergency contraception?
60 µg
explanation: The dose of ulipristal is 30 mg tablet and it should be taken within 5 days of intercourse. Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and acts by: Preventing/delaying ovulation Suppressing endometrial and follicular growth Inhibiting implantation Side effects are headaches and mood changes. It is contraindicated in women with severe hepatic dysfunction and severe asthma. Note: The use of ulipristal for the treatment of fibroids has been discontinued due to the increased incidence of severe liver injury. Vaginal Infections
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis?
explanation: Caucasian race is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis. The risk factors for bacterial vaginosis are: Oral sex Vaginal douching African race Cigarette smoking Sex during menses Intrauterine device Early age of sexual intercourse New or multiple sexual partners Sexual activity with other women Note: Bacterial vaginosis is not an infection. It most commonly affects young women. Although it is not a sexually transmitted disease, the chances of developing bacterial vaginosis seem to increase with the number of sexual partners that a woman has had.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: Gardnerella vaginalis is a causative agent
Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis
Oral metronidazole is given for treatment
explanation: Vaginal itching is not seen in bacterial vaginosis. It is a symptom of Trichomonas vaginitis. About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic women mostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia. Option A: Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the absence of lactobacilli. This causes an increase in the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Myco- plasma□ hominis. Option B: Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. 3 out of 4 criteria are needed to make a positive diagnosis. Option D: Oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or oral clindamycin 300 mg twice daily for 7 days is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Treatment remains the same in pregnancy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge for the past 2 weeks. On examination, the discharge is adherent to the vaginal mucosa and has a fishy odour. What is the most likely cause?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella. Patients with BV have profuse and yellowish vaginal discharge with a fishy odour. It is adherent to the vaginal mucosa. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are absent. On microscopy, clue cells are visible. Option A: In trichomonas vaginitis, the vaginal discharge is frothy, greenish-yellow and has an offensive smell. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are generally present. Option B: In candidal vaginitis, the discharge is thick and curdy white. Option D: In chlamydial infection, the vaginal discharge is generally scanty.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not be seen?
explanation: An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora. A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Given below is the image of a smear prepared from the vaginal discharge of a patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of clue cells on microscopy is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. A swab of the vaginal discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation of the smear is done on a gram stained smear. It would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman comes to the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, the discharge was profuse and had a fishy odour. Which of the following is the best criteria to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis which is confirmed by using Amsel’s criteria. 3 out of 4 of the following criteria are needed, to make a positive diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis: A homogeneous, thin, greyish-white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls. A vaginal pH > 4.5. A positive whiff test - an amine like fishy odour is produced when a drop of 10% KOH is added to the sample of vaginal discharge. The presence of >20% clue cells on saline wet mount. These are vaginal epithelial cells studded with adherent coccobacilli at the edge of the cell. Option A: Boer-Miesel's criteria is used for the prognostic evaluation of pelvic inflammatory disease. Option B: Light's criteria is used for determining the nature of the pleural fluid i.e., transudate or exudate, in the diagnosis of pleural effusion. Option D: Nugent's criteria can also be used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. However, it is not the best confirmatory method.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient with suspected bacterial vaginosis, Nugent's criteria is used to quantify the following bacteria except....
explanation: Nugent's criteria is used to evaluate three types of bacteria in a case of suspected bacterial vaginosis: Mobiluncus, Lactobacillus, and Gardnerella/Bacteroides. Bacteria are graded through gram stain of vaginal samples. They are each graded on a scale of 1+ to 4+ where: 1+ is < 1 cell per field 2+ is 1-5 cells per field 3+ is 6-30 cells per field 4+ is >30 cells per field Lactobacillus and Bacteroides/Gardnerella are given scores between 0-4, but Mobiluncus is graded only from 0-2. The total scores are then calculated and interpreted as follows: 0-3 - Norma 4-6 - Intermediate bacterial count 7-10 - Bacterial vaginosis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A gynaecology resident noted a frothy, greenish, offensive-smelling vaginal discharge in a young lady. Whiff test was positive. Which organism is most likely implicated?
explanation: Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely organism implicated in this patient, causing trichomonas vaginitis. The whiff test can be positive in both Trichomonas and Gardnerella infections. However, greenish frothy discharge is seen in trichomonas vaginitis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient came to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism.
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely causative agent. Vaginal itching and foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge are seen in trichomonas vaginitis. The given image shows colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix, which is a characteristic finding of trichomoniasis. This is due to microscopic, punctate haemorrhages of the cervix.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following organisms can be detected on a hanging drop preparation?
explanation: Trichomonas vaginalis can be detected on a hanging drop preparation. Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan with four anterior flagellae, and a fifth posterior flagellum responsible for motility. The image given below shows trophozoites of Trichomonas vaginalis with flagella.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old woman came with complaints of greenish vaginal discharge. On saline microscopy, motile flagellated organisms were seen. What is the best treatment option for her?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trichomonas vaginitis and the best treatment option for her is oral metronidazole 2 g stat. The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis is: An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or A single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent infection. Treatment in pregnancy remains the same.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A pregnant woman in her 7th week of gestation was diagnosed with trichomoniasis. Which of the following can be used to treat her condition?
explanation: Trichomonas vaginitis is treated with oral metronidazole in pregnant women. According to the current guidelines, metronidazole is now considered safe for treating trichomonas vaginitis in pregnancy as it has no teratogenic effect. The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis in pregnant women include: An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or a single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g Usage of trichofuran suppositories Vinegar douche to lower the vaginal pH Betadine ge The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent infection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents to your OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge and intense itching. What is the likely causative agent for her condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moniliasis and Candida albicans is the likely causative agent. The risk factors for moniliasis are: Diabetes mellitus Obesity Multiple sexual partners Immunosuppression HIV Pregnancy Steroid therapy Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy Oral contraceptive pills Poor personal hygiene.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In an obese lady with complaints of vaginal discharge, a vaginal pH of 4.2 was detected. Which organism is implicated in this patient?
explanation: The likely causative agent in the given clinical scenario is Candida which is known to flourish in an acidic environment. The pH of the vaginal discharge in candidal vaginitis is in the range of 4-4.5.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing a candidal infection?
explanation: Hypertension does not increase the risk of developing a candidal infection. The risk factors for developing candidal vaginitis (moniliasis) are: Diabetes mellitus Obesity Multiple sexual partners Immunosuppression HIV Pregnancy Steroid therapy Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy Oral contraceptive pills Poor personal hygiene.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 32-year old woman presents to you with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching. On examination, you note a curdy white discharge and an inflamed vagina. What is the best treatment for her?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of candidal vaginitis. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg is the best treatment for treating candidal vaginitis. Intravaginal antifungal (imidazole/miconazole/clotrimazole) vaginal pessaries or creams can also be used for 3–6 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a primary site for gonococcal infection?
explanation: Ectocervix and vagina are lined by squamous epithelium which is resistant to gonococcal infection. The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium. Hence, gonococcus usually affects the following structures: Endocervix Urethra Skene’s glands Bartholin's glands.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following presentations is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea?
explanation: Haematuria is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea. Gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is: Excessive vaginal discharge associated with pruritus and inflammation Acute unilateral pain and swelling over labia due to the involvement of Bartholin’s gland Intermenstrual bleeding Non-gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is: Pharyngeal infection Dysuria Rectal discomfort due to associated proctitis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis?
explanation: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia trachomatis. The causes of non-gonococcal urethritis are: Chlamydia trachomatis (most common) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophillus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 35-year-old sex worker was suspected to have chlamydial cervicitis. What is the most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis?
explanation: The most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis of chlamydial cervicitis is the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It is fast, highly sensitive and specific (96%).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old woman had complaints of lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. On microscopy, the following finding was present. What is the selective culture media used to isolate the causative organism?
options: Culture on bilayer human blood agar
explanation: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most likely causative organism. This is suggested by the presence of characteristic iodine-stained inclusion bodies in the McCoy cell culture of the patient's endocervical sample. Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show abundant leucocytes but no organisms. The nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is currently done for the diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with complaints of vaginal discharge was evaluated. On an endocervical biopsy, chlamydia was detected. How will you treat this patient?
explanation: A single dose of 1 g of azithromycin is given and contact tracing is done to treat a patient diagnosed with a chlamydial infection. Treatment of chlamydial infection: Azithromycin 1 g single dose (or) Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID × 7 days (or) Ofloxacin 200 mg orally BID × 7 days (or) Erythromycin 500 mg orally BID × 7 days Contact tracing should always be done. The sexual partner should also be treated with the same regimen.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 25-year-old lady complains of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning. What is the route of administration of the first non-azole drug approved to treat this condition?
Ora
explanation: The clinical history of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The first and the only non-azole antifungal approved for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis is Ibrexafungerp. The route of administration of this drug is oral. Ibrexafungerp is a triterpenoid antifungal agent that acts by inhibiting glucan synthase. Glucan synthase is an enzyme involved in the formation of 1,3-beta-D-glucan which is an essential component of the fungal cell wall. The recommended dosage is 600 mg orally as 2 divided doses 12 hrs apart. Contraindications include pregnancy and hypersensitivity to ibrexafungerp. The most frequent adverse reactions are diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, dizziness, and vomiting. Vulval Infections
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts?
explanation: The causative agent of vulval warts is the human papillomavirus (HPV). Genital warts/venereal warts/condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favoured by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy. HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, as shown below. The diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The abnormal areas of the skin retain the blue dye. These areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination. The given image below shows condyloma acuminata:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman presented with the following lesion on her vulva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata that shows cauliflower-like masses of tissue on and around the female anogenital region. Condyloma acuminatum is an epidermal manifestation of the human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells of the epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. However, anogenital HPV infection is almost always acquired through sexual contact. Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load. Option B: The image given below shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a characteristic dimple at the centre. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum caused by the pox virus. Option C: The image given below shows firm papules with a rough horny surface. These are seen in verruca vulgaris caused by the human papillomavirus type 2. Option D: The image given below shows condyloma lata which is the characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sexually active woman presents with cauliflower-like lesions on the vulva. The biopsy of the lesion is taken and histopathology reveals the following picture. What is the most likely causative organism?
explanation: The given image shows koilocytes, a characteristic feature of infection with human papillomavirus (HPV). Other features that can also be seen on histology are: Perinuclear halo Multinucleation Orangeophilic cytoplasm Acanthosis Chronic inflammatory infiltrate Option A: Henderson-Paterson bodies are seen in molluscum contagiosum, caused by poxvirus. Option C and D: Cowdry bodies are seen in herpes infection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following serotypes are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus?
explanation: Serotypes 16 and 18 are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus (HPV). It is called Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months. Gardasil/Silgard is the quadrivalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16 and 18 and is given at 0, 2 and 6 months. Gardasil 9 is the nonavalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. In 2020 it has received an expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a treatment option for a patient with genital warts?
explanation: Genital warts are treated by a local application of 25% trichloracetic acid + 5% fluorouracil. Treatment of genital warts includes the local application of: Podophyllin 25% in alcohol/podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin daily for 4 days (or) 25% trichloracetic acid +5% fluorouracil daily for 4 days If this fails, the following treatment is given: Interferon ointment/cream or intralesional interferon injection Imiquimod cream thrice a week for 4 months If medical treatment fails then cryosurgery, diathermy or laser removal is done.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sexually active woman who presented with an ulcer over the vulva was diagnosed with primary syphilis. What is the characteristic feature associated with this condition?
options: Non suppurative, tender, and enlarged nodes
Firm, shotty, and painless nodes that do not suppurate
Painful, tender, and matted nodes forming an abscess
Painful, inflamed, necrotic nodes developing a chronic sinus
explanation: The characteristic feature associated with primary syphilis is firm, shotty, painless nodes that do not suppurate. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the motile spirochete, Treponema pallidum. In primary syphilis, the classical lesion i.e., chancre appears within 9–90 days from the first exposure. The macular lesion becomes papular and then ulcerates. The ulcer(s) is painless and firm, with a punched out base and rolled edges. If left unattended, these heal within 3–9 weeks. It is accompanied by painless inguinal discrete lymphadenopathy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 32-year-old woman known to have syphilis presented with the following lesions over the vulva. What is the stage of the disease?
explanation: The given image shows condyloma lata, a classic finding of secondary syphilis. Multiple moist well-demarcated papules and plaques are seen in condyloma lata. They are highly contagious, exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate and are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area and upper thighs.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sexually active patient was diagnosed with lymphogranuloma venereum. What is the causative organism for this condition?
explanation: The causative agent for lymphogranuloma venereum is Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3). Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted disease that causes genital ulcers. It has the following three stages of infection: Chlamydia trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite that appears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show leucocytes but no organisms. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture is used to isolate the organism. The slide given below is an iodine-stained smear prepared from the patient's endocervical sample. It shows inclusion bodies characteristic of Chlamydia trachomatis. Stage of LGV Characteristic features Primary stage Painless genital ulcerPapules Lymphangitis Secondary sta ge Painful unilateral/bilateral ly mphadenopathyBuboesGroov e sign Late stage Stricture formationFibrosis a nd fistulae of the anogenital r egion
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 26-year-old sexually active man comes to the STD clinic with a painful genital ulcer. On examination, the ulcer and the right inguinal lymph nodes were tender. What is the causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi which is a gram-negative anaerobe. Chancroid is symptomatic in men. Both ulcer and lymphadenopathy are painful. Lymphadenopathy in chancroid is either unilateral or bilateral. Chancroid is generally asymptomatic in women but sometimes presents as painful lymphadenopathy. The image below shows a chancroid ulcer with purulent and haemorrhagic discharge. It has a non-indurated, erythematous base.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sexually active man presents with complaints of painful swelling over the inguinal region. He also gives a history of a painless genital ulcer that resolved spontaneously. On examination, groove sign is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The pathognomic groove sign of Greenblatt is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1, L2, L3). This image shows groove sign which is seen in ■ of the cases in the secondary stage of LGV. It refers to the depression between the enlarged femoral and inguinal lymph nodes on either side of the inguinal ligament. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted disease that causes genital ulcers. It has the following three stages of infection: Stage of LGV Characteristic features Primary stage Painless genital ulcerPapules Lymphangitis Secondary sta ge Painful unilateral/bilateral ly mphadenopathyBuboesGroov e sign Late stage Stricture formationFibrosis a nd fistulae of the anogenital r egion
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 20-year-old female sex worker presents with complaints of constipation and blood in stools for 3 months. On DRE, a circumferential constriction is felt beyond which the finger cannot be advanced. Which of the following is a probable cause for this complication?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rectal stricture which is a complication of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3). Rectal involvement is commonly seen in women as the primary disease often goes unnoticed and untreated. Anorectal involvement causes proctocolitis and causes rectal strictures. This occurs due to the contiguous spread of the primary infection from the perirectal nodes leading to scar tissue formation. The complications of lymphogranuloma venereum include: Rectal stricture formation may lead to: Intestinal obstruction Rectovaginal fistulae Proctitis Vulvar cancer.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale?
explanation: The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva. It is highly contagious and transmitted through repeated sexual or non-sexual contact. The incubation period is 1-12 weeks. Clinical features: It begins as a painless nodule which later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers that tend to coalesce; the vulva is progressively destroyed, and minimal adenopathy may occur. Diagnosis: Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/ biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety pin) appearance. B ue-black stained organisms are seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear cells. Management: Azithromycin 1 g orally once per week or 500 mg daily for at least 3 weeks and until all lesions have completely healed. The given image below shows the donovanosis in a female patient with a beefy red ulcer:
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 19-year-old girl presented with multiple beefy-red ulcers over the labia. Microscopic examination of smear from the lesion showed intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and gram-negative bacteria having a safety pin appearance. What is your likely diagnosis?
Lymphogranuloma inguinale
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by a gram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected, they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resembling keloids. The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged.
