New lesions can appear along the lymphatic drainage channels. The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance of the hypervascular intravaginal tissues. The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The Pap smear of a healthy 30-year-old lady is given below. Identify the microorganism seen.
explanation: The organism seen in the given image of a Pap smear is the Doderlien’s bacillus, also known as Lactobacillus. This is a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus that grows in anaerobic conditions. It is a part of the normal vaginal flora that is responsible for the vaginal defence mechanism. It is an estrogen-dependent bacillus and appears at puberty and disappears after menopause. It converts glycogen into lactic acid and maintains the acidic ph in the vagina. This prevents the growth of pathogenic bacteria in the vagina. Its absence causes a condition called bacterial vaginosis where pathogenic organisms replaces the normal flora of the vagina. In this condition, clue cells are visible. Option B: Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common organism involved in bacterial vaginosis. As the patient in the given question is healthy, this is not the correct option. Option C: Trichomonas vaginalis is flagellated protozoa that causes trichomonas vaginitis. The organism and the nucleus of epithelial cells appear equal in size on the pap smear. This criterion is used for the identification of trichomonas as flagella are not visible on a pap smear. Option D: Frisch bacillus is another name for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It is not seen on Pap smears.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: All of the following are risk factors for PID except .
explanation: Pregnancy is not a risk factor for PID. Instead, it plays a protective role in this condition. The risk factors for developing PID are: Unprotected sexual intercourse Having multiple sex partners Previous history of PID IUD insertion Early age of sexual intercourse (<18years) The protective factors for PID are: Pregnancy Using barrier contraception like condoms, diaphragms Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) Menopause
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the following is not included in this condition?
explanation: Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, typically causing: Endometritis Salpingitis Oophoritis Peritonitis The minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are: Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following: Uterine tenderness Cervical motion tenderness Adnexal tenderness Cervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common symptom seen in acute PID?
options: Pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen
explanation: The most common symptom of acute PID is bilateral lower abdominal pain. The pain is severe in acute stages and it may or may not be accompanied by a high temperature ( >38.3° C). It may be followed by vomiting. Some patients with PID can present with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. This is seen in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome which is a form of perihepatitis. If PID occurs due to sexually transmitted organisms, dysuria and vaginal discharge may be seen.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman with fever and lower abdominal pain is diagnosed to have PID. Which is the most common cause for this condition?
explanation: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of PID. PID is an infection of the upper genital tract. It is generally transmitted sexually as an ascending infection along with sperms. It is usually a polymicrobial infection, Organisms causing PID include: Sexually transmitted: Chlamydia (most common) Gonococcus Mycoplasma Trichomonas Pyogenic Aerobes: Staphylococci Streptococci E Coli Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis Peptostreptococcus Clostridium Actinomyces (most common in IUD users) Other: Mycobacterium tuberculosis Note: Genital tuberculosis is the only PID that does not spread sexually. It has a hematogenous spread. Thus, it is the most common PID in virgin girls.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 42-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with abdominal pain and fever for the last 48 hours. She has been using a Cu T 380A for contraception for the past 8 years. On examination, cervical motion tenderness was present. What is the most likely organism to have caused her condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of PID in an IUCD user. The most common organism causing this condition is Actinomyces. It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if the device is worn for more than 2 years. This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strict follow up of women wearing these devices. Organisms causing PID are: Sexually transmitted: Chlamydia (most common) Gonococcus Mycoplasma Trichomonas Pyogenic Aerobes: Staphylococci Streptococci E Coli Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis Peptostreptococcus Clostridium Actinomyces (most common in IUD users) Other: Mycobacterium tuberculosis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory disease?
explanation: The mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory disease is mucosal. Gonococci ascend to the tubes mainly through mucosal continuity. This is facilitated by sexually transmitted vectors such as sperms and Trichomonas. The mucous membranes of the fallopian tubes are affected first. They become edematous and are infiltrated with leukocytes and plasma cells. Another route of spread is through the reflux of mucosal blood. Option A: Hematogenous spread is seen in genital tuberculosis. Option B: Lymphatics are involved in the spread of secondary organisms and in PID following post-abortal and puerperal infection. Option C: Parametrium facilitates the spread of Mycoplasma. The gut flora can directly spread to tubes.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which infection causes more damage to the mucosa and the wall of the tube leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage?
explanation: Among the given options, chlamydial infection causes the most amount of damage to the mucosa and the wall of the fallopian tubes leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage. Chlamydial infection can remain asymptomatic in the endo-cervix. Hence, the infection goes unnoticed and untreated. Thus, it can lead to more damage and complications. Gonococcal infection is more symptomatic than chlamydial infection. Hence, it is diagnosed early and causes less damage to the tubes than chlamydial infection. Mycoplasma and Mobiluncus generally cause lower genital tract infections like cervicitis and vaginitis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis of acute PID?
explanation: Pelvic endometriosis is not a differential diagnosis of acute PID. It is a differential diagnosis of chronic PID. Differential diagnosis of acute PID: Acute appendicitis Septic abortion Cholecystitis Twisted ovarian cyst Ectopic pregnancy Diverticulitis Ruptured endometriotic cyst Differential diagnosis of chronic PID: Uterine fibroids Pelvic endometriosis Ovarian tumou Tubercular tubo-ovarian mass
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 26-year-old female with endometritis did not complete the course of antibiotics she was prescribed. Following this, her infection failed to resolve and she developed a tubo-ovarian mass. How can this mass manifest?
explanation: The given scenario of development of a chronic tubo-ovarian mass following acute PID points towards a diagnosis of chronic PID. A chronic tubo-ovarian mass can manifest as a tubo-ovarian cyst, hydrosalpinx or even a chronic pyosalpinx. Failure to complete treatment of acute PID or drug resistance can lead to the development of chronic PID. This can lead to the development of chronic tubo-ovarian masses which may manifest as: Hydrosalpinx Chronic pyosalpinx Chronic interstitial salpingitis Tubo-ovarian cyst Tuberculous form A twisted ovarian cyst and a ruptured endometriotic cyst are differential diagnoses of acute PID.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition seen in the image given below?
options: Flattening of tubal plicae is seen on histology
Its ampullary region is filled with clear fluid
explanation: The above image depicts a hydrosalpinx. Its wall is not opaque but translucent. If a pyosalpinx responds to antibiotics, the pus present inside becomes sterile within 6 weeks of the initial attack. However, the damage to the tube remains as chronic pyosalpinx or hydrosalpinx. A hydrosalpinx represents the end result of previous acute salpingitis and is often bilateral. The tube becomes retort shaped due to the enormous dilatation of the ampullary region that is filled with clear fluid. Histological examination shows a flattening of the tubal plicae and exfoliation of the lining epithelium.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with fever and abdominal pain presented to the emergency. On examination, you note mucopurulent vaginal discharge and cervical motion tenderness. You suspect she has PID. Which of these is not included in the criteria to diagnose this condition?
explanation: Bilateral abdominal pain is not included in the criteria to diagnose PID. Bilateral abdominal pain is a clinical symptom of PID. Lower abdominal tenderness is included in the criteria to diagnose PID. CDC criteria for the diagnosis of PID: Definitive criteria: Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy Imaging study (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess) Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria: Cervical motion tenderness Uterine tenderness Adnexal tenderness Additional criteria: Oral temperature >38.3 oC Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge, cervical friability Raised ESR or CRP Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a definitive criterion used to diagnose PID?
explanation: A temperature of more than 38.3°C is an additional criterion and not a definitive criterion for the diagnosis of PID. CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID: Definitive criteria: Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (Tubo-ovarian abscess) Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria: Lower abdominal tenderness Adnexal tenderness Cervical motion tenderness Additional criteria: Oral temperature>38.3C Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability Raised ESR or CRP Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old woman presented with bilateral abdominal pain for 3 days and a temperature of 102°F. She also had a mucopurulent vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and a negative urine pregnancy test. Which is the gold standard investigation to confirm her likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is likely to be acute PID. Laparoscopy is the gold standard to confirm acute PID. Laparoscopy is not done routinely as it is an invasive procedure. It is reserved for only cases where the differential diagnosis is salpingitis, appendicitis, ectopic pregnancy or a case of a non-responding pelvic mass. The diagnosis of PID is mostly clinical. If diagnosis is unclear, the investigation of choice for PID is USG and culdocentesis. CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID: Definitive criteria: Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess) Laparoscopic evidence of PID Minimum criteria: Lower abdominal tenderness Adnexal tenderness Cervical motion tenderness Additional criteria: Oral temperature>38.3C Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability Raised ESR or CRP Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The laparoscopy report of a woman with pelvic inflammatory disease states she has Gainesville stage III PID. Which of the following presentations could have been seen in her?
explanation: Gainesville stage III includes two forms of PID - acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex. Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage as follows: Stage Condition Stage I Acute salpingitis without peri tonitis - no adhesions Stage I I Acute salpingitis with periton itis - purulent discharge Stage I II Acute salpingitis with superi mposed tubal occlusion or tu bo-ovarian complex Stage I V Ruptured tubo-ovarian absce ss Stage V Tubercular salpingitis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient with PID, laparoscopy shows the following appearance. What is true about the syndrome this patient likely has?
explanation: The image shows the laparoscopic finding of violin string adhesions that are characteristic of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. It is a form of perihepatitis that occurs in the setting of PID. It is characterized by right upper quadrant pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder. It rarely occurs in women with acute PID. The pathological mechanism is as follows: Gonococcal / Chlamydial infection  transperitoneal/vascular spread  inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surfaces  adhesions and fibrosis in the perihepatic region  Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome Cholecystitis and ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess are the differential diagnoses of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. Violin string adhesions would not be seen in these conditions.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the wrong statement with respect to silent PID.
options: Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood
explanation: Dysmenorrhea rarely occurs in PID. Pain is uncommon and is a result of subacute PID. Silent PID is thought to follow multiple or continuous low-grade infections in asymptomatic women. It is not a clinical diagnosis. Rather, it is an ultimate diagnosis given to women with tubal-factor infertility who lack a history of upper genital tract infection. On laparoscopy or laparotomy, these women may have evidence of prior tubal infection such as adhesions, but for the most part, the fallopian tubes are grossly normal. They can have ectopic pregnancies due to tubal dysmotility. Silent PID can occur following infection with M. tuberculosis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient is admitted to the gynaecology ward for pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the following is a part of this patient's treatment regimen?
options: Administration of cefotetan 2 g IV 12 hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV BD
Removal of IUD irrespective of antibiotic response
Administration of a single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM
Administration of 10 doses of Placentrex 2ml IM daily or on alternate days
explanation: Administration of cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours forms the crux of the treatment regimen for PID. This is followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/-metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days in all hospitalized patients having PID. Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients: Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route. Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia. Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines): A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks. IUD is not removed in a woman who responds to antibiotics. It is removed only in case of a failed antibiotic response. Barrier contraceptives and OCPs are recommended only in women unresponsive to antibiotics. The use of Placentrex (aqueous extract of the placenta) is outdated and is not recommended currently.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with fever, lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge. On examination, her vitals are stable and per vaginal examination reveals lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness. What is the best treatment option for her?
options: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 14 days
Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
Oral ofloxacin 200 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days
explanation: The given clinical scenario of fever and lower abdominal pain associated with lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID. The best treatment option for this patient is outpatient treatment with a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days. Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines): A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks. Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients: Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route. Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following would be an indication for surgery in a 30-year-old woman diagnosed with PID?
explanation: Intestinal obstruction would be an indication for surgery in a patient diagnosed with PID. Criteria for surgery in PID include: Drainage of pelvic abscess by colpotomy. Dilatation and evacuation of septic products of conception or for haemorrhage in the postabortal period. Acute spreading peritonitis resistant to a full course of chemotherapy. Presence of pyoperitoneum mandates laparotomy. Intestinal obstruction Suspected intestinal injury as diagnosed in criminal abortion. Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess A tubo-ovarian abscess of 2 cm is not an indication for surgery. Minimally invasive surgery is done in a tubo-ovarian abscess measuring more than 10 cm, that fails to respond to antibiotics in 48-72 hours. Peritonitis and sepsis are not an indication for surgery. They should be managed medically first. If they do not respond to antibiotic treatment then surgical management should be done.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following is an indication for minimally invasive surgery for tubo-ovarian abscess?
options: The size of the abscess is more than 5 cm
The size of the abscess is more than 2cm
The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48 - 72 h
The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 24 - 36 h
explanation: If the abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48–72 h, minimally invasive surgery is indicated. Criteria for minimally invasive surgery in PID: The size of the abscess is more than 10 cm The abscess fails to respond to antibiotics in 48-72 hours The abscess ruptures Pyoperitoneum Minimal invasive surgery includes laparoscopic drainage of the tubo ovarian abscess or posterior colpotomy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 55-year-old multiparous woman who presented with chronic lower abdominal pain has been diagnosed with chronic PID. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
explanation: The treatment of choice for an old multiparous woman with chronic PID is abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. A radical hysterectomy involves the removal of the whole uterus, tissue from the sides of the uterus, the cervix, and the upper part of the vagina. It is generally done only in cancer patients. A supracervical hysterectomy involves the removal of only the body of the uterus and is not done in chronic PID. It is done for the treatment of endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and uterine prolapse.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Who has described the prognostic evaluation for PID?
explanation: Boer-Meisel has described the prognostic evaluation for PID. It depends upon the following: Extent of adhesions Nature of adhesions such as flimsy or dense. Size of hydrosalpinx Macroscopic condition of hydrosalpinx. The thickness of the tubal wall. Boer-Meisel system is specifically used for predicting pregnancy outcomes in patients treated for PID. Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage. Westrom has reported that women with one previous attack of PID have a predisposition to another attack. Stages of PID Stage I Acute salpingitis without peri tonitis - no adhesions Stage I I Acute salpingitis with periton itis- purulent discharge Stage I II Acute salpingitis with superi mposed tubal occlusion or tu bo-ovarian complex Stages of PID Stages of PID Stage I V Ruptured tubo-ovarian absce ss Stage V Tuberculous salpingitis
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions?
Pyometra
explanation: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to pyometra. This refers to the collection of pus in the uterine cavity. The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Unilateral pain and swelling over the labia may be caused by the inflammation of the Bartholin glands. Depending on the extent of tissue involved, PID can be classified into five stages Stage I - Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - No adhesions Stage II - Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge Stage III - Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo ovarian complex Stage IV - Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess Stage V - Tubercular salpingitis Long-standing pelvic inflammation may also lead to: Dyspareunia Infertility Ectopic pregnancy Formation of adhesions like hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian abscess Chronic pelvic pain Note: Chronic pelvic inflammation leads to dense adhesions between the uterus and the appendages. Thus, it becomes difficult to define the uterus from the pelvic masses. They form a hard mass which is called the frozen pelvis. The most common cause of the spread of PID: Ascending infection along with sperms The only PID that does not spread with the sexual route is genital TB. It has a hematogenous spread. The most common PID in virgin females is genital TB. Investigation of choice in PID: Abdominal USG The surest sign of salpingitis is pus extruding from the fimbrial end of the tube. Genital Tuberculosis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for genital tuberculosis?
explanation: The ampulla of the fallopian tubes is the most common site for genital tuberculosis. The distribution of genital tuberculosis is given below: Site Percent age Fallopian tubesAmpulla is th 90-100 e most common site.Intramu % ral part is the least common site.Fimbriae are not involve d even in advanced genital T B. Endometrium 50-60% Ovaries 20-30% Cervix 5-15% Vulva and vagina <1%
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common mode of transmission of tuberculosis to the endometrium?
explanation: Endometrial tuberculosis is most commonly acquired by direct spread from the fallopian tubes. Hematogenous spread is thought to be the process by which the tubercle bacilli implant into the mucosa of the fallopian tubes and subsequently affect the endometrium by direct extension. Female genital tuberculosis is an important cause of significant morbidity, short and long-term sequelae especially infertility. Genital tuberculosis usually occurs secondary to pulmonary (commonest) or extrapulmonary TB like gastrointestinal, renal, skeletal, and miliary TB. However, primary genital TB can rarely occur in women whose male partners have active genitourinary TB (e.g., tuberculosis epididymitis) by transmission through infected semen Most common site involved in secondary genital TB is fallopian tube (90-100%) >endometrium (50-80%) >ovaries (20-30%) >cervix 5-15%) >vulva. The most common symptom of genital TB is infertility. Causes of infertility in genital TB: Tubal blockage If tubes are patent, then also infertility occurs due to loss of tubal function. Tubercular endometritis causes uterine scarring resulting in the destruction of the endometrium. Ovarian damage with poor ovarian reserve and volume A laparoscopy and dye hydrotubation (lap and dye test) is the most reliable tool to diagnose genital TB, especially for tubal, ovarian and peritoneal disease. The test can be combined with hysteroscopy. Multiple drug therapy ( ATT regimen provided by DOTS) in adequate doses and for sufficient duration is the mainstay in the treatment of TB including genital tuberculosis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman with fertility issues is diagnosed to have genital tuberculosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: The causative agent is Mycobacterium bovis
It generally occurs secondary to a primary focus
It commonly presents as a unilateral condition
explanation: Genital tuberculosis is a bilateral condition. It can be caused by both Mycobacterium tuberculosis (95% cases) and Mycobacterium bovis (5% cases). It almost always occurs secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body. The most common primary focus is lungs > lymph nodes > abdomen > generalised miliary infection. It mostly spreads hematogenously. Lymphatic spread is also seen sometimes. It can rarely spread by direct contact with the affected intraabdominal organs or peritoneum. The fallopian tubes are the first to be affected. The disease subsequently spreads to other genital organs and the peritoneum. This is followed by the involvement of bilateral pelvic lymph nodes. Vulvovaginal involvement is usually secondary to uterine involvement. The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common presenting symptom of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group?
explanation: The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility. Genital tuberculosis mostly presents in young women in the reproductive age group. It can present as: Infertility is the only complaint in 35-60 % of cases. Of these, 75% of women present with primary infertility. Menstrual abnormalities are seen in 10-40% of cases. Asymptomatic in 10% of cases. Other symptoms like fever and malaise can be seen. The treatment of infertility in women with genital TB depends on the condition of the endometrium. If the endometrium is receptive and the uterus is normal, then assisted reproductive techniques such as in-vitro fertilisation can be tried. If the endometrium is unfavourable then surrogacy may be considered.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a patient with tubercular salpingitis, which of the following statements is false?
options: The tubes are enlarged, roughened, and may show presence of greyish tubercles
The ampulla of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting
The granulomas and hyperplasia seen can be mistaken for carcinoma
The fimbriae are commonly involved in advanced tuberculous salpingitis
explanation: The fimbriae are often spared even in advanced forms of tubercular salpingitis. The involvement of fallopian tubes is 100% and bilateral, secondary to hematogenous spread. The ampullary part of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting. This gives the characteristic tobacco-pouch appearance as seen in the image below. The external surface of the tubes are enlarged, roughened, and may show the presence of greyish tubercles. The cut section shows yellowish-grey caseous matter in the lumen. Sometimes, serosanguinous fluid can also be seen in the lumen of the fallopian tube. This is called tuberculous hematosalpinx. On histopathological examination of the tubes, granulomas and chronic inflammatory infiltrate with hyperplasia is seen. This could be mistaken for malignancy as it also produces a similar histological image.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhoea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with abdominal pain, amenorrhoea, pelvic mass and ascites is suggestive of genital tuberculosis. Genital tuberculosis: It is caused by M. tuberculosis and almost always occurs secondary to primary infection elsewhere in the extragenital states. The sites and frequency of involvement are as follows: Fallopian tubes (90-100%) Endometrium (50-60%) Ovaries (20-30%) Cervix (5-15%) Vulva and vagina (< 1%) Presentation is variable and it can be asymptomatic in 10-20% of cases, infertility, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain and mass, vaginal discharge, fistula formation, ectopic pregnancy and ascites. The mass is made up of rolled-up omentum that is adherent to the uterus and adnexa. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weakness, anorexia or night sweats may be present. Investigations: CBC, ESR and Mantoux test Hysterosalpingography shows a lead-pipe appearance of the fallopian tube, calcification of the tube, beading and variation in the filling, cornual block, jagged fluffiness of tubal outline and tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx. Laparoscopy establishes the diagnosis of genital TB. It shows tuberculous lesions and perihepatic adhesions (if present). Differential diagnosis: Ovarian cyst, broad ligament cyst or encysted fluid Pelvic inflammatory disease Ectopic pregnancy Carcinoma cervix Elephantiasis of the vulva Pregnancy Puberty menorrhagia and postmenopausal bleeding Fungal infection and sarcoidosis Management: It is treated with anti-tubercular therapy for 6 months (DOT strategy): Indications and contraindications for surgery: Types of surgery include vulvectomy (if vulval hypertrophy is present), removal of the adnexal mass, drainage of pyometra and fistula repair. TAH+BSO is rarely required nowadays. Tuboplasty is contraindicated. Option B: Ovarian tumors usually don't affect menstrual cycles. Though virilizing tumors can cause amenorrhoea, other features of virilization such as hirsutism, flattening of breasts, and enlargement of the clitoris are generally present. Option C: Though ectopic pregnancy may be suspected here, the tube is likely to rupture with exacerbation of pain, bleeding, and peritonitis before six months of gestation. Additionally, the absence of vaginal bleeding/spotting, and the presence of weight loss makes the diagnosis unlikely. Option D: Submucous fibroid is associated with menorrhagia. First 2 months Next 4 months Isoniazid 15 mg/ kg body wei ghtRifampicin 450-600 mgP yrazinamide 30 mg/body wei ghtEthambutol 30 mg/ kg bo dy weight3 times a week. Isoniazid 15 mg/kg body weig htRifampicin 450-600 mg3 ti mes a week Indications Contraindications Unresponsiveness of the dise ase in spite of adequate antit ubercular chemotherapy.Tub ercular pyosalpinx, ovarian a bscess or pyometra.Persisten t menorrhagia and/or chronic pelvic pain causing deteriora ting health status Presence of active tuberculosi s in extragenital siteFavorabl e response to antimicrobial t herapy with the diminishing size of the pelvic massThe ac cidental discovery of tubercul ar tubo-ovarian mass on lapa rotomy in a young patient.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A gynaecologist suspects tuberculous salpingitis in a young woman and suggests some investigations to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is true about these investigations?
options: A differential WBC count shows lymphocytosis in advanced disease.
The ESR is frequently raised and is non-specific in early disease.
The Mantoux test is positive and indicative of current exposure to tubercle bacilli.
The Quantiferon test is positive and indicates latent tuberculosis.
explanation: The Quantiferon test will be positive in patients having genital TB. It is an indicator of latent tuberculosis. The Quantiferon test measures the release of interferon-gamma by T cells following stimulation by antigens unique to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. A differential WBC count shows lymphocytosis at all stages of genital tuberculosis. The ESR is frequently raised and is a non-specific investigation at any stage of the disease. None of these tests can be used for confirmation as these markers are raised in many infections. The Mantoux test is positive in 90% of cases of genital TB. It is indicative of past exposure to the tubercle bacilli. It is not a confirmatory investigation but a negative result indicates tuberculosis to be unlikely.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Hysterosalpingography was done in a young woman with infertility and menstrual abnormalities. Which of the following findings would not point towards a diagnosis of tubercular salpingitis?
options: A wedge shaped defect at the uterine isthmus
Beading and variations in filling defect
Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
explanation: A wedge-shaped defect is not suggestive of tubercular salpingitis. It is seen at the uterine isthmus in patients with a history of Cesarean section with a uterine scar. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) features of genital tuberculosis are: Lead pipe appearance due to rigid nonperistaltic pipe-like tube Beading and variation in filling defect Calcification of the tube Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube. Rosette type appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular like outpouching surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration. HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes. The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. The tubercle bacilli are present in the deeper layers of the endometrium. They come to the surface just before menstruation. Hence, an endometrial biopsy is done 1 or 2 days before menstruation. Menstrual blood can also be used for detecting mycobacteria. An HSG showing the features of tuberculous salpingitis is given below.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
The image below shows the hysterosalpingogram of a 37-year-old nulliparous woman. Identify the false statement about this finding.

It is a thick walled structure on sonography
options: Tubal plicae are flattened on histology
explanation: The given image shows bilateral hydrosalpinx. It appears as a thin-walled structure. A hydrosalpinx is a chronic cystic swelling of the fallopian tube that forms after a distal tubal obstruction. The tubes are enormously distended due to filling with clear serous fluid and become retort-shaped. On histology, the tubal plicae appear flattened. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during HSG. It is caused due to: Pelvic inflammatory disease Endometriosis Tuberculosis - tubercular salpingitis may also cause tobacco-pouch appearance, lead pipe appearance and pyosalpinx Fallopian tube neoplasms (rare) It can be an incidental finding during a pelvic exam or ultrasound. The patient may be asymptomatic, or present with infertility or chronic pelvic pain. On HSG, it appears as terminal sacculation and occlusion of both fallopian tubes with a normal uterine cavity. Usually, a thin-walled, hypoechoic, cystic structure is seen. However, it may appear as multiple hyperechoic mural nodules around the inner circumference of the tube creating a 'beads on a string' appearance. Treatment: Treat the underlying cause Laparoscopic salpingostomy - in mild disease IVF recommended for women with infertility and severe hydrosalpinx Infertility
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation required to establish the diagnosis of infertility in a couple?
explanation: The accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation to establish the diagnosis of infertility in a couple is one year of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse. Infertility is an apparent failure of a couple to conceive while sterility is an absolute inability to conceive. Infertility is of two types: Primary infertility - when there have been no previous pregnancies. Secondary infertility - when there has been a prior pregnancy (although not necessarily a live birth).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of male infertility?
explanation: The most common cause of male infertility is disorders of spermatogenesis. Male factor is the cause of infertility in about 20% of infertile couples. However, it is a contributing factor for infertility in 50% of cases.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of .
explanation: The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of inhibin secreted by Sertoli cells. GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to secrete FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinizing hormone). FSH acts on Sertoli cells while LH triggers testosterone secretion by the Leydig cells. Sertoli cells secrete inhibin B which in turn inhibits FSH but stimulate LH secretion.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old man underwent semen analysis as a part of an infertility workup. The results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is normospermia. Different types of disorders of sperms are as follows: Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen. Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL. Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL. Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology. Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility. Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms. Note: Morphology > motility is the most important marker in sperm analysis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: While going through a patient's file at an infertility clinic, you note his semen analysis is reported to be normal. What had his semen leukocyte level likely been?
explanation: The normal leucocyte level in human semen is approximately 1 million/ml. The semen sample should be collected after 2-7 days of ejaculatory abstinence. The patient should collect the sample by masturbation at the doctor's office. If not possible, then the sample may be collected at home and delivered to the laboratory within an hour of collection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What does azoospermia refer to?
explanation: Azoospermia is defined as the complete absence of sperm in semen. Other types of sperm disorders are as follows: Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen. Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL. Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL. Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology. Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility. Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young couple being treated for infertility require donor semen for artificial insemination. Which of the following is the likely cause of infertility here?
options: Presence of antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucucs
explanation: Artificial insemination with donor semen is done in cases of infertility where the husband has azoospermia. Azoospermia is defined as a complete absence of sperms. Hence artificial insemination with the husband's/partner's semen cannot be performed. Indications for artificial insemination with husband's/partner's semen are: Chronic medical disorder Oligospermia after sperm washout Impotence Premature and retrograde ejaculation Hypospadias Antisperm antibodies in cervical mucus Unexplained infertility- direct intraperitoneal insemination (DIPI) is done HIV-positive male or female X-Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection in cases of genetic and chromosomal abnormalities Indications for artificial insemination with donor semen are: Azoospermia Uncorrectable immunological factors Genetic disease in husband/partner Chronic ill health Sperms can be frozen and used later for artificial insemination e.g. if the husband requires to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy, or if the husband is a frequent traveler and is not available at the time of ovulation. Artificial insemination techniques include: Intrauterine Insemination (IUI) Intrafallopian-tube Insemination Intracervical Insemination Direct Intraperitoneal Insemination (DIPI) Steps required to do artificial insemination are: The semen is washed to remove abnormal sperms, debris, and seminal plasma containing antibodies. It is concentrated, and its quality is improved by the 'swim up technique' or by the use of the Percoll gradient. Semen with normal sperms and good motility is obtained. Around the time of ovulation, semen obtained is inseminated into the female genital tract. About 0.5 ml of semen is injected 36 hours after hCG injection when the ovarian follicle reaches 20 mm.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Indications for artificial insemination with donor's semen are all except .
explanation: Artificial insemination with donor's semen is not indicated in idiopathic male infertility. The preferred treatment in such cases is in vitro fertilization (IVF).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 50-year-old man with erectile dysfunction requires treatment with sildenafil. Which of the following is not a contraindication for the use of this drug?
explanation: Pulmonary hypertension is an indication for the use of sildenafil. The contraindications for the use of sildenafil are: Retinitis pigmentosa Diabetic retinopathy Patient on antihypertensive drugs, nitrates Cardiac disease, previous myocardial infarct, stroke In the treatment of erectile dysfunction, sildenafil in the dose of 25–100 mg is given 1 hour before intercourse. However, it does not improve libido.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of infertility in women?
explanation: The most common cause for infertility in women is due to ovarian causes. According to WHO, female factor infertility was reported in 37% of infertile couples in developed countries. Male factor infertility was reported in 8% of infertile couples while 35% of couples had both male and female factor infertility. The major ovarian causes of infertility are: Anovulation (PCOS) Decreased ovarian reserve, e.g., premature menopause In women with ovulatory disorders, clomifene and metformin increase ovulation and pregnancy rates. Less common factors responsible for female infertility are: Endometriosis Pelvic adhesions Tubal blockage Other tubal abnormalities Hyperprolactinemia
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 34-year-old woman presented with secondary infertility following radiation therapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma. You plan to test her ovarian reserve. Which of the following is the best indicator of this parameter?
explanation: Among the given options, the level of follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) is the best indicator of ovarian reserve. Ovarian reserve is the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase on day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle. A high FSH level indicates that the ovarian reserve is getting depleted and fewer oocytes are present in the ovary. FSH is high in ovarian hypofunction and postmenopausal women. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a better marker than FSH for ovarian reserve. Unlike FSH, its levels can be estimated at any time of the cycle. AMH is produced by the granulosa cells in ovarian follicles. Note: Studies show that AMH levels decrease under the current use of oral contraceptive pills and tobacco smoking.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve?
explanation: In low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) will be <1 ng/ml. AMH is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of the primordial follicle of the ovary. It helps in oocyte maturation and mono-follicular development. AMH is also used in assessing ovarian reserve. In women, AMH is always absent during embryogenesis and is secreted by the granulosa cells after puberty. It helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. Estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in female infertility and secondary amenorrhoea. In men, AMH starts to be secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testes by the 7th week of intrauterine life. It continues until puberty. It inhibits the development of the Müllerian system. The absence of AMH results in the development of hermaphroditism. AMH levels in ng/ ml Interpretation 2–6.8 Normal <1 Poor ovarian reserve >10 PCODHyperstimulation synd rome
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In a woman diagnosed with infertility, which of the following antihormonal substance can be used to induce ovulation?
explanation: Clomiphene citrate is an antihormonal substance used to induce ovulation in a patient diagnosed with infertility. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting from day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility, and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
explanation: The image depicts the proliferative phase of the endometrium. During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely; proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below: Proliferative phase The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium. Arteries become more coiled and spiralled. The endometrium is thick, the stoma is compact and short straight glands are present. The image below shows proliferative endometrium Secretory phase The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation. Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity) Corkscrew-shaped glands The image below shows secretory endometrium Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The microscopic appearance of the cervical mucus of a woman having irregular periods and infertility is shown in the image below. In which phase of the menstrual cycle was this sample likely taken?
explanation: The image shows the characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus which is seen in the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle. A specimen of cervical mucus is obtained using a platinum loop or pipette. This is spread on a clean glass slide and allowed to dry. When viewed under the low-power microscope, a palm leaf or fern type pattern is seen in the follicular phase. The ferning is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the effect of estrogen. This pattern disappears after ovulation. If it was previously present, its disappearance is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity. Under the influence of progesterone, the cervical mucus becomes thick and tenacious and impenetrable to sperms and bacteria. The below image shows the microscopic appearance of dried cervical mucus showing the fern appearance.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the Miller-Kurzrok test?
options: Penetration of > 3 cm at 30 minutes is considered normal
Cervical mucus is placed alongside husband's semen on a glass slide
It is done at the time of ovulation
Jerky motility of sperm is considered normal
explanation: In the Miller–Kurzrok test, sperm acquiring jerky motility after penetrating cervical mucus is considered abnormal. The Miller-Kurzrok test is a special test done in semen analysis to diagnose the cause of infertility. It is an in vitro test of sperm–mucus interaction. It is based on the basic principle that a normal cervical mucus permits invasion by motile sperms. It is done at the time of ovulation. The test consists of placing cervical mucus on a glass slide alongside the specimen of the husband's semen and studying the penetration of sperms under the microscope. The penetration of sperm > 3 cm into the mucus at 30 minutes is considered normal. Other special tests in semen analysis include: Sperm penetration test Semen–cervical mucus contact test Postcoital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A post-coital test was done in a couple who presented with an inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. Which of the following conditions cannot be detected by this test?
explanation: The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions: Sperm count Sperm morphology Ferning during the estrogenic effect Ovulation The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucous In the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to the ovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. On microscopy, 10–50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucus is also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence of cervical infection. An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: During your posting in the infertility clinic, you notice the following instrument. Identify it.
explanation: The instrument in the given image is Rubin's cannula. It is used while performing a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). The cone prevents the retrograde spillage of the dye into the vagina, while the dye is instilled into the uterine cavity. This investigation is performed to study tubal patency in women. Another cannula that can be used to perform HSG is Spackman cannula. It allows for the intra-operative manipulation of both anteverted and retroverted uterus.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient with secondary amenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed to have Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall. How would you classify this patient?
options: Cannot be classified with the given information
explanation: This patient would be classified as a case of moderate Asherman syndrome as 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces are present. Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows: Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia. Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall. Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions. Asherman syndrome can present in the following ways: Secondary amenorrhea Oligomenorrhoea Dysmenorrhoea Habitual abortions Infertility The causes of Asherman syndrome are: Dilatation and curettage (D&C) Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage Uterine infection Tubercular endometritis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old patient with complaints of inability to conceive underwent the following investigation. Which of the following is false about the same?
options: The best time to perform it is before ovulation
It is perfomed to detect uterine anomalies
It is the first-line investigation in genital tuberculosis
Premedication can be done with atropine
explanation: The given image shows a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis. Procedure of HSG: It is best performed in the period between the last day of menses to ovulation, usually on the 9th/10th day of the cycle. 10-15ml radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity via Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. Fluoroscopy is performed as the dye passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia into the peritoneum, and smear the adjacent bowel. It is used for the detection of: Tubal block - It can be due to: Strictures - fibrotic block Inspissated amorphous material Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia. Uterine anomalies Uterine polyps Uterine synechiae The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology. Contraindications: Genital tract infections, such as genital tuberculosis. This is due to the risk of spreading infection. Bleeding Suspected pregnancy Allergy to the dye Premenstrual phase: If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged. Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end. There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient who has been trying to conceive for the past 6 months underwent hysterosalpingography (HSG). The findings are given below. What is your interpretation?
explanation: The given image shows a normal hysterosalpingogram (HSG). Both fallopian tubes are patent with a spill into the peritoneal cavity. The following images show the findings of an abnormal hysterosalpingogram: The hysterosalpingogram given below shows bilateral dilated fallopian tubes with no free spill suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx: The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a unicornuate uterus: The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a bicornuate uterus/septate uterus: There is an overlap in the appearance of the bicornuate uterus and septate/sub-septate uterus on HSG. The distinction lies in the shape of the uterine fundus, which is usually not visible on HSG. An ultrasound or MRI should be done to differentiate between these conditions if intervention is planned. The hysterosalpingogram given below shows filling defects:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which the following are not the advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy?
options: Trauma is avoided as no trocar is needed
Good view of the anterior surface of the ovary and genital organs
explanation: Fertiloscopy helps in obtaining a good view of the posterior surface (and not the anterior surface) of the ovary and genital organs. This is an advantage of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy. The other advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy are: The Trendelenburg position is not needed. The procedure can be done in a lithotomy position Trauma can be avoided as no trocar is needed No CO2: Hydroperitoneum with saline Peritoneal spill can be seen Fertiloscopy is a new mini-invasive diagnostic technique that allows the visualization of the posterior pelvis. In this technique, an optical device is introduced into the pouch of Douglas, through the posterior vaginal fornix, under general/local anaesthesia. It can also be used for small interventions, such as adhesiolysis, ovarian drilling, coagulation of endometriosis spots and to perform chromosalpingoscopy and salpingoscopy. With fertiloscopy, surgical intervention can be avoided and it is a good alternative to diagnostic laparoscopy. The image given below is of a fertiloscope.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the next step in management will be hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery. Tubal contractions, particularly cornual spasms, can give an incorrect impression of proximal fallopian tube obstruction (a false-positive result) on hysterosalpingography. Laparoscopy with chromotubation is therefore considered to confirm the diagnosis of cornual spasm. Laparoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic in this condition. Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides an endoscopic view of the endometrial cavity and tubal ostia via the cervix, performed in the preovulatory phase. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. It is the gold standard investigation for visualizing the uterine cavity and tubal ostia. Contraindications to hysteroscopy are as follows: Acute genital tract infection (Eg: genital herpes infection) Viable intrauterine pregnancy During menstruation, the view is obscured, and the infection rate is high. Scarred uterus and enlarged uterus of size  12 weeks are relative contraindications. Cervical stenosis can cause cervical tears and uterine perforation. Cardiopulmonary disorder due to increased risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema. Known cases of cervical cancer Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the evaluation of tubal factors in infertility, commonly done in the proliferative phase. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. Benefits of laparoscopic evaluation: Tubes: For detection of tubal patency, block (site and side), motility, hydrosalpinx change, eritubal adhesions, fimbrial agglutination Ovaries: PCOS changes, endometriosis, PID, adhesions Uterus: Anomalies, fibroids Peritoneal factors: Adhesions, PID, endometriosis, tuberculosis Therapy at the same sitting (as appropriate) Therapeuticindications of hys teroscopy Diagnosticindications of hyst eroscopy Uterine septumAsherman sy ndromeRetained IUCDPolyp ectomySubmucous fibroidAb normal uterine bleedingTuba l sterilization using sclerosin g agents To study the endocervical mu cosal liningCongenital malfor mations of the uterusEndom etrial tuberculosisMisplaced I UCDEndometrial lesionsEnd ometrial polypAsherman syn dromeCornual tubal blockage Diagnostic Therapeutic (Operative) Age >35 yearsHistory of pelvi c pain, dyspareunia, pelvic su rgery, adhesionsAbnormal H SGFailure to conceive after a reasonable period (6 months) with normal HSGWomen wi th comorbid pelvic pathology (PID, endometriosis) Unexplained infertilityRecon structive tubal surgeryAdhesi olysisFulguration of endomet riotic implantsOvarian drillin g in PCOSGIFT and ZIFT pro cedures
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A woman came to the clinic complaining of amenorrhoea and inability to conceive. She had undergone hypophysectomy for a tumour a year ago. What would be the best line of management for her?
Clomiphene citrate
options: Human menopausal gonadotrophin, followed by hCG
explanation: The best line of management for the given patient is human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG) followed by hCG. The patients who have undergone hypophysectomy i.e. removal of the pituitary gland, can not produce endogenous gonadotropins. Exogenous gonadotropins such as hMG are given to such patients. Timed administration of hCG is needed to induce ovulation after the follicle has matured. The human menopausal gonadotropin is an extract of urine from postmenopausal women. It contains FSH and LH in the required ratio for follicular growth. Clomiphene, letrozole, and GnRH analogs stimulate the release of gonadotropins from the pituitary gland. These are not helpful in a patient whose pituitary gland has been removed. Perimenopause, Menopause and Post-Menopausal Bleeding
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Menopause is defined as cessation of menses for a period of .
explanation: Menopause is defined as cessation of ovarian function for 12 months resulting in permanent amenorrhoea. It is a retrospective diagnosis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with menorrhagia is diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Prior to starting treatment, you want to check if she is premenopausal. On which day of the menstrual cycle will you estimate her FSH levels?
options: On day 2-5 after last menstrual period
On day 11-14 after last menstrual period
explanation: The follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) level is studied on day 2–5 after the last menstrual period to detect the premenopausal stage. It is a period of 3–4 years before menopause and is associated with mild ovarian hormonal deficiency leading to menstrual disorders, especially menorrhagia. The climacteric phase is the phase of waning of ovarian activity. It begins 2 to 3 years before menopause and may continue 2-5 years after menopause. It marks the transition from active to inactive ovarian function and involves physical, sexual, and psychological adjustments. The predictors of approaching menopause include: A fall in the level of inhibin B and a corresponding rise in FSH level A fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) - This is a better marker of ovarian reserve and can be tested on any day of the cycle.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the diagnostic value of FSH in menopause?
explanation: The diagnostic value of FSH in menopause is >40 mIU/mL. Hormone levels in menopausal women: Hormone Level Estradiol 5 to 25 pg/m l FSH >40 mIU/m L LH 50-100 mIU L/ml Growth hormone, inhibin B, AMH Decreases
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the average age of menopause?
explanation: The average age of menopause in India is 47 years, and ranges from 45 to 50 years. Menopause sets in when the follicle number falls below 1000. If this happens before 40 years, it is termed premature menopause while attaining it after 55 years is delayed menopause. The age at which menopause is attained is not related to age at menarche, race, number of pregnancies, socio-economic status, or oral contraceptive pills usage. However, it is directly influenced by smoking and genetic disposition.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A menopausal woman presents with complaints of hot flushes. Which of the following neurotransmitters are responsible for these symptoms?
explanation: Norepinephrine and serotonin are responsible for hot flushes in menopausal women. A fall in the level of estrogen causes a reduction in hypothalamic endorphins. This causes a release of more norepinephrine and serotonin, which lower the set point in the thermoregulatory nucleus. As a result, the heat-loss mechanism is triggered by even subtle changes in core body temperature. Risk factors for hot flushes: Low estradiol levels High BMI Sedentary lifestyle Surgical menopause has increased risk Low socioeconomic status History of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) Depression.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 53-year-old woman presents with episodes of sensation of intense heat involving the face and upper chest which rapidly spreads across the entire body. The episodes last about 2-4 minutes and are associated with profuse sweating. What is the most effective treatment for her?
explanation: The clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a menopausal woman for which the most effective treatment is estrogen therapy. Treatment options include: Hormonal Estrogen therapy - most effective Combined OC pills - given when estrogen is contraindicated Tibolone Non-hormonal Clonidine SSRIs (eg: fluoxetine) Dopamine antagonist Non-prescriptive Vitamin E Soya Isoflavones Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of vasomotor symptoms, osteoporosis (prevention and treatment), and vaginal atrophy. Endometrial hyperplasia can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. Hence, for patients with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone. This is not necessary for women who have undergone hysterectomy. Note: Even though OCPs contain both estrogen and progesterone, a lesser dosage of each component is given for the treatment of hot flushes.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal lady presented with complaints of dyspareunia and vaginal spotting. On examination, the vagina appeared pale with small petechiae. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 3mm thick endometrium with no abnormality. Which among the following would be the next step in management?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic vaginitis. The next step in management should be topical estrogen therapy such as the estradiol-releasing vaginal ring. Atrophic vaginitis is a common cause of post-menopausal bleeding due to low estradiol levels. Patients may present with dry vagina, dyspareunia and a purulent or blood-tinged discharge. The vagina appears pale, dry, and may show petechiae. Treatment of atrophic vaginitis involves topical estrogens in the form of creams, tablets, or rings. Estrogen replacement restores vaginal mucosal elasticity, vaginal fluid secretion levels, blood flow, and sensorimotor responses. Systemic therapy may help prevent recurrence. Vaginal lubricants and moisturizers can be given for symptomatic relief. FOGSI guidelines for evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding:
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Reduction in breast size in post-menopausal women is due to the withdrawal of .
explanation: The reduction in breast size in postmenopausal women is due to the withdrawal of estrogen and progesterone. Estrogen exerts proliferative effects on the ductal component, while progesterone exerts a proliferative effect on the glandular component.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 67-year-old woman is being screened for osteoporosis with a DEXA scan. Which of the following sites are useful for the detection of early rapid bone loss?
explanation: Early rapid bone loss can be determined from a dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan of the hip and lumbar vertebra. The risk for most fractures is inversely proportional to bone density. The reference standard for the diagnostic purpose is DEXA at the hip (femoral neck or total hip). These sites are superior to the spine in predicting hip as well as an overall osteoporotic fracture. DEXA is used to assess bone mineral density (BMD). It is interpreted as follows: Condition T Score range Normal +2.5 and -1.0 Osteopenia -1.0 and -2.5 Osteoporosis -2.5 and below Severe or established osteopo rosis -2.5 and below with one or m ore fracturesOR-3.5 or below even in the absence of fractur es
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Hormone replacement therapy is not indicated in which of the following patients?
explanation: HRT is no longer recommended for the management of menopausal women with ischemic heart disease. Indications for HRT is as follows: Severe hot flushes Premature menopause Surgical oophorectomy Turner syndrome (gonadal dysgenesis).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for estrogen therapy?
explanation: Hypertension is not a contraindication for hormone replacement therapy (HRT). HRT can be initiated in patients with a history of hypertension, diabetes, or smoking; provided they are regularly monitored. Contraindications of estrogen therapy: Breast cancer, uterine cancer, or family history of cancer Previous history of thromboembolic episode Liver and gall bladder diseases Uterine fibroids - as the fibroids may enlarge in size.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about hormone replacement therapy and breast cancer?
options: Cancer risk is not increased up to 3 years of combined HRT
Cancer risk is not increased up to 5 years of estrogen-only replacement therapy
HRT impedes screening for breast cancer with mammography
HRT may cause high grade breast cancer with poor prognosis
explanation: Breast cancer developing subsequent to HRT is of low grade and has a good prognosis. The risk of breast cancer is not increased up to 3 years of HRT and 5 years of estrogen-only replacement therapy. Lower risk is seen with the use of dydrogesterone in HRT. HRT can cause recurrence of breast cancer and is, therefore, contraindicated in a woman who has been treated for breast cancer. HRT increases the density of breast tissue and subsequently impedes the screening for breast cancer with mammography.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are prescribing estrogen therapy for a woman with hot flushes. What is the minimum number of days in a month during which you should combine it with progesterone?
explanation: A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone must be added to estrogen therapy. This reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%. The risk of cancer with estrogen therapy is dose and duration-dependent. Combined estrogen and progesterone provides better protection against endometrial cancer. Tibolone is a safe drug and does not cause endometrial hyperplasia.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 50-year-old woman presents with complaints of vaginal bleeding and mentions that her last menstrual period was 10 months ago. What is the minimum duration of amenorrhoea following which she should be evaluated for possible causes?
explanation: Vaginal bleeding occurring after 6 months of amenorrhoea in women of menopausal age group should be considered as postmenopausal bleeding and investigated. This must be done irrespective of a previous diagnosis of menopause. All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma. Even in those women who are perimenopausal, endometrial carcinoma must be suspected if they fall under the above-mentioned clinical category.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
explanation: Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high. For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step. Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include: Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially n females >35 years. Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used. Hysteroscopy and biopsy is the investigation of choice for endometrial cancer. Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy. Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool. If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy. Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Visualization of a mass with a single feeding vessel on a color Doppler is characteristic of an endometrial polyp. In contrast, submucous leiomyomas often receive blood flow from multiple vessels (option A). Endometrial polyps are soft, fleshy growths within the uterus that consist of endometrial glands, fibrous stroma, and surface epithelium. Risk factors for endometrial polyps include increasing age, obesity, and tamoxifen use. They are usually asymptomatic. When symptomatic, they present with heavy menstrual bleeding, prolonged bleeding, intermenstrual bleeding, or infertility. The main diagnostic tools for endometrial polyps include transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) with applied color Doppler, saline infusion sonography, and hysteroscopy. The risk factors for the malignant transformation include postmenopausal status, age older than 60, and abnormal bleeding. Other factors such as larger polyp size (>1.5 cm), tamoxifen use, diabetes, and obesity may also contribute to a higher risk. Hysteroscopic polypectomy may be considered most effective for symptomatic women or those with risk factors for malignant transformation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A patient is planned to undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. What is the ideal agent for distention?
Glycine
explanation: Normal saline is the ideal fluid media used for bipolar electrocautery as it can function regardless of the fluid electrolyte content. Normal saline and lactated Ringer solutions are commonly used isotonic, electrolyte-containing fluids in operating rooms for diagnostic hysteroscopy procedures. These solutions can cause volume overload and, if rapidly absorbed in large volumes, may lead to pulmonary edema. Isotonic, electrolyte-containing fluids are contraindicated for use with monopolar electrosurgical devices because they conduct electrical current, dissipate instrument energy and render the instrument ineffective. Low-viscosity, electrolyte-poor fluids such as 1.5-percent glycine, 3-percent sorbitol, and 5-percent mannitol are preferred as they are non-conductive and can be safely used with monopolar electrosurgical energy devices. The primary risk of using hypotonic, hypoosmolar solutions is the intravascular absorption of these fluids, which can lead to acute hyponatremia and hypo osmolality. The criteria for terminating the procedure for electrolyte-deficient fluid is a deficit of 1 L and electrolyte-rich fluid is a deficit of 2.5 L. Ovarian Tumors
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which is the most common type of ovarian tumor?
explanation: Epithelial tumors are the most common type of ovarian tumors.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is the most carcinogenic gene in ovarian cancer?
explanation: BRCA 1 is the most carcinogenic gene in ovarian cancer. 5–10% of malignant ovarian tumors are genetic. BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. BRCA 1 is on chromosome 17q and BRCA 2 is on chromosome 13q. MSH2 and MLH1 gene mutation is seen in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). It is associated with malignancy of the colon, ovary, and endometrium.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following reduces the risk of developing ovarian cancers?
explanation: Bilateral tubectomy and hysterectomy reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. Some ovarian malignancies originate in the fallopian tubes as dysplastic lesions which later spread to the ovary (dropping down theory). Thus, bilateral tubectomy reduces the risk of ovarian malignancy. Risk factors for ovarian cancer: Advancing age Early menarche and late menopause Talc exposure to the perineum Family history of breast / ovarian cancer Ovulation induction therapy by clomiphene citrate Protective factors against ovarian cancer: Use of oral contraceptive pills Multiparity Breastfeeding Anovulation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following is the largest benign ovarian tumor?
explanation: Mucinous cystadenoma is the largest benign ovarian tumor. Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucoid-containing, thick-walled cyst. It is usually multilocular and lined by single columnar epithelium. It is the third most common epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has a 10% chance of becoming malignant. About 40% of dermoid cysts are found in conjunction with mucinous cystadenomas.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding borderline ovarian tumors?
options: Mitotic figures are < 4/10 high power field
Serous type is more common than mucinous type
explanation: Stromal invasion is not seen in borderline ovarian tumors. Borderline tumors of the ovary (also called tumors of low malignant potential) are a heterogeneous group of lesions defined histologically by atypical epithelial proliferation without stromal invasion. The clinical progression of these tumors is distinct from ovarian carcinoma, so they are considered a distinct clinical entity. Features of borderline ovarian tumors: No stromal invasion Mitotic figures <4/10 high power field Survival rate is 90% Usually occurs between 35-55 years of age Serous type is the most common, followed by mucinous type.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ovarian cysts?
options: Cobweb appearance is seen on USG in haemorrhagic cyst
Theca lutein cyst regresses with a fall in hCG levels
Leutoma of pregnancy is associated with multiple pregnancy
Follicular cyst is a benign epithelial tumor
explanation: Follicular cyst is a physiological/functional cyst of the ovary. Physiological/functional cysts of the ovary: Follicular cyst - Failure of rupture of the follicle during ovulation. Theca lutein cyst - Stimulation of atretic follicles by abnormal HCG levels. It regresses when hCG levels fall. Luteoma of pregnancy - Due to prolonged elevation of hCG, like in multiple pregnancies. Hemorrhagic ovarian cysts usually occur due to bleeding into the corpus luteum or other functional cysts at the time of ovulation. Hemorrhagic cysts are normal findings in ovulatory women, generally resolving within 8 weeks. Cobweb appearance on USG in a hemorrhagic cyst is shown below.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Meigs' syndrome was suspected in a woman with right-sided pleural effusion, ascites, and an ovarian tumor. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: Can be caused by ovarian fibroma
The tumor would be immobile with an irregular surface
Ascites and hydrothorax resolve after resection of the tumor
Pleural effusion is more common on the right side
explanation: In Meig's syndrome, a benign ovarian mass is likely to be seen. Irregular surface and immobility are features of malignant tumors. Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of: Benign ovarian tumors Ascites Right-sided pleural effusion. The pleural effusions are usually right-sided, even though the left-sided and bilateral effusions are possible. Tumors causing Meigs' syndrome include ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma. However, when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and benign ovarian cysts (such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma), the condition is called Pseudo Meigs' syndrome. Resolution of ascites and pleural effusion is seen after the removal of the tumor. Management: Repeated paracentesis for ascites. Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy in young patients for preserving fertility Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO) in postmenopausal women. Note: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients may also have a combination of ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated serum levels of CA-125. This is known as Tjalma syndrome or pseudo-pseudo Meigs’ syndrome.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An elderly woman who was found to have an ovarian mass underwent staging laparotomy. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Psammoma bodies. What is the most probable diagnosis?
