explanation: Psammoma bodies are a histopathological finding of serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary. They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Their presence does not denote malignancy. Psammoma bodies are seen in the following conditions: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid Papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary Meningioma The image below shows Psammoma body.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 49-year-old woman presented with complaints of dull pain over the right lower abdomen for the past 2 months. CT scan revealed a left-sided multiloculated adnexal mass and exploratory laparotomy showed small mucoid implants scattered in the peritoneal cavity.
Which of the following is associated with this condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario and findings point to a diagnosis of pseudomyxoma peritonei. It is associated with mucinous cystadenoma. Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare clinical entity characterized by diffuse intra-abdominal gelatinous and mucoid material on peritoneal surfaces. Spontaneous perforation of a mucinous cystadenoma leads to implantation of low-grade malignant tumor cells in the peritoneum. However, the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei is carcinoma of the appendix. Diagnosis is by CT, MRI, and laparoscopy. Even after the removal of the ovarian tumor, these cells continue to secrete mucin. Recurrence rates are high.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation was rushed to the ER with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. Which of the following most commonly leads to this condition?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during puerperium. Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function. Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected. Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii. The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Staging laparotomy was performed in a teenage girl who presented with an adnexal mass. Histopathological examination showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given histopathological image shows Schiller-Duval bodies. It is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor). It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal areas in young children. It is usually unilateral. These tumors are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin. The image below depicts Schiller-Duval bodies. It consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. 50% of yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the counterpart of seminoma in females?
explanation: The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. It is a germ cell tumor. It usually arises in young women or in children. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence. Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis. Dysgerminoma was considered to be the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. Recent data indicates that in the past few decades, their incidence has reduced considerably. Immature teratomas are now the most common type of malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The most common ovarian tumor in women less than 20 years of age is .
explanation: Germ cell tumors are the most common ovarian tumor in women aged less than 20 years. Epithelial tumours are the commonest tumours. It accounts for 80% of all ovarian malignant tumours.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following tumors show raised CA-125 levels?
explanation: Non-mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has elevated CA- 125 levels. CA-125 value > 35 U/ml is suggestive of epithelial ovarian cancer. Malignant conditions with raised CA 125 levels: Ovarian epithelial carcinoma (most common cause) Endometrial cancer Pancreatic cancer Colon cancer Breast cancer Lung cancer Lymphoma Benign conditions with raised CA 125 levels: Pregnancy Pelvic inflammatory disease Endometriosis Uterine fibroid Normally elevated in 1% females Acute peritonitis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A young woman with an adnexal mass is diagnosed with dysgerminoma. Which of the following tumor markers are likely to be elevated in her?
explanation: Lactate dehydrogenase is the tumor marker in dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%). It is seen in young women with an average incidence of 20 years of age. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (PALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and -hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence. Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A post-menopausal woman is found to have an adnexal mass on evaluation. Above what risk of malignancy index (RMI) score is there a high risk of ovarian malignancy?
explanation: Risk of malignancy index (RMI) score of 200 or more indicates a high risk for ovarian cancer in a patient with an adnexal mass. Risk of malignancy index (RMI) = U x M x CA125 U = Ultrasound score The ultrasound result is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics: multilocular cysts, solid areas, metastases, ascites, and bilateral lesions. U = 0 (for an ultrasound score of 0) U = 1 (for an ultrasound score of 1) U = 3 (for an ultrasound score of 2–5). M = Menopausal status M= 1 (for pre-menopausal) M= 3 (for post-menopausal) CA-125 = Serum CA-125 level (in IU/ml) For any post-menopausal woman with an ovarian cyst of size >1cm, RMI should be calculated.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Brenner tumor?
options: It is associated with Meig's syndrome
Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei are seen
It is not a malignant tumor
explanation: Brenner tumors are usually benign but rarely they can turn malignant. Brenner tumor (transitional cell tumor) is a benign, epithelial, unilateral tumor, resembling a fibroma. Histologically, Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei are seen. Brenner tumor represent only 2-3% of all ovarian neoplasms, and <2% of these tumors are malignant. It is called Meigs' syndrome if the clinical picture is caused by an ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma. Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of: Benign ovarian tumor Ascites Right-sided pleural effusion. Pseudo Meigs' syndrome is when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and benign ovarian cysts such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma. The image given below shows Walthard cell rest. The image given below shows coffee bean nuclei.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 31-year-old woman presenting with 12 weeks of amenorrhea and passage of vesicles per vagina is suspected to have a molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the left ovary appears as shown below. Which of the statements is not true regarding this condition?
options: Regresses spontaneously after removal of molar pregnancy
It is seen with clomiphene administration
Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor
explanation: The above scenario points to a diagnosis of theca lutein cysts in association with molar pregnancy. Theca lutein cysts are not associated with the use of oral contraceptives. Lutein cysts types : Granulosa lutein cysts - They occur due to failure of regression of corpus luteum after 14 days of vulation. Theca lutein cysts - They are found in association with hydatidiform moles, choriocarcinoma, and gonadotropin (hCG), or clomiphene therapy. Theca lutein cysts occur due to the hyperstimulation of ovaries as a result of high hCG levels in molar pregnancies and other conditions. They are usually bilateral. These cysts usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2-4 months following the evacuation of a molar pregnancy. Sometimes they can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of the cyst has to be done.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman noticed premature breast development in her 7-year-old daughter and brought her to the gynecology OPD. USG revealed a right-sided adnexal mass. The patient underwent laparotomy and the biopsy revealed Call-Exner bodies. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
options: Most common malignant tumor of ovary
Inhibin A is elevated more than inhibin B
explanation: The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of granulosa cell tumor. It is associated with carcinoma endometrium. Granulosa cell tumors cells are estrogen-secreting ovarian tumors. It is seen in 80% of women over 40 years and 5% of pre-pubertal girls. Precocious puberty is seen due to excess secretion of estrogen. It is a low-grade malignancy. It is almost always unilateral. Tumor marker inhibin B is frequently elevated more than inhibin A. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice. On histopathology, it has characteristic Call-Exner bodies. It appears as a rosette arrangement of cells around an eosinophilic fluid space, as shown below.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following high-risk patients are suitable for prophylactic oophorectomy?
options: History of ovarian cancer in a 2nd-degree relative
Abnormal ovary in reproductive age group woman
One ovary removed for benign neoplasm
explanation: Prophylactic oophorectomy is indicated if one ovary has already been removed for benign neoplasm. Candidates suitable for prophylactic oophorectomy: Nulliparous aged > 45 years Any age with a history of ovarian, endometrial, or colon cancer in a 1st-degree relative Grossly abnormal ovary in the premenopausal age group One ovary removed for benign neoplasm Previous history of breast carcinoma Radiation-induced menopause
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. On CT scan, a bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and liver capsule involvement was seen. What stage does this belong to?
explanation: Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement. Grading of ovarian cancer: Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less likely to spread or recur. Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells. Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared t normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman is diagnosed with early-stage ovarian cancer. Which surgery should be done in her case?
explanation: Unilateral oophorectomy is preferred in a young woman who has not completed her family in case of early-stage disease.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following ovarian tumors is the most radiosensitive?
explanation: Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. They are highly susceptible to radiotherapy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman on HRT presented with abdominal pain for the past 6 months. On examination, a non-tender, right adnexal mass was palpable. USG showed a 3 x 3 cm smooth ovarian cyst. What is the next best step in her case?
options: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirmation of USG findings by CT scan
Exploratory laparotomy for evaluation of cyst
CA- 125 level estimation; if normal, advise regular follow-up
explanation: CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for post-menopausal ovarian cysts. Management includes the following: Calculation of Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) = U x M x Ca-125, where U = ultrasound score M = menopausal status Ca 125 = serum levels Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size >5 cm or RMI >200. Option B - CT scan is not recommended for initial evaluation. It is done only for further evaluation and when RMI > 200.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
Examination of a resected specimen of an ovarian mass reveals signet ring cells are seen as shown below. Which of the following conditions is this associated with?

Mucinous cystadenoma
explanation: Signet ring cells are seen in Krukenberg tumor. A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy that metastasized from a primary site, most commonly from the stomach (70%). Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites. The route of spread may be: Lymphatic Hematogenous Transcoelomic They are usually bilateral and have a smooth surface with a waxy consistency. They retain the shape of a normal ovary. Given below are the images of the Krukenberg tumor's gross appearance and histological appearance with signet ring cells: Vulval & Vaginal Malignancy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following is not a premalignant lesion of vulva?
explanation: Condyloma lata is not a premalignant lesion of vulva. Premalignant lesions of the vulva include: Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) - most common Paget’s disease Lichen sclerosus Squamous cell hyperplasia Condyloma acuminata Bowen’s disease (erythroplasia of Querat)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is a common differential diagnosis of verrucuos carcinoma?
explanation: Condyloma acuminata is the common differential diagnosis of verrucous carcinoma. It refers to anogenital warts and has a verrucous appearance. Verrucous carcinoma is a variant of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. It is locally invasive and rarely metastasizes. Condyloma lata is a benign and painless cutaneous manifestation of secondary syphilis. It is characterized by gray to white lesions, typically located in the oro-genital region. Chancre is a painless genital ulcer most commonly formed during the primary stage of syphilis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A sexually active woman presents with multiple lesions over her genital region as shown below. Which of the following organisms are implicated in this condition?
explanation: The given scenario and image are suggestive of genital warts. Human papillomavirus (HPV) 6 and 11 cause nearly all genital warts. It is usually clinically diagnosed but if co-existing neoplasia is suspected then a biopsy is required. HPV serotyping is not required for routine diagnosis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the earliest symptom in patients with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia?
explanation: Pruritus is the earliest symptom of VIN as well as vulvar cancer. Clinical features of VIN include: Pruritus White discharge per vagina Dyspareunia Vaginal bleedin
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with vaginal itching is suspected to have vulval intraepithelial neoplasia. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
explanation: HPV 16 is the most common cause of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN). Causes of VIN include: HPV 16, 18, 31, 33 HSV 2 Syphilis Gonorrhea Gardnerella vaginalis
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An elderly woman is diagnosed with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia 3. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
explanation: Elderly women with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) - 3 are HPV negative. VIN 3 is of two types: Young women – HPV +ve, multiple lesion, 90% regress Elderly women – HPV –ve, single lesion, associated with lichen sclerosis, often progress to invasive cancer
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies?
explanation: Among the given gynecological malignancies, sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most useful in vulval carcinomas. This is because women with earlier stages of vulval cancer can have diseased lymph nodes even without palpable enlargement of nodes. Hence, sentinel lymph node biopsy helps in early diagnosis lymph node spread which can be managed by lymph node dissection. A sentinel lymph node is a physiologically, the first lymph node to receive tumor lymphatic drainage. Malignancies where sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly done are : Vulval carcinoma Breast carcinoma Penile carcinoma Malignant melanoma Lymphatic mapping is similar technique to SLNB that can also be used in vulval cancers.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which is most common type of vulval cancer?
explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulval cancer. Other types of vulval cancer include: Adenocarcinoma Melanoma Basal cell carcinoma Sarcoma
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common type of vaginal cancer likely to be seen in a woman with a history of intrauterine di-ethyl stilbesterol exposure?
explanation: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is commonly seen in adoloscent girls with a history of intrauterine DES exposure. It involves the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Radical hysterectomy, vaginectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy is the treatment of choice. The most common lesion due to DES exposure is vaginal adenosis and not clear cell adenocarcinoma. It is a benign condition.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common site of vulval cancers?
explanation: The most common site of vulval cancer is labia majora > clitoris > labia minora.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Vulvar carcinoma was diagnosed in a 68-year-old woman who presented with itching and mass over the vulva for 6 months. Sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed positive inguinal nodes. What is the stage of the tumor?
explanation: According to FIGO staging, tumor with positive inguinal lymph node is classified as stage III.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: In patients with vulval cancer, what is the least common route through which the malignancy spreads?
explanation: Vascular route of spread is rare in vulval cancer. Lymphatic is the most common route of spread in vulval cancer. Lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor. The sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer. Lymph nodes involved are, superficial inguinal nodes (sentinel node) > deep inguinal nodes > femoral group of nodes.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An elderly woman is found to have abnormal cells on a pap smear. Further investigations reveal vaginal squamous cell carcinoma extending up to the pelvic wall. There is no evidence of distant metastasis. What is the stage of the tumor in this patient?
explanation: Vaginal cancer extending up to the pelvic wall is stage III. Vaginal cancer commonly affects females >70 years of age. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histologic type. It commonly involves the upper third of the posterior wall of the vagina. Patients are mostly asymptomatic. They may present with painless abnormal vaginal bleeding, post-coital bleed, and foul-smelling discharge per vagina. Vaginal cancer staging: Stage 0 - Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia Stage I - Carcinoma limited to the vaginal wall Stage II - Carcinoma extending beyond the vagina, but not extending to the pelvic walls Stage III - Carcinoma extends up to the pelvic walls Stage IVA - Carcinoma extending beyond the true pelvis/or involving the bladder and/or rectum, or evidence of distant metastasis Stage IVB - Spread to the distant metastasis
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 70-year-old presented with a lesion over the vulva as shown below. Bilateral inguinal lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy of the lesion revealed cells containing large, pleomorphic nuclei. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

It is the 2nd most common vulval cancer
options: The most common site is clitoris
It may arise from a junctional naevus
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of vulval melanoma. The most commonly involved site is labia majora followed by labia minora and clitoris. Vulval melanoma is the second most common vulval cancer. It may arise from junctional naevus. It has a high propensity for local and distant recurrence and has a poor prognosis. Radical vulvectomy and bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment. Carcinoma Cervix
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for carcinoma cervix?
explanation: HPV serotypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with carcinoma cervix. Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include: Human Papilloma virus (most important) Sexual intercourse before 18 years Multiple sexual partners Multiparity Poor personal hygiene Smoking and drug abuse Women with STD, HIV, HSV Immune suppression Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV DNA detection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding HPV?
options: E1 and E2 are viral proteins needed for replication
E6 and E7 are viral proteins needed for malignant transformation
E6 acts via the retinoblastoma gene
HPV 16 is the most common serotype causing carcinoma cervix
explanation: E6 acts via the tumor suppression gene p53. It increases proteasome-dependent p53 degradation. E7 binds and acts via the retinoblastoma (Rb) gene. The viral E6 and E7 oncoproteins encoded by the high-risk type HPVs (such as HPV 16 and HPV 18) are necessary for malignant transformation. E1 and E2 oncoproteins are responsible for viral replication.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which is the HPV serotype most commonly associated with carcinoma cervix?
explanation: HPV 16 is the most common type associated with carcinoma cervix. Associations between human papilloma virus (HPV) serotypes and carcinoma cervix: Most common serotype - HPV 16 Most malignant serotype - HPV 18 Most specific serotype - HPV 18 Most common serotype associated with Squamous cell carcinoma - HPV 16 Adenocarcinoma - HPV 18 Cancers caused by HPV: Male - penile, oral, anal Female - cervix, vagina, vulva
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is false about the Cervarix vaccine?
explanation: The Cervarix vaccine is not protective against genital warts. It is mainly protective against CIN and cervical cancer. Vaccine Type Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil 9 Bivalent vaccine Quadrivalent vaccine Nonavalent vaccine HPV types HPV 16,18 HPV 6, 11, 16, 18 HPV 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58 Dosage 0.5 mL 0.5 mL 0.5 mL Schedule 0, 1, 6 months 0, 2, 6 months 0, 2, 6months Vaccine Type Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil 9 Diseases prevent ed CINCarcinoma cer vix CINCarcinoma cervixGenital warts CINCarcinomacervixGenital wartsVulvalcancerVaginalepit helial cancerOropharyngealca ncer Adjuvant AS04 Alum Alum
subject: OBGYN

question_text: HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes?
explanation: HPV nonavalent vaccine (Gardasil 9 or HPV9) is active against HPV 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58. Currently, HPV nonnavalent vaccine has replaced Gardasil which is a quadrivalent vaccine acting against 6,11,16,18. Vaccines available for HPV: Brand name Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9 Cervavac Characteristic and HPV subtypes Bivalent:16,18 Quadrivalent:6,11,1 6,18 Nonavalent:6,11,16, 18,31,33,45,52,58 Quadrivalent:6,11,1 6,18 Protects against: CINCA cervix Anogenital wartsCI NCA cervix Anogenital wartsCI NCA cervixVulvalin traepithelialneoplas iaVaginalintraepith elialneoplasiaAnal c ancerOropharyngea l cancerHead and n eck cancers Anogenital wartsCI NCA cervix Dose 0.5 ml,IM. 0.5 ml,IM. 0.5 ml,IM. 0.5 ml,IM. Ideal Age range: Ideally at 11-12 year s or9-26 years Ideally at 11-12 year s or9-26 years Ideally at 11-12 year s or9-26 years The targeted age gr oup is 9-26 years
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 45-year-old patient comes with repeated infections of trichomonas vaginitis, her physician advises for a Pap smear. She asks you regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your appropriate response?
options: It is a screening test for cervical cancer
It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital trac
It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her
explanation: A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. It is not a diagnostic test (option C). The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage. If trichomonas is reported from Pap testing, it should be confirmed by saline microscopic preparation (option B). Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and Pap co-test every 5 years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years. HIV+ women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life. Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation. Procedure: The patient is put in a dorsal position, and the labia are parted Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayer’s spatula: Bifid end - ectocervical sample Blunt end - vaginal cytology Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush The sample is spread on a glass slide The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol Stained with Papanicolau stain or short-duration Papanicolau stain (SPS).
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the gynecology OPD for a routine Pap smear. The histopathology slide is shown below. Identify the cell marked as "A".
explanation: The cell marked A is the superficial cell. ACOG guidelines recommend cervical exfoliative cytology every 3 years starting 21 years as screening for cervical cancer. The image below shows a superficial cell (a) and an intermediate cell (b): The image below shows parabasal cells (marked by black arrows): Koilocytes are epithelial cells that contain eccentric, hyperchromatic, moderately enlarged nucleus hat is displaced by large perinuclear vacuole. It is a feature of HPV infection.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Match the following:
explanation: Various systems of classification are used to describe cervical cytology after Pap smear such as: Papanicolaou classification - describes the exfoliative cytology of the cervix in a Pap smear. Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) - histopathological description of how much of the hickness of the cervical epithelium is replaced by dysplastic cells Bethesda classification - it is another method to describe cervical dysplasia The various systems and their corresponding classes are given below: where, CIS: Carcinoma in situ, CIN: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, SCC: Squamous cell carcinoma, SIL: Squamous intraepithelial lesion, ASCUS: Atypical squamous cell of undetermined significance, HPV: Human papillomavirus. Pap classification (1943) Cervical intraepithelial neopl asia / CIN (WHO 1975) Bethesda system Grade I Normal Normal Grade II Inflammatory InflammatoryHPV ASCUS Grade III CIN I Low SIL Grade IV CIN II, CIN III, CIS High SIL Grade V SCC SCC
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management?
explanation: The appropriate management of a 45-year-old with a positive pap smear and post-coital bleeding is a colposcopy-directed biopsy. A per speculum examination must be done whenever a female comes with post-coital bleeding in order to evaluate for carcinoma of the cervix. If growth is visible, a punch biopsy should be done, and else if no growth is visible, then a pap smear is done. A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage. Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and pap co-test every 5 years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If a pap smear is suspicious, then screening is continued till 75 years. HIV+ve women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life. Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 30-year-old sex worker presented with irregular menses, post-coital bleeding, and occasional foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She was advised to undergo a Pap smear. What is the best time for this investigation?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of cervical carcinoma. The best time to do a Pap smear is around ovulation, but it can be performed at any other time as well. Prerequisites of doing a Pap smear: It should be done prior to vaginal examination Lubricants should not be used The patient should not be menstruating during the pap tes The ideal time is around ovulation The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. Based on Pap smear findings, dysplasia of cervical cells is graded using various classification systems such as WHO grading, CIN grading, and the Bethesda system.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is false about Schiller's test?
options: Lugol's iodine is used to paint the cervix
The epithelium is stained mahogany brown
It detects the presence of glycogen in the epithelium
explanation: The abnormal cells remain unstained on performing Schiller's test. Schiller's test, also known as VILI (visual inspection with Lugol's iodine), involves painting the cervix with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the cervix and vagina, such as in cases of carcinoma cervix. The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen, therefore stains mahogany brown on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in the colposcopic biopsy of a patient with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia?
explanation: The basement membrane is intact in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). Features of CIN: Varying degree of dysplasia Altered nuclear-cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio Hyperchromatic nuclei Mitotic figures Intact basement membrane.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following methods is most commonly used for the treatment of CIN?
options: Large loop excision of transformation zone
explanation: Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) is the most commonly used treatment option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). It is also known as loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP). It is applicable for the treatment of CIN anywhere in the lower genital tract. This uses electric current through a monopolar wire electrode to either cut or coagulate cervical lesions. Like other excisional procedures, it is done in the immediate post menstrual phase. The procedure involves minimal patient discomfort, cost, and complications. Since it can be performed using local anesthesia, it has become the primary outpatient treatment modality for high-grade cervical lesions.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following is the treatment of choice when microinvasion of cervix neoplasia is suspected?
explanation: Conization is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is suspected. Indications of conization Endocervical dysplasia Transformation zone is not completely visualized When there is discrepancy of findings between cytolology, colposcopy & biopsy Microinvasion is suspected Indications of hysterectomy Older & parous women Uterus is associated with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed Recurrence or persistent lesion In-situ adenocarcinoma cervix
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management?
explanation: Colposcopy with LEEP would be appropriate management for CIN III. Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is an opd procedure done under colposcopic view and local anesthesia.Here, a low voltage current is passed through the loop and a cone of tissue is removed from the cervix. This procedure causes minimal bleeding and the tissue removed is sent for histopathological examination (HPE). This is the treatment of choice for CIN 2&3 of any age and parity.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which is the most common malignancy in women in India?
explanation: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women in India as well as globally. Cervical cancer is the most common genital cancer in India. Lip and oral cavity cancer is the most common malignancy in men. Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include: Human Papilloma virus (most important) Sexual intercourse before 18 years Multiple sexual partners Multiparity Poor personal hygiene Smoking and drug abuse Women with STD, HIV, HSV Immune suppression
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding the transitional zone?
options: Nabothian cysts mark the original site
It is limited to external os
explanation: The transitional zone or squamocolumnar junction is well outside the external os during the reproductive period. It is the site where the squamous epithelium lining the vagina merges with the columnar epithelium of the endocervix. The original squamocolumnar junction is marked by the presence of Nabothian cysts and glandular openings. It is a dynamic part and moves with age and hormonal influence: During pregnancy and with oral contraceptives, it pouts out of os. Following menopause, it gets indrawn inside the os. The cells here are highly sensitive to irritants, mutagens and viral agents such as HPV. Cancer screening using Pap smear involves scraping this area and studying the cells for nuclear changes.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the false statement regarding adenocarcinoma of the cervix.
options: Most common site is transformation zone
Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India
explanation: The most common site of adenocarcinoma is endocervix. It commonly occurs in young females and OCP users, and is associated with HPV 18.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You would suspect and evaluate for carcinoma cervix in patients presenting with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Patients with carcinoma cervix most commonly present with metrorrhagia, now known as intermenstrual bleeding. Post-coital bleeding is the most specific symptom of carcinoma cervix.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common site of hematogenous metastasis of cervical cancer?
explanation: The most common site of hematogenous metastasis of cervical cancer is the lung. About 1-2% of patients with cervical carcinomas present with lung metastases, and 5-35% eventually develop lung metastases. Other common sites of blood-borne metastases include bone, liver and bowel.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes for follow-up a few months after surgery for carcinoma cervix. On evaluation, she is found to have a recurrence of the malignancy. Which of the following is true about her condition?
options: Most common site of recurrence is pelvic lymph node
Mortality in patients with recurrence is due to pulmonary embolism
Treatment involves surgery with lymph node dissection
Recurrent tumor with largest diameter <3cm has good prognosis
explanation: A recurrent tumor with the largest diameter of <3cm is associated with a good prognosis. The extent of recurrent disease and involvement of pelvic lymph nodes are prognostic factors for survival. An isolated central pelvic tumour with no involvement of the pelvic sidewall also has a good prognosis. Most recurrences are seen within 3 years and the prognosis is poor with uremia being the most common terminal event. Recurrences most commonly involve the pelvis than the para-aortic or pelvic lymph node. All patients with a suspected recurrence should undergo PET/CT for evaluation and biopsy for confirmation. Treatment involves either radical chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration. Concurrent chemotherapy with cisplatin and/or 5-fluorouracil may improve the outcome.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the true statement about the staging of cancer cervix.
options: Clinical examination is the first step in staging
Tumor markers are important for diagnosis of metastasis
CT scan is the best method to assess principal tumors
MRI is the best method to assess nodal metastasis
explanation: Clinical examination is the first step in staging carcinoma cervix. Clinical examination was the principal method in staging until the 2018 FIGO guidelines which recommended the use of imaging and histological investigations when available. USG, CT, MRI, and PET-CT can be used to assess the extent of the tumor, nodal status, and local or systemic spread. MRI is the best method to assess the principal tumor while PET-CT is the best method to assess nodal metastasis. FIGO no longer mandates biochemical investigations, such as tumor markers, for diagnosis of metastasis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What is the stage of the disease?
explanation: The stage of cervical carcinoma is II B as it involves the upper part of the vagina and parametrium.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding. She was diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage IB after evaluation. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
explanation: Type III hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix - stage IB. It involves radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy and para-aortic lymph node evaluation. Stage IB is defined as a macroscopic lesion still confined to the cervix, with the depth of invasion 5mm. It is the first stage in which lesions become clinically visible. Hysterectomy types include: Type I - Simple / extrafascial Type II - Modified radical / Wertheim Type III - Radical / Meigs-Wertheim Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy Type V - Exenteration.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
A 30-year-old woman is found to have a lesion in the cervix which is 7mm wide and has a depth of 4mm. She has one child and wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most
appropriate management?
explanation: The woman has stage I A2 cervical cancer and the most appropriate management is radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy. Radical trachelectomy is a fertility-preserving surgical procedure. This involves the removal of the entire cervix and parametrium. Cervical conization with laparoscopic or extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy is an alternative that also preserves fertility.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following are contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix?
explanation: Post-menopausal status is not a contraindication for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix. Contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix include: Pelvic inflammatory disease Young patient (to preserve ovarian function) Associated myoma, prolapse, ovarian tumor, genital fistula Vaginal stenosis Adenocarcinoma or adenosquamous carcinoma – surgery preferred.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
You are planning to administer radiotherapy to a 58-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix. What is the dose to be administered at point B?
7000 cGY
explanation: In the treatment of carcinoma cervix, the dose to be administered at point B is 6000 cGy. Radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix: Point A Point B Locatio n 2cm above and 2cm lateral to external os 2cm above and 5cm lateral to external os Structu re Paracervical/Parametrial lym ph node Obturator lymph node Dose 7000-8000 cGy 6000 cGy Carcinoma Endometrium
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding?
explanation: The most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding all over the world is senile endometrial atrophy. In a menopausal woman, hypoestrogenism causes atrophy of the endometrium and vagina.The atrophic endometrial surfaces contain little or no fluid to prevent intracavitary friction. This results in micro-erosions of the surface epithelium and a subsequent chronic inflammatory reaction, making the endometrium prone to light bleeding or spotting. H rmone replacement therapy is the second most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding all ver the world. Cervical cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in India, while endometrial cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in developed countries. Note: Endometrial cancer accounts for only 10 % of cases of post-menopausal bleeding. Still, all postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma, since this is a potentially lethal disease.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 58-year-old, postmenopausal woman presented with bleeding PV. Hysteroscopic biopsy revealed complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the risk of progression of this condition to cancer?
explanation: Complex hyperplasia with atypia has a 29% increased risk of progression to endometrial cancer. It has the highest risk of progressing to carcinoma compared to other varieties of endometrial hyperplasia. The risk of endometrial hyperplasia progressing to cancer is tabulated below. Type of hyperplasia Progression to cance r Simple without atypia 1% Complex without atyp ia 3% Simple with atypia 8% Complex with atypia 29%
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which is the most common benign cause of pyometra?
explanation: The most common cause of pyometra is senile endometritis. Pyometra refers the collection of pus in the uterus. The most common cancer that causes pyometra is carcinoma cervix followed by carcinoma endometrium.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia?
explanation: Simple hysterectomy is the best treatment in a case of atypical endometrial hyperplasia in a peri-menopausal and post-menopausal female. Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia carries 29% risk of developing into endometrial carcinoma and hence, must be treated with total abdominal hysterectomy (simple hysterectomy ). The presence of any concomitant endometrial cancer must be ruled out by doing fractional curettage (or dilatation and curettage) before doing a hysterectomy. If a premenopausal woman does not desire to undergo hysterectomy, progesterone can be given and the patient is followed up every 3-6 months. If the atypia persists during the follow-up hysterectomy should be performed. The table below summarizes the management of patients with endometrial hyperplasia Management of Endometrial hyperplasia Hyperplasia without atypia Pre-menopausal women Progesterone therapy Postmenopausal women:Sim ple hyperplasia without atypi aComplex hyperplasia withou t atypia Follow up without therapyPr ogesterone therapy Hyperplasia with atypia Pre-menopausal women If patient wishes to preserve uterus,give High-dose proges terone therapyIf atypia persis ts, then perform Total abdom inal hysterectomy Peri-menopausal women Total abdominal hysterectom y Post-menopausal women Total abdominal hysterectom y +BSO (bilateral salphingo-o phorectomy)
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding?
explanation: A finding of endometrial thickness  4 mm (according to ACOG) in a postmenopausal women requires further evaluation, such as endometrial biopsy. If the endometrial thickness is 4 mm in a post menopausal female, malignancy is rare and hence, can be managed by tranexamic acid. If the bleeding still persists, the patient needs to undergo fractional curettage and hysteroscopy. The algorithm for next step for abnormal uterine bleeding in different age groups is as follows: Age group Endometrial thickness on T VS Action Age <40years >12mm Endometrial sampling/Endo metrial biopsy Age>40 years or Age >45 yea rs - Endometrial sampling/Endo metrial biopsy is done irrespe ctive of usg findings Age group Endometrial thickness on T Action VS Age group Endometrial thickness on T Action VS Age group Endometrial thickness on T Action VS Post menopausal women 4mm Endometrial sampling/Endo metrial biopsy Post menopausal women <4mm Reassurance+tranexamic aci dIf, bleeding still persists the n do endometrial biopsy
subject: OBGYN

question_text: What is the most common histopathological variety of endometrial cancer?
explanation: The most common variety of endometrial cancer is adenocarcinoma. The other varieties of endometrial cancer are squamous cell, clear cell, and serous. The most malignant varieties are clear cell carcinoma and papillary serous tumor.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following predisposes a patient to develop type 2 carcinoma endometrium?
explanation: Type 2 carcinoma endometrium is commonly seen in menopausal women with atrophic endometrium. Histological classification of endometrial cancer: Note: Type 1 (estrogen-dependent) endometrial CA is the more common type. Type 1 (Endometrioid) Type 2 (Nonendometriod) Estrogen dependent Estrogen independent Occurs in Pre- and Peri-meno pausal women Occurs in post-menopausal w omen Type 1 (Endometrioid) Type 2 (Nonendometriod) Type 1 (Endometrioid) Type 2 (Nonendometriod) Hyperplasia present Hyperplasia absent Good prognosis Poor prognosis Associated with PTEN/KRAS mutation Associated with p53 mutatio n
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following constitute corpus cancer syndrome?
explanation: Corpus cancer syndrome constitutes of: Diabetes mellitus Obesity Hypertension Cancer of the body of the uterus. Etiology of endometrial carcinoma: (Mnemonic: Family Has OLD AUNTI) Family history Hypertension Obesity Late menopause/Early menarche Diabetes Atypical endometrial hyperplasia Unopposed estrogen/increased estrogen  Hormone replacement therapy, fibroid, PCOD Nulliparous Tamoxifen therapy (Raloxifene has no genito-urinary action) Infertility/irregular menses. Protective factors against endometrial carcinoma include the use of OCPs, smoking, and multiparity.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A gynecologist is performing the following procedure in a woman with postmenopausal bleeding. Identify it.
explanation: The image depicts saline infusion sonography (SIS), also known as sonohysterography. It is usually done after a transvaginal ultrasound, to assess the detailed anatomy of the uterine cavity. In this procedure, a balloon catheter is inserted through the cervix and the endometrial cavity is distended with 20-40ml of sterile saline. The balloon is inflated to block the backflow of the infused sterile saline and transvaginal ultrasound is performed to visualize the cavity. It is used: To determine the endometrial thickness To determine the cause in cases of infertility To identify Mullerian anomalies To visualize endometrial polyps and pedunculated fibroids The image given below shows the appearance of the uterus on SIS. Option A: Transvaginal ultrasound is the initial evaluation for postmenopausal bleeding. Option B: In balloon endometrial ablation, a balloon is inserted into the uterus and inflated with glycine or 5% glucose. It is then heated up, and the endometrium is ablated by the tamponade effect. Option D: In hysterosalpingography, contrast dye is inserted into the uterus via a catheter, and the uterine and fallopian tube anatomy is visualized.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A menopausal patient suspected to have endometrial carcinoma is undergoing a transvaginal ultrasound. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with her diagnosis?
explanation: Decreased vascular resistance with increased tumor vascularity is seen in carcinoma endometrium. USG findings in carcinoma endometrium include: Endometrial thickness >4 mm in postmenopausal women and >10 mm in perimenopausal women Hyperechoic endometrium with irregular outlines Increased tumor vascularity with low vascular resistance Fluid in uterine cavity
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 52-year-old■ woman with postmenopausal bleeding has an endometrial thickness of 7 mm on ultrasound. What is the next step in her management?
explanation: The next line of management in a patient with increased endometrial thickness is an endometrial biopsy. In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness. If it exceeds 4 mm, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory, irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms. In a perimenopausal woman, the cutoff for normal endometrial thickness is 10mm. Hysteroscopy and biopsy is preferred over other blind curettage methods for HPE. A biopsy is made from suspicious areas after visualization so chances of missing the lesion are reduced.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 54-year-old woman with postmenopausal bleeding is suspected to have an endometrial lesion. What is the gold standard investigation to confirm her diagnosis?
explanation: Hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy is now considered the gold standard in the diagnosis of an endometrial lesion. It is preferred for the initial evaluation of women with bleeding suspicious for malignancy. Endometrial sampling can be done by hysteroscopic biopsy. It is more sensitive for focal endometrial lesions. Dilatation and curettage may also aid the sampling of endometrial lesions. Ultrasound, CT, and MRI are adjuvant to other investigations. Diagnostic laparoscopy will be required to study the nature of the tumor and its spread if ultrasound picks up a pelvic tumor. The image given below shows the procedure of hysteroscopy.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 62-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding 11 years after she had attained menopause. An endometrial biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma. What is the gold standard method for staging her condition?
explanation: The given scenario depicts endometrial carcinoma and the gold standard method for staging this condition is surgery. According to FIGO/TNM classification system, a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection is the standard staging procedure for endometrial cancer. Option A: Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) appears to be the best radiographic modality for detecting myometrial invasion or cervical involvement. Option C: Hysteroscopy visualizes the entire uterine lining and a biopsy is taken from suspicious areas. This is not 100% predictive, as an early lesion can be missed. Recently, the concern has been raised regarding the spilling of cancer cells into the peritoneal cavity during hysteroscopy. Option D: PET–CT reveals metabolic activity in the tissue and is highly sensitive and specific for detecting positive pelvic and/or para-aortic lymphadenopathy as well as distant metastases in selected high-risk patients with endometrial cancer.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which lymph nodes are most commonly involved in patients with endometrial carcinoma?
explanation: Pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are commonly involved in endometrial cancer. The spread is through the infundibulopelvic ligament. Rarely, inguinal & femoral lymph nodes are involved.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A patient presented with carcinoma endometrium involving >50% myometrium, extending to the vagina but with no involvement of para-aortic and pre aortic nodes. What is the stage of her disease?
explanation: Carcinoma endometrium involving the vagina but having no lymph node involvement is classified as stage IIIB.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is indicated for the treatment of a patient with early endometrial cancer?
options: Hysterectomy, B/L salpingo-oophorectomy, lymph node sampling
explanation: Early endometrial cancer (stages I & II) is primarily managed surgically. The surgery performed here is abdominal hysterectomy, B/L salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy and pelvic & para-aortic lymph node sampling. Postoperative management of endometrial cancer: In low-risk endometrial cancer, no further treatment is required. In intermediate-risk, radiotherapy is done. In high risk, chemotherapy + radiotherapy is done.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true?
options: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
explanation: The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance. This is known as the inverse square law in radiotherapy. Chemoradiation is the mainstay of treatment of stage III and IV endometrial cancers. They are treated with brachytherapy followed by external radiation. Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. Other options: Option B: Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature. Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells. Option D: Small intestinal epithelial cells (intestinal crypts), which divide rapidly with no differentiation are the most radiosensitive.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
Which among the following is the mainstay of treatment in a patient diagnosed with Stage III endometrial cancer?
Surgery
explanation: Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment in Stage III endometrial cancer. In order to stage carcinoma endometrium, total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and lymphadenectomy is done (surgical staging). Thus the management, once staging is done, is mainly postoperative. Up to stage II, radiotherapy can be given. Stages III & IV are managed by chemotherapy such as doxorubicin, cisplatin, and paclitaxel. Note: Stage III is said to be inoperable but debulking surgery is sometimes attempted. However, the mainstay of treatment for stage III disease remains chemotherapy. Instruments
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You notice the following instrument being used to monitor a primigravida in the first stage of labor. What is the investigation being performed here?
explanation: The image shows a cardiotocograph (electronic fetal monitor) that is used to perform cardiotocography in labor. It can be used in both antenatal and intranatal mothers. It measures fetal heart rate and uterine contractions. It is used to perform the non-stress test (NST) in the antenatal period and cardiotocography during labor.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: During your OBG posting, one of the senior residents asks you to induce labor in a primigravida admitted at 40 weeks of gestation. Identify the following device that you can use for this purpose.
explanation: This is an image of cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the Bishop's score. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 10-hours.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The following instrument is used to augment labour in a 28-year-old primigravida via low rupture of membranes. Identify this instrument.
explanation: The given instrument is Kocher's artery forceps and is identified by the presence of a single tooth at the tip. Kocher's artery forceps are used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels. They are also used in low rupture of membranes to augment labour or for the surgical induction of labour. The difference between artery forceps and needle holders is in the edge and smoothness of corrugations. Artery forceps have smooth edges and single lined corrugations whereas, needle holders have rough edges and crossed lines forming square to diamond shaped corrugations.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A primigravida was diagnosed with a prolonged second stage of labor due to the fetus being in occipitoposterior position. The obstetrician decided to give a posterior mediolateral cut at the introitus to facilitate delivery. Which of the following instruments would she use for the same?
explanation: The given scenario of prolonged second stage of labor can be managed by performing an episiotomy. In the given figure, the instrument marked as "D" corresponds to episiotomy scissors. An episiotomy is done to prevent posterior extention leading to obstetric anal sphincteric injuries.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The following instrument is used on an exhausted primigravida during crowning of the fetal head. Which of the following is false about this instrument?
options: It can be used in caesarean sections.
It can be used to deliver aftercoming head in breech.
It is a type of outlet forceps.
explanation: The given image shows Wrigley's forceps. These are used as outlet forceps for the extraction of the fetal head. It is used to provide traction force. It can also be used in C-section for delivery of the baby. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Conditions that require to be fulfilled for the use of outlet forceps are: The fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia (crowning) The fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, or is on the perineum The sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°) Note: Delivery of aftercoming head in breech is done with Pipers forceps.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: While assisting in the caesarean section of a multigravida, you see the senior obstetrician using the following instrument. Identify it.
explanation: The given instrument is Green-Armytage forceps. Its tips are broad and hence can compress a wide area. During lower segment caesarean section (LSCS), these forceps are applied at the bleeding cut uterine edges for hemostasis.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: An obstetrician performs an aspiration of the endometrial cavity in a woman with complaints of a missed period 2 weeks back. Identify the following instrument. What is the procedure it is used for?
explanation: The instrument is Karman’s cannula and syringe, which is also used for menstrual regulation. Menstrual regulation is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity within 14 days of a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle. Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators. Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction. The cannula is rotated, and pushed in and out with gentle strokes. This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation. The drawbacks of the procedure include a missed implanted zygote or an unrecognized ectopic pregnancy. This procedure is not commonly done anymore.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 20-year-old woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for check-up following an MTP. On ultrasound, retained tissue was found and the following instrument was used for its removal. What is this instrument?
explanation: The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe. Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation . The indications of this procedure are given as follows: Medical termination of pregnancy Incomplete abortion or missed abortion Molar pregnancy Endometrial aspiration
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the following instrument that is commonly used in a dilatation and curettage procedure.
explanation: The given image shows Hegar's double-ended dilator which is used to dilate the cervix in dilation and curettage procedure. Pratt dilator is also a double-ended dilator but has a more linear shape as compared to the curved Hegar's dilators. The image given below shows a Pratt dilator. Option A: Hawkin dilator is a single-ended dilator. The image given below shows a Hawkin dilator. Option C: Bakes rosebud dilator is a single-ended dilator used to dilate the urethra. It is called so since its tip is similar to a rosebud. The image given below shows a Bakes dilator. Option D: Fenton dilator is also double-ended but it has a notch in the middle. The image given below shows a Fenton dilator.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 25-year-old woman presents with dyspareunia due to scarring secondary to perineal tears from previous vaginal delivery. The gynaecologist advises the use of the following dilator to widen the introitus. Identify this instrument.
explanation: The image shows a Fenton dilator. These can be identified by the neck/notch at the centre. Fenton's or modified Fenton's procedure is performed to widen the introitus in women with superficial dyspareunia secondary to scarring. The narrowing of introitus could be due to scarring secondary to perineal tears during childbirth or from conditions such as lichen sclerosus or vestibulitis. Fenton dilators come in sizes numbered from 3-10 and the sizes of the dilators range from 3mm to 26mm. Option B: Hawkins dilator is single-ended. Options A and C: Hegar and Pratt dilators are also double-ended dilators but they do not have a notch at the centre. Pratt dilator is more linear in appearance compared to Hegar dilator.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You have posted a 43-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding for dilatation and curettage in the minor OT. Identify the following instrument used in this procedure.
explanation: The instrument shown in the image is Sim's curette. It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage. It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of the uterine tissue.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The following instrument is used for all except:
explanation: The image shows a double-ended uterine curette with a sharp and a blunt end. It is not used in uterine length measurement. Uterine length measurement is done with a uterine sound which is given below.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement about the instrument given below?
options: It measures the uterine cavity and the cervical lengt
It differentiates between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis
explanation: The given instrument is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used to retract the vagina for cervical examination. This is done using Sim's speculum. The instrument is held like a pencil with the thumb and the first 2 fingers and introduced into the uterine cavity by keeping it in the midline and ensuring it is not forced. The uses are given as follows: To measure uterine cavity and cervical lengt To diagnose cervical stenosis To sound a polyp, IUCD or uterine septum To break adhesions To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You see a resident use the following instrument to grasp the anterior lip of the cervix in a patient posted for a vaginal hysterectomy. What is this instrument known as?
explanation: The image shows vulsellum forceps. It is used to grasp the cervical lip and steady the cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed. Option A: Allis forceps can be identified by continuous teeth, equal on both ends. It is used to hold structures with a firm grip. Option C: Kocher's artery forceps are non-traumatic with a single tooth at the tip. They help in achieving hemostasis by firm pressure. Option D: Lahey's tissue grasping forceps has teeth similar to dinner forks. They are used to hold fibrous tissue and they give a firm grip without slippage.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the following instrument.
explanation: The given instrument is a towel-holding clip. It is used to secure drapings and towels during surgery. Sponge-holding forceps are non-traumatic forceps. They are used for painting and preparation of parts preoperatively. Filshie clips are used for laparoscopic tubal sterilisation. They are made of titanium on the outer side and sialistic material on the inner side.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: You are assisting a case of vaginal hysterectomy where your assistant professor asks you to hold the retractor shown in the image. What is this retractor known as?
explanation: The image shown is that of a Simon vaginal retractor, used to retract vaginal walls during examination and vaginal procedures. The below image is of Doyen's retractor. It is used during abdominal procedures like C-section.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Identify the instrument.
explanation: The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy. The image given below shows Sim's speculum. The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: Your senior resident uses the following instrument while performing a pap smear test for screening of cervical cancer in a 36-year-old woman. Identify the same.
explanation: The image shows an endocervical brush. It is used to collect samples from the endocervix cervix, especially from deep lesions. Option A: Cervex brush is ideal for collecting samples for liquid-based cytological studies. Option C: Ayres spatula is used to collect samples from the ectocervix and the endocervix for cytological studies. Option D: Aylesbury spatula has a sharper and longer tip than Ayers spatula.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 32-year-old working IT professional came for a mobile cervical cancer screening camp planned at her workplace. What is the following instrument used to perform this screening test?
explanation: The given instrument used in the patient's pap smear preparation is Ayre's spatula. Sharpness on the end can differentiate between Ayre's and Aylesbury spatula. Aylesbury spatula has a more sharp and longer tip than Ayer's spatula. So, Aylesbury spatula is superior to Ayre's in collecting endocervical samples. The image given below shows a slide holding bottle i.e. Kopliks jar with Ayre's spatula.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: A 35-year-old lady who had tested positive for HPV is undergoing an investigation where the following device is used. Which of the following statements is false about this investigation?
options: It is used in lithotomy position
Green filter is used to study vascular pattern
External os is visualised at a distance of 50 cm
explanation: The device shown in the image is a colposcope. It is used to perform colposcopy where the cervix is visualized at a distance of around 20 cm with the patient in the lithotomy position. This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular pattern as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.
subject: OBGYN

question_text: The following instrument is used for a young lady with fibroids posted for open myomectomy. Identify it.
explanation: The given image shows a Doyen myoma screw. It is used to perform an open myomectomy. The handle present in this can be used to distinguish it from a laparoscopic myoma screw which also has a similar tip.
subject: OBGYN

question_text:
Identify the use of the instrument given below:

For tubal ligation
options: For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy
explanation: The given instrument is a fallope ring applicator. It is used in tubal ligation. Falope ring sterilization is accomplished by applying silicone rubber bands to the fallopian tubes. The major advantage is the elimination of thermocoagulation. The occlusion is only in a short segment and can allow for tubal reconstruction.
subject: OBGYN
